question_text: A 10-year-old child came with complaints of pain over the right lower quadrant and lower back pain. On examination, the patient had pain over the right side of the hip on passive extension with a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical history of lower back pain, mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin and pain on passive extension of the ipsilateral hip is suggestive of a psoas abscess. Psoas abscess is a retroperitoneal abscess, caused due to various etiologies. Previously, tuberculosis of the spine was the most common cause secondary to spreading infection from the digestive or urinary tract, which can cause psoas abscess. Nowadays, Crohn’s disease is the most common cause. Patients present with flank pain, fever and chills, malaise and weight loss. They can have referred pain to the hip, groin or knee. When the swelling extends across the groin and below the inguinal ligament along the course of the iliopsoas, it becomes cross fluctuant across the inguinal ligament. Imaging is done by a CT scan, which shows a low-density mass with surrounding inflammation and infiltration of surrounding fat and gas or air-fluid levels. Treatment is done by percutaneous CT-guided drainage and appropriate antibiotics. Other options: Option A: Pyelonephritis is usually associated with a history of urinary tract infection and sudden onset of pain in the flank and hypochondrium, not the lumbar region. Option C: Appendicitis (retrocaecal) can present with pain on passive extension of the hip (psoas sign), but the presence of a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin makes it an unlikely diagnosis. Option D: Testicular torsion is a surgical emergency condition presenting with sudden onset pain in the scrotum, groin and lower abdomen, tenderness, redness and edema of the scrotal skin.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 3-year child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of the lateral neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found in the lateral side of the neck, as shown in the image. The slip sign is negative, and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: A soft, painless, brilliantly transilluminant, fluctuating mass found in the posterior part of the neck in a child, is most likely to be a cystic hygroma. Cystic hygroma is a lymph-filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development. It is most commonly present in the posterior triangle of the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. Since the sac is filled with lymph, it is soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly transilluminant. Treatment: Aspiration of the contents, followed by excision once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue. Single cysts can be treated with sclerosing therapy. Commonly used sclerosants include OK–432 or Picibanil, which is a mixture of group A Streptococcus pyogenes strain, pure ethanol, interferon alpha-2a, and doxycycline. Complete excision is done in case of multiple cysts. Option B: A branchial cleft cyst also presents as soft fluctuant swelling. It is present in the anterior neck and at the junction of the upper third and middle third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Option C: Lipoma is less commonly seen in children. The swelling is non-fluctuant and when palpated, the edge slips under the finger. This is known as the slip sign. Option D: Cervical lymphadenopathy is seen in children with infections of the parotid and upper respiratory tract infections. On palpation, they are firm and non-fluctuant.
subject: Surgery

question_text: The most common location of cystic hygroma is .
explanation: Cystic hygroma, also known as cystic lymphangioma and macrocystic lymphatic malformation, is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that can arise anywhere but is classically found in the left posterior triangle of the neck. The other common sites are the axillary, mediastinal, inguinal, and retroperitoneal regions. It occurs as a result of sequestration or obstruction of developing lymph vessels. The cysts are lined by endothelium and filled with lymph. The image below shows a newborn with cystic hygroma on the right side of the neck.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 15-year-old girl presented with a slow-growing, rubbery, non-tender swelling on the side of the neck as shown in the image. Examination shows the presence of freckles and skin patches over the face and trunk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: A lateral neck mass in a pediatric patient, which is non-tender and present in association with freckles, and hyperpigmented skin patches (cafe-au-lait spots) is suggestive of neural tumor i.e. neurofibroma. Neurofibroma is a benign tumor arising from the connective tissue of the nerve containing ectodermal, neural and mesodermal connective tissue components. It can be single or multiple. It is the most common intradural extramedullary spinal tumor. Neurofibromas can be local, generalized (von Recklinghausen's disease) or plexiform types. Patients present with mild pain or a painless swelling usually in the subcutaneous or cutaneous plane with tingling, numbness and paraesthesia along the distribution of the nerve. Complications of neurofibroma include cystic degeneration, erosion into deeper planes, cord compression and paralysis (spinal neurofibroma) and sarcomatous changes. Treatment is excision under general or regional anesthesia. Indications for surgery in neurofibroma include symptomatic patients (pain and pressure symptoms), cosmetic problems and malignant transformation (5%). Option A: Cystic hygroma is a type of congenital lymphangioma. This swelling is soft and partially compressible, which shows positive fluctuation and translucency test. Option B: Chemodectoma or carotid body tumor is a rare tumor, most commonly present in the fifth decade and there is an association with pheochromocytoma. These patients usually present with a slowly enlarging, painless lump at the carotid bifurcation. Option D: A lipoma is a soft painless swelling. It shows the characteristic slip sign and is freely mobile.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A first-born, 5-weeks-old male infant presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. The abdominal radiograph shows the following finding. Which of the following will be the preferred investigation in this case?
explanation: The given clinical vignette and the radiographic image showing the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble) are suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). Ultrasound examination is the investigation of choice for this condition. Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is characterized by abnormal thickening of the pylorus muscles in the stomach leading to gastric outlet obstruction. First-born male infants are at the highest risk. Infants usually present with Projectile, non-bilious vomiting due to gastric outlet obstruction, most commonly between 3 and 6 weeks of age. Olive-shaped mass palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. Visible peristalsis after feeding, moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting. Metabolic abnormalities include hypokalemic, hypochloremic, metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of  4 mm and a pyloric length of  16 mm. Ultrasound signs seen in Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis are: Target sign (Hypoechoic thickened pyloric muscle with a hyperechoic central mucosa) Cervix sign Nipple sign. Antral nipple sign The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery. The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment. The ultrasound image given above shows hypertrophied pylorus resembling that of the uterine cervix (cervix sign) and double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protruding into the stomach, (Nipple sign). The ultrasound image given above shows redundant pyloric mucosa protruding into the antrum - Antral nipple sign.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 2-month-old baby is brought to the outpatient department for a facial defect. On examination, the following findings were noticed. The soft and the hard palate are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this child?

Cleft lip repair immediately
options: Cleft lip repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months
explanation: The given clinical image is that of a child with a cleft lip on the left side. The most appropriate management for this patient would be a cleft lip repair at 4-6 months. Etiology of the cleft lip can include familial, protein and vitamin deficiency, rubella infection, radiation, chromosomal abnormalities, maternal epilepsy and drug intake during pregnancy (steroids/eptoin/diazepam) Majority of the cases are unilateral and cleft lip alone is uncommon. Millard Criteria (Rule of 10) is used to undertake surgery for cleft lip. 10 pound in weight 10 weeks old 10g% Hemoglobin Millard cleft lip repair by rotating the local nasolabial flaps is done. The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months. According to Delaire timing of cleft surgery - unilateral cleft lip alone can be operated in one stage operation and is done at 4-6 months. The different types of facial clefts are shown below: Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate Bilateral cleft lip and palate Cleft palate only Trauma - Scores, Investigations and Assessment
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is not expected to increase as an immediate response to surgical stress or trauma?
explanation: Insulin levels in plasma are decreased in the immediate ebb phase of surgical stress or trauma. There are three phases in the physiological response to injury: Ebb phase Flow phase Recovery phase. The ebb phase begins at the time of injury and is characterized by hypovolemia and decreased basal metabolic rate. The predominant hormones regulating the ebb phase are catecholamines, cortisol, and aldosterone. The following mechanism leads to a reduction in insulin secretion during this phase: Pro-inflammatory cytokines like interleukin-1, tumour necrosis factor , IL-6 and IL-8 are produced within the first 24 hours of injury. In the later flow phase, insulin secretion begins to normalize i.e., relatively increases. However, insulin resistance by target cells occurs because of a defect in the insulin receptor/intracellular signalling pathway. Thus, the perioperative period is characterized by a state of functional insulin deficiency.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Following a mass casualty, how would you triage the following patients?
explanation: The patients should be triaged as follows: Triage means 'to sort'. It is done to categorize the need for priority of patients in cases of mass casualties. START triage scheme stands for Simple Triage And Rapid Treatment. Patient Triage color cod e A patient with tension pneu mothorax Red A patient with 95% third-deg ree burns Black A patient with a laceration on the forehead Green A patient with a degloving inj ury šellow

question_text: The components of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) include which of the following:
explanation: The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a physiologic scoring system based on the initial vital signs of a trauma patient. Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes : Glasgow coma scale Respiratory rate Systolic BP The score range is 0–12. A lower score indicates a higher severity of injury.

question_text: Trauma and Injury Severity Score (TRISS) includes which of the following components?
explanation: TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) includes : Injury Severity Score (ISS) Revised Trauma Score (RTS) Age Mechanism of injury (blunt/penetrating).

question_text: A 22-year-old man sustained a roller crush injury of his left arm up to mid-humerus and was brought to the casualty. The duty orthopedician uses the MESS score to decide about limb salvage. The score does not include which of the following?
explanation: Neurogenic injury is not included in the Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS). The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is useful in deciding about limb salvage. The components of the Mangled Extremity Severity score are: The energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury Limb ischemia Shock Age of the patient.

question_text: Diagnostic peritoneal lavage is being done in a patient with suspected hemoperitoneum. Which of the following statements is not true?
options: Presence of more than 100,000 RBCs/mm3 is a positive finding
Presence of more than 200 white cells/mm3 is a positive finding
Aspiration of at least 10 mL of gross blood is an indication for laparotomy
Amylase levels more than 175 units/dL is a positive finding
explanation: The presence of more than 500 white cells/mm3 in blunt trauma indicates a positive finding of diagnostic peritoneal lavage. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage detects the presence of intraperitoneal blood. Its use has decreased to virtually nil at many centres with the advent of the FAST examination. Indications for diagnostic peritoneal lavage are: Abdominal pain or tenderness Low abdominal rib fractures Unexplained hypotension Spinal or pelvic fractures Paraplegia or quadriplegia Assessment hampered by altered mental status due to neurologic injury or intoxication. Procedure: It is performed through a small infraumbilical incision with the placement of the catheter under direct vision. The supraumbilical approach is indicated in pregnant patients and those with pelvic fractures. Aspiration of at least 10 mL of gross blood is an indication for laparotomy. If no blood is aspirated, a catheter is placed and 1 L of Ringer lactate solution is instilled into the peritoneal cavity and then allowed to drain by gravity. At least 200 mL of lavage fluid should be recovered to allow for accurate interpretation. Disadvantages: Neither qualitative nor quantitative Cannot identify the source of hemorrhage Relatively small amounts of intraperitoneal bleeding may result in a positive study May not detect small and large injuries to the diaphragm Cannot rule out injury to the bowel or retroperitoneal organs.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 32-year-old professional boxer was brought to the emergency department following a blow to the abdomen. On examination, his vitals were normal, and his abdomen was tender on palpation. Which among the following is the best modality to assess the injury to the abdominal organs for this patient?
explanation: A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the best diagnostic modality (gold standard) for stable patients with blunt trauma to the abdomen. It is a non-invasive and sensitive investigation. It can identify haemorrhage, intraabdominal as well as retroperitoneal organ injury. However, performing CECT is time-consuming (when compared to FAST) and therefore it can be used only in stable patients. FAST ultrasound is a limited examination directed to look for intraperitoneal fluid or pericardial injury as a marker of the underlying injury. The best imaging modality for hemodynamically unstable patients with blunt trauma of the abdomen is FAST.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young man is brought to the trauma unit following a road traffic accident. He is hemodynamically unstable. As an adjunct to the primary survey, the managing surgeon decides to do a FAST. Which of the following areas would not be visualized in this procedure?
explanation: The left lower quadrant is not assessed in FAST examination. FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries. FAST also stands for Focussed abdominal sonography for trauma. However, since FAST is not only used to assess abdominal injuries but also to assess haemopericardium in cases of pericardial injuries, the expansion Focussed assessment with sonography for trauma is preferred. It can be performed within 2-4 minutes. Technique of FAST examination: With the patient in the supine position, a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer is used. Four regions may be scanned: Subxiphoid transverse view - To assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant - To assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morrison's pouch. Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant - To assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury. Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region - To assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas. In an extended FAST or eFAST scan, left and right thoracic views are used to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following describes the correct sequence of evaluation in the FAST technique?
options: Pericardial sac  Perihepatic region  Perisplenic region  Pelvis
Perihepatic region  Perisplenic region  Pelvis  Pericardial sac
Pelvis  Pericardial sac  Perisplenic region  Perihepatic region
Perisplenic region  Perihepatic region  Pericardial sac  Pelvis
explanation: The correct sequence of evaluation in the FAST technique is Pericardial sac  Perihepatic region  Perisplenic region  Pelvis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient with a history of blunt trauma is brought to the casualty and an eFAST examination is performed. Which of the following statements about the investigation is false?
options: B-lines indicate a normal ultrasonographic finding of the lung
Stratosphere sign seen in M-mode USG is indicative of pneumothorax
It can be reliably used to detect less than 100 mL of free blood
It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum
explanation: FAST is not reliable in detecting less than 100 mL of free blood. Disadvantages of FAST: Does not directly identify injury to hollow viscus Cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma Unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum. B-lines or "comet trails" are echogenic bright linear reflections beneath the pleura that are usually lost with any air between the probe and the lung tissue. B-lines’ are expected in normal aerated lung and are visualized moving along with the sliding pleura. Excessive ‘B-lines’, especially in the anterior lung, are abnormal and are usually indicative of interstitial edema. Therefore, the presence of B-lines along with seashore sign indicates the absence of pneumothorax. The image below shows the seashore sign. Barcode sign which is also known as the stratosphere sign and lack of sliding movement in the lungs diagnosed by an M-mode USG is suggestive of pneumothorax.
subject: Surgery

question_text: An intensivist is evaluating a patient for brain stem death in the ICU. Presence of which of the following features should not be misinterpreted as evidence for normal brainstem function in this patient?
explanation: Babinski reflex, tachycardia, and normal systolic blood pressure can be occasionally seen in patients with brain stem death. So, this should not be misinterpreted as evidence for normal brainstem function Brain death is not characterized by decerebrate or decorticate posturing, which is a brain-originating motor response. Brainstem death is defined as the irreversible loss of cerebral and brain-stem function. Ideal criteria for brain stem death contain three essential elements: Widespread cortical destruction that is re■ected by deep coma and unresponsiveness to a forms of stimulation Global brainstem damage demonstrated by absent pupillary light reaction and by the loss of oculovestibular and corneal re■exes Destruction of the medulla manifested by complete and irreversible apnea. Brainstem death entails testing twice, by two clinicians, to demonstrate the absence of: Response to pain Respiratory drive (apnea despite arterial PCO2  60 mm Hg ) Pupillary light reflex Corneal reflex Vestibulo-ocular reflex Oculo-cephalic reflex The following manifestations are occasionally seen in brain dead patients and should not be misinterpreted as evidence for brainstem function: Normal systolic blood pressure >100 mmHg Movements originating from the spinal cord or peripheral nerve may occur Sweating, flushing, tachycardia Deep tendon reflexes, superficial abdominal reflexes, triple flexion response Babinski reflex Spontaneous movements of limbs other than pathologic flexion or extension response Respiratory-like movements (shoulder elevation and adduction, back-arching, intercosta expansion without significant tidal volumes).
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding imaging in the primary survey of a trauma patient?
options: Hemodynamically unstable patient should not be sent for CT scan
All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only
X-ray of the pelvis is essential in primary survery
X-rays in primary survey must also be done in pregnant women
explanation: Chest X-ray and X-ray pelvis are taken in AP view in the adjuncts to the primary survey of a trauma patient.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey?
options: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient
explanation: Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey. Primary survey identifies and manages the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first. The secondary survey includes investigations that help identify all other injuries, excluding the apparent ones. This includes X-rays of the spine and extremities and a CT of the abdomen, head, chest, and spine.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A patient who sustained an RTA was brought to the ER in a semiconscious state. He makes incoherent sounds, withdraws from painful stimuli, and opens his eyes to painful stimuli.
Calculate his GCS score.
explanation: The GCS score in this patient is 8. Withdraws from pain = 4 Incoherent sounds = 2 Opens eyes to painful stimuli = 2 Total GCS score = 4 + 2 + 2 = 8.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient who was admitted after a road traffic accident is put on mechanical ventilation. He opens his eyes on verbal command and moves all four limbs spontaneously. Calculate his GCS.
explanation: The patients GCS is Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6. It is calculated as follows: Eye opening: Opening to verbal command - 3 Verbal response: In the case of endotracheal intubation, the verbal response score is noted as NT (non-testable) Motor respone: Movement of all 4 limbs spontaneously - 6 Total GCS score is not recorded since one of the components is non-testable.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is considered balanced resuscitation?
options: Maintain ph by ensuring acid-base balance
Fluid resuscitation by giving colloids and crystalloids
explanation: Permissive hypotension is a part of balanced resuscitation in trauma management to avoid bleeding. Damage control resuscitation (DCR) i.e. balanced resuscitation is used in the settings of major trauma. It aims to control hemorrhage and prevent coagulopathy prior to the development of the trauma triad of death (hypothermia, acidosis, and coagulopathy). The components of DCR include: Permissive hypotension until definitive surgical contro Minimize crystalloid based resuscitation Early use of blood products (PRBCs, FFP, platelets, cryoprecipitate) in the ratio of 1:1:1 Use of hemostatic agents such as tranexamic acid, recombinant factor 7a, prothrombin complex concentrates DCR has the following advantages: Minimizes the impact of trauma-induced coagulopathy Limits blood product waste Reduces the complications that occur with aggressive crystalloid resuscitation.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following drugs have a significant role in the mortality reduction of trauma patients based on the CRASH-2 trial?
explanation: The CRASH-2 trial has shown mortality reduction in bleeding trauma patients by early usage of tranexamic acid (preferably within the first 3 hours) with a loading dose of 1 g over 10 minutes and then infusion of 1 g over 8 hours.
subject: Surgery

question_text: In a patient with massive haemorrhage, damage control surgery is being performed. What does this consist of?
explanation: Damage Control Surgery refers to performing limited surgical intervention in order to arrest hemorrhage, control sepsis, and protect from further injury. This concept of tailoring the operation to match the patient’s physiology and staged procedures to prevent physiological exhaustion is called Damage Control Surgery. Furthermore, definitive repairs are delayed and not until the patient is hemodynamically stable and physiologically capable of sustaining the procedure. Crystalloid and colloid infusions are limited in order to avoid dilutional coagulopathy. The term Damage Control Surgery is borrowed from the military, which ensures the continued functioning of a damaged ship above conducting complete repairs which would prevent a rapid return to battle.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young man sustained multiple injuries following a road traffic accident. On examination, his pulse rate is 100/min and BP is 85/60 mmHg. He is diagnosed with pelvic fracture and is suspected to have retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Which of the following statements is true?
options: Coagulopathy is corrected in phase II of damage control surgery
Definitive repair of injuries is done 12-24 hours after phase III
Internal iliac artery ligation is done in phase II
Hypothermia and acidosis are corrected in phase I
explanation: Coagulopathy is corrected in phase II of Damage Control Surgery. Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries. It consists of three phases: Phase I - Initial Exploration: This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active haemorrhage and contamination. Phase II - Secondary Resuscitation: This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis. Phase III - Definitive Operation: It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
Which of the following is not a component of the trauma triad of death?
Hypothermia
explanation: Shock is not considered to be a component of the trauma triad of death. The trauma triad of death is a combination of clinical features that are seen in exsanguinating trauma patients and contribute to the majority of trauma-related mortality and morbidities. The triad includes: Hypothermia Coagulopathy Acidosis During the resuscitation phase of trauma, adequate precautions should be taken to prevent the development of these features. Hypothermia is prevented by maintenance of ambient temperature within the patient’s room, usage of prewarmed iv fluids, blankets, etc. Coagulopathy can be prevented by judicious use of i.v crystalloids (<1-1.5 Lit), early initiation of blood and blood products, usage of tranexamic acid, etc. Acidosis can be prevented by correction of shock, ensuring adequate oxygenation, usage of sodium bicarbonate, etc. Trauma - Spinal, Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries
subject: Surgery

question_text: All of the following can be done to transport a polytrauma patient who is conscious except?
options: Strap their thorax, abdomen and lower limbs on a stretcher
Place in prone position to prevent aspiration
Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately
Roll the patient onto a hard board
explanation: Patients with polytrauma are shifted into a supine or prone position (not in a lateral position) by laying them over a firm surface to restrict spinal movement. As per ATLS guidelines, in patients with trauma, airway management is first done along with cervical spine stabilization. All trauma patients until proven otherwise are considered to have an injured vertebral column. The patients are placed supine on a firm surface without rotating or bending the spinal column and a rigid cervical collar (philadelphia collar) is applied. Aspiration can be prevented by putting the patient in the prone position and strapping can be done to provide further stabilization. Long spine boards with straps are helpful in the rapid transport of the patient from one place to another. The patient can be put on the long spine board by log-rolling (a technique where four people hold the patient and roll the patient like a log without allowing rotation or bending of the spine). Conscious and alert patient indirectly means that they don’t need intubation and their airway is patent. If the patient is unconscious always check the airway and if needed, endotracheal intubation must be done immediately by various methods. Preferably by direct laryngoscopy and intubation.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A man met with a road traffic accident, which resulted in paralysis of both his upper and lower limbs. He has not passed urine and tenderness is elicited in the cervical region. What will you advise regarding radiography?
options: The patient should not be shifted and portable x-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization.
Instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest x-ray.
Instruct the radiographer to take cervical x-ray AP and lateral view without any cervical support.
Order a cervical x-ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself.
explanation: The given clinical situation suggests a cervical spine injury due to trauma. The patient should not be shifted and a portable X-ray machine should be used for radiography after neck stabilization. Management in a trauma patient with a suspected cervical fracture involves the following steps: Spinal immobilization with a rigid cervical collar and a long spine board is the immediate step in the management of blunt/penetrating cervical trauma cases. It is followed by a gross assessment of spinal cord function by eliciting extremity movement. Tenderness over the injured vertebrae or the presence of a deformity is indicative of an associated fracture. Imaging is done by X-ray or CT. Portable X-ray machines are preferred to avoid further injury while mobilizing the patient. They are useful in visualizing thoracic and lumbar vertebrae but not the cervicothoracic junction. Cervical CT has been made the modality of choice in most emergency departments owing to the high quality of images that can be obtained.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 25-year-old construction worker sustained an injury to his neck after falling from the tenth floor of a construction site. The first aid team that rushed to his rescue log rolled him.
According to ATLS, what is the minimum number of people required for log-rolling this patient?
explanation: The 10th edition of ATLS recommends at least 4 people for the safe manoeuvre of log-roll in patients suffering from trauma. The first person is assigned to restrict the motion of the head and neck. The second person is positioned on the same side of the patient’s torso. He manually prevents segmental rotation, flexion, extension, lateral bending, or sagging of the chest or abdomen while transferring the patient. The third person is responsible for moving the patient’s legs. The fourth person removes the backboard and examines the back. Note: In a patient known to have a fracture of the extremities, a minimum of 5 people are required to safely perform the log-roll manoeuvre.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements about acute spinal injury is false?
options: Hypotension in acute spinal injury is due to the loss of parasympathetic tone
Immediate respiratory suppression can occur due to the involvement of the phrenic nerve
Canadian C-Spine rule and NEXUS help to determine the need for radiographic evaluation
Patients with neurological deficits should be removed from the backboard as soon as possible
explanation: Hypotension in acute spinal injury is due to loss of sympathetic tone. The classic presentation of neurogenic shock is hypotension in the setting of warm, well-perfused extremities in a paralyzed patient. This condition requires intravascular volume expansion and vasopressor support. Option B: High cervical spinal cord injury (SCIs) may have immediate respiratory suppression. This requires airway management and ventilatory support because of paresis of the phrenic nerves. Hypoventilation can occur from paralysis of the intercostal muscles (injury to the lower cervical or upper thoracic spinal cord) or the diaphragm (injury to C3 to C5). Option C: Canadian C-Spine rule and NEXUS are validated clinical decision tools to help determine the need for radiographic evaluation and to clinically clear the cervical spine. NEXUS criteria: There are five criteria included under NEXUS. If a trauma patient meets all five criteria, then no radiography is required and the cervical c-spine collar may be removed. However, if any one of the criteria is met then radiography is done to evaluate further. The NEXUS criteria include: No posterior midline cervical spinal tenderness No evidence of intoxication A normal level of alertness No focal neurologic deficit No painful distracting injuries Option D: Patients with or without neurological deficits should be removed from the backboard as soon as possible. A patient who is allowed to lie on the hardboard for more than 2 hours is at high risk for pressure ulcers.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 20-year-old college student sustained a superficial injury to his neck during a bar fight. What is the probable cause of sudden death in this patient?
options: Air embolism through external jugular vein
explanation: Air embolism through the external jugular vein is a cause of sudden death in patients with superficial neck injury. All other structures are deeper structures, hence are not involved much in superficial injuries of the neck.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 30-year-old man presented to the emergency department after suffering injuries in the neck during an armed robbery. On examination, several bleeding lacerated injuries are visible at the front and lateral aspects of the neck. Which of the following is not an indication for immediate surgical exploration?
explanation: Fluid responsive hemorrhagic shock is not an indication for immediate surgical intervention. The following are the indications for immediate surgical exploration of neck trauma. They are also known as the hard signs of neck trauma: Pulsatile bleeding Expanding hematoma Air bubbling from penetrating injury Absent radial pulse Respiratory distress Presence of neurological deficit Fluid resistant hemorrhagic shock Audible bruit or palpable thrill Signs of stroke/ cerebral ischemia The presence of any of these hard signs indicates major neurovascular/ airway injury and is an indication for surgical exploration of the trauma region as soon as possible. Neck trauma is classified based on the different regions of the neck. Zone I: thoracic inlet to cricoid, associated with maximum mortality. It contains large vascular structures as well as the trachea and esophagus. Zone II: cricoid cartilage to the angle of mandible, most commonly prone to injury and most easily accessible for surgery. It contains the carotid and vertebral arteries, jugular veins, and structures of the aerodigestive tract. Zone III: angle of the mandible to the base of the skull. Structures within zone III include blood vessels that are difficult to expose surgically. Management: If the patient is hemodynamically unstable: neck exploration If the patient is stable: Zone II injury: Conservative management Zone I and Zone III: Angiography and angioembolisation are indicated. If it fails then neck exploration should be done.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 38-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after suffering a stab injury to the lower chest. On presentation, he had bradycardia and hypotension which did not improve despite IV fluid administration. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a patient with a stab injury and hypotension not responding to IV fluids indicates persistent hypotension due to ongoing hemorrhage and the next step in the management is to perform an eFAST. Cardiogenic shock or hemorrhagic shock are the most likely causes of persistent hypotension in a trauma patient. Ultrasound evaluation using eFAST to look for pericardium, pleural cavities, and abdomen in combination with plain radiographs of the chest and pelvis will usually identify the source of the bleed. In patients with persistent hypotension due to blunt trauma, the pelvis should be wrapped in a sheet for stabilization until radiography can be done. Evaluation of CVP or ultrasound of the IVC may further assist in distinguishing between cardiogenic and hypovolemic shock. It is mostly fatal if not controlled, and requires immediate management. Blood and plasma transfusions are provided in a ratio of 2:1. Patients with persistent hypotension requiring surgical intervention include: Blunt trauma and massive hemothorax Penetrating trauma Hemoperitoneum Gunshot injuries to the chest or abdomen Penetrating weapon remaining in place. Other options: Options C and D: CECT can be done only when the patient is hemodynamically stable. Option B: Tube thoracostomy has no role in this patient's management since the X-ray shows clear lung fields.
subject: Surgery

question_text: eFAST is least helpful in diagnosing which of the following conditions?
explanation: Among the given options, eFAST(extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) is least useful in diagnosing retroperitoneal hematoma as the sensitivity of ultrasound for detecting retroperitoneal hematomas is extremely poor. FAST is a rapid, noninvasive bedside test that uses sonography to detect free fluid in the abdomen and assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. Technique: The patient is placed in a supine position With a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer the following regions are scanned : Subxiphoid transverse view: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas eFAST stands for extended FAST and incorporates Left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax. Computed Tomography (CT Scan) is the investigation of choice for retroperitoneal injury, but it can only be done in a hemodynamically stable patient.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 30-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department following a high-speed road traffic collision. His heart rate is 124 beats/min and BP is 78/56 mmHg on the right arm, and 64/50 mmHg on the left arm. A portable chest x-ray shows a widened mediastinum but normal lung and cardiac silhouette. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this patient?
explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of aortic injury. The investigation of choice in this hemodynamically unstable patient is transesophageal echocardiography (TEE). In hemodynamically stable patients, the investigation of choice is CECT or CT angiogram. Traumatic aortic injuries are commonly seen in deceleration injuries (e.g. road traffic accidents). The most common site of aortic injury is the isthmus, near the attachment of ligamentum arteriosum. Clinical features of aortic injuries: Hypotension Difference in blood pressure in bilateral limbs Absent pulse in the unilateral limb Widened mediastinum on chest x-ray Management Volume replacement: fluid therapy and blood transfusion Permissive hypotension: Beta-blockers, such as esmolol Immediate surgical repair: Endovascular stenting, or Open surgical repair with Dacron graft
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young man was rushed to the casualty with multiple rib fractures. On examination, you notice a paradoxical movement of the chest, and the patient is diagnosed with respiratory failure. How would you manage him?
options: Internal operative fixation of the fractures segments
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of flail chest with respiratory failure. Management of this condition is IPPV (invasive positive pressure ventilation). A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest of the thoracic cage. This condition results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures i.e., 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places. The blunt force required to disrupt the integrity of the thoracic cage typically produces an underlying pulmonary contusion as well. On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards, and therefore, less air moves into the lungs. On expiration, the segment moves outwards. This is known as paradoxical respiration. The diagnosis is made clinically, not by radiography. To confirm, the paradoxical motion of a chest wall segment can be observed for several respiratory cycles and during coughing. Voluntary splinting as a result of pain, mechanically impaired chest wall movement, and the associated lung contusion are all causes of hypoxia and respiratory failure. The patient is also at high risk of developing a pneumothorax or hemothorax. Treatment: Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided. Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia, and physiotherapy. IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is reserved for patients developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen. subject: Surgery

question_text: A 30-year-old man involved in a road traffic accident says that his bike handle hit the right side of his chest. On palpation, he had tenderness in the right upper chest. Chest radiograph shows a fracture in the right third rib. Which of the following should you not do while managing him?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of a rib fracture. Strapping is not done for rib fractures because it prevents the patient from taking deep breaths. This can lead to lung collapse. The vital step in the management of rib fractures is to reduce pain and prevent the development of pneumonia. Rib fracture causes intense pain during breathing and increases the risk of pulmonary infections as the patient is not able to cough forcefully. In mild to moderate cases, pain can be managed by intravenous opioids. In severe cases, patients may require epidural analgesia. In addition to adequate analgesia, chest physiotherapy like deep breathing, frequent coughing, incentive spirometry should be encouraged in these patients. This prevents the development of pneumonia and lung collapse. When chest wall injuries result in respiratory failure, mechanical ventilation should be provided.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 40-year-old female presents to the ER with a history of RTA. On examination, GCS is 15/15, heart rate = 110/min, BP = 90/60 mmHg, and there is elevated JVP. The right chest is hyperresonant on percussion with decreased breath sounds. The left chest appears normal.
But the patient is dyspneic and ecchymosis is noted over the chest wall. The abdomen was soft. The probable diagnosis is:
explanation: The given clinical scenario of trauma with decreased breath sounds and a hyper-resonant note on percussion indicates pneumothorax. The presence of tachycardia, hypotension and elevated JVP is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax develops when there is a parietal or visceral pleural tear. This tear acts as a one-way valve i.e. air enters the pleural space from the lung or chest wall during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration, leading to the collapse of the affected lung. It is characterized by chest pain, tachypnoea, acute dyspnea, sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness), neck vein distention, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, decreased chest movements on the affected side, hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side and absent or decreased breath sounds on the affected side. Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed awaiting radiological confirmation. Management includes: Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy with a wide bore needle n the 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line. In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location is at the 2nd intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line. Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th intercostal space n the triangle of safety. The triangle of safety is bounded anteriorly by the lateral border of the pectoralis major, posteriorly by latissmus dorsi and inferiorly by a horizontal line at the level of the nipple. The X-ray below shows a left-sided tension pneumothorax. There is a large, well-demarcated area devoid of lung markings on the left side. The yellow arrows are pointing to the tracheal deviation and the mediastinal shift to the right side. Other options: Options A: Pericardial tamponade can mimic tension pneumothorax, but the absence of a tympanic note on percussion rules out its possibility. A patient with pericardial tamponade can present with hypotension, raised JVP, and muffled heart sounds (Beck’s triad), with normal breath sounds and no tracheal shift. Option C: Dullness in percussion at the base of the left inferior angle of scapula in conjunction with tubular breath sounds (Ewart’s sign), chest pain that improves while sitting upright and worsens when lying down and pulsus paradoxus are indicative of pericardial effusion. Pericardial effusion develops into tamponade when the effusion leads to increased pressure, impairing ventricular filling and reducing cardiac output. Option D: Massive hemothorax is the accumulation of >1500 ml of blood or one-third or more of the patient’s blood volume in the chest cavity. The patient will have collapsed neck veins, decreased breath sounds and a dull note on percussion.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 20-year-old patient presented to the ER with tension pneumothorax following a road traffic accident. What is the first line of management?
options: Insert wide bore needle in 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line
Insert wide bore needle in 5th ICS in the mid-clavicular line
Insert wide bore needle in 2nd ICS in the mid-axillary line
Insert wide bore needle in 2nd ICS in the mid-clavicular line
explanation: Insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line is the first-line management in adults with tension pneumothorax. Management of tension pneumothorax: Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy i.e. insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety If a sucking wound is present, the immediate step is to cover the wound with gauze pieces and tape on 3 sides. Following this, chest tube is inserted away from the site of the wound. Note: According to ATLS 10th edition In adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line. In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line. This update was recommended since chest wall thickness influences the likelihood of success with needle decompression. Inserting needle in 5th ICS anterior to the midaxillary line had better outcomes.
subject: Surgery

question_text: An intern placed an intercostal drainage tube in a patient. Which of the following steps is incorrect?
options: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury
explanation: An intercostal tube (ICD) is placed along the upper border of the lower rib at the 5th intercostal space (ICS) to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle. Hence, option B is incorrect. Chest tube insertion (thoracostomy) is indicated in pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, and pleural effusion in order to drain air/fluid from the pleural space. The triangle of safety, usually in the 5th intercostal space, is the safest site for chest tube insertion, it is bound by: anterior to the midaxillary line above the horizontal line marked by the level of the nipple below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle Contraindications include pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia. Complications of this procedure: Infection at the site of insertion Unintentional injury to the lung - hemothorax Intercostal nerve/ vessel injury Subcutaneous hematoma/ emphysema
subject: Surgery

question_text: Proper functioning of ICD tube is indicated by .
options: Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain
Oscillation of water column in the tube
explanation: Oscillation of the water column level (moving up and down during respiration) within the tube in the water seal chamber is indicative of a functioning (patent) ICD tube. During spontaneous respiration, the water level rises with inspiration and falls with expiration. Whereas during positive pressure ventilation, the opposite occurs. This oscillation is also known as tidaling. Other options: Option A: Continous bubbling indicates an air leak in the drainage system, which should be corrected Option B: Chest X-ray is useful for assessing the position of the ICD tube inside the chest, not its functioning. Option C: Auscultation is not useful for assessing the functioning of an ICD tube.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 40-year old man is brought to the emergency room with a stab injury to his chest. On examination, the patient is found to be hemodynamically unstable. His neck veins are engorged and heart sounds are muffled. Which of the following statements about the patient is false?
options: Cardiac tamponade is likely to be present
The entry wound is sealed on all 4 sides with an occlusive dressing if pneumothorax is suspected
eFAST is done to confirm blood in pericardial sac
explanation: The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and muffled heart sounds are suggestive of cardiac tamponade. The entry wound is sealed on only 3 sides with an occlusive dressing if a pneumothorax is suspected. When there is a pneumothorax with a sucking wound, the immediate step is to cover the wound with gauze pieces and tape on 3 sides. As the patient breathes in, the dressing occludes the wound, preventing air from entering into the thoracic cavity. During exhalation, the open end of the dressing allows air to escape from the pleural space. This is known as a flutter-valve effect. Following this, a chest tube is inserted away from the site of the wound. Cardiac tamponade must be di■erentiated from tension pneumothorax in a patient with hemodynamic instability and distended neck veins. Cardiac tamponade is characterized by Beck’s triad: Muffled heart sounds Distended neck veins Hypotension Tension pneumothorax is characterized by absent breath sounds and hyper resonance on percussion on the affected side. These are not present in a patient with cardiac tamponade. Diagnosis of cardiac tamponade can be done by eFAST which shows fluid in the pericardial sac. Definitive management - emergency thoracotomy or sternotomy
subject: Surgery

question_text: In a blast injury, which of the following organs is least vulnerable to the blast wave?
explanation: In a blast injury, the liver is the least vulnerable to blast wave (primary blast) injury. Blast injury is a complex type of physical trauma resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion. Primary blast injuries result from the rapid overpressure or shock waves produced by an explosion. These injuries result from the dramatic changes in barometric pressure projecting outwards from the point of detonation. They predominantly cause damage to air-filled hollow organs of the body from rapid pressure change (barotrauma). This includes the middle ear, lungs, and GIT. The most sensitive and most frequently injured hollow organs are the tympanic membranes > lungs. Blast damage to the lungs is the most common cause of life-threatening injury following an explosion. Solid organs are the most resistant to blast injuries as the parenchymal disruption requires very high levels of overpressure. Classification of blast injuries: Classification Explanation Injury type Examples Primary blast Due to air pressure from the blast Shockwave (overpressure) Tympanic membraneinjury, blast lung, intestinal blast inj ury Secondary blas t Fragments from the blast, fo llowing a detonation Penetrating/fragmentation Allpenetratinginjuries Tertiary blast Gross movements of persons, objects, or infrastructure by the blast wind Blunt trauma Blunt and crushinjuries. Tra umatic amputation. Quaternary bl ast M scellaneous causes Exposure to explosive produ cts or toxic substances Burns, inhalation injury Quinary blast Theintentional additionof bi ological or radioactive mater ial to the explosive device Environmental contaminant s Radiationsickness,infection.

question_text: Following a motor vehicle collision, a 30-year-old male sustained blunt trauma to his abdomen. What is the organ most likely to be injured?
explanation: The spleen is the most common organ involved in blunt trauma injury of the abdomen. In blunt trauma, organs that cannot yield to impact by elastic deformation are most likely to be injured, namely, the solid organs (liver, spleen, and kidneys). For penetrating trauma, organs with the largest surface area when viewed from the front are most prone to injury (small bowel, liver, and colon). Additionally, since bullets and knives usually follow straight lines, adjacent structures are commonly injured (e.g., the pancreas and duodenum). Deceleration injures the pedicled organs by shearing the organs from their points of attachment to the retroperitoneum (intestines and kidney). The most commonly injured bowel in cases of blunt trauma of the abdomen is jejunum.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 30-year-old man stabbed his elder brother using a knife over a property dispute. Which is the most common organ that is likely to be injured in this patient?
explanation: The liver is the most common organ to be injured in penetrating stab injury of the abdomen. It is due to its anterior location, size and fragile parenchyma. The most common organ injured in blunt trauma to the abdomen is spleen > liver. The most common organ injured in gunshot injury is the small intestine > colon.

question_text: A landlord who was stabbed in his abdomen by one of his tenants for demanding rent was brought to the casualty. He was taken up for laparotomy which revealed a severely injured cecum. What is the best management option for this patient?
explanation: The best management option for this patient is right hemicolectomy with ileocolostomy. Injuries proximal to the middle colic artery are best managed by this procedure. Injuries distal to the middle colic artery require segmental resection with colocolostomy anastomosis. Immediate anastomosis should be avoided in patients with shock due to the high incidence of leaks following the procedure. In such patients, colostomy and delayed primary anastomosis should be done. Option A: Catheter tube cecostomy is of therapeutic value in refractory colonic pseudo-obstruction, cecal volvulus, or distal colonic obstruction. Option C: Transverse colostomy is generally done in patients with distal obstruction for temporary fecal diversion. Option D: An end-loop sigmoid colostomy is an ideal stoma for distal fecal diversion for incontinence or in association with complex anorectal procedures.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient is shifted for emergency laparotomy for the management of an intra-abdominal haemorrhage, following a road traffic accident. Intraoperatively, you find an active bleed from the liver. Which of the following techniques will you use to control the bleed?
explanation: The hepatoduodenal ligament can be clamped to decrease active hemorrhage from the liver. This is called Pringle's maneuver. This maneuver applies pressure on the portal triad which contains bile duct, portal vein and hepatic artery. This helps distinguish hepatic arterial and portal venous bleeding from hepatic vein bleeding. Hepatic venous bleed will persist with the hepatoduodenal ligament clamped. The liver laceration can then be explored and any actively bleeding vessels controlled with suture ligation. 4 P's in the management of liver injuries are: Push - compression of the edges of the laceration Pringle - applying pressure on the portal triad Plug the defects with silicon tubes Pack - apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient develops abdominal compartment syndrome following an emergency laparotomy. Which of the following is false about this condition?
explanation: Central venous pressure (CVP) increases due to inferior vena cava (IVC) and portal vein compression in abdominal compartment syndrome. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome (ACS) is defined as increased intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) >20 mm Hg resulting in compression of abdominal structures (Normal IAP = 5-7 mmHg and intraabdominal hypertension IAP  12 mmHg). This produces fatal complications due to pulmonary failure and mesenteric vascular compromise. Elevated intra-abdominal pressure leads to a decrease in venous return resulting in decreased cardiac output. An increase in heart rate partly compensates this. Systemic vascular resistance (afterload) is increased by the compression of both the aorta and systemic vasculature. This also leads to an increase in renal vascular resistance leading to a reduced glomerular filtration rate. Causes of primary ACS include: Abdominal trauma Hemorrhage Intestinal obstruction Retroperitoneal hematoma Causes of secondary ACS include: Pregnancy Ascites Ileus Intra-abdominal sepsis Large-volume fluid replacement (greater than 3L)
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements about abdominal compartment syndrome is false?
options: Hypoxia due to increased peak inspiratory pressure
Hypotension due to decrease in venous return
explanation: Oliguria is due to reduced renal blood flow. An increase in renal vascular resistance leads to a reduction in glomerular filtration rate and impaired urine output. Abdominal compartment syndrome is characterized by : A sudden increase in intraabdominal pressure Increased peak inspiratory pressure Hypercarbia and respiratory acidosis Decreased urinary output – due to reduced renal blood flow Hypotension - secondary to decreased venous return to the heart.
subject: Surgery

question_text: You are evaluating a patient in the burns unit, who had sustained third-degree burns to her abdomen and lower limbs (BSA of 30%). She had received 9 liters of Ringer's lactate at a primary center. On examination, extensive abdominal eschars are seen. BP - 84/50 mmHg, HR - 118 bpm and urine output has been less than 15 ml for the past 2 hours. The ventilator shows a peak airway pressure of 42 cm H2O. What is the most appropriate next step?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS). Measurement of bladder pressure using a urinary bladder catheter is the next best step in the management of this patient. The oliguria and hypotension in isolation could be suggestive of under-resuscitation. However, the history of large volume fluid administration, presence of abdominal eschars along with very high peak airway pressures should raise the suspicion for ACS. Abdominal compartment syndrome refers to an elevation of intra-abdominal pressure > 20mmHg with associated organ compression and dysfunction: Compression of the IVC leads to decreased cardiac output, and consequent increase in systemic vascular resistance, leading to hypotension. Cephalad displacement of the diaphragm results in decreased thoracic volumes and results in elevated peak and plateau pressures. Renal compression can lead to increased renal vascular resistance, decreased GFR and low urine output. Measurement of bladder (intravesical) pressure is the standard method to screen for ntra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) and abdominal compartment syndrome. Note: Direct methods such as pressure transducers and intraperitoneal catheters are more accurate but are limited by their invasiveness. Grade of Intra-abdominal hy pertension (IAH) Intra-abdominal pressure (IA P) Grade I 12–15 mmHg Grade II 16–20 mmHg Grade III 21–25 mmHg Grade IV >25 mmHg
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient is admitted to the intensive care unit following a trauma to the abdomen. His intraabdominal pressure is found to be 24 mmHg. What is the grade of abdominal hypertension?
explanation: Intraabdominal pressure (IAP) of 24 mm Hg falls under grade III of intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH). Normal intraabdominal pressure is 5 to 7 mmHg. Any acute process in the abdomen such as trauma, intestinal perforation, peritonitis, or acute pancreatitis can increase the intra-abdominal pressure. Increased abdominal pressure can diminish the blood flow to the abdominal organs and decrease the venous return to the heart. Measurement of bladder (intravesical) pressure is the standard method to screen for ntra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) and abdominal compartment syndrome. Grade III intra-abdominal hypertension is associated with hypoxia, ARDS and serious complications. It is associated with abdominal compartment syndrome which is defined as a sustained IAP >20 mmHg associated with organ dysfunction/failure. Grade of Intra-abdominal hy pertension (IAH) Intra-abdominal pressure (IA P) Grade I 12–15 mmHg Grade II 16–20 mmHg Grade III 21–25 mmHg Grade IV >25 mmHg
subject: Surgery

question_text: Following a road traffic accident, a child presents with abdominal pain. On examination, vitals are stable and tenderness is present in the left lumbar region. Which is the best investigation of choice for this patient?
explanation: The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a road traffic accident is suggestive of blunt renal trauma. The investigation of choice is CECT in a hemodynamically stable patient. Blunt trauma is the main cause of renal injuries and is self-limiting. Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross haematuria, shock in combination with microscopic haematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries. CECT is the investigation of choice. It assesses the extent of the injury, showing laceration, extravasation, surrounding hemorrhage, and vessel injury. It also shows non-renal injuries and effectively stages renal pedicle injuries. Arterial occlusion will manifest as rim enhancement of the normal renal contour. Blunt trauma is mostly treated conservatively. Most of the penetrating injuries require surgical renal exploration. Absolute indications for surgical intervention in renal trauma are: Massive hemorrhage Renal pedicle avulsion (grade 5 injury) Expanding, pulsatile, or uncontained retroperitoneal hematoma Relative indications are: Large laceration of the renal pelvis or avulsion of the ureteropelvic junction Bowel or pancreatic injuries Persistent urinary leakage, postinjury urinoma, or perinephric abscess Complete renal artery thrombosis of both kidneys Renal hypertension Exploratory laparotomy is recommended in stable patients with penetrating renal injuries.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A trauma patient suffers a renal laceration with urine extravasation. He is managed conservatively. However, after a few days, he presents with a urinoma. The next best management for this patient would be?
explanation: The patient with a history of grade IV renal injury (renal laceration with urine extravasation) who develops a persistent urinoma (a mass formed by encapsulated extravasated urine) should be managed with the placement of an internal ureteral stent. In patients not cured by ureteral stenting, percutaneous nephrostomy or transcutaneous drain may be required. Management of renal injuries Blunt trauma is the main cause of renal injuries and is self-limiting. Blunt trauma is mostly treated conservatively. Most penetrating injuries require surgical renal exploration. Grading of injury through CECT If hemodynamically stable Conservative management - Bedrest & hemodynamic monitoring In grade IV, a repeat CT scan to ensure the extravasation of urine has resolved. If hemodynamically unstable Surgical exploration and repair In grade V, nephrectomy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: While performing emergency laparotomy for an unstable RTA case with blunt abdominal trauma, the surgeon notices a hematoma around the left kidney. What will be the next step in the management of this patient?
explanation: The next step in the surgical management of the patient found to have a hematoma around the kidney, intraoperatively, will be a single-shot intravenous pyelography (IVP). If immediate operative exploration for other injuries is required, renal injury staging can be performed while the patient is still in the operating room, using single-shot IVP. It is useful in assessing the function of the kidneys and the extent of the injury. If the IVP is abnormal or the hematoma is pulsatile, then renal exploration should be performed. Note: CECT is the method of choice for staging a patient with hemodynamically stable renal trauma presenting at the emergency room.
subject: Surgery

question_text: An 8-year-old child presents with grade 2 splenic injury following blunt trauma to the abdomen. On examination, there are no signs of bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this child?
explanation: Conservative management is the most appropriate management in this child. Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) is usually followed in: Stable patients with no active bleeding Patients younger than 55 years of age Patients with grade I, II, III injuries. Any patient who is hemodynamically unstable, has active bleeding, and has grade IV and V splenic injury should be managed by surgery.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is a correct statement regarding retroperitoneal trauma?
options: All zone 1 injury to be treated conservatively
Zone 3 injury whether blunt or penetrative should always be explored
Zone 2 injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically
Mattox maneuver is when the ascending colon is mobilized to the right to visualise the aorta
explanation: A zone 2 retroperitoneal injury with expanding hematoma should be treated surgically. Zone of retroperitoneal injur y Type of viscer a Differential management Zone 1 Central Always explored, after proxi mo-distal vascular control Zone 2 Lateral Only explored if the hemato ma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembo lization Zone 3 Pelvic Only explored if the hemato ma is pulsatile or expanding, else conservative/ angioembo lization Surgical exploration is done in cases of penetrating injuries to any zone. Other options: Option A: Zone 1 injuries are always explored. Option B: Depending on the situation, zone 3 injuries can be managed with surgical exploration or conservatively. Option D: Mattox manoeuvre is left medial visceral rotation to expose the aorta, while the Cattell-Braasch manoeuvre is done by right medial visceral rotation to expose IVC.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young male patient is taken up for laparotomy following a stab injury. Pringle’s maneuver is done. Which of the following statements is false about this maneuver?
options: It is used to differentiate between hepatic arterial and hepatic venous bleed
Arterial bleed persists on performing the maneuver
Hepatic pedicle is compressed at the epiploic foramen
Prolonged application of pressure can lead to hepatic necrosis
explanation: Pringle maneuver may be required for the treatment of liver laceration. Hepatic venous bleed persists on performing this maneuver. When there is severe bleeding from the liver, this maneuver is a viable adjunct to slow blood flow enough to visualize liver injury. The hepatoduodenal ligament is clamped at the epiploic foramen or the foramen of Winslow. This applies pressure on the portal triad that contains bile duct, portal vein and hepatic artery. This helps to distinguish hepatic arterial and portal venous bleeding from hepatic vein bleeding. Hepatic venous bleed will persist when the hepatoduodenal ligament clamped. The liver laceration can then be explored and any actively bleeding vessels controlled with suture ligation. 4 P's in the management of liver injuries are: Push - compression of the edges of the laceration Pringle - applying pressure on the portal triad Plug the defects with silicon tubes Pack - apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding. Prolonged intraoperative use of Pringle maneuver can lead to hepatic ischemia and necrosis.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
An elderly lady presents to the trauma care centre following a motor vehicle collision. She complains of chest pain and abdominal pain. On examination, breath sounds are decreased
on the right side. X ray chest revealed the following finding. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this patient?
options: Most accurate evaluation of this condition is by VATS
Operative repair is indicated in all cases
In case of penetrating injury, repair can be done via thoracic incision
The defect must be closed with polypropylene sutures
explanation: The given clinical history and X-ray image showing obliteration of the diaphragmatic outline are suggestive of traumatic diaphragmatic injury in this patient. Penetrating diaphragmatic injury must be repaired via the abdomen and not the thorax, to rule out penetrating hollow viscus injury. Patients with diaphragmatic injury are generally asymptomatic. Chest X ray after the insertion of a nasogastric tube may help in identifying the herniation of the stomach in the thoracic cavity. However, the most accurate evaluation is by video assisted thoracoscopy (VATS) or laparoscopy. Abdominal contents may get herniated into the chest and get strangulated later. This is associated with high mortality. Hence, operative repair is indicated in all patients. The defect is closed with running 1-0 polypropylene suture.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 17-year-old boy is brought to the ED after being involved in a high-speed motorcycle collision. He is hypotensive with a systolic pressure of 60 mm Hg. A FAST scan is positive. At laparotomy, he is found to have a large amount of bleeding from behind the liver with
hollow-viscous perforation. Temporary application of a Pringle manoeuvre does not control the bleeding. However, laparotomy packs are placed, and the bleeding appears to slow down. The systolic blood pressure fails to increase even after aggressive resuscitation. The patient’s pH is 7.06 and his temperature is 34°C. What would be the next best step in the management of this patient?
Ligate the hepatic arteries
explanation: This patient has a blunt trauma abdomen. He is hypothermic and he is battling acidosis. Thus, he should be subjected to damage control surgery and must be shifted to ICU for further resuscitation. Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries. 3 Phases : Phase I (Initial Exploration) - This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active hemorrhage and contamination. Phase II (Secondary Resuscitation) - This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis. Phase III (Definitive Operation) - It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation. Pringle's manoeuvre can be performed to decrease the active haemorrhage from the liver in a liver laceration. It is done by applying pressure on the portal triad at the Foramen of Winslow. The pressure can be applied either digitally or with the use of a soft clamp. Rapid control of the vessels entering the porta hepatis can be obtained by compressing them in the free edge of the lesser omentum. Porta hepatis is a deep, transverse fissure that is situated on the inferior surface of the right lobe of the liver. Structures entering at porta hepatis: Portal vein Hepatic artery Hepatic nervous plexus Structures exiting the porta hepatis: Right and left hepatic bile ducts Lymphatics The images attached below shows the porta hepatis and the gif demonstrates the pringles manoeuvre. 4 P's in the management of liver injuries are: Push- Compression of the edges of the laceration Pringle- Applying pressure on the portal triad Plug the defects with silicon tubes Pack- Apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding General guidelines for the management of blunt trauma to the liver: Patients who are haemodynamically unstable will require an immediate laparotomy for damage control resuscitation. For the patient who is haemodynamically stable, imaging by CT should be performed to further evaluate the nature of the injury. Most patients with a blunt liver injury who are haemodynamically stable can be managed conservatively. The indication for discontinuing conservative treatment is the development of haemodynamic nstability, evidence of ongoing blood loss despite correction of any underlying coagulopathy and the development of signs of generalised peritonitis. Interventional radiology has an important role in the management of liver trauma and embolisation to control hepatic artery bleeding is safe and effective in a stable patient with no evidence of hollow viscus perforation. question_text: Which of the following hormones will stimulate lobular development of the breast?
explanation: Progesterone stimulates lobular development of the breast and differentiation of the epithelium. Hormone Action Estrogen Ductal development Progestero ne Lobular development and dif ferentiation of the epithelium Prolactin Lactogenesis Oxytocin Milk ejection

question_text: Which of the following is not true regarding lymphatic drainage of the breast?
options: The axillary nodes receive approximately 85% of the drainage.
The lateral group is located along the axillary vein.
The anterior group drains most of the breast.
Lymph nodes are divided on the basis of their relation to the pectoralis major.

question_text: A 55-year-old woman presented to the OPD with a 4 x 2 cm painless lump in the left breast. She is planned for a mastectomy. Sentinel lymph node biopsy done showed involvement of evel 1 lymph nodes. Which of the following lymph nodes will not be affected in her case?
explanation: Interpectoral lymph nodes are level 2 axillary lymph nodes. Level 1 axillary lymph nodes include anterior, lateral, and posterior/subscapular nodes.

question_text: During a routine antenatal checkup, a pregnant woman in her third trimester is noticed to have accessory nipples. Which of the following does this condition refer to?
explanation: Polythelia or supernumerary nipples refer to the presence of accessory nipples. Polymastia or polymazia is a congenital anomaly with the presence of accessory breast tissue. Symmastia is a condition characterized by webbing between the breasts, at the midline. Supernumerary mazia is the presence of accessory breasts with a complete ductal system, areola, and nipple in addition to two normal breasts. Note: Athelia refers to the absence of nipples, and amastia refers to the congenital absence of the breast and nipple. The image below shows a third nipple below the left breast:

question_text: Which of the following is not true regarding accessory breast tissue?
options: It is associated with Poland’s syndrome
It develops along the line of Schultz
It is also known as polymazia
explanation: Poland’s syndrome is not associated with accessory breast tissue. It is associated with amastia with the absence of the sternal portion of the pectoralis major muscle. Polymastia or polymazia is a congenital anomaly in which there is presence of accessory breast tissue. Axilla is the most frequent site for accessory breast tissue along the line of Schultz. Accessory breast tissue develops along the milk line/ line of Schultz, which appears by the 6th week of embryonic development. The milk line extends from the axilla to the inguinal region. It is ectodermal in origin. The image below shows the milk line/ line of Schultz: The image below shows accessory breast tissue in the right axilla:
