question_text: A of the following statements about amazia are true except .
options: Amazia may be associated with Poland's syndrome
Amazia is the absence of the nipple.
Amazia is often the result of surgical intervention.
Amazia may be caused by radiation therapy.
explanation: Amazia is a condition wherein the breast tissue is absent, but the nipple-areolar complex is present. It results from iatrogenic causes such as radiation, excision of a misdiagnosed infantile or childhood mass that actually represented breast buds or incision and drainage of a suspected abscess. Note: Amastia is the congenital absence of the breast and nipple. Athelia is the absence of the nipple.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following will you not see in a patient with Poland’s syndrome?
options: Athelia with the absence of the pectoralis major
Amastia with the absence of pectoralis major
explanation: Athelia with absence of pectoralis major is not associated with Poland’s syndrome. Poland’s syndrome is associated with unilateral: Amastia with the absence of the sternal portion of the pectoralis major muscle Abnormalities of the chest wall muscles Loss of costal cartilage Digital abnormalities such as brachysyndactyly, which is the abnormal shortness of the fingers or toes combined with webbing between the adjacent digits In some cases, associated skeletal abnormalities, such as underdeveloped or absent upper ribs, underdeveloped forearm bones, and elevation of the shoulder blade (Sprengel deformity) may also be present. Note: Poland's syndrome is a constellation of anomalies with varying clinical presentations. Patients with this syndrome can present with amazia (absence of one or both of the mammary glands) or amastia (complete absence of breast tissue, nipple, and areola) in addition to any or all of the above-mentioned abnormalities.

question_text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with pain over the lateral aspect of her right breast for the past 5 days. Examination finding is as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mondor's disease. The image shows the presence of a subcutaneous cord and a narrow shallow groove along the side of the cord. Mondor’s disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. The most commonly involved vein is the lateral thoracic vein. Patients usually present with pain along the lateral chest wall and a tender, firm cord below the breast. It is a benign condition and gets resolved on its own within 4-6 weeks. Warm compresses and anti-inflammatory medicines can be used to reduce pain. If the symptoms persist despite medications, the affected segment of the vein can be excised. Option A: Tietze’s syndrome is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages. Option B: Zuska disease is the subcutaneous abscess of the breast tissue beneath the areola of the nipple. It is also called a subareolar abscess. Option D: Stewart–Treves Syndrome is characterized by lymphangiosarcoma in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the commonest cause of pathological nipple discharge in a non-lactating woman?
explanation: The most common cause of nipple discharge in a non-lactating woman is duct ectasia. The discharge is usually black or greenish in color. Option B: Intraductal papilloma is the most common cause of bloody nipple discharge. It is a true polyp of the epithelium-lined ducts of the breast. Contrary to what one might expect, they are not associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Option C: Paget's disease of the breast can present with discharge from the surface of the nipple. Option D: Galactorrhea is the milk production from breasts unrelated to pregnancy or lactation.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A chronic smoker presented with complaints of intermittent discharge from bilateral nipples for the past few months. On compression of her breast during the examination, a discharge was observed as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis of a patient with greenish discharge from multiple ducts is duct ectasia. Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes. The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green-colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis. Patients may present with nipple discharge, abscess, fistula, or nipple retraction. Treatment includes: Initial stages - oral antibiotics, needle aspiration, or incision and drainage of the abscess Recurrent episodes - Hadfield operation (cone excision of multiple ducts) A single duct involvement - microdochectomy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the best method of management in a patient with recurrent episodes of multiple duct ectasia?
options: Wide excision involving the affected ducts
explanation: The best method of management in a patient with multiple duct ectasia is to perform Hadfield's operation. This operation consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts. The initial stages of duct ectasia can be managed by oral antibiotics, needle aspiration, or incision and drainage of the abscess. Recurrent episodes of infection are best managed by Hadfield operation. If a single duct is involved, then microdochectomy is performed.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Amongst the following, the most common cause of blood-stained nipple discharge from a single duct is:
explanation: Ductal papilloma is the most common cause of blood-stained nipple discharge from a single duct. Solitary intraductal papillomas are true polyps of the ducts which are usually small (<1 cm) but may grow to 4-5 cm. They are often associated with bloody nipple discharge. They do not have malignant potential. Treatment is by excision. Note: The most common cause of blood-stained discharge from multiple ducts is carcinoma.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A probe is inserted into the duct from which the nipple discharge is emerging. A tennis racquet incision is made and the flap is dissected to reach the duct. The duct is then excised. This procedure is known as?
options: Wide excision of the lactiferous duct.
explanation: Microdochectomy is the excision of the entire lactiferous duct (single duct disease). It is done for duct papilloma. Microdochectomy: In a duct papilloma where no palpable mass is present, the duct is expressed to observe the discharge. A fine probe or stiff nylon suture is gently inserted into the duct, and the probe is secured to the nipple skin using silk sutures to prevent displacement during the procedure. A tennis racquet shaped incision is made to elevate the skin flaps, and the duct with the probe is excised along with the skin flap for 5 cm until the papilloma is identified (The papilloma wi always be located within 5 cm from the duct orifice). The wound is closed without a drain, and a compression bandage is applied. It is ideal to rule out DCIS by frozen section biopsy. Cone excision and wide excision are done under major duct excision (Adair-Haldfield operation). It is done for duct ectasias with multiple duct involvement and multiple papillomas.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following aberration of normal development and involution of breast tissue is present in patients with fibroadenoma?
explanation: In fibroadenoma, aberration of normal lobular development is present. It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth, firm, non-tender, solitary, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). It is a biphasic tumor consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined gland. question_text: A 19-year-old girl presents with a lump in her right breast for the past 6 months. On examination, the lump is around 1 x1 cm in size, firm, and freely movable on the breast tissue. Ultrasound shows the presence of a circumscribed oval lobulated mass. Which of the following is not true regarding the given condition?
options: Peak incidence is in second decade
It is a form of ANDI
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of fibroadenoma. Mammography may show the presence of popcorn calcification. Eggshell calcification can be seen in traumatic fat necrosis. Fibroadenoma is a form of aberrations of normal development and involution of the breast (ANDI). The most common age group affected is 15-25 years (early reproductive period) with a peak incidence in the second decade. It arises from hyperplasia of a single lobule and presents as a well-circumscribed, smooth, firm, non-tender, solitary, freely mobile mass (mouse in the breast). It is a biphasic tumor consisting of fibroblastic stroma and epithelium-lined gland. Excision is not advised unless there is suspicious histology on FNAC. Giant fibroadenoma is more than 5cm in size and is common in adolescent girls. It requires excision by submammary incision. The image below shows popcorn calcification on mammography:

explanation: Giant fibroadenomas are over 5 cm in diameter and occasionally occur during puberty. They are often rapidly growing but are similar to smaller fibroadenomas and are enucleated through a submammary incision.

question_text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lump in the left breast as shown in the image below. Biopsy done revealed increased stromal cellularity with typical leaflike architecture. Which of the following is false about this condition?
options: Treatment is wide excision with margin
Originates from hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast
explanation: The given clinical scenario and histopathology report point to malignant cystosarcoma phyllodes, which metastasize via the bloodstream. Metastasis to lymph nodes is rare. Phyllodes tumor also known as a sero-cystic disease of Brodie or cystosarcoma phyllodes, originates from hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast. It is usually a benign condition and affects women >40 years of age, but can be seen in younger women. Sometimes, may develop malignant transformation. Clinical features: Large, sometimes massive, with an unevenly bosselated surface Ulceration of overlying skin occurs because of pressure necrosis Remains mobile on the chest wa There is no role of FNAC in phyllodes tumor. Histopathology of the lump biopsy shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture. Tumors are treated by excision with margins of at least 2 cm to prevent local recurrence. Large or malignant phyllodes tumors may require a mastectomy. The axillary dissection is not recommended because axillary lymph nodes rarely get involved. Note: Malignant phyllodes tumors contain liposarcomatous or rhabdomyosarcomatous elements rather than fibrosarcomatous elements.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A breastfeeding mother presented to the clinic with fever and breast pain for the past 2 days. The affected breast appears as shown in the image below. There is extreme tenderness on palpation. Which of the following is the most common source for the organism causing this condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of lactational mastitis. The most common source of infection is from the infant's nasopharynx. Lactational mastitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus present in the infant's nasopharynx. The organism enters the breast tissue through cracked nipples and multiplies in the stagnant breast milk. Patients present with fever with a firm, red, tender, and swollen quadrant of the unilateral breast. Painful breasts must be managed by the use of analgesics. Breastfeeding should be continued if the pain is less severe. Antibiotics like flucloxacillin, co-amoxiclav are used to treat the infection. If the patient develops an abscess, then the abscess has to be drained by aspiration or incision. question_text: A female patient presents with a breast abscess. An aspiration was attempted under antibiotic cover which failed to reveal any aspirate. What is the next step in management?
options: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected
explanation: In a patient with a breast abscess, the next step after a failed aspiration is to attempt aspiration once again under antibiotic cover. Incision and drainage is not preferred, as it can potentially interfere with breastfeeding, and delicate structures such as ducts, lobules, and tubules may be injured, possibly leading to a non-healing milk fistula. A breast abscess is a complication of acute mastitis, which is more common in new mothers at the beginning of lactation (lactational mastitis). Non-lactational mastitis is more common in diabetic, immunosuppressed people and people predisposed by duct ectasia and periareolar infections. Clinical features of a breast abscess include: Fever and malaise Localized pain and tenderness Redness and swelling of the affected breast Positive fluctuation test. An ultrasonogram of the affected breast is performed to confirm the abscess, and treatment proceeds as follows: Analgesics, antipyretics, and breast support for pain and fever relief. Aspiration is performed under antibiotic cover, and the pus is cultured. If aspiration proves unsuccessful, it should be reattempted after a few days. Incision and drainage should be considered in cases of: Mastitis unresponsive to antibiotics for 48 hours. Brawny induration. question_text: A 37- year-old woman presented to the clinic with a breast lump. Clinical examination and ultrasound revealed the presence of a single large cyst in her right breast. On aspirating the cyst, you find blood-stained fluid. What will be the next best step in the management of this patient?
options: Wait for refilling and reattempt aspiration
Perform mammogram to rule out carcinoma
explanation: The next step in management is the excision of the cyst. Treatment of breast cyst: If the aspirate is clear (non-blood stained) or if the cyst resolves completely then no further treatment is required. If the aspirate is blood-stained or if the cyst recurs, then a core biopsy or local excision should be performed. The resulting tissue should be sent for histopathology for the exclusion of cystadenocarcinoma, especially in elderly women.

question_text: Physiological gynecomastia is not seen in which of the following?
explanation: Physiological gynecomastia is not seen in obese males. In obese men, increased fat deposition over the breasts is referred to as pseudo-gynecomastia. Gynecomastia is defined as  2 cm subareolar breast tissue. It can be physiological or pathological. Physiologic gynecomastia occurs during three phases of life: Neonatal period Adolescence Senescence Common to each of these phases is an excess of circulating estrogens in relation to circulating testosterone. Neonatal gynecomastia is caused by the action of placental estrogens on neonatal breast tissues. In adolescence, there is an excess of estradiol relative to testosterone. In senescence, the circulating testosterone level falls, resulting in relative hyperestrogenism.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman has been experiencing breast pain for the past 6 months. The pain is present just before her menstrual period. Breast examination and mammography are normal. A of the following medications/supplements can help in reducing the pain except:
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of cyclical mastalgia. Caffeine is not useful in reducing pain. On the contrary, caffeine has to be avoided to reduce pain. Medications that can be used to treat mastalgia are evening primrose oil, danazol, and tamoxifen.

question_text: A breastfeeding mother presented to the clinic with a gradually progressive painless breast ump. On examination, a well-circumscribed and freely mobile mass was palpable. USG showed a solitary, well-defined, anechoic lesion with thin, echogenic walls. Aspiration revealed a white fluid. What is the best treatment option for this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of galactocele. The best treatment option for this condition is USG guided fine-needle aspiration. A galactocele is a milk-filled cavity in the breast of a woman who is usually lactating. It can be caused due to lactation problems, prolactin stimulation by drugs, or duct obstruction. It presents as a palpable, round, well-circumscribed, and freely mobile mass with no fever, pain, or inflammation. It is usually subareolar and unilateral. USG guided fine-needle aspiration is both diagnostic and therapeutic. It will show thick milky white secretion confirming the diagnosis. Aspiration resolves galactocele in most cases. Surgery is done for infected cysts or recurrent cases. Antibiotic therapy is not needed if the galactocele is not infected.

question_text: A woman presented to the clinic with redness and itching over the left breast as shown in the image below. Histopathology showed large pale vacuolated cells with round nuclei in the epithelium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical picture and histology are suggestive of Paget's disease of the breast. Paget’s disease is a rare type of cancer involving the nipple-areolar complex, often with an underlying in-situ or invasive ductal carcinoma. It presents as a chronic, eczematous eruption of the nipple which may progress to ulceration. Paget disease of the breast is often mistaken for eczema. A nipple biopsy specimen of Paget's disease will show a population of cells that are identical to the underlying malignant cells. The presence of large, pale, vacuolated cells (Paget cells) with round or oval nuclei are pathognomonic for this condition. Depending on the type and extent of underlying malignancy, it can be treated with lumpectomy or mastectomy. question_text: Which is the most common variant of breast carcinoma?
explanation: Invasive ductal carcinoma (not otherwise specified) is the most common variant of breast carcinoma. It is also known as infiltrating ductal carcinoma.

question_text: Which of the following is not true regarding breast carcinoma?
options: Cutaneous oedema in inflammatory carcinoma is the result of blockage of the sub-dermal lymphatics with carcinoma cells
Mucinous carcinomas are usually hormone negative
Calcifications are frequently associated with ductal carcinoma in situ
Lobular carcinoma in situ is multi centric and bilateral
explanation: Mucinous carcinoma is usually hormone-positive (90%). It is also called colloid carcinoma. It is a low-grade tumor with a good prognosis. It typically presents as a bulky mass in the elderly. Option A: Pathologic hallmark of inflammatory carcinoma is a painful, swollen breast, which is warm with cutaneous edema due to blockage of subdermal lymphatics with carcinoma cells. Option C: Calcification is usually associated with ductal carcinoma in-situ (DCIS). It is the most common malignancy detected in screening mammograms. Option D: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is mainly multicentric (sometimes multifocal) and bilateral.

question_text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of swelling of the right breast over the past 15 days. On examination, there was local rise of temperature, and the swelling was mobile over the chest wall. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: In the given scenario, the rapid onset of the disease and the examination findings are suggestive of inflammatory carcinoma of the breast. Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. It mimics acute mastitis. The hallmark of inflammatory breast carcinoma is the diffuse tumor involvement of the dermal lymphatics within the breast and the overlying skin, often without a discrete underlying tumor mass (peau d' orange appearance). The patient presents with rapidly progressive swelling of the breast, warmth, erythema and edema. A breast lump may or may not be present. A diagnosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma should be suspected when a patient with rapidly progressive swelling with inflammatory skin changes does not respond to antibiotics. The imaging features with ultrasound and a mammograph is non-specific due to the underlying erythema and edema. A biopsy should be done to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment includes combined-modality treatment: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy Mastectomy Radiation therapy Hormonal therapy- for ER-positive tumors Trastuzumab for HER-2-positive tumors Option B: Giant fibroadenomas occasionally occur during puberty. These are benign solid encapsulated slow-growing tumors over 5 cm in diameter. It presents as a painless lump in the breast. They are managed by excision via a submammary incision. Option C: Phyllodes tumors usually occur in women over the age of 40 years but can appear in younger women. Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called cystosarcoma phyllodes. It presents as a large tumor with an unevenly bosselated surface. They are usually mobile over the chest wall despite their large size. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin. Nipple retraction is not seen in this condition. Benign lesions can be treated with enucleation or wide local excision. Massive tumours, recurrent tumours and malignant lesions are treated with a mastectomy. Option D: Galactocele are the most common benign breast lesions in lactating women. It is a cystic enlargement of the mammary gland containing milk. They are mostly detected during lactation or in the third trimester of pregnancy but rarely, may also present after stopping breastfeeding. Clinically, the mass is usually firm and non-tender and presents as a solid tumour-like lesion on physical examination. The patient usually notes the lesion during lactation or some period after lactation. Needle aspiration, followed by excision should it recur, is the standard method of treating galactocele.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A postmenopausal lady came to the clinic with complaints of breast pain and a lump in her right breast for the past 2 months. On examination, the breast appears as shown in the image. What is the most likely cause for this finding?
explanation: In the given image, the orange peel-like appearance, also called as peau d’orange is caused by cutaneous lymphatic edema, due to the obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics. It is the hallmark of inflammatory carcinoma. Option A: Infiltration of Cooper’s ligaments leads to dimpling of the skin. Option C: Infiltration of the lactiferous ducts leads to nipple retraction. Cancer-en-cuirasse is an aggressive form of cancer, where there is cutaneous and subcutaneous infiltration of the cancer cells. Note: While Peau d’orange indicates skin involvement, dimpling of the skin and nipple retraction do not indicate skin involvement.

question_text: A middle-aged woman presented with a painless lump in the breast. Mammography done showed suspicious microcalcifications. USG-guided core biopsy revealed large cells with cytoplasmic mucoid globules and neighborhood calcifications. There is no invasion into the basement membrane and fibrovascular stroma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The presence of large cells with cytoplasmic mucoid globules with an intact basement membrane, and neighborhood calcifications are characteristic of lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). Lobular carcinoma in-situ is usually detected as an incidental finding on evaluation of either a mass lesion or abnormalities on mammography. The slide below shows cytoplasmic mucoid globules seen in lobular carcinoma in situ. Option A: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) can have various histological appearances like solid, comedo, papillary cribriform, etc Option B: Histology of Paget’s disease of the breast shows the presence of large pale vacuolated cells (Paget cells) in the rete pegs of the epithelium. Option D: Histology of phyllodes tumor consists of nodules of proliferating stromal cells, that are covered by epithelium. This resembles a leaf and is hence termed as phyllodes.

question_text: Which of the following is most likely in a woman with bilateral and multicentric breast lumps?
explanation: Bilaterality and multicentricity are most commonly associated with lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS). LCIS occurs bilaterally in 50 - 70% of cases. Multicentricity is seen in 60 - 90% of patients with LCIS. Multicentricity refers to the occurrence of second breast cancer outside the breast quadrant of the primary cancer (or at least 4 cm away). Multifocality refers to the occurrence of a second cancer within the same breast quadrant as the primary cancer (or within 4 cm of it).

question_text: An annual screening mammogram done for a middle-aged woman showed clusters of microcalcifications. Stereotactic trucut biopsy revealed a comedo growth pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The presence of microcalcifications on mammography and comedo pattern on histology is suggestive of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Treatment: Breast conservation surgery with radiotherapy or, Simple mastectomy- least loco-regional recurrence No role of chemotherapy If ER, PR +ve- hormonal therapy Comedo subtype refers to the presence of necrosis. It implies that the tumor cells are growing rapidly and the blood vessel is not able to supply all the malignant cells. On the contrary, non-comedo subtype implies that the tumor is growing slowly and the blood vessel is able to supply all the cells. Therefore, the comedo subtypes are of high-grade DCIS.

question_text: A woman with BRCA1 gene mutation presented with lumps in both breasts and enlarged axillary lymphadenopathy. She gives a history of breast cancer in her sister. MRI and trucut biopsy done confirmed the diagnosis of medullary carcinoma of the breast. Which of the following statements is true regarding the given condition?
options: Lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia
It is a slow growing tumor
Tamoxifen can be used in the treatmen
Has poorer prognosis than invasive lobular carcinoma
explanation: Medullary carcinoma of the breast is associated with intense lymphocyte proliferation. Therefore, the lymph node enlargement can be due to reactive hyperplasia rather than the spread of the cancer cells to the lymph nodes. Medullary carcinoma is a common type of breast cancer associated with BRCA1 gene mutation. Bilateral tumors are common when family history is present. The tumor can enlarge rapidly due to necrosis and hemorrhage. The majority of the tumors are triple-negative (ER/PR/Her-2 negative). Histopathology consists of: A dense lymphoreticular infiltration composed predominantly of lymphocytes and plasma cells A sheet-like growth pattern of anaplastic cells with absent ductal or lobular differentiation It has a better prognosis than invasive ductal or invasive lobular carcinoma.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A male patient who presented with a lump in his right breast is diagnosed to have breast carcinoma. Which of the following is true regarding the given condition?
options: The prognosis is worse than in females
Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type
Tamoxifen is not effective in treatmen
explanation: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer seen in men. Breast cancer in men accounts for less than 1% of all breast cancers. The peak incidence is between 60-70 years of age. Majority of the patients present with a hard mass in the breast. Important risk factors are: BRCA2 mutation Radiation exposure Estrogen therapy Testicular feminizing syndrome Klinefelter syndrome Diagnosis of male breast carcinoma is similar to females which involves a clinical examination, imaging, and tissue biopsy. Grading, treatment, and prognosis are the same as female breast cancer. The majority of male breast cancers are hormone receptor-positive and hence tamoxifen is used in the treatment.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 35-year-old woman is worried about developing breast cancer. Her mother and sister had developed breast cancer at the age of 30 years and 32 years respectively. She has 2 daughters. After evaluation, she is found to have a BRCA-1 gene mutation. Which of the following methods will you suggest for the maximum risk reduction of developing carcinoma breast in this patient?
Close surveillance with MRI every 6 months
explanation: Prophylactic mastectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy will provide maximum risk reduction in this patient with a complete family, a positive gene mutation, and positive family history. Breast cancer risk reduction techniques: Lifestyle modification: Low-calorie diet, daily exercise, no smoking, no drinking, etc. More frequent screening every 6-12 months with mammogram +- MRI Chemoprevention: Preferred in women >35 years of age in patients who are ER/PR positive. Given for 5-10 years. SERMS (selective estrogen receptor modulators) - Tamoxifen and raloxifene - have adverse effects. If a patient on tamoxifen develops abnormal uterine bleeding, the drug needs to be stopped. Aromatase Inhibitors (AIs): Better tolerated than SERMs have a low risk of cardiovascular and endometrial complications. They are used only in post-menopausal women. Risk-reduction surgeries: done in patients with gene mutations or patients with first-degree relatives with breast cancers. Provides >90% risk-reduction. Preferred in patients who have completed their family. Best results when done < 40 years of age. Bilateral mastectomy Salpingo-oophorectomy: preferred in patients with BRCA1/2 mutations to prevent the risk of ovarian cancer too. Investigations in Breast diseases

question_text: What is the recommended age for starting screening mammography?
explanation: The recommended age for women to start annual screening mammography is 40 years of age. Until 44 years of age, it is her individual choice to decide on whether she wants screening mammography or not. For ages between 45 and 49 years, it is mandatory to get annual breast screening done. After the age of 50 years, it is advised that women get a second yearly screening done.

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding screening mammography?
options: Sensitivity of the test will increase with her age.
It is best performed in the 2nd half of her menstrual cycle.
Mediolateral oblique view will show the greatest volume of her breast tissue.
Craniocaudal view will provide better visualization of the medial aspect of her breast.
explanation: Mammography is best performed in the 1st half of the menstrual cycle, as breast tissue is less dense in the follicular phase. Also, in the 2nd half of the menstrual cycle, since ovulation occurs and there is a chance for pregnancy, the radiation can potentially affect the embryo. The sensitivity of mammography increases with age, as the breast tissue becomes less dense. It involves 2 standard views: Mediolateral oblique (MLO) view- covers a greater volume of breast tissue, including the upper outer quadrant and the axillary tail of Spence. Craniocaudal (CC) view- provides better visualization of the medial aspect of the breast. Mammography uses low-voltage, high-amperage X-rays. The radiation dose from mammography is around 0.1 cGy per study.

question_text: A 58-year-old woman presents with complaints of a painless lump in her left breast which she noticed during a routine self-examination. On palpation, a hard lump with irregular margins and enlarged left axillary lymph nodes were found. Which among the following is the best modality to detect malignancy in her case?
explanation: Tomosynthesis (3D mammography) performed along with conventional 2D mammography is the best investigation among the given options to detect breast carcinoma. Breast Tomosynthesis is typically performed in conjunction with conventional mammography. Hence, the radiation dose is doubled. However, the accuracy is improved and false positives are lesser. It can be used for dense breasts and those with high-risk factors. Screen-film mammography is the conventional 2D mammography. Digital mammography/full-field digital mammography uses digital technology instead of films. The diagnostic accuracy is similar to that of screen-film mammography. A minor advantage is the greater accuracy in predicting lesions in dense breasts. Note: Overall, the best modality for detecting breast carcinoma is MRI. question_text: A mammogram done for a 45-year-old female patient with a breast lump was reported as BIRADS category 0. What is it suggestive of?
explanation: Category/score 0 in BIRADS suggests an incomplete assessment. All breast imaging should be reported by BIRADS (breast imaging-reporting and data system).
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 48-year-old woman with a lump in her right breast was advised to undergo mammography which was reported as BIRADS 3. What will be the appropriate next step of management in this patient?
explanation: A BIRADS score of 3 means that it is probably a benign lesion. The next appropriate step is to follow up with this patient every 6 months for the next 2 years. During this period, the score can either downgrade to BIRADS 2 or upgrade to BIRADS 4 or 5.
subject: Surgery

question_text: An anxious 45-year-old woman presented with complaints of a lump over her left breast for 2 months. The patient underwent mammography, and the lump was categorized as BIRADS 4a. What is the likelihood of her lesion being malignant?
explanation: There is a 2-10% likelihood for a lesion with BIRADS 4a to be malignant. BIRADS Categories/Grades Grades 1 and 2: 0% chance of being malignant. Grade 3: >0% but 2% chance of being malignant Grade 4: 4a: >2 to 10% chance of being malignant 4b: >10 to 50% chance of being malignant 4c: >50 to <95% chance of being malignant Grade 5:  95% chance of being malignant
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 36-year-old pregnant lady was referred to the surgery OPD at 12 weeks of gestation with a lump in her right breast for the past 1 month. On examination, a lump of 2 x 1 cm size was palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Which of the following investigations would you initially advise her for the assessment of the breast lump?
explanation: Ultrasonography (USG) is the preferred initial investigation in pregnant women who present with a breast lump. It can differentiate between solid and cystic lesions of the breast and is able to detect abnormal axillary lymph nodes. USG is preferred in women with dense breast tissue such as: Pregnant women Lactating women Young women (less than 40 years old) Conventional Mammography/ Tomosynthesis with 2D mammography is less useful in pregnant women due to the increased density of breast tissue. MRI is not the initial investigation used for the assessment of breast lumps. It can be used in cases where metastasis or spread to other breasts is suspected.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A USG can detect lymph node metastases in a patient with breast cancer and clinically negative lymph nodes by what percentage?
explanation: A USG can detect lymph node metastasis in a patient with clinically negative lymph nodes by 50-60%. The clinical determination of axillary lymph node metastases has an accuracy of only 33%. Ultrasound (USG) is more sensitive than physical examination alone in determining axillary lymph node involvement during the preliminary staging of breast carcinoma. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) or core biopsy of sonographically indeterminate or suspicious lymph nodes can provide a more definitive diagnosis than USG alone. Ultrasonography can also be utilized to image the regional lymph nodes in patients with breast cancer. The sensitivity for the status of axillary nodes ranges from 35% to 82% and specificity ranges from 73% to 97%. The features of a lymph node involved with cancer on USG include: Cortical thickening Change in shape of the node to a more circular appearance Size larger than 10 mm Absence of a fatty hilum Hypoechoic internal echoes
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following features on USG will not be suggestive of breast malignancy?
options: Lump will be taller than wider
explanation: Malignant breast lump on USG, has an ill-defined echogenic halo, is hypoechoic, and the lump will be taller than wider. Benign breast lumps have a thin echogenic pseudo-capsule on USG.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young female patient presents to the clinic with a painless lump in her right breast. She underwent breast augmentation surgery 3 years back. Which of the following will be the best investigation to assess the breast tissue in this patient?
explanation: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the best investigation to assess breast tissue in a patient with a breast implant. MRI of the breast is also used in: Screening of high-risk individuals with a positive family history. Assessing loco-regional spread (multifocality and multicentricity) of carcinoma. To differentiate scar from recurrence in women who have had breast conservation surgery for breast cancer. Option A: Tomosynthesis is not preferred, as radio-opaque implants are usually compressed together with the breast tissue, obscuring the visibility and thereby reducing its sensitivity. Option B: Ultrasonography is used as an initial investigation in the evaluation of breast abnormalities in patients with breast implants. Option D: Computed tomography is not routinely used in the evaluation of breast lumps.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 40-year-old woman with an elder sister with BRCA1 gene mutation presented to the OPD with a normal mammography report. Which of the following is the next preferred investigation to further evaluate this patient?
explanation: In the given scenario, since the patient is at high risk for breast malignancy (first degree relative with BRCA1 gene mutation), MRI followed by trucut biopsy will be the appropriate next step for further evaluation. MRI is helpful in the screening of high-risk individuals and is the most sensitive imaging modality. However, it should be done after initial radiological evaluation, in case the results are inconclusive. American Cancer Society Risk Criteria for Breast Magnetic Resonance Imaging Screening: Women at high lifetime risk (20%-25% or greater) of breast cancer- Known BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation First-degree relatives with BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutation, but have not had genetic testing themselves. Radiation therapy to the chest between the ages of 10 and 30 years Li-Fraumeni syndrome or Cowden syndrome or a first-degree relative with one of these syndromes. Women with a personal history of breast cancer, ductal carcinoma in situ, lobular carcinoma in situ, atypical ductal hyperplasia, or atypical lobular hyperplasia, are at a moderately increased lifetime risk for breast cancer. Options A & D: Breast tomosynthesis or repeat mammography is not preferred as the next investigation in high-risk patients. Option C: Trucut biopsy will be done following MRI in high-risk patients.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A postmenopausal woman who was on HRT for the past 2 years, presented with a 4 x 3cm lump over the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. On examination, a peau d’orange appearance was seen and a hard and fixed lump was palpated over the breast. Which of the following is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: The history and physical examination point towards a diagnosis of breast malignancy. The investigation of choice for confirmation of breast carcinoma is trucut biopsy/core-needle biopsy. An excisional biopsy can be done, in case it is inconclusive. Trucut needle biopsy permits the analysis of breast tissue architecture. A 14 G- 16 G needle is used. The advantages include a low complication rate, minimal scarring, and a lower cost as compared to excisional breast biopsy. Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a cytological investigation and, hence, not the investigation of choice. A 22-30 G needle is used for FNAC. Trucut biopsy is preferred over FNAC as it: Allows a definitive preoperative diagnosis Differentiates between DCIS and invasive disease Allows the tumor to be stained for receptor status, which is important for starting neoadjuvant therapy. Image-guided biopsy is used only in the case of non-palpable lesions.
subject: Surgery

question_text: As a surgery resident, which of the following will you perform in a patient with suspected breast malignancy as part of the triple assessment?
explanation: Triple assessment in relation to breast carcinoma includes the following: Clinical assessment includes both history and clinical examination Radiological imaging, including ultrasonography (USG) and/or mammography Histopathological examination (HPE), including fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) and/or Tru-Cut biopsy The positive predictive value of the triple assessment is 99.9%. Note: Bailey & Love 27th Ed mentions that clinical assessment, radiological imaging, and HPE constitute triple assessment. However, clinical assessment includes both history and clinical examination. Hence, history is a part of the triple assessment.
subject: Surgery

question_text: An actress with bilateral silicone breast implants presents for regular follow-up. On radiological evaluation, she was found to have signs suggestive of intracapsular breast implant rupture. Which of the following named signs will you see on imaging?
explanation: Linguine sign (on MRI) and Stepladder sign (on USG) are specific for intracapsular breast implant rupture. After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the free-floating shell appears as a group of wavy lines (like the Italian linguine pasta as shown below). Hence, this has been termed the "linguine sign". Stepladder sign (seen on USG) is identified as multiple, discontinuous, parallel, linear echoes in the lumen as shown below. Snowstorm sign (seen on USG) is seen in extracapsular rupture of breast implant. Comet tail sign is a finding that can be seen on chest CT. The comet-tail sign is produced by the distortion of vessels and bronchi that lead to an adjacent area of round atelectasis, which is the mass. The bronchovascular bundles appear to be pulled into the mass and resemble a comet tail. Note: Detection of intracapsular silicone ruptures is almost impossible on mammography.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A woman came with complaints of breast pain following surgery. Her MRI is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above image shows curvilinear hypointense lines (arrows) in the left breast implant indicative of the collapsed shell floating in the silicone gel. This is called the linguine sign that is seen in intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant. After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines. This has been termed the "linguine sign" and has been most commonly described with MR imaging. Multiple hyperintense foci on T2-weighted images are sometimes found within the implant lumen. These findings are referred to as the salad oil sign or droplet sign. Indications for breast MRI: Screening for DCIS in high-risk patients Evaluation of breast implants Evaluation of breast scar tissue versus recurrent tumors. Ultrasound is the preferred modality of imaging in suspected cases of extracapsular rupture. The snowstorm sign on USG is seen in extracapsular rupture.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 50-year-old female patient presents with a 4*3cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast, which is not fixed to the skin or the chest wall. A lymph node of 2cm is palpated in the right axilla. No mass is palpated in the opposite breast. Which of the following investigations would you perform on this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of breast malignancy with locoregional spread with unlikely distant metastasis. For further evaluation of this lesion, bilateral mammography, a biopsy of the breast mass and a USG-guided biopsy of the suspicious lymph node need to be performed in order to determine staging and decide on further management. Statement 2: PET Scan is usually performed in advanced cases of breast cancer. It is not routinely used in the assessment of locoregional disease. Statement 1: Diagnostic mammography is used to evaluate women with abnormal findings such as a breast mass or nipple discharge. Mammography is more accurate than clinical examination for the detection of early breast cancers. Mammographic features suggestive of breast cancer include a solid mass with or without stellate features, microcalcifications, irregular soft tissue shadow, spiculations and duct distortion. Statement 3: Pathological diagnosis of carcinoma is made by a core needle biopsy (tru-cut biopsy) or fine-needle aspiration before any type of treatment is started. Statement 4: The presence or absence of axillary lymph node involvement in breast cancer is one of the most important prognostic factors for determining staging and treatment. Ultrasound-guided lymph node biopsy should be done in patients with suspicious or clinically palpable lymph nodes. Ultrasound features suggestive of breast cancer include a hypoechoic, irregular mass with indistinct, angulated or spiculated margins, acoustic shadowing, ductal extension and a branched pattern of mass.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 22-year-old woman is found to have the BRCA1 mutation. She got herself tested after her mother’s death due to breast cancer with a BRCA1 mutation. At what age and with which modality would you start breast cancer screening in this patient?
explanation: Patients with BRCA mutations or positive known first-degree family history are considered high-risk patients. These patients need to undergo annual screening MRI + Mammogram from the age of 25yrs. Patients with a family history of breast cancer but no known gene mutation should also start screening before 40 years. Screening should begin 10 years before the earliest age of diagnosis of breast cancer in the first-degree relative. E.g- If the mother was detected with breast cancer at 40 years of age, the daughter should start screening by the age of 30 years. High-risk patients for breast cancer: Women with a known BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation Two first-degree relatives with breast cancers with or without gene mutations Women with a history of chest irradiation between the ages of 10 and 30 2 or more cases of breast cancer < 50 years old in the family Mutation (or a first-degree relative with a mutation) in the TP53 or PTEN genes
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A young woman with a distant breast cancer relative comes to you in the clinic. You are advising her to practice self-examination of her breasts. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this practice?
It should be done once a month, every month
options: Ideally, be done between the 3rd to 6th day of the menstrual cycle
It should only be done while standing
The examination should be done by using the middle three fingerpads
explanation: Self-examination of breasts can be done while standing or lying down. It should be ideally be done once a month, every month between the 3rd to 6th day of the menstrual cycle. If the periods are irregular or the patient is post-menopausal, then the patient can pick any day of the month. It can be done any time of the day while showering, dressing, standing, or lying down at night. Steps of the self-examination: Visual inspection: See for any abnormalities, like shape, size, dimpling, puckering of the skin, nipple discharge, etc. Manual inspection: It is done by using the middle three fingerpads. Feel for any lumps. Techniques used are (either one of them): Horizontal stripes method Vertical stripes method Dial clock method Be sure to check under the areola and press the nipple gently to check for any discharge. Carcinoma Breast - Staging, Prognosis & Molecular Types
subject: Surgery

question_text: Tis classification is used for the staging of:
explanation: Tis classification is used for the staging of ductal carcinoma in situ and Paget’s disease only. Tis means carcinoma in-situ. Tis (DCIS) - includes ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) Tis (Paget) - includes Paget's disease of the nipple NOT associated with evident invasive carcinoma and/or carcinoma in situ (DCIS) in the underlying breast parenchyma According to the latest American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) classification system (8th edition), lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is not included in Tis since it is a benign entity. LCIS is considered a proliferative disease that has a risk of developing breast carcinoma in the future, and hence, it is not included in the classification system. Pleomorphic LCIS is also considered a benign condition.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A postmenopausal lady presented with painless lumps in the right breast. On examination, two lumps of size 6 x 2 cm and 4 x 1 cm were palpated in the upper outer quadrant.
Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes were felt. On evaluation, there was no distant metastasis. What is the TNM staging of this tumor?
explanation: TNM staging of the tumor is T3 N1 M0. In the given scenario: The bigger lump is 6 cm in size - T3 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes - N1 No distant metastasis - M0. In tumor size assessment, the greatest dimension is taken into consideration. For example, in a 6 x 2 cm lump, 6 cm is taken into account, and the tumor is classified as T3 (>5 cm). If 2 lumps are present in the same breast, staging is according to the bigger lump. If lumps are present in bilateral breasts, separate staging is done for both the lumps. Any contralateral lymph node involvement is considered as distant metastasis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A woman came with a 4 x 3 cm lump over the right breast. On examination, the breast appears as shown below. Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes are palpable with fixed axillary nodes on the left side. What is the most appropriate tumor staging?
explanation: TNM staging in the given scenario is T4d N3c M1. Tumour of any size with typical skin changes involving > 1/3 of breast- T4d (Inflammatory breast carcinoma) Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph node involvement - N3c Involvement of any contralateral lymph nodes indicates distant metastasis - M1
subject: Surgery

question_text: A middle-aged woman presented to the clinic with a 7 x 3 cm lump in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast. On palpation, the lump was found to be fixed to the pectoralis major muscle. What is the T staging of the tumor in this patient?
explanation: In the given scenario, as the lump is 7 cm in size, the T stage of the tumor is T3 ( >5 cm). Irrelevant to the size of the tumor, if the tumor shows extension to the chest wall or skin, it is classified as T4. However, there are two exceptions: Invasion or adherence to pectoralis muscle in the absence of chest wall involvement does not qualify as T4 Involvement of the dermis alone does not qualify as T4

question_text: During immunohistochemistry for ER, PR status, staining of what percentage of cells indicates positivity?
explanation: The staining of  1% of cells is considered positive. Expression of estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) in breast cancer cells is mainly assessed by immunohistochemistry.

question_text: A trucut biopsy is obtained from a woman who presented with a breast lump. The biopsy confirms the presence of mucinous carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry shows ER, PR and HER2/neu positive. What is the molecular subtype of breast cancer in this patient?
explanation: Breast cancer with ER, PR +ve and HER2/neu +ve status will be classified as luminal B type. It is also known as triple-positive cancer. Along with ER, PR, and HER2/neu, a proliferation index known as the ši67 index is also used. question_text: In breast cancer patients, FISH for gene amplification will be done based on which of the following IHC staining for Her-2/neu?
options: Gene Amplification is done irrespective of Her 2 Neu status
explanation: Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) should be performed in all cases of breast tumors with an immunohistochemistry (IHC) score of 2+. Expression of estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and HER2/neu in breast cancer cells is mainly assessed by immunohistochemistry. HER2/neu IHC interpretation: 1+ = Negative 2+ = Equivocal - FISH is done to differentiate whether the tumor cells are positive or negative for HER2/neu expression 3+ = Positive HER2/neu- complete circumferential membrane staining in >10% of tumor cells The given image shows HER2/neu, ER, and PR positivity.

question_text: Which of the following is true about Oncotype Dx, a molecular test used for breast cancer?
options: Helpful in predicting the advantage of adding radiotherapy
explanation: Oncotype Dx assay is a molecular test based on the assessment of 21 genes. Higher scores predict increased benefits from chemotherapy. On the other hand, lower scores in this assay predict lesser benefit from chemotherapy and increased benefit from endocrine therapy. It is used for patients with lymph node-negative, ER-positive breast cancer.
subject: Surgery

question_text: After performing Oncotype Dx for a breast tumor, a low recurrence score is obtained. Which of the following is true regarding management in this patient?
options: Tumor resection with chemotherapy should be done
Brachytherapy with chemotherapy should be done
Chemotherapy should be used along with hormonal therapy
There is no advantage in adding chemotherapy
explanation: A low recurrence score after Oncotype Dx suggests that there is no survival advantage of adding chemotherapy. A high recurrence score, on the other hand, suggests that chemotherapy should be added.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is not related to breast carcinoma?
explanation: MACIS is not used in breast cancer. It is a prognostic index for thyroid cancer. The Nottingham prognostic index, Gail and Claus models, and Van Nuys prognostic index are all associated with breast cancer assessment. Van Nuys prognostic index is used to identify patients with duct carcinoma in situ (DCIS) who d not need radiation therapy. This grading system is based on the following parameters: Patient’s age DCIS nuclear grade and presence of microcalcification Size of the lesion Width of the surgical margin The Nottingham prognostic index segregates the patients into four groups and is used to predict the 5-year survival. It helps to formulate treatment plans. Nottingham Prognostic Index = (0.2 × Tumor size in cm) + grade + nodes The Gail and Claus models are used for assessing the risk of development of breast carcinoma. It includes the following parameters: Number of first-degree relatives with carcinoma breast Age at menarche Age at first live birth Number of breast biopsies Claus model provides individual estimates of breast cancer risk according to the decade of life, based on the presence of first- and second-degree relatives with breast cancer and their age at diagnosis. Note: Neither the Gail model nor the Claus model accounts for the risk associated with mutations in the breast cancer susceptibility genes BRCA1 and BRCA2.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor in a patient with breast carcinoma?
options: Involvement of skin over the breast
explanation: Axillary lymph node status is the most important determinant in the staging and prognosis of women with breast cancer. In axillary node-negative breast cancer, ER, PR receptor status becomes the most important prognostic factor.
subject: Surgery

question_text: The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include:
explanation: Staining for estrogen and progesterone receptors is not part of the Van Nuys system used for grading DCIS. The components of the Van Nuys prognostic index (VNPI) are as follows: Size of the tumor Extent of resection margin Histological variant of DCIS - based on nuclear grade, presence of necrosis, presence of microcalcification Age of the patient Patients with a high score in this grading system benefit from radiotherapy after excision, whereas those with low-grade and completely excised tumors, need no further treatment. A score ranging from 1 (lesions with the best prognosis) to 3 (lesions with the worst prognosis) is given for each of the four prognostic predictors. Total scores range from 4 (least likely to recur) to 12 (most likely to recur). Note: The type of microcalcification seen on imaging, helps in determining the nuclear grade of DCIS. While the linear branching type of microcalcification is associated with high nuclear grade, fine granular type is associated with low nuclear grade. question_text:
A 42-year-old woman presented with a history of painless breast lump measuring 6.2 X 4.5 cm in the left upper outer quadrant and no axillary nodes. Core cut biopsy showed ductal carcinoma in situ. She underwent tumor resection with adequate margins and postoperative
HPE showed DCIS with intermediate-grade necrosis and with 6-mm clearance on margins. What is the next step of treatment?
No additional treatment
explanation: According to Silverstein Van Nuys prognostic index for DCIS, the total score is 9. Hence, the patient would require adjuvant radiotherapy. Age: 42 years (score 2), size: 62mm (score 3), clearance margin: 6mm (score 2) with intermediate-grade necrotic features (score 2). Silverstein Van Nuys prognostic index for DCIS: Treatment: Scores 4-6 with >3mm margin: Excision alone Score 7 with < 3 mm margin, score 8 with > 3mm margin, score 9 with >5mm margin: Excision with RT Score 9 with < 5mm margin & score 10-12: Mastectomy If the patient is ER/PR+, adjuvant hormonal therapy with tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor is indicated. Current data does not support the use of HER-2-directed therapy in DCIS. Indications for adjuvant radiotherapy in breast cancer: Locally advanced breast cancers (T3, T4, N1, N2, N3) Following breast conservation surgery After mastectomy if tumor size  5 cm, skin or chest wall involvement, lymphovascular invasion and axillary node-positive for metastasis. Post-treatment surveillance after treatment for DCIS includes history, physical examination, and routine mammography (if applicable). question_text: What procedure is depicted in the image?
explanation: The image shows a sentinel lymph node biopsy using a gamma camera. The sentinel lymph node is the first draining lymph node. SLNB was first described in penile cancer by Cabana. Sentinel lymph node biopsy is only done on node-negative tumors. Methylene blue dye or radioisotope i.e., technetium-labeled albumin is injected into breast tissue (or subdermal tissue) at the site of the primary tumor or at the subareolar position. The sentinel node is identified as a blue node or as a radioactive node (using a gamma camera). The frozen section biopsy is sent to the pathologist for identification of cancer cells. If the biopsy is positive for cancer cells, then axillary dissection is simultaneously performed. Note: The combination of blue dye and technetium-labeled colloid has been reported to improve the detection of sentinel lymph nodes. Newer techniques involve the use of a fluorescent or magnetic tracer instead of the radiolabelled dye.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding sentinel lymph node biopsy in a patient with a T2 N1 M0 breast tumour?
options: If biopsy is positive, then axillary dissection is not don
If biopsy is negative, then axillary dissection is don
If biopsy is positive then tumour free margin should be > 2 cm
explanation: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is only done in node-negative tumors. It is not done in N1 stage tumors.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a lump in her right breast. On examination, a 3 cm palpable mass is felt in the right upper quadrant of the right breast. A mammogram is suggestive of a malignant lesion. Biopsy confirmed invasive ductal carcinoma with no nodal involvement. How will you manage this patient?
options: Breast conservation therapy with adjuvant radiotherapy
Modified radical mastectomy with adjuvant radiotherapy
explanation: This patient has stage T2 breast carcinoma. These patients are managed with breast conservation therapy with adjuvant radiotherapy. Indications of breast conservation surgery (BCS): DCIS/Tis tumors T1-2 tumors No contraindication for adjuvant radiotherapy Excision with clear margins is possibl Who does not want a mastectomy Locally advanced tumors with excellent response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Breast conservative surgery can be performed in which of the following patients with breast carcinoma?
explanation: Breast conservation surgery can be done in a post-partum woman. Breast cancer diagnosed during the second or third trimester can be managed with breast conservation surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. For breast cancer diagnosed late in the third trimester, breast conservation surgery can b performed, deferring breast irradiation until after delivery. Breast cancer diagnosed during the first trimester should be treated with mastectomy. Breast conservation surgery is contraindicated in the first trimester since post-operative radiotherapy cannot be deferred for a long time and chemotherapy is contraindicated in the first trimester.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient with early breast carcinoma of stage T3 N0 M0 does not want to undergo mastectomy. What is the next best treatment of choice in her case?
options: Breast conservation surgery followed by radiation therapy
Chemotherapy alone since mastectomy is the only option
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by breast conservation surgery
Mastectomy only since it is a large operable tumour
explanation: According to the clinical scenario, neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by breast conservation surgery (BCS) is the next best treatment. Stage T3 N0 M0 tumors are lesions of size >5 cm and are considered as large operable breast cancer (LOBC). The best management for such tumors is mastectomy. In case the patient is not willing for mastectomy, the next best treatment is neoadjuvant chemotherapy to shrink the tumor, followed by breast conservation surgery.
subject: Surgery

question_text: You are assisting in a modified radical mastectomy. Which of the following steps will not be done by the operating surgeon during this procedure?
explanation: Pectoralis major is not removed in modified radical mastectomy. Structures removed in modified radical mastectomy: Whole breast tissu The skin over the breast tissu Nipple-areola complex Pectoral fascia Levels I, II, ± III axillary lymph nodes The pectoralis minor muscle is either cut (Patey's, Scanlon's modification) or retracted (Auchincloss).
subject: Surgery

question_text: In patients with which of the following features of tumor involvement should you not perform radical mastectomy?
explanation: Distant metastasis is a contraindication for radical mastectomy. Excision of the breast, the pectoralis major and minor muscles, and all axillary lymph nodes constitute radical mastectomy. It is seldom performed given that it causes substantial morbidity due to shoulder joint restriction, pain, significant upper limb lymphedema, and chest wall deformity, with no survival advantage when compared to less radical surgery. In the case of distant metastases, less radical surgery is of no benefit either.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following structures will not be removed while performing radical mastectomy in patients with breast carcinoma?
explanation: Supraclavicular lymph nodes are not removed in radical mastectomy. In Halsted radical mastectomy, the following structures are removed: All breast tissue and skin Nipple-areolar complex Pectoralis major and pectoralis minor muscles Level I, II, and III axillary lymph nodes.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 50-year-old patient underwent a modified radical mastectomy for breast cancer. A drain was inserted at the site of the surgery. When can the drain be removed?
explanation: The drain after mastectomy is removed when the output is <30-40 cc for 2 consecutive days. The closed system suction drains are put in to prevent the formation of seroma. It is the most common complication of mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection.
subject: Surgery

question_text: The following image shows the boundaries of axillary lymph node dissection. The inferior boundary marked as ‘A’ denotes .
explanation: The space of axillary lymph node dissection is inferiorly bounded by the angular vein (marked as ‘A’). Boundaries of axillary lymph node dissection (ALND): Superior - Axillary vein Lateral - Thoracodorsal pedicl Medial - Costoclavicular ligament (Halstead ligament) Inferior - Angular vein Indications for ALND: Locally advanced (T4a, b, c) or inflammatory breast cancer Metastatic disease in axillary lymph node(s) proven by needle biopsy, clinically palpable or nonpalpable nodes which are abnormal on imaging Structures preserved during ALND: Lateral and medial pectoral nerves Thoracodorsal pedicl
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the most common complication of mastectomy?
explanation: The most common complication post-mastectomy is the development of a seroma. Seroma is a collection of fluid in a surgically created cavity, that results from the transection of vessels and lymphatics. It presents as a localized, well-circumscribed swelling with discomfort. The fluid is clear, yellow, and viscous. Placement of closed suction drains that obliterate the space between the pectoralis major and skin flap is used to prevent seromas. Other complications include: Wound infection Skin flap breakdown or necrosis Lymphedema Hemorrhag
subject: Surgery

question_text: After modified radical mastectomy, a patient complained of loss of sensation over the medial aspect of the right upper arm. The nerve most likely damaged is .
explanation: Resection of the intercostobrachial nerve (ICBN) causes loss of sensation over the medial aspect of the upper arm. The intercostobrachial nerve is the lateral cutaneous branch of the second intercostal nerve.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The generalized swelling of the left arm of the patient post-surgery for breast carcinoma is suggestive of post-mastectomy lymphedema. Lymphoedema occurs when interstitial fluid accumulates due to defective lymphatic drainage. It is a common complication of breast cancer treatment, involving axillary lymph node dissection and radiotherapy. Sentinel lymph node dissection (SLND) reduces the risk of lymphedema significantly. Clinical signs and symptoms are observed in the ipsilateral arm. A significant increase in limb size due to swelling is seen. Other symptoms are heaviness, tightness, numbness, tingling, limb fatigue, and reduced limb mobility. Diagnosis is predominantly based on the clinical swelling of the arm. The girth of the affected arm >2 centimetres than the normal limb, a 200-mL or more increase in limb volume, or a 5% or greater limb volume change are other diagnostic criteria. Management: Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices to reduce swelling. Using a low-pH water-based moisturizer to prevent dry skin caused by excess fluid accumulation. Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) by the patient daily aids interstitial fluid evacuation. Surgical options include lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking. Other options: Option B: Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma seen in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy (more than 10 years). They present as single/multiple bluish-red skin and subcutaneous nodules. They can ulcerate and hemorrhage. Option C: Axillary venous thrombosis or Paget-Schrotter disease is seen in patients doing rigorous exercise and in weightlifters. The compression of the subclavian vein at the thoracic outlet causes painful swelling of the arm. Option D: Cellulitis (lymphangitis) is a bacterial infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It is characterized by a painful area of erythematous and edematous tissue.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A patient presented with acute worsening of edema of the left hand, which was present for the past 5 years. Her surgical history was relevant for a radical mastectomy with radiation therapy for left-sided breast carcinoma. On examination, the limb appears as shown below.
What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: The clinical scenario and image are suggestive of Stewart–Treves syndrome. The development of angiosarcoma after a combination of postmastectomy lymphedema and radiation therapy is known as Stewart–Treves syndrome. It can arise de-novo or in association with post-mastectomy lymphedema. It presents with acute worsening of edema with subcutaneous nodules which are hemorrhagic or ulcerative. Treatment is preoperative chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgical excision (radical amputation of arm). The prognosis is poor. Option A: Tietze syndrome is an inflammatory condition characterized by chest pain and swelling of the cartilage around the ribs at the costochondral junction. Option C: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that affects the muscle tissue, mostly in children and adolescents. Option D: Milroy's disease is a familial disease, caused by congenital abnormalities in the lymphatic system. Disruption of the normal drainage of lymph leads to fluid accumulation and hypertrophy of soft tissues.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Identify the flap shown in the image used for breast reconstruction.
explanation: The image shows a deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap. It is a free flap and a variant of TRAM flap where only the skin and fat are moved to the chest. Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is either based on the superior or inferior epigastric artery or both (supercharged TRAM). In a TRAM flap, the skin, fat, and rectus muscle are moved to the chest. If robust DIEA perforators are identified with a good caliber and dissection can be performed without dividing the muscle, a DIEP flap is preferred. Otherwise, if small-caliber perforators are encountered and not aligned over the medial or lateral row, a TRAM flap is performed to ensure flap viability. Option C: Latissimus dorsi (LD) flap is an axial flap based on the thoracodorsal pedicle. DIEP flap, TRAM flap, and LD flap are autogenous tissues used in breast reconstruction.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the gold standard flap used in breast reconstruction with autogenous tissue?
explanation: The gold standard in breast reconstruction with autogenous tissue is the deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap. In DIEP flap, using a microvascular technique, only subcutaneous fat and skin are taken, and no muscle is removed. As the muscle is spared, there is a decreased risk of abdominal wall weakness and its associated complications. Lattismus dorsi flap (LD flap) - does not provide the bulk necessary and an implant is usually required. Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous flap (TRAM flap): Skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest. It is the most commonly used flap. It provides good cosmesis and bulk. An implant is usually not required. Since the rectus abdominis muscle is excised in the procedure, it can lead to abdominal wall weakness and hernias. The easiest type of reconstruction is using a silicone gel implant under the pectoralis major muscle. Capsular contraction is a dreaded complication of silicone implants. In breast reconstruction surgeries, the timing of reconstruction may be immediate or delayed. Impediments to immediate reconstruction include insufficient theatre time and a lack of experienced reconstructive surgeons. In addition, if the patient is likely to need post-op radiotherapy, then a delayed reconstruction using a flap often gives better results.

question_text: A 60 yr old woman underwent a simple mastectomy followed by radiation therapy for ER/PR positive breast cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug to be given to her to prevent the recurrence of breast cancer?
options: No drug is effective to prevent recurrenc
explanation: Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor and it is the drug of choice for the prevention of recurrence of ER/PR positive breast cancer in post-menopausal women (usually >50 years). It is given for 10 years. Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) and it is the drug of choice for preventing recurrence in pre-menopausal women. It has an agonistic action on the endometrium, leading to an increased risk of endometrial cancers. Hence, it is not used in post-menopausal women. Trastuzumab is a her2/neu receptor antagonist. It is given in patients with her2/neu status positive. It would not be effective in this patient.

question_text: Which of the following is not true about accelerated partial breast irradiation?

explanation: Accelerated partial breast irradiation (APBI) is a localized form of radiation delivered after lumpectomy to only the part of the breast where the tumor was removed. Patients of age <40 years are considered unsuitable, while those between 40 and 49 years of age are included in the cautionary group. question_text:
A postmenopausal woman presented with a 4 cm lump in her left breast. Clinical and radiological examination revealed ipsilateral fixed axillary lymph node involvement without distant metastasis. Histopathology confirms invasive breast carcinoma.
Immunohistochemistry is positive for ER, PR but negative for HER-2/Neu. What is the best method of management for this patient?
explanation: The best method of management in this patient is neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, radiation therapy, and letrozole. Step 1: Evaluate the TNM staging and stage grouping of the tumor Tumor size 4cm - T2 Ipsilateral fixed axillary lymph nodes are positive - N2a No distant metastasis - M0 T2N2M0 belongs to the stage group IIIA which is considered locally advanced breast cancer (LABC). question_text: A 41-year-old woman underwent treatment for breast cancer of 1.2 X 1 cm with positive axillary nodes. She completed radiotherapy and chemotherapy and is now receiving tamoxifen. How would you follow up this patient?
options: Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months
Follow-up with tumour markers once in 6 months
explanation: Follow-up of patients after treatment of breast cancer consists of a physical examination once in 3-6 months for the first 3 years and an annual mammogram. Mammography is the only imaging modality necessary for follow-up after breast cancer surgery. There is currently no role for tumor markers, serum investigations, or any other imaging studies like bone scans in routine follow-ups. Guidelines for follow-up after primary treatment: Physical examination: every 3-6 months for the first 3 years, every 6-12 months for years 4 and 5, and annually thereafter. Mammography: initially, 6 months after surgery, and thereafter, annually. Breast self-examination: Monthly Pelvic examination: Annually in patients taking tamoxifen

question_text: A pregnant woman at 11-weeks of gestational age presents with a painless lump in the upper quadrant of her left breast. Ultrasound and trucut biopsy revealed the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
options: Perform mastectomy and start chemotherapy immediately after delivery
Mastectomy followed by hormonal therapy in the second and third trimester
Mastectomy followed by chemotherapy in the second and third trimester
explanation: Mastectomy followed by chemotherapy in the second and third trimester is the best step of management in a pregnant woman diagnosed to have breast cancer in the first trimester. Pregnancy-associated breast cancer is defined as breast cancer that is diagnosed during pregnancy or within 1 year postpartum. It is the most common non-gynecologic malignancy associated with pregnancy. Most patients present with a painless mass in the breast with or without bloody nipple discharge. Diagnosis is done by ultrasonography and tissue biopsy. Treatment of breast cancer in pregnancy involves: Mastectomy in any trimester along with chemotherapy in the second and third trimesters. Radiotherapy and hormonal therapies are absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy becaus of teratogenicity. They can be initiated after delivery. Since radiotherapy is a component of breast conservation therapy, it is contraindicated in th first trimester of pregnancy. However, breast-conserving lumpectomy and axillary lymph nod dissection with chemotherapy can be done in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy followed by radiation after delivery.
