question_text: What is the most common site for a thyroglossal cyst?
options: At the level of the hyoid
explanation: The most common site for thyroglossal cyst is infrahyoid region. It can occur anywhere along the migratory course of the duct: Infrahyoid (most common site) Region of thyroid cartilage Suprahyoid Floor of mouth Beneath foramen caecum A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood. Normally, the thyroglossal duct regresses once the thyroid gland has completely descended. If it fails to regress, a thyroglossal duct cyst is formed. It can be differentiated from other midline neck swellings by the following features: Can be moved sideways but not vertically Moves with both deglutition and tongue protrusion Surgical management of a thyroglossal cyst is via Sistrunk procedure. Note: Presence of thyroid in the midline posterior 1/3rd of tongue is called lingual thyroid. It is due to failure of descent of the thyroglossal duct during development.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 25-year-old patient presented with neck swelling which moves with deglutition as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: A thyroglossal cyst is the only midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition. This is because the thyroid gland is fixed to the hyoid. Thyroglossal duct cyst: It is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood often noticed after an upper respiratory infection. It represents the persistence of the track of the thyroid gland and can be found adjacent to the midline. The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. At the time of descent, the hyoid bone has not been formed and the track of the thyroid gland is variable, passing in front, through, or behind the eventual position of the hyoid body. Clinical features of thyroglossal cyst: Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. Swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), nontender, mobile, often transilluminant. Thyroid fossa is empty, if there is no thyroid in the normal location. C mplications of thyroglossal cyst: The most common complication is infection. Thyroglossal fistula is an acquired condition that either follows infection of the cyst which bursts pen or due to inadequate removal of the cyst. 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type f cancer is papillary (85%). Neck swellings that move with deglutition are: Thyroid swellings Subhyoid bursitis Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone However, only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This is because the duct extends from the foramen caecum of the tongue to the isthmus of the gland. Sistrunk’s operation is performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves the excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum along with the core of tissue on either side.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A child with a midline swelling on the neck is being prepared for a Sistrunk procedure. Along with en bloc cystectomy, which of the following structures will be resected?
options: Thyroglossal tract and part of thyroid
Central hyoid bone and thyroglossal tract
Thyroglossal tract and associated cervical lymph nodes
explanation: Sistrunk operation involves en bloc cystectomy with excision of the entire thyroglossal tract till the base of the tongue along with the central hyoid bone. It is the procedure of choice for the surgical management of thyroglossal duct cysts. It is done to prevent recurrence and malignant transformation. The most common malignancy in thyroglossal cysts is papillary thyroid carcinoma. In such a case, Sistrunk operation with total thyroidectomy is considered.

question_text: A patient with a nodule of the neck presents to the surgery OPD. A junior resident performs the following method to palpate it. Identify the procedure shown in the video below.
explanation: The video depicts Lahey’s method of palpation of the left lobe of the thyroid gland. In Lahey's method, for palpating the left lobe, the examiner initially pushes the right lobe medially with the left hand, and then using the right hand, the border and consistency of the left lobe is palpated. Other options: Option B: In Crile's method the patient is asked to swallow, while the examiner palpates the gland with the thumb. This gives a clear indication regarding the slight enlargement of the thyroid gland or small nodules. Option C: Kocher's method is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor. Option D: Pemberton's sign (not method), is engorgement of neck veins when the patient is asked to raise their hands above the head and the arms should touch the ears. It is seen in patients with retrosternal goiter.

question_text: A patient with a solitary, 2x3 cm, nodular thyroid swelling came to your clinic with a recent report that showed elevated T4 and normal TSH levels. What is the next best step in management?
explanation: Ultrasonography is the next best step in the evaluation of a euthyroid (normal TSH) patient with a solitary thyroid nodule. USG is a non-invasive and inexpensive way to stratify the risk of the nodule into benign or malignant tissue. Benign nodules are easily compressible and can be seen to deform by applying pressure with the probe while performing USG. Malignant nodules tend to be hard and firm. Ultrasound findings of a nodule that are considered suspicious of malignancy include: Microcalcifications Hypervascularity Infiltrative margins Hypoechoic compared with surrounding parenchyma

question_text: A patient presents with a painless swelling of the neck. The histology of the tissue is as given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The slide shows the histopathology of Hashimoto thyroiditis, with: Follicular destruction Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration A well-developed germinal centre may be seen Hurthle (Askanazy) cells that have abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm lining the follicles Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is also known as struma lymphomatosa or lymphocytic thyroiditis. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure. Clinical features: Most prevalent between 45-65 years of age More common in females Painless enlargement of the thyroid Hashitoxicosis: When the auto-antibodies attack and damage the follicles, there is a sudden release of thyroid hormones from these follicles. This leads to a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis. Hypothyroidism: Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism. Diagnosis: T3 and T4 are low TSH is raised Autoantibodies against: Thyroid receptors Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) Thyroglobulin These patients are managed with thyroid hormone replacement therapy. In patients with long-standing goiter, there is a risk of compressive features and the development of thyroid lymphoma. Such cases can be treated with total thyroidectomy. It may also predispose to papillary thyroid carcinoma. Other options: Option A: Histological features of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid include polygonal to spindle-shaped cells in the form of nests, trabeculae or follicles. Small, round anaplastic cells may be found in some cases and amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present in the stroma. The given slide below shows medullary carcinoma of thyroid: Option C: Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder characterized by hyperthyroidism due to circulating autoantibodies. The thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins bind to the TSH receptors, causing overgrowth of the thyroid gland and increased thyroid hormone synthesis. Histologically, there is acinar cell hypertrophy and hyperplasia with the absence of normal colloid in the tall columnar epithelium (normally the epithelium is flat with colloid). Lymphoid infiltrates, consisting predominantly of T cells, along with scattered B cells and mature plasma cells, are present throughout the interstitium. Germinal centers are common. question_text: A middle-aged female patient presented with malaise, fever, and painful neck swelling. She had recently recovered from an episode of upper respiratory tract infection. Lab reports show slightly elevated T4 and ESR was 100 mm/hr. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of De Quervain's thyroiditis for which NSAIDs is the treatment of choice. In this condition, T3, T4 and thyroglobulin may be raised due to the release of preformed hormones from the destructed follicles. De Quervain’s thyroiditis (subacute or viral thyroiditis) is a granulomatous enlargement of the thyroid gland, usually following a viral infection. It is an inflammatory condition and not an infection as the thyroid gland is inherently resistant to infection due to its extensive blood and lymphatic supply, high iodide content, and fibrous capsule. It predominantly occurs in women between the ages of 30-40 years. The condition is self-limiting, and management is symptomatic i.e. aspirin and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are used for pain relief, but steroids may be indicated in more severe cases. Note: Acute suppurative thyroiditis mimics De Quervain’s thyroiditis in that it is often preceded by a pyogenic upper respiratory tract infection or otitis media. However, acute suppurative thyroiditis is more common in children.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 45-year-old lady, with a painless neck swelling, presented with palpitations and weight loss. Thyroid function tests revealed elevated T3 and T4, low TSH, and negative TSH-R Ab. Iodine scan showed multiple thyroid nodules with increased iodine uptake. Initial anti-thyroid treatment was given. What is the next step of management?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of toxic multinodular goitre. The next step of management once a euthyroid state is achieved is a near-total thyroidectomy. Toxic nodular goiters are often large, uncomfortable, and are prone to recurrence. In a developing country like India, a near-total thyroidectomy eliminates the risk of recurrence and simplifies follow-up. However, it causes immediate thyroid failure and necessitates lifelong thyroxine replacement. Option A: Toxic multinodular goitres may show a decreased response to antithyroid drugs or may even enlarge further. Therefore, surgical management is recommended. Option B: Sub-total thyroidectomy has chances of recurrence and hence cannot be a definitive therapy. Option C: Large goiters show decreased response to radioactive iodine and the chances of recurrence are also high.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What will be the most likely associated condition with increased TSH and low T4 levels?
explanation: Increased TSH and low T4 levels are seen in primary hypothyroidism. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the only cause of primary hypothyroidism in the given options. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure. It is the most common cause of primary hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. They also have autoantibodies against thyroid receptors, thyroid peroxidase and thyroglobulin. Other options: Option A: Hypoparathyroidism is generally not associated with hypothyroidism, except in certain congenital multisystem disorders such as DiGeorge's syndrome. Option C: Grave's disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. It is an autoimmune disorder caused due to autoantibodies against the TSH receptor. There will be elevated T3 and T4 levels with low TSH levels. Option B: A TSH-producing pituitary adenoma can have increased TSH levels, but there will be elevated T3, T4 levels as well.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 50-year-old hypothyroid female patient presents with a painless, hard anterior neck mass, which progresses over weeks to years associated with dysphagia. Physical examination reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to the surrounding tissues. Which of the following investigations will confirm the provisional diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Riedel’s thyroiditis, which is confirmed by an open thyroid biopsy. FNAC is inadequate due to the firm and fibrous nature of the gland. Riedel’s thyroiditis is invasive autoimmune fibrous thyroiditis where thyroid gland tissue is replaced by fibrous tissue. It is an IgG4-related systemic disease characterized by: Elevated serum IgG4 levels Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate Abundance of IgG4 bearing plasma cells It is associated with other focal sclerosing syndromes including mediastinal, retroperitoneal, periorbital, retro-orbital fibrosis, and sclerosing cholangitis. Clinical features: Occurs predominantly in women between 30-60 years Painless, hard anterior neck mass Progresses over weeks to years to produce symptoms of compression: Dysphagia Dyspnea Choking Hoarseness Symptoms of hypothyroidism and hypoparathyroidism as the gland is replaced by fibrous tissue Physical examination reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to surrounding tissues Treatment includes surgery, high-dose steroids, tamoxifen, and thyroxine replacement.
subject: Surgery

question_text: The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via:
explanation: The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck and the most common type of goitre approached is the secondary retrosternal goiter. A goiter is considered to be retrosternal if at least 50% of the thyroid tissue is located intrathoracically. They can be primary or secondary. Retrosternal goiter presents with dyspnoea, stridor, and dilated neck veins. Pemberton’s sign (venous congestion of the neck on the raising of hands above the head) is seen. C ntrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the neck is performed to assess the location f the thyroid. The definitive treatment is surgical excision of the ectopic thyroid. Other options: Option B & C: Median sternotomy (via chest) is indicated in: Primary mediastinal goiter Malignant retrosternal goiter Very large retrosternal goiter Recurrence in the mediastinum Primary retrosternal goiter Secondaryretrosternal goiter Occurrenc e 1% Majorityof retrosternal goiter s Origin Arise fromectopic thyroid tiss uein the chestNo connection with the thyroid tissue in the neck Arise from thedownward exte nsion of cervical thyroid tissu ealong the fascial planes of th e neck Blood sup ply Intrathoracicblood vessels Superior and inferior thyroid arteries

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about retrosternal goitre?
options: Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms
Sternal incision is always required to operate
It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery
Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision
explanation: Most of the retrosternal goiters can be removed by neck incision (transcervical approach). Retrosternal goitre is defined as having >50% of the goiter below the suprasternal notch. It can be either primary or secondary. Primary: rare and arises from ectopic thyroid tissue in the mediastinum; receives blood supply from intrathoracic blood vessels. It is not related to thyroid tissue in the neck. Secondary: they are the most common type; an extension of enlarged thyroid from the neck, usually arising from the lower pole of nodular goitre. It receives its blood supply from superior and inferior thyroid vessels. The majority of patients are asymptomatic or have minimal symptoms. If the gland enlarges within the thoracic inlet, the pressure may lead to dysphagia, tracheal compression, and eventually airway symptoms. Pemberton sign can be positive (facial flushing and dilatation of cervical veins upon raising the arms above the head). CECT neck and thorax is the investigation of choice. Over 95% of retrosternal goiters can be removed via a transcervical incision since they are an extension from thyroid tissue in the neck. Other options: Option A: Surgical removal of the retrosternal goiter is indicated in patients with significant airway compression, and in young patients who have symptoms such as dyspnoea or dysphagia. Option B: Median sternotomy approach is indicated in: Primary mediastinal goiter Malignant retrosternal goitre Very large retrosternal goiter Recurrence in the mediastinum For a primary mediastinal goiter whose boundaries are completely within the chest, resection is often achieved through median sternotomy or thoracotomy to ensure that the vessels supplying the tumor are properly ligated. Removing the tumor through a cervical approach can result in uncontrolled bleeding and is generally avoided. Option C: Blood supply to the retrosternal goiter is from the thyroid vessels (secondary retrosternal goiter).

question_text: A patient with toxic adenoma is being prepared for surgery. Which of the following statements is wrong regarding this?
options: Iodine may be given pre-operatively with carbimazole
Beta blockers administered pre-operatively must be continued post operatively
Nadolol is given in a once daily regimen pre-operatively
The last dose of carbimazole must be given 24 hours before surgery
explanation: The last dose of carbimazole may be given the evening before surgery. Toxic adenoma is a benign functioning thyroid tumour, which usually presents as a toxic solitary nodule. It is an autonomously functioning tumour that does not respond to TSH. Treatment involves antithyroid drugs or radioactive iodine. This is followed by hemithyroidectomy as the surrounding normal thyroid tissue regains normal function. Traditional preparation of a thyrotoxic patient aims to make the patient biochemically euthyroid. There are two methods of preparation that can be used: Carbimazole 30-40 mg per day is the drug of choice. When euthyroid (after 8-12 weeks), the dose may be reduced. Beta-blockers, if used preoperatively, must be given on the morning of surgery and continued for a week post-op. Propranolol 40 mg TDS or a longer-acting nadolol 160 mg once daily may be given to achieve beta-blockade. It is important to continue treatment up to 7 days postoperatively. Iodine may be given with carbimazole or a beta-blocker 10 days before the operation. It produces transient remission and reduces thyroid vascularity.

Rose position is preferred for thyroid surgery. The patient is supine with a towel roll below the shoulder to enable neck extension of 30°. question_text: At which of the following points is the recurrent laryngeal nerve at the highest risk for injury during thyroid surgery?
options: At the level of Berry's ligament as it enters the larynx
In the tracheoesophageal groove as it forms one side of the Beahrs triangle
Under the tubercle of Zuckerkandl on the posterolateral portion of the gland
As the nerve loops around the aorta
explanation: The point at which the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is at the highest risk for injury during thyroid surgery is at its entry point into the larynx. This point is at the cricothyroid joint, at the level of Berry's ligament. The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve. On the left, it recurs over the arch of aorta, and on the right over the subclavian artery. Beahrs' triangle or recurrent laryngeal nerve triangle is formed by: Common carotid artery Inferior thyroid arteries Recurrent laryngeal nerve Note: On the left side, the nerve has more distance in which to reach the transesophageal groove. Hence it runs in a medial plane. On the right, there is less distance and the nerve runs more obliquely to reach the groove.

question_text: A patient presented with a thyroid nodule. The USG showed an irregular hypoechoic mass with microcalcifications. Lymph nodes were not involved. FNAC showed a follicular neoplasm with predominantly Hurthle cells. Intra-op frozen section confirms capsular invasion. What is the most appropriate management?

It cannot be diagnosed solely by FNAC as these cancers are characterized by vascular & capsular invasion. question_text: A 45-year-old man came to the surgery OPD with a midline neck swelling. He does not have any other complaints. The patient had received chemoradiation for Hodgkin’s lymphoma nearly 20 years ago. On palpation, the mass is about 3 cm in size, non-tender, hard, fixed, and seems to arise from the right lobe of the thyroid. TSH levels were raised. A radioiodine uptake study showed cold nodule. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The history of radiation therapy to the head and neck for Hodkin's lymphoma and a cold nodule on radioiodine uptake scan are suggestive of papillary thyroid cancer. Radiation exposure is an identifiable aetiological factor in the development of differentiated thyroid cancer (follicular and papillary thyroid cancer). The most important factor, however, is irradiation of the thyroid before 5 years of age. Thyroid lymphomas are non-Hodgkin’s B-cell lymphomas. They present with B-symptoms like fever, night sweats, and weight loss in addition to neck swelling. Thus, thyroid lymphoma is an unlikely diagnosis. Thyroid lymphomas often develop in the setting of lymphocytic infiltration.

question_text: A 45-year-old patient presents with diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland. Laboratory studies reveal low T3, T4, high TSH and the presence of anti-TPO antibodies. FNAC from the gland shows enlarged cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Which of the following malignancies is commonly associated with this condition?
explanation: The clinical case scenario is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Thyroid lymphoma or malignant lymphoma is associated with long-standing Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. Thyroid lymphomas are usually non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas, often associated with long-standing Hashimoto’s thyroiditis (autoimmune lymphocytic thyroiditis). The clinical features include: B - symptoms i.e. fever, night sweats, and weight loss As FNAC cannot characterize lymphoma, Tru-Cut biopsy is preferred. Chemotherapy and radiation therapy are often sufficient. Total thyroidectomy is indicated only in residual/recurrent disease. A chemotherapy regimen (RCHOP) is the first line of management. question_text: A 72-year-old woman has a history of papillary thyroid carcinoma left untreated for 2 years. She complains that the rapid enlargement in her neck swelling over the last month has made it difficult for her to swallow and talk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: Local invasion of the surrounding structures
explanation: An elderly woman with rapidly enlarging neck mass and dysphagia in the setting of an untreated papillary carcinoma suggests a diagnosis of anaplastic thyroid cancer. Anaplastic thyroid cancer, a poorly differentiated thyroid carcinoma, is the most aggressive cancer and has the worst prognosis of all thyroid malignancies. It usually occurs in elderly females. The typical manifestation is an with rapidly enlarging neck mass, dysphagia, and cervical tenderness. Patients usually have a history of untreated differentiated thyroid carcinoma (DTC). Local invasion to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) causes hoarseness. It may also cause tracheal obstruction. Distant metastasis is more common in the lungs via the hematogenous route. Diagnosis is made by FNAC. However, trucut/open biopsy is frequently used to confirm the diagnosis in cases of doubt. Management: If metastasis is absent: Total thyroidectomy + LN dissection If metastasis is present: Palliative care with chemotherapy and radiotherapy If tracheal obstruction: Isthmectomy to relieve obstruction
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 34-year-old woman was brought in a dehydrated state and complains of loose stools. On examination, a tender neck swelling was found which was found to be present for 1 year. Histopathology of the swelling shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). Histopathology shows the presence of amyloid deposits that are derived from the altered calcitonin molecules. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumor of parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid gland. They are derived from the neural crest cells of the ultimobranchial bodies. Most of the MTCs occur sporadically. However, around a quarter of the cancers are associated with familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B. Patients with sporadic MTC present at an older age, whereas patients with familial MTC usually present at a younger age. Features of MTC include: Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy Dysphagia, dysphonia or dyspnea if locally invaded Diarrhoea due to increased intestinal motility by serotonin Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production Metastasis is blood-borne Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid stroma It is diagnosed by careful family history, physical examination, raised calcitonin, CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass. Total thyroidectomy with central neck node dissection is the treatment of choice in MTC patients. External beam radiotherapy can be used in patients with unresectable tumors. Targeted therapy can be considered using vandetanib, sorafenib, sunitinib, and cabozantinib. Prophylactic total thyroidectomy should be considered within 5years of age in MEN2A mutation and within 1year of age in MEN2B mutation.
subject: Surgery

explanation: Medullary thyroid tumors secrete calcitonin, serotonin, histaminadases, and CEA (carcinoembryonic antigen).

question_text:
A patient with medullary thyroid carcinoma is posted for surgery. He is nearly 6.5 ft tall, with a slender build and elongated digits. What is the screening test that should be done
pre-operatively?
explanation: This patient with medullary thyroid carcinoma and features of marfanoid habitus (very tall patient with long, slender fingers and toes) is suggestive of MEN 2B syndrome. Such patients are to be screened for pheochromocytoma by measuring urinary catecholamines. Pheochromocytoma, if present, should be treated first, and then MTC is to be treated next. A thyroid swelling with elevated calcitonin indicates a medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MTC can either be sporadic (80%) or familial (RET gene mutation). In case of familial medullary thyroid carcinoma, stimulation with pentagastrin increases the release of calcitonin. This can be used for the screening of medullary thyroid carcinoma. MTC can be inherited as a part of autosomal dominant (AD) syndromes such as: Familial MTC MEN 2A MEN 2B Prophylactic total thyroidectomy should be considered within 5years of age in MEN2A mutation and within 1year of age in MEN2B mutation. Note: Serum calcium is measured to screen for parathyroid adenoma in MEN 2A.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient is diagnosed with medullary thyroid carcinoma. Which of the following could be used to screen the rest of her family?
explanation: Screening of patients with familial MTC was historically done using pentagastrin stimulation test for calcitonin levels to make the diagnosis. Pentagastrin is a synthetic gastrin analogue. It acts on the CCK-B/gastrin receptor of the C cells and increases the basal rate of calcitonin secretion. Basal calcitonin level = total C cell mass x rate of secretion. Medullary thyroid tumors secrete calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), but also other peptides such as calcitonin gene-related peptide, histaminadases, prostaglandins E2 and F2, and serotonin. Another test that can be used for screening is calcium-stimulated calcitonin levels.

question_text: Prophylactic thyroidectomy is indicated in patients with which of the following features:
options: Marfanoid habitus, multiple neuromas on the lip and familial pheochromocytoma,

explanation: Prophylactic thyroidectomy is indicated in MEN 2B syndrome as they can develop medullary thyroid carcinoma. Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) can be inherited as familial MTC, MEN 2A or MEN 2B syndromes. These conditions are autosomal dominant and occur due to RET proto-oncogene mutation. question_text: Which of the following statements is false about the 8th edition AJCC staging of thyroid neoplasms?
options: In DTC, distant metastasis is IVB
In staging, age barrier is 55 years
N1a includes level VI and VII
explanation: Minor extrathyroidal extension detected only on histological examination is removed from the definition of T3 disease and therefore has no impact on either T category or overall stage. Differentiated Thyroid Cancer: The age cutoff used for staging is increased from 45 to 55 years of age at diagnosis. N1 disease no longer upstages a patient to stage III. If < 55 years of age at diagnosis, N1 disease is stage I. If  55 years of age, N1 disease is stage II. T3a is a new category for tumors > 4 cm confined to the thyroid gland T3b is a new category for tumors of any size demonstrating gross extrathyroidal extension into strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles) Level VII lymph nodes, previously classified as lateral neck lymph nodes (N1b) is re-classified as central neck lymph nodes (N1a) to be more anatomically consistent and because level VII presented significant coding difficulties for tumor registrars, clinicians and researchers. In differentiated thyroid cancer, the presence of distant metastases (M1) in older patients is classified as IVB disease rather than IVC disease. Distant metastasis in anaplastic thyroid cance continues to be classified as IVC disease. Minimal or occult/microcarcinoma are tumors 1 cm or less in size. They have no evidence of local invasiveness through the thyroid capsule or angioinvasion. Occult malignancies are usually not associated with lymph node metastases. However, about 25% of patients with these tumors have associated occult lymph node metastases. These are nonpalpable and are found incidentally at operative and histologic examinations or at autopsy. Anaplastic : Unlike previous editions where all anaplastic thyroid cancers were classified as T4 disease, anaplastic cancers now use the same T definitions as differentiated thyroid cancer. question_text: Which of the following will not be a treatment option for a pregnant patient with papillary thyroid carcinoma?
options: Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection
explanation: Radioiodine ablation of thyroid is contraindicated in pregnant women due to risk of radiation exposure to the fetus. Therapeutic uses for radioactive iodine In primary thyrotoxicosis after 45 years. In autonomous toxic nodule after 45 years, it is useful as remaining gland still will function adequately after radiotherapy. In follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy, if there are secondaries elsewhere in the body, as in bones or lungs, then I131 is given.

question_text: A patient with papillary thyroid carcinoma underwent total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection, a month ago. At present, a whole-body iodine scan is positive. What is the next step in management?
explanation: Radio-iodine ablation is undertaken when a whole-body iodine scan is positive after a total thyroidectomy for any differentiated thyroid cancer (papillary or follicular carcinoma). The presence of any metastatic or residual thyroid tissue after total thyroidectomy can be detected by observing the uptake of radio-iodine in the entire body. To achieve effective uptake of radio-iodine, TSH levels need to be greatly increased, for example, by withdrawing thyroxine after the surgery for 4-6 weeks. A positive whole-body iodine scan after total thyroidectomy indicates that there is either a metastatic or residual disease present. These patients are treated with I131 for radio-iodine ablation. A negative scan means there is no metastasis or residual thyroid tissue. They are followed up regularly with serum thyroglobulin, TSH and USG-neck. If the tumour is resistant to radioiodine ablation, EBRT (external beam radiotherapy) is done.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A whole-body iodine scan is not useful in patients with which thyroid malignancy?
explanation: After a total thyroidectomy, a whole-body iodine scan is not useful for detecting residual thyroid tissue or metastasis in medullary thyroid carcinoma. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumour of parafollicular or C cells. These cells which are derived from neural crest cells, do not take up iodine. A whole-body iodine scan is useful in thyroid tumours derived from follicular cells that take up iodine.

question_text:
Which of the following scales consider the completeness of surgical resection to determine the prognosis of a patient with thyroid cancer?
AMES
explanation: MACIS scale includes completeness of the original surgical resection to determine the prognosis of the thyroid cancer. Prognostic indicators of well differentiated thyroid cancers: AGES system - Age, histologic Grade, Extrathyroidal invasion, and metastases and tumor Size. AMES system - Age (men <40 years old, women <50 years old), Metastases, Extrathyroidal spread, and Size of tumors (< or >5 cm). DAMES - DNA aneuploidy + AMES GAMES - Grade + AMES TNM staging - Tumor, Nodal status, Metastases. MACIS scale (postop modification) - distant Metastases, Age at presentation (<40 or >40 years old), Completeness of original surgical resection, extrathyroidal Invasion, and Size of original lesion (in centimeters). question_text: While performing a subtotal thyroidectomy, accidental ligation of which artery can potentially lead to hypoparathyroidism?
explanation: Truncal ligation of the inferior thyroid artery can potentially result in hypoparathyroidism. Both superior and inferior parathyroid glands receive their blood from the inferior thyroid artery which arises from the subclavian arteries.Hence during thyroidectomy, only capsular branches closer to the thyroid gland should be ligated. The inferior parathyroid glands may have a variable blood supply, from either the ascending branch of the inferior thyroid arteries or the thyroid ima artery.

question_text: Identify the correct pair based on their embryological development.
options: Thymus, Inferior parathyroid gland - Third pharyngeal pouch
Thymus, Superior parathyroid gland - Fourth pharyngeal pouch
Superior and Inferior parathyroid gland - Third pharyngeal arch
Thymus, Superior parathyroid gland - Fourth pharyngeal arch
explanation: The thymus and inferior parathyroid glands originate from the third pharyngeal pouch. They migrate from the upper neck to the mediastinum during embryonic development. Inferior parathyroid glands have more variation in their anatomical position due to a long descent. The superior parathyroid glands originate from the fourth pharyngeal pouch. They are more constant in their position.

question_text: Which of the following is the most common site of ectopic parathyroid gland?
explanation: The most common site of the ectopic parathyroid gland is paraesophageal. The common sites of ectopic parathyroid glands are Paraesophageal - most common Mediastinal Intrathymic Intrathyroidal Carotid sheath High cervical or undescended Ectopic parathyroid is the most common cause of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism. In such cases, treatment involves surgical removal of the gland.

question_text: What is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients?
explanation: Cancer is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients, whereas hyperparathyroidism is the most common cause of hypercalcemia detected incidentally in outpatients. The causes of hypercalcemia in cancer : Cancers affecting bone like multiple myeloma, leukemia, bony metastasis - cause the bone t break down which releases excess calcium into the blood Pseudohyperparathyroidism - tumours producing parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) cause the bone to release calcium into the blood. The most common carcinoma associated is squamous cell carcinoma of lung. Cancers affecting kidneys - failure to remove excess calcium from the blood Dehydration caused by nausea and vomiting - difficult for the kidneys to remove calcium from the blood properly Lack of physical activity - causes bone breakdown, releasing calcium into the blood

question_text: What is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism?
explanation: A single adenoma is the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. They are most often located in the inferior parathyroid glands. Primary hyperparathyroidism is due to excess or non-suppressed PTH secretion from the following: Single parathyroid adenoma Multiple adenomas Hyperplasia Carcinoma Sporadic primary hyperparathyroidism (HPT) is more common than familial (MEN syndrome/ familial HPT/ Familial HPT with jaw tumor syndrome). Women are affected more commonly than men.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Lab investigations in a patient with fatigue and colicky abdominal pains show elevated PTH and calcium, and low serum phosphate. Which of the following ophthalmic findings is pathognomonic of this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Band keratopathy is pathognomonic of this condition. It is due to the deposition of calcium phosphate crystals in the cornea. In patients with elevated PTH, calcium and phosphate levels are measured. Elevated calcium and decreased phosphate levels are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Normal calcium and elevated phosphate levels are suggestive of secondary hyperparathyroidism. The image given below shows band keratopathy. Option A: Kayser Fleischer rings are brownish-yellow rings in the corneoscleral junction due to the deposition of copper in the cornea. Option C: Ocular chrysiasis is the deposition of gold in the cornea, after repeated parenteral administration of gold salts. Option D: Hudson Stahli line is a superficial brown line at the junction of the upper 2/3 and lower 1/3 of the cornea in an otherwise normal cornea. It is attributed to the deposition of iron.

question_text: During a clinical trial, it was found that some individuals who showed radioactive uptake on Sestamibi scan, showed no other evidence of hyperparathyroidism. They were instead found to be suffering from a Hurthle cell nodule of the thyroid gland. Which of the following radioactive tracer tests could be used to rule out the false positives?
explanation: A thyroid-specific tracer like 99Tc-Pertechnetate and subsequent subtraction images could be used to rule out the false positives caused by the solid thyroid nodules such as Hurthle cell nodule. The Sestamibi scanning is a nuclear-based imaging test used to localize the parathyroid glands. Sestamibi is a monovalent lipophilic cation that accumulates in mitochondria. Due to this, there is a difference in the rate at which it gets washed out depending upon the number of mitochondria in each tissue. Parathyroid adenomas often have a high concentration of oxyphilic cells with high mitochondrial content and they retain tracers and have a slower washout compared to the normal glands. In patients with nodular goiter or functional tumors of the thyroid gland, increased uptake of sestamibi by the thyroid gland makes parathyroid visualization difficult. There are two primary techniques to differentiate sestamibi uptake by abnormal parathyroid and thyroid tissue: Dual-isotope subtraction imaging (with sestamibi and either iodine-123 or 99mTc pertechnetate) - 99mTc pertechnetate is taken up only by the thyroid. The 99mTc pertechnetate scintigram is then digitally subtracted from the sestamibi scan to allow parathyroid localization. Single-isotope dual-phase imaging (with sestamibi alone with early and delayed imaging) - since the rate of washout from the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland is slower when compared to the thyroid gland. The image given below shows the dual-isotope subtraction imaging.

question_text: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy and abdominal pain. He had an X-ray taken a few days ago, which is given below. Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at a diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with the X-ray showing nephrocalcinosis is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Angiography of renal arteries is not a useful investigation for hyperparathyroidism. Nephrocalcinosis occurs in this condition due to hypercalcemia. It decreases renal concentrating ability, which may cause polyuria and polydipsia. Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism: Bones: Pathological fractures Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in radial aspect Salt and pepper skull Osteitis fibrosa cystica or VonReckling Hausen’s disease of bone Stones Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common Nephrocalcinosis Abdominal groans - colicky due to pancreatitis Psychiatric overtones - raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms Band keratopathy Features of hypercalcemia - Vomiting Confusion ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval The image given below shows salt and pepper skull seen in hyperparathyroidism. Investigations done in primary hyperparathyroidism: Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for the localization of abnormal parathyroid glands. Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is also a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue. Dual-energy radiographic absorptiometry is a useful tool to demonstrate skeletal involvement in primary hyperparathyroidism. The image given below shows a radiolabeled Sestamibi scan.

question_text: In a patient with asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism, when will you perform parathyroidectomy?
options: If bone mineral density of > 2.5 SD above peak bone mass
In the presence of hypercalciuria but absence of nephrolithiasis
If creatinine clearance is reduced by 30%
explanation: Reduction in creatinine clearance by 30% is an indication for parathyroidectomy in patients with asymptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism.

question_text: A 55-year-old lady with a history of multiple pathological fractures and renal stones was diagnosed with parathyroid hyperplasia involving all four glands. Which of the following treatment modalities will you use to treat her?
options: Complete removal of all four glands alone
Complete removal of three glands with a partial resection of the least affected gland
Partial resection of the affected glands with autotransplantation of the least affected gland
explanation: Hyperplasia involving all four parathyroid glands is treated by complete removal of three glands with partial resection of the least affected gland (Subtotal parathyroidectomy). Total cervical parathyroidectomy with heterotropic transplantation can also be done in this patient. Modes of treatment for parathyroid hyperplasia: Subtotal parathyroidectomy - The affected glands are completely removed and the least affected gland is partially resected. The remnants left behind should ideally be 30 mg. A lower gland is preferred because its location reduces the risk of injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Total parathyroidectomy with heterotopic transplantation - All 4 parathyroid glands are removed and parathyroid tissue is immediately transplanted to the non-dominant forearm. Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted. Complications of parathyroidectomy include: Persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism Hypoparathyroidism Hungry bone syndrome Injury to recurrent laryngeal nerve
subject: Surgery

question_text: Autotransplantation was done after total parathyroidectomy in a patient with hyperplasia of all 4 parathyroid glands. Which of the following best describes this procedure?
explanation: Parathyroid is transplanted heterotopically i.e. organ is implanted in another anatomic location. In total parathyroidectomy, all 4 parathyroid glands are removed and parathyroid tissue is immediately transplanted to the brachioradialis muscle in the non-dominant forearm.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Parathyroid gland post surgery is commonly transferred to:
explanation: The parathyroid is commonly transferred to the brachioradialis muscle post-surgery. This will facilitate easy removal if there is disease recurrence after surgery. Parathyroidectomy is indicated in: Symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism (HPT): Asymptomatic primary HPT with: raise in serum calcium >1mg/dl of the normal range >400 mg urinary calcium in 24-hour urine test < -2.5 Z-score of bone mineral density Age <50yr and failed medical treatment Severe cases of secondary HPT Parathyroidectomy is performed in neck hyperextension (semi-Fowler position). The thyroid gland is mobilized, and the parathyroid gland with adenoma is identified and resected. The parathyroid tissue is transplanted to the non-dominant forearm. Pockets are made in the belly of the brachioradialis muscle, and one to two pieces of parathyroid tissue measuring 1 mm each are placed into each pocket. A total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted. This is a type of heterotopic transplant. Miami criteria (confirm the absence of another hyperactive parathyroid): A drop of parathyroid hormone intraoperatively, to more than half the maximum value at 10 minutes postresection is considered an adequate resection in a parathyroid adenoma. However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration. Complications of parathyroidectomy include: Persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism Hypoparathyroidism (presenting as hypocalcemia) Hungry bone syndrome Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve

question_text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of numbness around the lips and a tingling sensation in her fingers. She underwent parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism one year ago. An ECG was done and is given below. What will be your immediate management?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and ECG showing a prolonged QT interval (QT interval more than 0.43 seconds) is suggestive of hungry bone syndrome i.e. hypocalcemia post parathyroidectomy. Acute symptomatic presentation of hypocalcemia is treated with IV calcium gluconate. Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia: Mild circumoral or digital numbness Paresthesia Laryngeal spasms Cardiac arrhythmias Chvostek sign: This is elicited by gently tapping over the facial nerve in front of the tragus of the ear. There is hyperexcitability of the facial muscles, manifesting as a contraction of the muscles. Trousseau's sign: This is elicited by making the forearm ischemic by applying a sphygmomanometer cuff to the arm and keeping the pressure above systolic blood pressure (SBP) for 5 minutes. The hand goes into a painful carpopedal spasm and assumes the accoucheur’s hand position. (shown in the image below) Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with: 10 ml of 10% calcium gluconate is given slowly through intravenous route Calcium and vitamin D replacement is given orally Magnesium supplementation may also be required due to the synergistic actions of calcium and magnesium The continuous need for calcium or vitamin D, 1-year postoperatively is called permanent hypoparathyroidism.

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about secondary hyperparathyroidism?
options: Lithium intake may cause secondary hyperparathyroidism
Calciphylaxis is seen in early stages
explanation: Calciphylaxis (calcific uremic arteriolopathy) is a disseminated calcification seen late in the course of secondary hyperparathyroidism. In calciphylaxis, the underlying calcification in the vascular and arteriolar walls  ischemic necrosis  ulceration and gangrene  sepsis  death. It presents as an expanding cutaneous lesion which is predominantly seen in the extremities and lower abdomen. Prognosis is poor and an urgent parathyroidectomy is shown to increase median survival. Causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism: Chronic renal failure (most common) Vitamin D3 deficiency GI malabsorption Lithium intake To minimize the risk of missing parathyroid glands, transcervical thymectomy should be considered as a routine part of total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation and subtotal parathyroidectomy. In addition, careful cervical exploration for secondary hyperparathyroidism should be carried out. The image below shows calciphylaxis.

question_text: A 45-year-old patient with chronic renal failure presents to the OPD with complaints of recent onset pain in her feet. Blood investigation showed elevated PTH levels and normal serum calcium values. All of the following mechanisms contribute to elevated PTH in this patient except
options: Stimulation of parathyroid cells by hyperphosphatemia
Increased secretion of FGF-23 by osteocytes
Reduced expression of Vitamin D receptors and CaSR (calcium-sensing receptor) in bones
Interference with parathyroid kinase C signal transduction pathway and Wnt pathway
explanation: The clinical scenario described here showing elevated PTH and normal calcium levels is that of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to renal failure. Interference with parathyroid kinase C signal transduction pathway and Wnt pathway is the proposed mechanism of secondary hyperparathyroidism in the setting of lithium consumption and not renal hyperparathyroidism. Causes for increased PTH in secondary hyperparathyroidism due to renal failure: Abnormal renal tubular reabsorption  hyperphosphatemia  stimulation of parathyroid cells  elevated PTH Increased FGF-23 secretion from osteocytes  decreased 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D  decreased intestinal absorption of calcium  elevated PTH Normally, ECF calcium controls PTH secretion by interacting with CaSR. Stimulation of CaSR by high calcium suppresses PTH secretion. In chronic renal disease, there is reduced expression of Vitamin D and CaSR by bones  increased skeletal resistance to PTH  elevated PTH.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 32-year-old female patient is undergoing focussed parathyroidectomy for parathyroid adenoma. According to the Miami criteria, for the resection to be considered adequate, the intraoperative drop in parathyroid hormone should be .
options: More than one third the maximum preoperative value in 10min
More than one third the maximum preoperative value in half an 30 min
More than half the maximum preoperative value in 10min
More than half the maximum preoperative value in 30 min
explanation: Drop of parathyroid hormone to more than half the maximum value at 10 min postresection is considered an adequate resection in a parathyroid adenoma by the Miami criteria. Most of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have single adenoma, and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay for Miami criteria. It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to >50% of the preoperative PTH level within 10 minutes. However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

question_text:
A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of fatigue, vomiting, abdominal cramps and bone pain. She had undergone total parathyroidectomy and heterotopic autotransplantation for the same complaints 8 months ago. Sestamibi scan was done and found to be normal.
What is the next step in management?
options: Post her for bilateral neck exploration
Label her as persistent hyperparathyroidism and start her on medical management
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent hyperparathyroidism which could be due to recurrence in the neck or graft (graft hyperplasia). The next step would be to perform Casnova test to differentiate between them, as Sestamibi scan has ruled out ectopic parathyroid. Casanova test involves selective venous sampling for PTH levels from neck veins and brachial veins. If PTH from the brachial venous sample is >20 times that of neck vein sample, graft hyperplasia is confirmed. Persistent parathyroidism is defined as hypercalcemia that fails to resolve after parathyroidectomy i.e. within 6 weeks of surgery. Recurrent parathyroidism is hyperparathyroidism that occurs after an intervening period of at least 6 months of biochemically documented normocalcemia. Causes of persistent/recurrent hyperparathyroidism include: Ectopic parathyroid Unrecognized hyperplasia - graft site hyperplasia Missed adenoma in normal position Incomplete resection Familial hyperparathyroidism MEN-1 syndrome The image below summarises the management protocol for a case of persistent/recurrent hyperparathyroidism. *FHH stands for Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

question_text: All of the following are indications for surgical intervention of tertiary hyperparathyroidism except
options: Nodular hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland
explanation: Reduced serum phosphate is not an indication for surgical intervention in tertiary hyperparathyroidism. Renal transplantation in patients with chronic kidney diseases may be associated with autonomous functioning of the parathyroid gland. This is called tertiary hyperparathyroidism where there is hypercalcemic hyperparathyroidism. The indications for surgical intervention in tertiary hyperparathyroidism are as follows : Subacute severe hypercalcaemia (>3 mmol/L) Impaired graft function Nodular hyperplasia of the parathyroid gland(s) Progressive symptoms for >2 years following transplantation Worsening bone disease - pain, fractures, bone loss Renal stones/nephrocalcinosis Soft tissue or vascular calcifications
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 75-year-old lady with type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis presents with hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and elevated PTH. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?
explanation: The patient’s long-standing renal failure and elevated calcium, phosphate, and PTH are suggestive of tertiary hyperparathyroidism. This form of hyperparathyroidism can be life-threatening, and all patients with it should be referred for surgical intervention. The surgical procedure of choice for tertiary hyperparathyroidism is subtotal parathyroidectomy. In subtotal parathyroidectomy, the affected glands are completely removed and the least affected gland is partially resected. Option A: Total parathyroidectomy without an autograft is not a treatment option due to the postoperative and persistent difficulties in managing the associated hypocalcemia. Option C: Minimally invasive approaches commonly refer to the removal of a localized abnormal parathyroid gland through an incision less than 3cm in length. It is based on the principle that over 80% of individuals with primary hyperparathyroidism have a single adenoma. It is contraindicated in multi-glandular disease, lithium-induced hyperparathyroidism, and hyperparathyroidism associated with familial syndromes. Option D: Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic used in the treatment of secondary hyperparathyroidism. The use of calcimimetics in tertiary hyperparathyroidism remains controversial and has not been approved for this indication.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 41-year-old man with a history of treatment for Hodgkin's lymphoma in childhood presents with severe abdominal cramps and right flank pain. He has a firm 2x2cm mass in the front of his neck. He has a Calcium of 15.2 mg/dl, normal TSH, markedly elevated PTH, and PGP9.5+ on immunohistochemistry. What is the leading cause of mortality in his condition?
explanation: The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. With early-onset, neck mass, and positive IHC for PGP9.5+, it is concerning for parathyroid cancer. Hypercalcemia is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with parathyroid cancer. Parathyroid cancer is a rare malignancy and makes up 1% of cases of primary hyperparathyroidism. History of prior neck radiation is considered to be a risk factor. Patients usually present a decade earlier than primary hyperparathyroidism (5th - 6th decade), with an equal preponderance in males and females. Patients may present with a neck mass and severely elevated calcium and PTH levels. Treatment is focused on controlling hypercalcemia and surgery is the mainstay. Option B: Cardiovascular disease is a major contributing cause of mortality in patients with hyperthyroidism and chronic kidney disease.
subject: Surgery

question_text: In patients with parathyroid carcinoma, which of the following treatment modalities would you not consider?
options: En-bloc excision of the tumor and ipsilateral thyroid lobe with MRND
explanation: Etelcalcetide has no role in the treatment of parathyroid carcinoma. It is ineffective. Etelcalcetide is a calcium-sensing receptor agonist used to treat secondary hyperparathyroidism in adult patients with chronic kidney disease undergoing dialysis. Treatment modalities for parathyroid carcinoma: Surgical - Bilateral neck exploration + En-bloc excision of the tumor and ipsilateral thyroid lobe with/without MRND (Modified radical neck dissection) in presence of lymph node metastasis. Pharmacological: Cinacalcet hydrochloride, a calcimimetic, can reduce PTH levels by directly binding to the CaSR (calcium-sensing receptor) cells on the parathyroid gland; used to control hypercalcemia in refractory parathyroid carcinoma. Azidothymidine (telomerase inhibitor) Octreotide Anti-parathyroid hormone immunotherapy Radiation therapy - for unresectable disease or for palliation of bone metastases Risk factors for parathyroid carcinoma incude: Radiation exposure Hyperparathyroidism jaw bone syndrome HPRT gene or parafibromin inactivation

question_text:
A 34-year-old man presents with severe hypercalcemia. His father had similar complaints and was found to have hyperparathyroid-jaw tumour syndrome. Which of the following is pathognomonic of his condition?
Cystic mandibular lesions
explanation: Ossifying jaw fibromas are a pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroid-jaw tumour syndrome. It arises due to inactivating mutations in the HRPT2 gene on chromosome 1 q21-32, encoding parafibromin. It is a rare cause of primary hyperparathyroidism with an early onset (32 years) which presents with severe hypercalcemia. It is associated with an increased risk of parathyroid carcinoma and other conditions like polycystic kidney disease. Surgical intervention may be considered to remove all enlarged glands. Osteitis fibrosa cystica is a feature of hyperparathyroidism but is not considered pathognomonic of any condition. The Adrenals

question_text: Which of the following conditions is correctly matched with its layer of origin?
explanation: The area marked ‘2’ depicts the zona fasciculata, which secretes glucocorticoids. In ACTH-independent Cushing’s syndrome, excess cortisol is produced from this layer. Parts of the adrenal glands: The adrenal cortex is arranged in a zonal configuration in three zones - Outer zona glomerulosa- secretes mineralocorticoids (aldosterone) Middle zona fasciculata- secretes glucocorticoids (cortisol, corticosterone) Inner zona reticularis- secretes androgens (dehydroepiandrosterone) The adrenal medulla- stores and secretes catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine) On histological examination, the different layers are identified as: Outer zona glomerulosa - small, compact cells Central zona fasciculata - larger lipid-rich cells arranged in radial columns Inner zona reticularis - pigmented, compact cells Adrenal medulla - thin layer of large chromaffin cells Option A: Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine producing tumour derived from chromaffin cells and arises from the adrenal medulla. Option C: In Conn’s syndrome, excess aldosterone is secreted from zona glomerulosa. Option D: Neuroblastoma arises from the adrenal medulla.

question_text: An adrenal incidentaloma was detected in a patient who underwent evaluation for renal calculi. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?
options: The majority of these adrenal masses are functional tumours
The likelihood of the adrenal mass being an adrenocortical carcinoma is independent of the size of the mass
The only indication for biopsy of this adrenal mass is to confirm adrenal gland metastasis
explanation: The only indication for an adrenal gland biopsy is to confirm adrenal gland metastasis. An adrenal incidentaloma is defined as a clinically unapparent adrenal lesion that is incidentally detected on imaging performed for indications other than evaluation for adrenal disease. The majority of these lesions are non-functional tumours i.e. benign. The likelihood of an adrenal mass being an adrenocortical carcinoma increases with the size of the mass (25% chance if size >4 cm). Incidentalomas are evaluated to classify them as functional and non-functional. Non-functional incidentalomas <4cm are managed conservatively with MRI surveillance every 3-6 months. If >4cm, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is done. Note: An adrenal mass should never be biopsied until a pheochromocytoma has been biochemically excluded.

question_text: A patient being evaluated for primary aldosteronism underwent selective adrenal venous sampling. A comparison of the samples obtained from both the adrenal veins showed a significant difference in the aldosterone-cortisol ratio. What is the preferred line of treatment for this patient?
options: Medical treatment with spironolactone and supplemental antihypertensives
explanation: During selective adrenal vein sampling, a significant difference in the aldosterone-cortisol ratio on one side indicates unilateral hyperaldosteronism. In this case, unilateral laparoscopic adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice. Primary hyperaldosteronism (PHA) is characterized by hypersecretion of aldosterone with suppressed plasma renin levels (due to the negative feedback). The most frequent cause of PHA is unilateral adenoma. CT or MRI is used to detect the tumour. In a patient with bilateral micronodular hyperplasia, there could be a unilateral non-functioning tumour. Selective adrenal vein sampling can be done to differentiate between unilateral and bilateral disease. Conservative management with 3-6 months of MRI surveillance is done in non-functional adrenal tumours of < 4cm. Medical management is done in patients with bilateral disease, the commonly implemented therapeutic approach is treatment with spironolactone and antihypertensive medication. Surgical management is done in unilateral and asymmetrical bilateral disease by unilateral laparoscopic adrenalectomy. A subtotal resection can be considered in the case of a typical single Conn’s adenoma. However, it is not superior to unilateral adrenalectomy.

question_text: ‰ou are asked to perform sequential adrenal vein sampling in a patient with bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. Which of the following is the correct sequence of veins that you will go through to test the left adrenal gland?
options: Femoral veinIVCright renal veinright adrenal vein
Femoral veinIVCleft renal veinleft adrenal vein
Femoral veinIVCleft gonadal veinleft adrenal vein
explanation: The correct sequence encountered during sequential venous sampling is femoral veinIVCleft renal veinleft adrenal vein. On the right side, the order is femoral veinIVCright adrenal vein.

question_text: A patient was found to have an elevated 24-hour urinary cortisol level and elevated ACTH. On administration of high-dose dexamethasone, ACTH levels were suppressed. MRI of the pituitary gland shows no enlargement. What is the next best step?
options: CT scan of the chest and abdomen
CT scan/ MRI to assess the adrenals
Venous sampling from the inferior petrosal sinus
explanation: The given scenario of elevated ACTH levels that respond to high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is indicative of a pituitary source of hypercortisolism. Since the MRI pituitary is inconclusive, the next best step is to perform a venous sampling from the inferior petrosal sinus. The stepwise approach to hypercortisolism is as follows: Confirmation: This includes 2 steps: Tests to detect hypercortisolism ( 2 abnormal test results): Midnight salivary or serum cortiso 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST) Low dose DST Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome: Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test Identifying the source Localizing the lesion

question_text: A patient with Cushing’s syndrome presents with deep vein thrombosis. Which of the following mechanisms do not contribute to this?
explanation: Increased factor V does not contribute to the risk of thromboembolic complications like DVT in a patient with Cushing's Syndrome. There is increased factor VIII, vWF, and decreased fibrinolysis in Cushing’s syndrome patients which causes an increased risk of developing thromboembolic complications. Patients with Cushing's Syndrome are at a greater risk of acquiring hospital-acquired infection, thromboembolic and myocardial complications. Therefore, prophylactic anticoagulants and antibiotics constitute an essential component of pre-operative management.

question_text: Bilateral adrenalectomy is advised in all of the following conditions except
options: Unlocalised primary tumour of the adrenals
explanation: Unilateral adrenalectomy is done in adrenal incidentaloma with a size >4cm. Bilateral adrenalectomy is advised in: Bilateral ACTH-independent disease Ectopic ACTH-dependent Cushing’s Syndrome Irresectable or unlocalized primary tumor Adrenalectomy is done as a surgical measure in severe hypercortisolism or Cushing's disease. The adrenalectomy can be unilateral or bilateral depending on whether the tumor autonomously secrete hormones that could have a detrimental effect on health or If the adrenal mass benign or malignant.

question_text: A 57-year-old male patient has undergone unilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing’s syndrome and you have been asked to start him on cortisol supplementation, post-surgery. What is the rationale behind it?
options: Remaining adrenal gland has insufficient reserve
Contralateral adrenal gland is suppressed by prolonged cortisol over-secretion
explanation: The rationale behind cortisol supplementation after the surgical removal of the adenoma is that there is suppression of the contralateral adrenal gland by the pre-operative elevated cortisol levels. This causes primary adrenal insufficiency. Patients undergoing unilateral adrenalectomy typically require exogenous steroids for up to a year, which is usually the duration the remaining adrenal gland takes to recover adequate function. In bilateral adrenalectomy, steroids are required indefinitely, and patients may also require mineralocorticoid replacement therapy. Option A: The remaining adrenal gland usually has sufficient reserve to maintain homeostasis. Option C: A deficiency of ACTH causes secondary adrenal insufficiency. However, the adrenal insufficiency post adrenalectomy is primary i.e due to the hyposecretion of cortisol from the gland itself. Option D: Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome is a bilateral adrenal infarction associated with meningococcal sepsis and is rapidly fatal unless immediately treated.

question_text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of new-onset hyperpigmentation of the skin. He had undergone bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing’s disease 2 years ago. Which of the following statements is not true regarding his current condition?
options: It is characterized by elevated ACTH
Glucocorticoid replacement has to be continued
Screening is done using brain MRI
explanation: The given clinical scenario of new-onset hyperpigmentation post-adrenalectomy is suggestive of Nelson’s syndrome. The first-line and definitive management is surgical resection of the pituitary adenoma. Nelson’s syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is a procedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) when resection of the primary tumor is not possible. The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increases CRH. This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of the original pituitary tumor or formation of a new one. Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of: Hyperpigmentation Excessive ACTH secretion Corticotroph adenoma Screening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain performed at regular intervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. The primary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoid replacement, as they do not produce cortisol. The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the need for bilateral adrenalectomy these days.

question_text: Pheochromocytoma is a ten percent tumor. Which of the following statements is false about pheochromocytoma?
options: 10% of pheochromocytomas are seen in children
explanation: 10% of pheochromocytomas are bilateral.

question_text: A 40-year-old male patient admitted for evaluation of treatment-resistant hypertension and paroxysmal palpitations was found to have elevated metanephrines on urine screen. What is the next best step in the clinical management of this patient?
options: Imaging study with an MRI scan
Medical pre-treatment with phenoxybenzamine followed by laparoscopic resection
Imaging study with a contrast CT scan
explanation: In this scenario, the elevated urinary metanephrines point towards the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. Hence, the next best step is an MRI to localise the site of the tumour. MRI is preferred for the localization of pathologies because contrast media used for CT scans can provoke paroxysms. Classically, pheochromocytomas show a ‘Swiss cheese’ configuration. 123 Iodine-MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is essential for the detection of multiple extra-adrenal tumours and metastases, but PET scan using FDG or DOPA is more sensitive in detecting metastatic foci. The image given below shows MRI (marked B and C) and high uptake on 123I-mIBG scintigraphy (marked D and E) Laparoscopic resection is now a routine in the treatment of pheochromocytoma. An -adrenoreceptor blocker, phenoxybenzamine, is used pre-operatively to block excess catecholamine and its consequences during surgery. -blocker is added if there is tachycardia or arrythmia.

question_text: Germline mutations of which of the following genes is not associated with hereditary pheochromocytoma?
explanation: Germline mutation in NF2 gene is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2, and not hereditary pheochromocytoma. Hereditary pheochromocytomas are associated with NF1 germline mutations. Pheochromocytomas can occur in isolation or can be associated with hereditary tumor syndromes with the specific germline mutations such as: Neurofibromatosis type 1 - mutation in NF1 gene Familial paraganglioma syndrome - mutations within succinate dehydrogenase complex subunit B (SDHB), SDHD, SDHC genes Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2) - activating germline mutations of RET proto-oncogene Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome - mutations in VHL gene

question_text: A 15-year-old boy undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, there is no sign of bleed. What could be the cause of this?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of hypotension with no presence of bleeding and bilateral adrenalectomy is suggestive of an Addisonian crisis. It is a life-threatening condition caused due to sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones. Acute adrenal insufficiency (adrenal or addisonian's crisis) is a medical emergency caused due to a precipitating illness unmasking insufficiency or trauma or severe sepsis causing adrenal hemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome) or surgical removal of the glands. It presents with non-specific symptoms such as shock with fever, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, hypocalcemia and electrolyte imbalances. It may be often misdiagnosed as an acute abdominal emergency. Adrenal insufficiency can be primary (due to adrenal pathology), secondary (due to pituitary pathology- lack of ACTH) or tertiary (due to hypothalamus pathology- lack of CRH). Autoimmune adrenalitis is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency worldwide. Tuberculosis is the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency in India. Adrenal crisis requires immediate intervention owing to its high mortality rate. Immediate rehydration is initiated with a saline infusion at 1 litre/hr with continuous cardiac monitoring. Glucocorticoid replacement is initiated with an initial bolus injection of hydrocortisone 100 mg followed by 200 mg over 24 hours, preferably by continuous infusion or alternatively by IV or IM injections. Mineralocorticoid replacement is initiated once the daily dose of hydrocortisone has been reduced to <50 mg, since hydrocortisone at higher doses provides sufficient stimulation of mineralocorticoids.

question_text: Neuroblastoma can originate in all of the following except
explanation: Neuroblastoma does not originate in the adrenal cortex. Neuroblastoma is an embryonal tumour of the sympathetic nervous system. These tumours arise during fetal or early postnatal life from sympathetic cells derived from the neural crest. Therefore, tumours can originate anywhere along the path which neural crest cells migrate, including: Adrenal medulla - most common site Paraspinal sympathetic ganglia Sympathetic para ganglia such as the organ of Zuckerkand Note: Neuroblastoma is the most common abdominal (extradural) tumour in children and the most common overall tumour in infants.

question_text: A 2-year-old girl child with failure to thrive was found to have a palpable, firm, irregular abdominal mass that crossed the midline. CT revealed a calcified mass near the left kidney which on biopsy showed Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?
options: 70% patients present with metastasis at diagnosis
Urine homovanillic acid is used for screening
Amplification of N-myc gene is a good prognostic factor
Abdominal mass is a common presentation of the condition
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of neuroblastoma and amplification of N-myc gene is an indicator of poor prognosis. Neuroblastoma arises from the adrenal medulla. Homovanillic acid (HVA) and vanillylmandelic acid(VMA) are elevated in the urine of approximately 95% of patients and are used to diagnose and monitor this tumor. Clinical features: Abdominal mass (retroperitoneal or hepatic) Periorbital ecchymoses ("raccoon eyes," from periorbital ecchymosis caused by orbita metastases) Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome Hypertension - due to secretion of catecholamines Metastatic disease is present in more than 70% of patients at presentation. Histopathology is the gold standard for diagnosis. Histologically, classic neuroblastomas are composed of small, immature ganglion cells with dark nuclei. Typically, Homer-Wright pseudorosettes can be found which are tumour cells concentrically arranged about a central space filled with neuropil. The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumour and chemotherapy.

question_text:
What is the most common presentation of adrenal carcinoma?
Abdominal mass
Cushing syndrome
Pain
explanation: The most common presentation in patients with adrenal carcinoma is Cushing’s syndrome due to excess cortisol. Patients with non-functioning tumours frequently complain of abdominal discomfort or back pain (large tumours). Mc Farlane classification is used for staging adrenal carcinoma. Treatment involves complete resection of tumour and chemotherapy. Esophagus - Congenital, Motility & Inflammatory Disorders

question_text: A full-term infant with a history of polyhydramnios in utero presents with respiratory distress soon after birth. On examination, the child has frothing of saliva and the resident suspects tracheoesophageal fistula. What is the most common type of fistula likely to be present in this child?
explanation: Type C is the commonest variety of tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF). A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal communication between the esophagus and trachea. Type C lesion is associated with proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF. The proximal blind pouch ends approximately at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF. Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies. Drooling of saliva, inability to pass a nasogastric tube and history of polyhydramnios suggest a diagnosis of oesophagal atresia with or without TEF. This can be confirmed with a chest X-ray image showing a coiled nasogastric tube in the oesophagal pouch as shown in the image below.

question_text: A neonate was brought by his mother with complaints of regurgitation of the feeds given to him. The nasogastric tube could not be passed to the stomach. Radiograph is shown below. The birth weight of the neonate was 2.7kg. There is no current evidence of pneumonia. What is the most suitable management in this case?
explanation: The above scenario along with the radiograph is suggestive of a type-E or H-type tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). The management for this case would be Cameron Haight's surgery. Management of TEF is based on Waterson's criteria: Diagnosis of TEF: Confirmatory - Contrast study (Iohexol) Investigation of choice for H-type - Combined tracheo-esophagoscopy Definitive surgery for: Types B, C, D, and E - Cameron Haight surgery Type A - Anastomosis with/without gastrostomy Categ ory Weight/Comorbidities Management A Birth weight > 2.5kg Definitive surgery B Birth weight 1.8-2.5kg or pne umonia or congenital anomal y Needs stabilization before su rgeryAntibiotics + Build up n utrition C Birth weight < 1.8kg or sever e pneumonia or congenital a nomaly Staged repairAntibiotics + ga strostomy
