question_text: What is the following image of a barium swallow suggestive of?
explanation: The image shows a markedly dilated esophagus and characteristic bird's beak appearance (distal narrowing), which is suggestive of achalasia cardia. Achalasia cardia is caused due to the degeneration of the neurons in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. This degeneration results in the failure of relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) on swallowing. The patients present with a classic triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods. As the food gets accumulated in the esophagus, patients may complain of halitosis. With further progression of the disease, the patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc. The initial diagnosis is made by barium swallow or endoscopy, which shows the presence of dilated esophagus due to the constriction of the lower esophageal sphincter (bird-beak appearance). The gold standard test to confirm achalasia cardia is esophageal manometry.
subject: Surgery

question_text: In which of the following conditions is normal peristalsis not seen?
explanation: Achalasia cardia does not show normal peristalsis. Manometric features of achalasia cardia are as follows: Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation Aperistalsis of the esophageal body Elevated LES pressure Diffuse esophageal spasm is characterized by simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of the esophagus. The contractions are spontaneous and may be of abnormally high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration. Intermittent normal peristalsis is seen. Nutcracker esophagus is characterized by high amplitude ( 180 mmHg) contractions with an increased mean duration. The peristaltic sequence is normal. Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter is characterized by elevated LES pressure ( 26 mmHg). Normal peristalsis is seen in the body of the esophagus.

question_text: A young woman was admitted with chief complaints of dysphagia since adulthood which worsened in the last three months followed by odynophagia, nausea, and vomiting of undigested food. Her barium swallow shows features suspicious of achalasia and she is advised to undergo esophageal manometry. Which of the following will not be seen?
options: Absent peristalsis of the esophageal body
explanation: There is increased esophageal baseline pressure in achalasia cardia. Manometric features of achalasia cardia are as follows: Incomplete lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation Absent peristalsis of the esophageal body Elevated LES pressure Increased intraesophageal baseline pressures relative to the gastric baseline pressure High-resolution manometry (HRM) is a gastrointestinal motility diagnostic system that measures intraluminal pressure activity in the gastrointestinal tract using a series of closely spaced pressure sensors. For a manometry system to be classified as high-resolution instead of classic, the pressure sensors must be spaced at most 1 cm apart.

question_text: Which of the following is true about Chicago classification?
options: The classification is based on readings obtained by classic manometry
Type l achalasia exhibits panoesophageal pressurization pattern
Per oral endoscopic myotomy is the definitive treatment for type I achalasia
explanation: Type III achalasia in Chicago classification is also known as spastic achalasia. Achalasia cardia is a motility disorder of the esophagus in which the LES (lower esophageal sphincter) fails to relax due to loss of ganglion in the myenteric plexus. Chicago classification of esophageal motility divides achalasia cardia into 3 types. This classification is based on the readings obtained by high-resolution manometry (HRM). Type I achalasia cardia does not show pressurization pattern. Treatment options: Pneumatic dilatation Laparoscopic myotomy POEM (per-oral endoscopic myotomy) The definitive treatment for Achalasia is surgical myotomy (Hellers myotomy) + fundoplication.

question_text:
A 32-year-old male was diagnosed with achalasia cardia. High-resolution manometry revealed massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal oesophagus. According to the
Chicago classification, the patient has which type of achalasia?
explanation: The given features are suggestive of type III achalasia cardia. Type III achalasia cardia is characterised by massive, simultaneous, high-pressure contractions of the distal esophagus. Achalasia cardia occurs due to the loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus of GIT. During swallowing, the food bolus normally triggers a primary peristaltic wave, which is responsible for carrying the bolus to the stomach, accompanied by the relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to allow esophageal emptying into the stomach. Achalasia is characterized by a disruption of this normal process. Failure of relaxation of the LES causes an elevated median integrated relaxation pressure and a complete failure of peristalsis. The esophagus becomes progressively more tortuous, leading to a megaesophagus.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 50-year-old woman presented with long-standing complaints of dysphagia which was getting worse for the past 4 months. A barium swallow was performed and it showed the following finding. Which of the following is the definitive treatment of this condition?
explanation: The patient likely has achalasia cardia and the definitive treatment is Heller's myotomy. Surgical management is the first-line treatment modality. Achalasia or 'failure to relax' in Greek occurs due to the lack of ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus (Auerbach's). The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax leading to dysphagia, regurgitation of food, and progressive dilation of the esophagus proximal to the constriction. Barium radiology shows hold-up in the distal esophagus, abnormal contractions in the oesophageal body, and a tapering stricture in the distal esophagus often described as a ‘bird’s beak’. Laparoscopic Heller's myotomy is the procedure of choice. Here, the muscles of the lower esophagus and cardia are cut. However, this can cause iatrogenic gastroesophageal reflux (GERD) due to damage to the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). Thus, newer techniques involve a partial fundoplication like Dor's procedure to reinforce the sphincter and reduce GERD symptoms. Endoscopic myotomy is a newer, alternate procedure. Here, a submucosal tunnel is formed in the mid esophagus region that allows a long myotomy. Option A: Calcium channel blockers can be given in the initial stages of the disease. They relieve the chest pressure that occurs around mealtimes. However, they are not permanent treatments and can be used while waiting for surgery. Option B: Botulinum toxin injection can be used as a treatment in patients who may not be candidates for surgery or dilatation. Limitations to botulinum toxin injections are that the effect is short-lived (6-12 months) and patients often require multiple treatments. Option C: Pneumatic dilatation of the LES has is successful in 75% of patients. It involves using a balloon to stretch the LES and improve competence. It requires multiple sessions and has a low risk of esophageal perforation.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following esophageal carcinomas is most likely to develop in patients with long-standing achalasia cardia?
explanation: The most common type of carcinoma associated with this condition is squamous cell carcinoma. Achalasia is a premalignant condition. It becomes malignant due to long-standing, retained, undigested fermenting food in the body of the esophagus, causing mucosal irritation. Adenocarcinoma may also arise in the setting of achalasia but is less common as compared to SCC. Small cell carcinoma is a rare type of neuroendocrine esophageal carcinoma more common in the lower esophagus. It is very aggressive and the 5-year survival rate is 8%. Carcinoid tumors are slow-growing tumors of neuroendocrine cells that form in the GI tract, mainly in the rectum, small intestine, or appendix.
subject: Surgery

question_text: In which of the following conditions is peroral endoscopic myotomy done?
explanation: Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is used in achalasia cardia. Treatment options: Pneumatic dilatation Laparoscopic myotomy POEM (per-oral endoscopic myotomy) With the use of an operating endoscope, the mucosa of the esophagus is divided around the mid to the distal third, and a submucosal tunnel is created. Through this tunnel, the muscular layer of the distal esophagus, lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and cardia are visualized and divided, effectively performing an endoscopic myotomy. The major downside of POEM is that an effective anti-reflux valve cannot be created, exposing the patient to a 40%–50% risk of post-procedural gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient presented with complaints of crushing chest pain radiating to the jaw and dysphagia. It starts whenever he has ice cream and he takes sublingual nitroglycerin which provides him relief. He underwent manometry which showed simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg). What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The above clinical scenario with episodes triggered by cold foods and manometric findings are suggestive of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES). Diffuse esophageal spasm is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus. It is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body. It is more common in women. Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain. Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles. It is often triggered by cold foods. It mimics symptoms of myocardial infarction and also shows improvement when sublingual nitroglycerin is administered. It causes smooth muscle relaxation of the esophagus. A barium swallow shows a corkscrew esophagus. However, manometry (high-resolution manometry is preferred) is the gold standard test for diagnosis. In classic manometry, if there are simultaneous, multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds) it is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm. On high-resolution manometry, a DCI (distal contractile integral) >450 mmHg is suggestive of DES. The distal contractile integral (DCI) is an index of contractile vigor in high-resolution manometry, calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction. Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter - It is achalasia in evolution. Shows increased LES pressure but normal peristalsis. Nutcracker’s esophagus - It is the most common motility disorder of the esophagus. In conventional manometry, it shows a high-amplitude peristaltic contraction ( >180mmHg) and a longer duration of contraction (>7sec). In high-resolution manometry, a DCI > 8000mmHg is suggestive of nutcracker's esophagus.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient with dysphagia was evaluated with a barium swallow as given in the image. Which of the following is false regarding the management of this condition?
options: Calcium channel blockers and nitrates are first line therapy
Pneumatic dilatation only provides short term relief
Myotomy of only the affected segment is done
Endoscopic botulinum injection is given when medical therapy is contraindicated
explanation: The given image is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm (DES). Myotomy involves the entire length of the affected segment along with a margin of several centimeters to the spastic region to prevent remnants of spasticity. First-line therapy is with calcium channel blockers and nitrates. Endoscopic botulinum toxin injection and pneumatic dilation are second-line therapies. Calcium-channel antagonists, vasodilators, and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects. Botulinum toxin injection is also considered an effective and low-risk procedure but for short-term symptom relief. Pneumatic dilation is targeted at the exact anatomic site of narrowing. Surgical treatment includes extended myotomy of the esophageal body or peroral endoscopic myotomy. Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is a safe and effective treatment for patients, especially those who are refractory to medical therapy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 72-year-old female patient presented to the hospital with complaints of difficulty swallowing and generalised weakness for 4 months. Peripheral smear revealed the following and an esophagography was done as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The above clinical scenario with microcytic hypochromic anemia and characteristic esophagogram is suggestive of Plummer-Vinson syndrome. Plummer-Vinson syndrome/Paterson–Kelly syndrome has a triad of: Post-cricoid webs Dysphagia Iron-deficiency anemia The webs are made up of fibrovascular stroma and esophageal epithelium. Glossitis, angular stomatitis, koilonychia are also associated with this condition. Laboratory investigations reveal microcytic-hypochromic blood picture and barium esophagography or esophagogastroduodenoscopy(EGD) will help detect post-cricoid webs. Treatment includes correcting the iron-deficiency anemia which may improve dysphagia and pain. Esophageal bougies can be used during upper endoscopy to dilate the post-cricoid webs and allow normal swallowing and passage of food. Complications include the risk of perforation during dilatation and also malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma. The image below shows endoscopic appearance of post-cricoid web.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 22-year-old male presented with intermittent dysphagia for the past 3 months. Barium swallow showed the following characteristic appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Schatzki’s ring. The barium swallow shows a thin circumferential ring in the distal esophagus, which is suggestive of Schatzki’s ring. Schatzki’s ring is a benign condition wherein there is a concentric, fibrous thickening and narrowing of the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ), with squamous epithelium above and columnar cells below. Schatzki's ring is made up of mucosal and submucosal layers. It causes dysphagia and is associated with gastroesophageal reflux disorder (GERD). It is most commonly seen in the lower third of the esophagus. Treatment is endoscopic dilation with antireflux therapy and repeated dilation is often necessary. Persistent strictures should always raise suspicion for malignant disease. The image below shows endoscopic appearance of the Schatzki's ring.

question_text: A 20-year-old woman presented with a 1-year history of nonprogressive dysphagia for solids with no previous similar episodes. Barium swallow revealed fixed narrowing of the esophagus at the level of the aortic arch. CT angiography revealed the following. Which anomaly is most commonly seen in this condition?
explanation: The above image shows the origin of the aberrant right subclavian artery (red arrow) causing extrinsic compression of the esophagus that is suggestive of dysphagia lusoria. In dysphagia lusoria, the right subclavian artery arises as the fourth branch of the aortic arch instead of branching from the brachiocephalic artery. It then courses behind the esophagus to supply blood to the right arm. This causes pressure on the esophagus and results in dysphagia. It is diagnosed by CT angiography. A barium swallow shows fixed narrowing of the esophagus at the level of the aortic arch without mucosal abnormality. Treatment is surgical repair either by reconstruction or ligation of the aberrant right subclavian artery.

question_text: A 65-year-old man presents with halitosis and swelling in the lateral aspect of the neck. He also complained of persistent cough and regurgitation of food remnants shortly after consumption. He underwent a barium swallow which is given below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Occurs in the midline posteriorly and as sac enlarges lies on the left side
Dohlman’s procedure is indicated when size > 2-5 cm
Herniates through the thyropharyngeus and cricothyroid muscle
explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of a Zenker’s diverticulum or pharyngeal pouch. It is caused due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the space between thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus. This space is known as Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is a pulsion diverticulum, formed due to increased intraluminal pressure forcing mucosa and submucosa to herniate. A small Zenker’s diverticulum < 2cm is managed by diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeal myotomy. Large diverticulum > 2-5cm is treated by endoscopic diverticulopexy (Dohlman’s procedure) or by a diverticulectomy with cricopharyngeal myotomy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which among the following is a true esophageal diverticulum?
explanation: M d esophageal diverticula is a true diverticula. It involves all three layers of the esophageal wall such as mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis. Esophageal diverticula are herniations of the esophagus that extend into neighbouring structures. They occur as a result of primary motor disturbance or abnormality of the esophageal sphincters. They are classified based on their location into: Zenker’s diverticulum (hypopharyngeal) Mid esophageal (parabronchial) Epiphrenic (supradiaphragmatic) Epiphrenic and Zenker's diverticula are false diverticula involving herniation of only the mucosa and submucosa through the muscular layer of the esophagus. M desophageal diverticula may be caused by traction on the esophagus from adjacent nflammation and fibrosis (classically tuberculosis). question_text: A man presented with complaints of chest pain and a feeling of food getting stuck in the esophagus, after a meal. He has asthma and is under treatment. PPIs were prescribed but it did not resolve the problem so a barium swallow was done and showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above clinical scenario and imaging findings are suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis. Eosinophilic esophagitis is an idiopathic condition commonly affecting the proximal one-third of the esophagus. There is migration of eosinophils to the esophagus and they contribute to extensive tissue damage and inflammation. Clinical features include swallowing difficulty, food impaction, vomiting, and heartburn. Barium swallow shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus which is suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis. These rings appear as stripes on the cat and is also known as the feline esophagus. Feline esophagus: The definitive diagnosis requires biopsy with a histologic finding of >15–20 eosinophils per high-power field. Treatment includes oral corticosteroids and immunotherapy.

question_text: A 40-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department after the ingestion of a large amount of household cleaning liquid. She complained of a burning sensation in the throat and severe abdominal pain. She has a history of depression for the past 1 year. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: It is a risk factor for esophageal carcinoma
Early endoscopic evaluation is recommended to assess the grade of mucosal injury
Prophylactic antibiotics improve the clinical outcome
Acids only cause superficial damage to the esophagus
explanation: Prophylactic antibiotics have not been shown to improve the clinical outcome of acute corrosive esophagitis and are not recommended. Corrosive esophagitis is caused due to the ingestion of alkali or acid and can be accidental or from attempted suicide. The injury caused by alkali ingestion is deeper due to the process of saponification of fats and dehydration. The injury caused by acids is more superficial because they cause coagulative necrosis with eschar formation, which prevents the deeper penetration of the acid. The acids also cause severe pylorospasm and therefore more gastric damage compared to alkali due to the accumulation of the contents in the antrum. Severe corrosive injury may lead to esophageal perforation, bleeding, stricture, and death. It is a risk factor for esophageal carcinoma. Therefore, early endoscopic evaluation is recommended to assess mucosal injuries even if there is no signs of oral injury. Management of corrosive esophagitis: Hemodynamic stabilization and management of patient's airway Endoscopic evaluation of injuries Surgical management includes laparotomy and Esophageal stenting and jejunostomy for limited hemorrhage and superficial ulceration Esophagogastric resection and jejunostomy for extensive necrosis.

question_text: What is the most common site for pill-induced esophagitis?
explanation: The most common site for pill-induced esophagitis is in the mid esophagus near the crossing of aorta or carina. These structures externally compress the esophagus and prevent the movement of the pills. Pill-induced esophagitis is caused when the pill lodges within the lumen of the esophagus. This pill causes direct damage to the mucosa. The risk factors for pill-induced esophagitis include poor pill-taking habits, consuming inadequate liquids, and lying down immediately after consuming the pill. Drugs causing esophagitis are: Doxycycline Quinidine Phenytoin NSAIDs Bisphosphonates

explanation: The image showing serpiginous ulcers in the otherwise normal mucosa of the distal esophagus is suggestive of cytomegaloviral esophagitis.

question_text:
A middle-aged man presented to the emergency department with upper abdominal pain after having a heavy meal. On clinical examination, upper abdominal tenderness was noted. On
chest radiography widening of the mediastinum with pneumomediastinum was seen. What is the probable diagnosis?
options: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung
explanation: The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of spontaneous perforation of the esophagus. In a perforated peptic ulcer, patients develop sudden onset severe generalized abdominal pain, tenderness, and board-like rigidity and an erect plain chest X-ray shows gas under the diaphragm (Option B). The foreign body in the esophagus can be asymptomatic or may present with perforation after ingestion. The radiopaque foreign body can be seen with a chest X-ray (Option C). Rupture of emphysematous bullae of the lung will lead to secondary pneumothorax, which manifests as chest pain and dyspnoea. A plain chest X-ray shows air in the thorax, and the mediastinum is pushed to the opposite side (Option D). Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus needs immediate diagnosis and intervention due to the higher mortality associated with it. The most common site of perforation is the lower esophagus towards the left esophageal cavity. Causes: Iatrogenic perforation (most common) Boerhaave's syndrome (spontaneous emetogenic perforation) Sharp foreign body Corrosive ingestion Esophageal carcinoma It usually manifests as severe pain in the chest or abdomen after a meal or after a bout of drinking, commonly associated with dyspnoea. On clinical examination, there is rigidity and tenderness in the upper abdomen. The diagnosis is usually confirmed by a chest radiograph which shows pneumomediastinum, pneumoperitoneum, and pneumothorax. Subcutaneous emphysema can be seen in Boerhaave's syndrome. Patients with sepsis will have a fever, tachycardia and tachypnea. Treatment includes adequate drainage, antibiotics, closure of the perforation site if possible and supportive measures.

question_text: A 45-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a history of severe chest pain radiating to the back and difficulty in breathing following several episodes of vomiting. PR- 110bpm and BP- 80/50 mm of Hg. On examination, there is palpable crepitus over the chest wall. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
options: Most common in lower third of esophagus
Iohexol is used as contrast agent
Cervical esophagostomy and gastrostomy is done in early presentation
Most common cause of mortality is mediastinitis
explanation: The above clinical scenario points to Boerhaave's syndrome. Primary closure is done in stable patients presenting within 24 hrs and not cervical esophagostomy with gastrostomy. Boerhaave syndrome is the spontaneous perforation of the esophagus caused due to episodes of vomiting. During vomiting, the pressure in the esophagus rises rapidly and the esophagus ruptures at the weakest point. They usually have a history of heavy meal intake and alcohol abuse. Clinical features include Mackler's triad: Retching Chest pain Subcutaneous emphysema The diagnosis is made by contrast esophagogram(iohexol) in unstable patients or contrast-enhanced CT scan, in stable patients. Treatment includes primary closure within 12 hours of the injury for a better prognosis. If the patient is unstable or presents late, the perforated part is resected and cervical esophagostomy is performed. A T-tube is placed into the esophagus along with appropriately located drains and a feeding jejunostomy or gastrostomy is performed for nutrition. Most common cause of mortality in Boerhaave syndrome is mediastinitis (40% to 50%).

question_text: A 47-year-old woman underwent endoscopy for the evaluation of dysphagia. After the procedure, she developed severe chest pain radiating to the back and respiratory distress. What is the initial investigation you will perform on this patient to identify the cause?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of esophageal perforation following endoscopy. The initial investigation that is performed in this condition is a contrast esophagogram which will show the extravasation of the contrast. Water-soluble contrast (iohexol) should be used instead of barium contrast to prevent barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum if there is perforation. If the esophagogram is normal, contrast-enhanced CT is useful in identifying the injury. If the radiological investigations are normal and suspicion of esophageal perforation is high, then endoscopy can be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

question_text: Which of the following cases of esophageal perforation will you not manage surgically?
options: Crepitus in the neck and difficulty breathing after nasogastric tube insertion
Severe chest pain and breathing difficulty following several episodes of vomiting
Septic shock due to pyothorax and mediastinitis on left side of lower esophagus
Epigastric pain radiating to the shoulder with air under the diaphragm
explanation: The patient with crepitus in the neck and difficulty breathing after nasogastric tube insertion most likely has perforation of the cervical esophagus. Instrumental perforations in the cervical esophagus are usually small and can nearly always be managed conservatively. Esophageal perforation is mostly due to spontaneous or iatrogenic causes. Iatrogenic instrument-induced perforation is the most common cause of esophageal perforation and is most common in the cervical esophagus in the cricopharyngeal area. Clinical features include pain as the most common presentation. Crepitus may be present. Hamman sign is heard during auscultation which is a crunching, rasping sound, synchronous with the heartbeat. Investigations include: X-ray chest CT scan Esophagogram Thoracentesis Serum amylase level may be raised. Treatment is primary closure within 24 hours of injury and conservative treatment in selected cases. Complications of esophageal perforation are pneumothorax and empyema (most common in the left side of the chest and bilateral in 10% of cases). Option B: The patient with severe chest pain and breathing difficulty following several episodes of vomiting most likely has Boerhaave syndrome which affects the lower third of the esophagus and requires primary closure within 24 hours of the injury for a better prognosis. Option C: Patients presenting with septic shock due to an infection in the chest (pyothorax or mediastinitis) following an esophageal perforation require emergency surgical stenting, debridement, or drainage. Option D: The presence of epigastric pain radiating to the shoulders with air under the diaphragm point to a diagnosis of abdominal esophagus perforation. It requires immediate surgical intervention to restore the integrity of the esophagus. A 48-year-old woman presented with dysphagia and postprandial chest pain that is relieved on loud belching. On examination, the patient had pallor. Chest radiography showed an intrathoracic gas bubble. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
Achalasia cardia
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a hiatus hernia. Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm. Type 1 - sliding hernia: Gastroesophageal junction or cardia migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus is reduced leading to GERD. Most of the patients are asymptomatic. The treatment of choice in symptomatic patients is fundoplication. Type 2 - rolling hiatus hernia: Gastroesophageal junction or cardia is normal but a portion of the stomach migrates into the thoracic cavity. The length of intra abdominal esophagus remains the same in a true rolling hiatus hernia. Clinical features: Chest pain or fullness relieved on belching. Dysphagia. Longitudinal ulcers (Cameron’s ulcer) that bleeds, leading to anemia. Surgical reduction of hernia and tightening of diaphragmatic crura is the best treatment modality even in asymptomatic patients to avoid life-threatening complications like volvulus. Type 3 - mixed hiatus hernia: A combination of sliding and rolling hiatus hernia. Treatment is the same as rolling hiatus hernia. Type 4 hiatus hernia: Other contents of GIT herniates into the thoracic cavity. Eg: Colon. CT with oral contrast is the best method of diagnosis of hiatus hernia. It highlights gastric anatomy and also helps to identify other structures involved. Chest X-ray shows an intrathoracic gas bubble. Esophagus - GERD & Carcinoma

question_text: What is the most important pathophysiological factor implicated in GERD?
explanation: Frequent transient lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation accounts for more than 90% of the cases of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a condition that develops when there is a retrograde flow of stomach contents back into the esophagus. It can present as non-erosive reflux disease or erosive esophagitis. A hiatal hernia is the next common cause of GERD. Factors contributing to the high pressure in the LES zone: Factors contributing to the high pressure in the LES zone: Intrinsic musculature of the distal esophagus and sling fibers of the cardia of stomach which are in tonic contraction During inspiration, the anterposterior diameter of the crural opening of diaphragm is decreased (increases LES pressure) Transmitted pressure of the abdominal cavity on the LES zone

question_text: Which of the following foods will you recommend to a patient to reduce symptoms of GERD?
explanation: Protein increases the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) pressure, thereby allowing the closure of the sphincter and reducing reflux. Other options: Option A: Chocolate and coffee both contain methylxanthine, which causes muscles to relax and lowers the LES pressure. In addition, coffee can stimulate gastric secretions, which can promote reflux. Option C: Fatty foods have been found to delay gastric emptying and decrease the LES pressure, thereby prolonging the esophageal exposure time to the stomach acid and the volume available for reflux. Option D: Alcohol, mint, citrus, tomatoes, and/or carbonated beverages may cause further irritation to the damaged esophageal mucosa but have not been found to cause reflux themselves.

question_text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a feeling of fullness and sensation of a lump in the throat for the past 3 weeks. He has no other complaints like weight loss or dysphagia. Rigid endoscopy showed no growth or foreign body in the throat. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
options: Lump in the throat only felt during swallowing
Does not interfere with eating or drinking
explanation: The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of globus hystericus. It is a feeling of fullness or lump in the throat that is felt always and not only when swallowing. Globus hystericus or globus pharyngeus is a persistent abnormal sensation in the throat in the absence of any observable pathology. The exact cause of globus sensation is uncertain. The sensation is often relieved by the act of swallowing and it does not interfere with eating and drinking. Examination and investigations may be carried out to exclude any other underlying problem. It is often attributable to GERD. Reassurance that there is no serious underlying problem may be all that is needed in terms of treatment.

question_text: What is the most common complication of Nissen's fundoplication?
explanation: The most common complication of Nissen’s fundoplication is gas-bloat syndrome. Fundoplication is the procedure in which the fundus of the stomach is wrapped around the lower end of the esophagus. After this procedure, most patients are unable to belch gas from the stomach into the esophagus. This causes increased gas in the stomach resulting in bloating sensation, abdominal discomfort, and flatulence. This is known as gas bloat syndrome and occurs more commonly with Nissen total fundoplication. Pneumothorax is the most common complication that occurs intraoperatively.

question_text: The fundus is wrapped (270°) around the posterior aspect of the esophagus in which of the following corrective procedures for GERD?
explanation: Partial posterior fundoplication between 180 to 270° is called Toupet fundoplication. It is used in the surgical management of GERD. Partial anterior fundoplication is Dor’s fundoplication and total fundoplication is Nissen’s fundoplication.

question_text: What is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus?
explanation: Leiomyomas are the most common benign tumors of the esophagus. Leiomyomas are benign tumors that arise from the muscularis propria. They are found in the mid to distal esophagus. They are more common in males and small, asymptomatic lesions are observed, while symptomatic lesions are enucleated.

question_text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus?
explanation: Barrett’s esophagus is a risk factor for adenocarcinoma of the lower end of the esophagus, not for squamous cell carcinoma. question_text: Which of the following is not true about Barrett's esophagus?
options: It is the intestinal metaplasia of esophagus
Mucus secreting foveolar cells are characteristic
Alician blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimen
It is a reversible cell adaptation
explanation: Mucus-secreting goblet cells (not foveolar cells) are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus, as there is intestinal metaplasia of the esophagus. Foveolar cells are the mucus-secreting cells in the stomach. Barrett's esophagus is a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and it is estimated to occur in about 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD. Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation and sometimes dysphagia. Obese white men over the age of 60 years represent the highest-risk group. Intestinal metaplasia in the esophagus occurs due to chronic irritation of the esophagus in GERD (option A) since intestinal epithelium is better suited to handling gastric acid exposure. Hence, mucus-secreting goblet cells are characteristic of Barrett's esophagus. Since all metaplasia are reversible, Barrett's esophagus is also reversible (option D). Only 0.2 to 1% of Barrett's esophagus leads to dysplasia and adenocarcinoma. Alician blue is used in the staining of the biopsy specimen, as it stains the goblet cells (option C). Mucicarmine is the specific stain. Seattle protocol is used for the management of Barrett's esophagus.

question_text: Investigation of choice for cardia metaplasia in Barrett's esophagus is
explanation: The investigation of choice for Barrett's esophagus showing cardia metaplasia is endoscopy with methylene blue. Barrett's esophagus is a metaplastic change (squamous to columnar change) in the lower end of the esophagus as a result of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease. Barrett’s esophagus can be- Classical Barrett's esophagus - > 3cm of columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus. Short segment Barrett's esophagus - < 3cm of columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus. Cardia metaplasia - microscopic Barrett’s in the GE junction. In cardia metaplasia due to lack of macroscopic changes, an endoscopic biopsy is difficult. So chromoendoscopy is the ideal investigation. Here mucosa is first stained by methylene blue to highlight abnormal mucosa. Here a 4 quadrant biopsy specimen is taken 1- 2 cm apart throughout the area of intestinal metaplasia. No signs of dysplasia - continue 2 yearly surveillance. Low-grade dysplasia - APC or RFA or EMR followed by 6 monthly surveillance. High-grade dysplasia - APC or RFA or EMR followed by 3 monthly surveillance. question_text: What is the blood supply of the conduit in gastric pull up done during esophagectomy?
options: Right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries
Right gastric and left gastroepiploic arteries
Left gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries
Left gastric and left gastroepiploic arteries
explanation: The blood supply to the gastric conduit is based on the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries. A gastric pull-up is done during esophagectomy for esophageal carcinoma. It is a surgical procedure where the stomach is pulled up into the thoracic cavity that now acts as a new passage (conduit) instead of the esophagus. During the esophagectomy, the proximal stomach and lymph nodes are typically resected along with the segment of the esophagus. The gastric conduit is then fashioned by tubularization of the stomach. The right gastroepiploic artery is preserved and the other arteries are ligated to make ample length and mobility for the conduit. It is of utmost importance the right gastroepiploic artery is preserved as ischemia to the stomach will result in anastomotic leakage, stricture, and even dehiscence. The rich supply of submucosal vascular networks can preserve the stomach on this single vessel. question_text: A 50-year-old man is diagnosed with esophageal carcinoma. Radiological investigations show a 2 cm tumor in the middle part of the esophagus. The tumor extends up to the submucosa with the involvement of mediastinal lymph nodes, there is no distant metastasis. What is the best treatment modality in his case?
explanation: Chemoradiation followed by esophagectomy is the best treatment modality for tumors extending to the submucosa (T1b) with regional lymph node involvement (N1). EMR (endoscopic mucosal resection) is done for small tumors confined to the mucosa, with no lymph node involvement. (T1aN0) Esophagectomy ± chemoradiation is done when the tumor extends into the submucosa, with no lymph node involvement. Chemoradiation followed by esophagectomy is done for tumors extending into the submucosa or beyond with lymph node enlargement Chemoradiation therapy alone is done as a palliative measure in case of advanced esophageal carcinoma or in those patients unfit for surgery. Esophageal stent placement is done in patients with advanced cancer and severe dysphagia that is not resolved by chemoradiation therapy. SEMS (self-expanding metallic stent) is the treatment of choice in malignant tracheoesophageal fistula.

question_text: A neonate presented with features of intestinal obstruction. The X-ray showed the following image. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: The above plain abdominal radiograph shows a typical double-bubble sign suggestive of duodenal atresia. The double-bubble represents dilatation of the stomach and the proximal duodenum. Duodenal atresia is often associated with trisomy 21/Down syndrome, prematurity, maternal polyhydramnios, cardiac malformations, and malformations of the hepatobiliary system. It is caused due to failure of recanalization or partial recanalization of the duodenum or failure of vacuolization of the duodenum from its solid cord stage. The anatomic variants are as follows: Type I: most common mucosal web with intact muscle wall (so-called windsock deformity) Type II: two ends separated by a fibrous cord, but muscle continuity present Type III: complete separation of two ends with a gap within the duodenum Clinical features: Obstructive features such a bilious emesis (due to duodenal obstruction distal to the ampulla of Vater) postprandial emesi upper abdominal distension with a scaphoid lower abdomen Delayed passage of meconium Abdominal radiographs show the double-bubble sign. If distal air is present, an upper GI contrast study should be considered to exclude midgut volvulus. Treatment: The initial treatment of infants with duodenal atresia includes nasogastric or orogastric decompression. IV fluids and parenteral nutrition are started to prevent acid-base imbalance. Echocardiography, renal ultrasound, and radiology of the chest and spine should be performed to evaluate for associated anomalies. Definitive correction of the atresia is done by duodenoduodenostomy. This procedure is also preferred in cases of the concomitant or isolated annular pancreas.

question_text: An infant with Edward's syndrome presents with the following radiological finding. Which of the following is false about this condition?
options: Mostly presents as vomiting within 1 week
Erythromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life can lead to this condition
Palpation of the pyloric olive is pathognomonic for this condition
explanation: The radiographic image showing the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble (single bubble) is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). It most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting between 2-8 weeks of age and is only rarely seen after 13 weeks. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk. Risk factors for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Turner syndrome Edwards syndrome Erythromycin or azithromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life either orally or via mother' milk. Palpation of the olive-shaped mass in the epigastrium is considered pathognomonic. USG criteria for diagnosing hypertrophic pyloric stenosis - pyloric muscle thickness of >3-4 mm or a pyloric length >15-18 mm in the presence of functional gastric outlet obstruction is diagnostic.

question_text:
An abdominal mass in a patient with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is best seen
.
options: During palpation over the left hypochondrium
explanation: In a child with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS), the abdominal mass is best seen during test feed in the right upper quadrant. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis most presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2 and 8 weeks of age. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. Male infants are at a higher risk. Clinically, when the infant is given a test feed, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant and visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right across the abdomen. Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality- hypochloraemic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis. Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). All infants with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis are evaluated with an ultrasound (investigation of choice). It confirms the diagnosis in the majority of cases. Management: Rehydration and metabolic correction prior to definitive surgery - Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy.

question_text: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Which among the following statements is true regarding her condition?
explanation: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) most commonly presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2-8 weeks of age. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting. Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality i.e hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-). The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3-. However, the loss of sodium stimulates the secretion of aldosterone via the RAAS pathway. The aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for K+ and H+ ions. Loss of potassium ions leads to the development of hypokalemia. Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in aciduria. It is called paradoxical aciduria, since the body initially lost H+ ions due to loss of HCl, and instead of compensating that loss, the body is losing more H+ ions through urine. The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs of CHPS seen on ultrasonography: Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called nipple ign. The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign. The given ultrasound image shows thickened pylorus, with cervix sign and nipple sign. Treatment: The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected preoperatively. The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

question_text: Which part of the GIT is most sensitive to ischemia following a hypovolemic insult?
explanation: Tonometry studies have shown that of all the parts of the gastrointestinal tract (GIT), the stomach is most sensitive to ischemia following a hypovolemic insult and is also the slowest to recover. This may explain the high incidence of stress ulceration in the stomach. The Griffiths point (or Griffiths critical point) refers to the site of watershed anastomosis between the ascending left colic artery and the marginal artery of Drummond occurring in the region of the splenic flexure. Most anatomy texts describe its location as two-thirds along the transverse colon. The Sudeck point (or Sudeck critical point) refers to a specific location in the arterial supply of the rectosigmoid junction, namely the origin of the last sigmoid arterial branch from the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA).

question_text: What is the most common cause of upper GI bleeding?
explanation: The most common cause of upper GI bleeding is peptic ulcer. The causes of upper GI bleed in decreasing order of frequency: Ulcer Esophageal (6%) Gastric (21%) Duodenal (33%) Erosion Mallory–Weiss tear Esophageal varice Tumour Vascular lesion

question_text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of dark-colored stools to the OPD. After undergoing endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper GI bleed. Which of the following structures is used as a demarcation point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?
explanation: The ligament of Treitz is used as the demarcation point to differentiate between upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding. It is a part of the duodenojejunal junction. Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

question_text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic, with a history of binge drinking and multiple episodes of vomiting, presents with hematemesis. On endoscopy, a longitudinal mucosal tear is found in the gastroesophageal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mallory Weiss tear. It is due to a longitudinal tear in mucosa or submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction. It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or straining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy. Management of Mallory Weiss tear Conservative, as it is usually is self-limiting. Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy. Angiographic embolization - if endoscopy fails. High gastrotomy - if all these maneuvers fail. Boerhaave syndrome is characterized by spontaneous perforation of the esophagus. Here all layers are involved. Clinical features include Mackler's triad Retching Chest pain Subcutaneous emphysema Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE) is characterized by dilated venules in the submucosa of the antrum. On endoscopy: Watermelon stomach. Management of GAVE Endoscopic argon photocoagulation (APC) If persistent - antrectomy. Dieulafoy lesion is a vascular malformation (dilated submucosal arterioles) that is seen along the lesser curvature of the stomach. The investigation of choice is endoscopy. Management of Dieulafoy lesion: Endoscopic electrocoagulation or sclerosant therapy Angiographic embolization.

question_text: A 25-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of increasing heartburn and dyspepsia for the past several months. He was prescribed PPIs for one month but he has no relief. You perform a urea breath test which is found to be positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the positive urea breath test are suggestive of a Helicobacter pylori infection which is most commonly associated with Type B gastritis. Type B gastritis usually affects the antrum. Intestinal metaplasia associated with chronic pan-gastritis and atrophy is seen. It has greater potential for malignancy as compared to Type A gastritis. Type A gastritis affects the fundus with antral sparing. Its features can be easily remembered by 4 ‘A’s: Autoimmune condition - has circulating antibodies to parietal cell Atrophy of parietal cell ma Achlorhydria - causes chronic hypergastrinemia and microadenomas of enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cell Anemia - leads to pernicious anemia, due to malabsorption of Vit B12 (as the intrinsic factor i also produced by parietal cells)

question_text: Which of the following causes gastritis in patients with AIDS?
explanation: Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) gastritis is secondary to infection with cryptosporidiosis. Granulomatous gastritis is seen rarely in Crohn’s disease and also may be associated with tuberculosis. question_text: What is the most common site of gastric ulcer?
explanation: The most common site of gastric ulcer is the lesser curvature near incisura. Approximately 60% of ulcers are in this location and are classified as type I gastric ulcers. question_text: A biopsy was obtained from a patient with chronic peptic ulcer disease. The pathological slide is given below. Identify the false statement regarding the causative agent of this condition.

Associated with causation of gastric MALToma
Considered by WHO as class I carcinogen
explanation: The given slide shows the GI mucosa, stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, infected with Helicobacter pylori. H. pylori cause hypergastrinemia. question_text: What is the most common complication that you expect in patients suffering from peptic ulcer disease?
explanation: The most common complication of peptic ulcer disease is bleeding, followed by perforation and obstruction. question_text: Which of the following is used for the classification of the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers in a patient with peptic ulcer disease?
explanation: Forrest classification is used for classifying the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers. It stratifies the risk of rebleeding based on observed stigmata of recent hemorrhage. Forrest classification is clinically very significant as it provides prognostic information to the surgeon about the need for endoscopic therapeutic intervention and the risk of rebleeding. question_text: Which of the following is the most commonly involved vessel in patients with bleeding peptic ulcers on the posterior wall?
explanation: The most common vessel responsible for bleeding in peptic ulcer disease is the gastroduodenal artery. Ulcers located in the posterior wall can erode the mucosa and the gastroduodenal artery, leading to hematemesis and melena.

question_text: A 23-year-old woman was admitted to the burns ward with an involvement of 45% of the body surface area. She is at an increased risk of developing ulcers in which of the following parts of the stomach?
explanation: A patient with burn is at risk of developing Curling’s ulcers (stress ulcers). Stress ulcers in the stomach are located most commonly in the fundus. Stress gastritis occurs after a physical trauma, shock, sepsis, hemorrhage, or respiratory failure. It is characterized by multiple superficial (non-ulcerating) erosions that begin in the proximal or acid-secreting portion of the stomach and progress distally. They are almost always seen in the fundus of the stomach and usually develop within 1 to 2 days after a traumatic event. The stress-induced splanchnic vasoconstriction causes systemic hypotension and reduced blood flow leading to mucosal injury. On microscopic examination, they appear as wedge-shaped mucosal hemorrhages, with coagulation necrosis of the superficial mucosal cells. Stress ulcers present as painless upper GI bleeds. Note: Cushing ulcers arise in individuals with intracranial disease. They occur in the stomach, duodenum, and esophagus and carry a high incidence of perforation. They occur due to gastric acid hypersecretion from direct vagal nerve stimulation.

question_text: A 30-year-old actress who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery for obesity, presents with complaints of sweating, palpitations, epigastric fullness, and loose stools which start immediately after meals. Which of the following would you not associate with her condition?
options: It is precipitated by carbohydrate rich food.
It is more common after partial gastrectomy with the Billroth II reconstruction.
It is relieved by lying down.
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of early dumping syndrome. Hypoglycemia■ does not occur in early dumping syndrome. Hypoglycemia is seen in late dumping syndrome secondary to raised insulin levels. Dumping syndrome is a complication occurring post gastrectomy. It can be early or late. Early dumping syndrome is due to the high osmotic load that reaches the small bowel, leading to sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract (GIT). This fluid shift induces autonomic responses. It is characterized by more GI and fewer cardiovascular effects such as: Epigastric fullne Sweating Lightheadedne Tachycardia Diarrhea Symptoms are aggravated by having more food and relieved by lying down. Late dumping syndrome is due to an increase in insulin levels and secondary hypoglycemia. This hypoglycemia causes a catecholamine surge, which results in predominantly cardiovascular effects such as: Diaphoresi Tremulousne Light-headedne Tachycardia Confusion The symptoms are aggravated by exercise and relieved by having food. The principal treatment for both types of dumping syndrome is dietary manipulation. Meals based on fat and protein are known to work the best. Octreotide before meals is useful.

question_text: A patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and recurrent retching with minimal vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. Surgery is performed through a transabdominal approach

No malignant potential

Caused by overexpression of TNF alpha
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds are characteristic of Menetrier’s disease. Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases of Menetrier's disease. Menetrier's disease is a premalignant condition. This results in gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, mucus production, and hypochlorhydria. The antrum is usually spared. There is a loss of albumin (up to 10 g/day), across the gastric mucosa leading to hypoproteinemia. Secondary symptoms include weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema. Histologically, it is characterized by hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance as shown in the image below. question_text: What is the most common site of gastric adenocarcinoma in the Asian population?

question_text: According to the Japanese classification for gastric carcinoma, which of the following is the level 5 lymph node?

question_text: A patient presented with vague abdominal pain and feeling of a lump in the abdomen for the past 1 year. He was found to have a tumor arising from the stomach on CT scan. Biopsy of the lesion showed tumor cells positive for CD117 and CD34. What is the most likely origin of the tumor?
explanation: The clinical and histopathological features are suggestive of gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). They arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal.

question_text: A 45-year-old man presents with epigastric pain and intermittent vomiting for 2 months. He was inadequately treated for H. pylori infection 3 months back. The patient is HIV positive and is on ART for the same. Endoscopy reveals a fungating mass arising from the stomach. Biopsy of the lesion shows tumor cells positive for CD20. Which of the following is false regarding this tumor?
options: Stomach is the most common organ involved.
Fundus is the most common site involved
It is associated with H. pylori infections
explanation: The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of gastric lymphoma. The most common type of gastric lymphoma is non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL). Among NHL, the most common type is diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) (55%), followed by gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, Burkitt lymphoma, mantle cell and follicular lymphoma. Immunodeficiencies and H. pylori infections are risk factors for the development of primary diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The antrum is the most common site for gastric lymphoma. The stomach is the most common organ to develop lymphoma in the GI system. Treatment: Combined modality - chemotherapy, surgery, and/or radiotherapy The most common chemotherapeutic combination for DLBCL is R-CHOP [Rituximab, Cyclophosphamide, Hydroxydaunomycin (doxorubicin), Oncovin (vincristine), prednisone].
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is not an indication for surgery in a patient with gastric lymphoma?
explanation: Intractable pain is not an indication for surgery in the case of gastric lymphoma. Indications for surgery in gastric lymphoma: Patients with symptomatic recurrence or treatment failure Patients who develop complications, such as bleeding, gastric outlet obstruction, and perforation

question_text: A woman underwent a total gastrectomy 5 months ago for gastric carcinoma. Which of the following is the most common metabolic complication expected in her?
explanation: The most common metabolic complication seen after gastrectomy is iron deficiency anemia. Although absorption of iron occurs primarily in the duodenum and proximal jejunum, it needs an optimum acidic environment for absorption. Hence, due to a combination of decreased iron intake, impaired iron absorption, and chronic blood loss, there is iron deficiency anemia. The addition of iron supplements to the patient’s diet corrects iron deficiency anemia. Complications of gastrectomy: Dumping syndrome: early and late Nutritional deficiencies- Iron deficiency anemia (most common), Vit B12 deficiency, and osteoporosis Diarrhea Duodenal stump leak/blow out Bile reflux gastritis and esophagitis Gall stones Roux syndrome

question_text: A 50-year-old male presented with upper GI bleeding, abdominal pain, and a palpable abdominal mass. An endoscopic biopsy revealed a 5 cm tumor, with a high mitotic rate and c-KIT positivity in the body of the stomach. Which of the following is the best treatment of choice?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of GIST with a high risk of malignancy (high mitotic rate). The best treatment modality in the given scenario is surgical resection (with negative margin) followed by imatinib. Imatinib is a tyrosine-kinase inhibitor. Option A: Surgical resection + surveillance is done for GIST with a low risk of malignancy. The risk of malignancy is determined by 2 factors - the size of the tumor and mitotic index. Option C: Lymphadenectomy (D2 gastrectomy) is not done in GIST as it does not show lymph node metastasis. Option D: GIST is radioresistant and does not respond to conventional chemotherapy. It only responds to imatinib. If imatinib resistant, sunitinib or sorafenib is given.

Tegafur

question_text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for bariatric surgery?
options: Failure to lose weight despite psychotherapy
explanation: Failure to lose weight by an obese patient despite psychotherapy, pharmacotherapy, and lifestyle modifications is an indication for metabolic surgery. question_text: For a patient being considered for bariatric surgery, which of the following will you not include when calculating the Obesity Surgery-Mortality risk score (OS-MRS score)?
explanation: Type-2 Diabetes mellitus (DM) is not a component of the Obesity Surgery-Mortality Risk Score (OS-MRS). question_text:
A 40-year-old male patient with a BMI of 42 kg/m² with central obesity is scheduled to undergo bariatric surgery. As preparation for surgery, he is advised to follow a
low-carbohydrate, low-fat, and moderate-protein meal, for two weeks. On follow-up, he is found to be non-compliant with the diet. What is the next best step?
explanation: Psychological re-evaluation is necessary to address the underlying psychological blocks in a patient who is unable to comply with the diet. Morbidly obese individuals, especially those with central obesity, have large livers that make surgery impossible. Liver shrinkage diet helps reduce the size of the liver. This allows mobility for the surgeon and increases the chances of a safer procedure. Liver shrinkage diet: Low-carbohydrate, low-fat and moderate protein diet Started at least 2 weeks prior to the surgery The ability to comply with the diet and lose weight suggests that the patient is willing to make an effort to adopt lifestyle modifications. Failure to do so must arouse suspicion of important underlying psychological blocks, which need addressing.

question_text: Which of the following is not a bariatric surgery?
explanation: Pyloric exclusion with gastrojejunostomy is not a bariatric surgery. It is a technique used in the repair of duodenal and pancreatic injuries. question_text: Which of the following is a reversible bariatric surgery?
explanation: Laparoscopic gastric banding and intra-gastric balloon placement surgeries are considered to be reversible bariatric surgeries. It is because the gastric band or the intragastric balloon can be removed once the desired weight loss or metabolic benefit is achieved. An inflatable band is placed just below the GE junction  A small virtual stomach pouch is created  Reduces hunger (probably vagally mediated)  Reduced consumption of food  Weight loss Complications of LAGB include: Prolapse / Slippage (most common) Band erosion of the stomach wall and rupture Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (highest risk within 1 month of surgery), managed with early ambulation, pressure stockings and LMWH.

question_text: In recent years, what is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery?
explanation: Sleeve gastrectomy is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery, in recent years. A vertical sleeve is created, resecting most of the greater curvature  Restriction of stomach capacity  Early satiety  Reduced consumption of food  Weight loss Advantages of sleeve gastrectomy: Less challenging procedure Preservation of pylorus (avoids gastric dumping) No need for serial adjustments (as seen with gastric banding) Reduction in internal hernias (as seen with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass) Complications of sleeve gastrectomy: Bleed from the staple line Leakage from staple line (close to the angle of His)

question_text: A 40-year-old woman with diabetes and a BMI of 46 kg/m² underwent laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG). On the second postoperative day, she developed fever, tachycardia, and blood reports show leucocytosis. What is the next best step in her management?
options: Send blood for culture and sensitivity
USG abdomen to locate the septic focus
explanation: The given clinical scenario of fever, tachycardia, and leucocytosis in a postoperative patient of LSG should raise suspicion for leak along the gastric staple line. The next best step in the management of this patient is to perform a contrast-enhanced CT. Leaks following LSG most commonly occur in the proximal third of the stomach, close to the angle of His. Early leaks are due to tissue trauma and staple misfire, and late leaks are usually due to ischemia and high intragastric pressure. Management of the leak involves providing nutritional support to the patient and adequate drainage. Once the leak is diagnosed, the patient should be kept nil per oral. Total parenteral nutrition and antibiotic therapy should be started in the patient. Drainage can be done either by CT-guided percutaneous catheter placement, endoscopic stenting, or operative procedures. Note: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is a risk factor for an anastomotic leak. Treatment with continuous positive airway pressure might reduce this risk.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Roux-en-Y gastric bypass in bariatric surgery?
options: Gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature.
Biliary limb is 100-150 cm in length
It is a purely restrictive type of procedure.
explanation: Gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature in Roux-en-Y gastric bypass. A small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature  Create a shorter biliary limb of 30 - 50 cm (duodenum); Create a longer Roux limb of 75 - 150 cm (jejunum)  Bowel continuity is restored by a Y - jejunojejunostomy  Restrictive + Malabsorptive mechanism  Weight loss Note: Biliary limb is usually kept short (30-50 cm) in order to reduce vitamin and mineral deficiencies.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 38-year-old woman presented to the casualty with vomiting and severe colicky pain in the abdomen for the past 48 hours. She had undergone a weight reduction surgery six months ago and had achieved around 30% weight loss. Her plain X-ray abdomen is given below.
Which of the following bariatric procedures was most likely done in this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and radiograph (dilated bowel segments with valvulae conniventes in the left upper quadrant) are suggestive of small bowel obstruction. Bariatric surgery, specifically, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery is associated with the creation of mesenteric defects. The small bowel can herniate through these defects (internal hernia) and get strangulated, resulting in bowel obstruction. In addition, as the person loses weight (due to the bariatric procedure), the protective, space-occupying effect of the mesenteric fat is lost and hernia spaces open up, further increasing the risk of internal hernia. The laparoscopic procedure has a higher risk compared to open surgery since fewer adhesions form to tether small-bowel loops and prevent them from herniating. Adequate closure of the mesenteric defects by the surgeon at the time of operation significantly reduces the risk of internal hernia. Other complications specific to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass: Nutritional deficiencies: iron (most common), folate, Vitamin A, D, K and B12 Anastomosis site leak Bleeding from the site of gastrojejunostomy Dumping syndrome Marginal ulcers Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism Option A: Sleeve gastrectomy is often complicated by staple line leak. Option B: Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding is associated with band slippage and erosion. Option D: Endoluminal stapling is also used to create a gastric sleeve. It is associated with postoperative nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and transient dysphagia.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient who previously underwent biliopancreatic diversion surgery has been having excessive malabsorption and is now being planned for a revisional procedure to increase the length of the common channel. What is the usual length of the common channel?
explanation: The usual length of the common channel in biliopancreatic diversion (BPD) is 50 cm (0.5 m). Revisions increase common channel by up to 150 cm. The length of the common channel plays a significant role in the amount of weight loss achieved with BPD procedure. A shorter common channel implies a greater length of the bypassed small bowel. This induces more malabsorption and thereby greater weight loss. Distal hemigastrectomy is performed to create a residual gastric pouch  Terminal ileum is divided 250 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve  Gastroileostomy: Proximal anastomosis between the distal end of divided ileum and residual gastric pouch  Ileoileostomy: Distal anastomosis between the proximal end of divided ileum and terminal ileum  A common channel of 50 cm is established  Malabsorption  Weight loss Prophylactic cholecystectomy is usually performed since there is an increased incidence of gallstones due to malabsorption of bile salts. Complications of biliopancreatic diversion surgery: Anastomosis site leak Nutritional deficiencies: Iron; folate; vitamins A, D, K, and B12 Marginal ulcers Bleeding Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (maximum risk within 1 month of surgery), managed with early ambulation, pressure stocking, and LMWH
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is not a surgical step that will be done during a duodenal switch procedure?
explanation: In duodenal switch (DS) surgery, gastroduodenostomy is not performed. Sleeve gastrectomy is performed  Duodenum is divided 2 cm beyond the pylorus; Terminal ileum is divided 250 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve  Duodenoileostomy: Proximal anastomosis between the distal end of divided ileum and duodenum  Ileoileostomy: Distal anastomosis between the proximal end of divided ileum and terminal ileum  A common channel of 100 cm is established  Malabsorption  Weight loss Prophylactic cholecystectomy is usually performed since there is an increased incidence of gallstones due to malabsorption of bile salts. Complications of duodenal switch surgery: Anastomosis site leak and bleeding Nutritional deficiencies - Iron, folate, Vitamin A, D, K and B12 Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (maximum risk within 1 month of surgery) - managed with early ambulation, pressure stocking, and LMWH In comparison to BPD, the incidence of marginal ulcers is negligible

question_text: What is the most common cause of death in patients who undergo bariatric surgery?

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the surgical anatomy of the small intestine?
options: The duodenum is demarcated from the jejunum by the ligament of Treitz.
The ileum makes up three-fifths of the small intestine.
The blood supply to the jejunum may have four or five separate arcades with shorter vasa recta
The jejunum has a larger circumference, is thicker than the ileum
explanation: The jejunum receives its blood supply from long, straight vasa recta arising from only one or two arcades. The blood supply to the ileum may have 4-5 separate arcades with shorter vasa recta. The ligament of Treitz or the suspensory muscle of the duodenum is found at the junction of the duodenum and jejunum. It also forms the line of demarcation for gastrointestinal bleeding: Upper GI bleeding - refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz Lower GI bleeding - refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.
