question_text:
A 42-year-old man with past history of inguinal hernia presented with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain that started 4 hours ago. His abdomen was tender and rigid along with a
lump in the inguinal region with purplish skin changes. Which of the following is the ideal management for this patient?
options: Resuscitative measures and arrange for immediate laparotomy
Conservative management with a nasogastric tube and IV fluid, assessment every 24 hrs
Perform an oral contrast study, followed by pneumatic decompression
explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of intestinal obstruction, due to a strangulated inguinal hernia. The ideal management is exploratory laparotomy as soon as possible with ongoing resuscitative measures until surgery. Bowel strangulation is a type of mechanical bowel obstruction, associated with complete cessation of blood supply leading to irreversible loss of viability of the affected bowel segment. Inguinal hernias, most commonly of non-reducible type, are associated with a high chance of strangulation and need urgent medical intervention. Bowel strangulation can be suspected in the presence of constant severe abdominal pain, abdominal tenderness with rigidity and peritonism, signs of shock, and lack of response to conservative management. Reduced bowel wall enhancement on CT When strangulation occurs in an external hernia, the lump is tense, tender, and irreducible with overlying skin changes (erythema or purplish discoloration). Supportive management: IV fluids Nasogastric tube to decompress the bowel and reduce abdominal distention IV antibiotics (adequate coverage required for gram -ve and anaerobes) Analgesia Definitive management: Continue supportive management up to 72 hrs if suspicious of adhesions. Surgical exploration and adhesiolysis should be done if there is no improvement. Immediate surgical exploration and resection of non-viable gut segments if suspicious of any of the following: Obstructed external hernia Clinical features suspicious of intestinal strangulation Obstruction in a ‘virgin’ abdomen (i.e no prior history of intraabdominal surgery)
subject: Surgery

question_text: A surgeon sees a necrotic bowel when operating on a child for an inguinal hernia. What is true about the resection and anastomosis of the bowel?
options: The surgeon must use chromic catgut
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures
The surgeon must use the single-layer, extramucosal suture technique
The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique
explanation: The standard technique used currently for resection anastomosis of the bowel is a one-layer extra mucosal suture technique since it causes the least tissue necrosis and luminal narrowing. Interrupted and continuous single-layer suture techniques are adequate and safe. The extra mucosal suture must also include the submucosa because this layer has a high collagen content and it is the most stable suture layer in all sections of the gastrointestinal tract. Catgut has now been replaced with absorbable synthetic polymers. Stapling devices can be used when speed is required.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 5-year-old child who underwent an appendicectomy is brought to the emergency with abdominal distension and vomiting. The mother tells that the child passed stools that looked like currant jelly. The ultrasound finding is shown below. What is the most likely location of this pathology in this child?
explanation: The clinical vignette and the USG showing the doughnut sign (target sign) are suggestive of postoperative intussusception and the most likely location is ileoileal in postoperative cases. Intussusception occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The most common location of intussusception is ileocolic. However, ileoileal is the most common location of intussusception postoperatively and in Henoch–Schönlein Purpura. Causes of intussusception are: Idiopathic (most common cause in children) Pathological lead points such as enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch, lymphoma, intestinal polyp, eiomyomas, etc. Meckel's diverticulum A recent upper GI or respiratory infection, rotavirus vaccination has also shown some association with intussusception in children. The characteristic clinical triad includes: Pain Palpable sausage-shaped mass Red currant jelly stools USG findings in intussusception include: Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)- The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic (submucosa and serosa) with hypoechogenic bands (muscularis propria). Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel: the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles the renal hilum. Crescent in a doughnut sign. Barium enema shows the characteristic coiled spring appearance. Treatment: Reduction of intussusception should be done immediately after the diagnosis. Radiologic hydrostatic reduction has a success rate of 80-95% in cases of ileocolic intussusception Surgical reduction is only done in the presence of refractory shock, suspected bowel necrosis or perforation, peritonitis, and multiple recurrences. The above image shows the coiled spring appearance
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. An erect X-ray of the abdomen is done and shown below. The neonate is taken up for surgery and an
apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is seen. Which type of ileal atresia has this feature?
explanation: The given image showing a triple bubble appearance and associated finding of apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is a feature of type 3 ileal atresia. Small bowel atresias present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth. Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia whereas abdominal distension is more with ileal atresia. Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction. Jejunal/ileal atresia - Triple bubble appearance Duodenal atresia - Double bubble appearance A contrast study is the next best investigation to exclude other bowel anomalies. In jejunal/ileal atresia, the distal end of the dilated proximal small bowel is resected and a primary end-to-end anastomosis is possible. If the proximal bowel is extremely dilated, it may need to be tapered to the distal bowel before anastomosis. Classification of Jejunoileal atresia: Type Feature Type 1 Mucosal web or diaphragm Type 2 With an atretic cord between two blind ends of bowel with intact mesentery Type 3 a Complete separation of the bl ind ends of the bowel by a V- shaped mesenteric gap Type 3 b Anapple peelorChristmas tre e deformitywith a large mese nteric gap Type 4 Multiple atresias, with a strin g of sausage appearance
subject: Surgery

question_text: A child with complaints of abdominal pain and vomiting for the past 24 hours associated with tenderness over McBurney's point undergoes open appendicectomy. However, during surgery, the appendix was found to be normal. On exploration of the ileum, the following finding is seen. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
options: It is a lead point for intussusception
Gastric mucosa is the most common heterotropic tissue
Located 60 cm proximal to ileocecal valve
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Meckel’s diverticulitis. It arises from the antimesenteric border of the small intestine. Meckel’s diverticulum is the most commonly encountered congenital anomaly of the small intestine. Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct or omphalomesenteric duct that develops during weeks 5 to 7 of gestation. It contains all 3 layers of the intestine and hence it is a true diverticulum. It is located 45 to 60 cm proximal to the ileocecal valve. The most common heterotopic tissue within the Meckel’s diverticulum is gastric mucosa (50%) followed by pancreatic mucosa(5%) and colonic mucosa. Most Meckel’s diverticula are benign and are incidentally discovered. Its clinical features include: Gastrointestinal bleeding (most common) Intestinal obstruction, which may occur as: Volvulus Intussusception (ileo-ileal or ileo-colic) Incarcerated Littre’s hernia. Complications of Meckel's diverticulum are: Diverticulitis - presents like appendicitis Perforation - resembles a perforated duodenal ulcer Peritonitis Neoplasms - neuroendocrine tumour (most common) > adenocarcinoma > GIST > ymphoma.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common presentation of Meckel’s diverticulum?
explanation: The most common presentation of Meckel’s diverticulum is lower gastrointestinal bleeding. Clinical features of Meckel's diverticulum include: Lower GI bleeding (most common in children and overall) Abdominal pain Vomiting Another common presentation is an intestinal obstruction (most common in adults), which may occur due to: Volvulus Intussusception (ileo-ileal or ileo-colic) Incarcerated Littre’s hernia.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following cannot be used to increase the sensitivity of the Tc-pertechnate scan in Meckel's diverticulum?
explanation: Metoclopramide is not used to increase the sensitivity of the Tc-pertechnate scan in Meckel's diverticulum. Metoclopramide stimulates gastric motility and decreases the time available for the uptake of Tc-pertechnate. Hence it reduces sensitivity. 99mTc-pertechnetate is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of the gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue. The sensitivity of the Tc-pertechnate scan is increased by: Glucagon: Relaxes the smooth muscles of the gastrointestinal tract. This decreases peristalsis, causing enhanced detection of the ectopic gastric mucosa in Meckel's diverticulum Pentagastrin: Potent stimulator of gastric secretions. Increases uptake and secretion of pertechnetate by the gastric mucosa Cimetidine: Increases radionuclide uptake, and decreases peptic secretion and the release of pertechnetate from the diverticular lumen. This results in higher radionuclide concentrations in the wall of the diverticulum.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What will be the investigation of choice in a child suspected to have Meckel’s diverticula?
explanation: The investigation of choice in a child suspected to have Meckel's diverticulum is a 99mTc-pertechnetate radionuclide scan. The radionucleotide is preferentially taken up by the mucus-secreting cells of the gastric mucosa and ectopic gastric tissue in the diverticulum. In adults, there is a reduced prevalence of ectopic gastric mucosa. Hence it is less accurate and barium studies are preferred. The image below depicts a 99mTc radionuclide scan showing Meckel’s diverticulum. Most of the Meckel’s diverticula are discovered incidentally. In the absence of bleeding, Meckel’s diverticula are rarely diagnosed prior to the time of surgical intervention. Other investigations for Meckel's diverticulum: Angiography is used to locate the site of bleeding in an acute hemorrhage. CT scan has a very low sensitivity. Enteroclysis has an accuracy of 75% but is usually not applicable during acute presentations.
subject: Surgery

question_text: While performing an inguinal hernia repair in a 3-year-old boy, you notice Meckel’s diverticulum as the content of the hernial sac. What is this hernia called?
explanation: Meckel’s diverticulum found in inguinal or femoral hernial sacs is known as Littre's hernia. It can cause intestinal obstruction. Option A: Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix. Option B: Narath’s hernia is seen in patients with congenital dislocation of the hip. It is a femoral hernia seen behind the femoral vessels. Option C: Cloquet’s hernia is a type of femoral hernia where the sac lies under the pectineus fascia.
subject: Surgery

question_text: While performing a laparotomy, the surgeon incidentally notices a narrow-mouthed, thickened Meckel’s diverticulum. What is the treatment of choice?
explanation: In a narrow-mouthed, thickened Meckel’s diverticulum, resection of the diverticulum is the treatment of choice. When Meckel's diverticulum is found in the course of abdominal surgery: In cases of narrow-mouthed, thickened Meckel’s diverticulum, resection of the diverticulum is the treatment of choice If it has a wide mouth and is not thickened, it can safely be left alone. Rarely, Meckel's diverticulum is complicated by a meso-diverticular band, which is believed to be a remnant of a vitelline artery. In such symptomatic cases, the treatment is diverticulectomy with the removal of associated bands connecting the diverticulum to the abdominal wall or intestinal mesentery. Segmental resection of the ileum that includes both the diverticulum and the adjacent ileal peptic ulcer should be performed if: There is bleeding from the diverticulum The base is inflamed or perforated The diverticulum contains a tumour.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common site for acquired diverticula in the small intestine?
explanation: The most common site for acquired diverticula in the small intestine is the second part of the duodenum (Windsock's diverticulum). The colon is the most common site for acquired/false diverticula overall, followed by the duodenum. Meckel’s diverticulum is the most common true congenital diverticulum of the small bowel. A barium swallow showing a well-defined diverticulum in the second part of the duodenum (Windsock's diverticulum) is shown below.

question_text: A 38-year-old man presents with dull aching abdominal pain for the past few weeks accompanied by loss of weight and appetite. A barium meal follow-through image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the barium study showing a shrunken caecum pulled-up away from the right iliac fossa is most likely suggestive of intestinal tuberculosis. The most common site of intestinal tuberculosis is the distal ileum and cecum. The yellow color arrow marks indicate the shrunken caecum, stricturous narrowing of the terminal ileum and ileocaecal junction, and proximal ileal dilatation.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A respiratory therapist presents to the OPD with abdominal pain. He also complains of low-grade fever, night sweats, and loss of weight. You investigate him for intestinal tuberculosis. Which of the following radiological signs are expected to be seen in him?
explanation: Creeping fat sign and apple core sign are not the radiological findings seen in intestinal tuberculosis. The creeping fat sign refers to the widely separated bowel loops due to fibrofatty proliferation seen in Crohn's disease. The apple core sign describes a short segment irregular circumferential stricture of the large bowel that has abrupt shouldered margins resembling an apple core. This appearance is classically seen in a stenosing annular colon carcinoma.

question_text: A young man presented with pain abdomen, diarrhoea, and fever gradually increasing in a step ladder pattern over the past 2 weeks. A Widal test confirmed the diagnosis and he was admitted. A few days later, he developed intestinal perforation and was taken up for exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following findings would you see in this patient?
explanation: Typhoid causes longitudinal ulcers. Typhoid fever is caused by Salmonella typhi. It presents with step-ladder fever and abdominal pain after an incubation period of 10–20 days. Over the next week, the patient can develop: Distension Diarrhoea Splenomegaly Characteristic rose spots on the abdomen caused by a vasculitis Surgical complications of typhoid are: Paralytic ileus Intestinal haemorrhage Free ileal perforation (characteristically occurs during the third week of the illness) Cholecystitis Longitudinal ulcers (usually situated in the distal ileum) Diagnosis of typhoid is confirmed by culture of blood or stool. Treatment is by antibiotics, usually chloramphenicol. Perforation requires surgery to wash out and close the ulcer. Intestinal resection is usually avoided. In unstable patients, with evidence of septic shock, the bowel should be exteriorized and the perforation closed after recovery. Paratyphoid infection also resembles typhoid fever and is treated in a similar manner. Note: Transverse ulcers with stricture formation are seen in tuberculosis.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A lady underwent a left hemicolectomy for colon cancer 5 days back. She now complains of abdominal discomfort and bloating. She is still unable to pass gas. On examination, the abdomen is distended and no bowel sounds are heard. X-ray shows gas-filled loops of
the intestine with multiple air fluid levels. Which of the following will be part of the management plan of the patient?
explanation: The given post-op scenario after 72 hours of laparotomy with no passage of flatus, absent bowel sounds, and X-ray findings are suggestive of paralytic ileus. Initiation of oral intake and emergency laparotomy is not done in paralytic ileus. The return of normal motility post-surgery occurs in the following sequence: Small intestine (within the first 24 hours)  Stomach (within 48 hours)  Colon (3 to 5 days). Paralytic ileus is an adynamic/functional obstruction in which there is a failure of transmission of peristaltic waves. This is secondary to neuromuscular failure in the myenteric (Auerbach’s) and submucous (Meissner’s) plexuses. Since there are no rigorous contractions, there is no colicky pain. The resultant stasis leads to the following clinical features: Abdominal distension - marked and tympanitic Effortless vomiting Absence of bowel sounds Absolute constipation Paralytic ileus takes on clinical significance if any of the following are observed at 72 hours after laparotomy after handling of the bowel: No return of bowel sounds on auscultation No passage of flatus Radiologically, the abdomen shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple air fluid levels in an erect X-ray. A CT scan is more accurate for differentiating functional from mechanical obstruction Paralytic ileus is managed by nasogastric tube decompression and restriction of oral intake until bowel sounds and the passage of flatus return. Electrolyte balance must be maintained.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 22-year-old male presents with purulent discharge from the umbilicus. He underwent laparoscopic appendicectomy 6 months back. X-ray sinogram of the patient reveals an enterocutaneous fistula tract as shown below. Which of the following aids in the spontaneous
closure of the fistula?
options: Foreign body in the fistula tract
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the X-ray sinogram showing a fistula tract connecting the skin opening and the small intestine are suggestive of an enterocutaneous fistula. In this case, it is most likely due to the umbilical port used during appendicectomy. Fistula track length >2.5 cms is likely to heal. Enterocutaneous fistulas of length <2.5 cm are unlikely to heal and close. Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified according to their location and volume of daily output. These factors determine the treatment and mortality rates. Proximal fistulas are associated with higher output, greater fluid and electrolyte loss. Distal fistulas tend to have lower output, making them easier to manage and more likely to close spontaneously. Type of fistula Output/da y High-output fistula >500 mL Intermediate fistul a 200 - 500 mL Low-output fistula <200 mL
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 25-year-old man, who underwent exploratory laparotomy for acute abdomen develops a fever on the 5th postoperative day. The sutured site is erythematous and on the removal of two skin sutures, there is a leakage of gastrointestinal contents through the wound. An electrolyte panel done shows hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic acidosis. What is the probable diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of an enterocutaneous fistula. From the electrolyte panel showing hyponatremia, hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis, a diagnosis of duodenal fistula can be made. The electrolyte abnormalities with gastric fistula are hypochloremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified according to their location and volume of daily output. Proximal fistulas are associated with higher output, greater fluid, and electrolyte loss, and greater loss of digestive capacity. Distal fistulas tend to have lower output, making them easier to manage and more likely to close spontaneously. Although both gastric and duodenal fistulas are proximal fistulas, duodenal fistulas receive an additional 1 to 2 litres of enzymes, electrolytes, and water from the pancreatic and bile ducts. Hence duodenal fistulas are at greater risk for more electrolyte imbalance than gastric fistulas. The management of enterocutaneous fistula is based on well-established principles known as SNAP which includes: S - Sepsis elimination and skin protection N - A period of parenteral nutrition may well be required A - Anatomical assessment P - Definitive planned surgery
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 26-year-old bride-to-be presented with nausea, vomiting, and recurrent episodes of postprandial epigastric pain. She has lost nearly 25 kgs in the last 6 months to look good in her wedding dress. Proton pump inhibitors were tried but were unsuccessful. A barium meal
follow-through of the patient is given below. Which of the following is false about her condition?
options: Weight gain is part of the management
Lying in prone position postprandially improves symptoms
The second part of duodenum is commonly involved
explanation: The false statement about her condition is that the second part of the duodenum is commonly involved. The given clinical scenario with rapid weight loss and the barium follow-through demonstrating dilation of the duodenum with an abrupt cut-off at its third part, coinciding with the line of the superior mesenteric artery is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome. The third part of the duodenum is involved in SMA syndrome. SMA syndrome (also known as Wilkie's syndrome) is usually seen in young asthenic women. It is a rare condition characterized by compression of the third portion of the duodenum by the SMA against fixed retroperitoneal structures. SMA syndrome is associated with: Rapid childhood growth Profound weight loss Abdominal surgery Inflammatory diseases of the abdomen Short ligament of Treitz Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis (cast syndrome) Its clinical features include: Episodic vomiting Profound nausea Abdominal distention Postprandial epigastric pain Upper gastrointestinal barium swallow or hypotonic duodenography demonstrates abrupt or near-total cut-off of the flow of barium from the duodenum to the jejunum. CT and magnetic resonance (MR) arteriography can also be used for additional anatomical detail. The normal aortomesenteric angle is between 28-65°. This is reduced to less than 25° in SMA syndrome. A CT scan showing the reduced aortomesenteric angle is given below: In SMA syndrome, initial conservative management includes: Frequent small feedings Lying in a prone position or on the left side postprandially Weight gain (to increase mesenteric fat pad and thereby increase the aorto-mesenteric angle) Removal of a body cast in cast syndrome Laparoscopic lysis of the ligament of Treitz is beneficial in few cases. If all the above treatments fail, duodenojejunostomy is done.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young male, who wishes to pursue his higher studies abroad gets a chest X-ray done as a part of the immigration clearance. X-ray shows air under bilateral domes of the diaphragm. He is currently asymptomatic with normal vital signs. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with an asymptomatic patient having air under the diaphragm without evidence of peritonitis (sterile pneumoperitoneum) is suggestive of pneumatosis intestinalis. Pneumatosis intestinalis presents as multiple gas-filled cysts of the gastrointestinal tract. It is usually located in the subserosa, submucosa, and rarely the muscularis layer. The common sites are jejunum > ileocecal region > colon. It represents one of the few cases of sterile pneumoperitoneum. Pneumatosis in neonates is usually associated with necrotizing enterocolitis. Predisposing factors include: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease Immunocompromised state Inflammatory, obstructive, or infectious conditions of the intestine Endoscopy and jejunostomy Ischemia Diabetes Patients can be asymptomatic. Symptoms if present, is usually nonspecific like: Diarrhoea Abdominal pain Abdominal distention Nausea, vomiting Weight loss Mucus in stoo Diagnosis can be made on the basis of: Plain X-ray showing radiolucent areas within the bowel wall (appear as grape-like clusters or tiny bubbles) Barium contrast CT studies Treatment involves: Management of the uncomplicated primary disease. When symptoms demand treatment, the first line is intermittent high flow oxygen therapy, providing a concentration of 70% continuously for 5 days by nasal specula. The cysts may also resolve with antibiotics, particularly metronidazole. In resistant cases, maintenance treatment with sulfasalazine may be helpful. The prognosis in most patients is that of the underlying disease.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 55-year-old man with IHD presents with sudden, severe, generalized abdominal pain and multiple episodes of vomiting. On examination, the pulse rate is 118bpm, rhythm is irregularly irregular, BP is 90/60 mmHg. The abdomen appears soft, non-distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following could be a likely diagnosis in this case?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a patient with sudden onset severe abdominal pain which is out-of-proportion to the physical examination findings along with atrial fibrillation is suggestive of acute mesenteric ischemia. Mesenteric ischemia may be acute or chronic. The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) is most likely affected. An embolus is the most common cause of SMA occlusion. Possible sources for SMA emboisation include: Left atrium in atrial fibrillation Previous history of ischemic heart disease/myocardial infarction Vegetations on mitral and aortic valves associated with endocarditis An atheromatous plaque from an aortic aneurysm. Other causes of mesenteric ischemia include: Atherosclerosis of mesenteric vessels Vasculitides Venous thrombosis in factor V Leiden mutation Non-occlusive mesenteric ischemia due to alterations in splanchnic blood flow. The most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated clinical features include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and the passage of bloody stools. The gold standard for the diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is angiography, and management is laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to resect the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy. Other options: Option B: A pulsatile abdominal mass is seen in the case of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Acute pain and hypotension occur with rupture of the aneurysm, which requires an emergency operation. Options A and D: Acute severe pancreatitis and peptic ulcer perforation have no association with atrial fibrillation. They usually present with pain over the upper abdomen associated with guarding and rigidity on examination.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the minimum dose of radiation that can cause radiation enteritis of the small intestine?
explanation: The minimum radiation dose in the small intestine that can cause radiation enteritis is 4500cGy. Radiation enteritis is a common complication of radiation treatment aimed at the abdomen and pelvis. It causes diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and stomach cramps. The amount of radiation appears to correlate with the probability of the development of radiation enteritis. In general, serious late complications are unusual if the total radiation dosage is less than 4000 cGy. Morbidity risk increases with dosages exceeding 5000 cGy. The table below shows various parts of GIT and the radiation doses that can cause enteritis. Part of GIT Radiation dose (in cGy) Esophagus 6000 to 7500 Part of GIT Radiation dose (in cGy) Part of GIT Radiation dose (in cGy) Stomach 4500 to 5000 Small intestine & colon 4500 to 6500 Rectum 5500 to 8000
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient who is a known case of Crohn's disease underwent ileal resection for a stricture. Which of the following is not a part of the management of postoperative complications in this patient?
explanation: Administration of folic acid is done in jejunal resection. Ileal resection causes vitamin B12 deficiency which requires administration of parenteral vitamin B12. Extensive resection of the small intestine (<150 cm of remaining small intestine) can result in metabolic and nutritional consequences. This is known as short bowel syndrome. The presentation of the patient is dependent upon the site and extent of intestinal resection. The ileum is the only site of absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts. Following resection of the ileum, the loss of bile salts increases resulting in fat malabsorption and diarrhea. Other complications of resection include: Peptic ulcers - Due to gastric hypersecretion Cholelithiasis - Due to interruption of the enterohepatic cycle of bile salts Initial treatment priorities include repletion of fluid and electrolytes lost in severe diarrhoea by initiating TPN. Long-term management involves: Administration of oral cholestyramine to bind with bile salts Dietary fat restriction Parenteral vitamin B12 Proton pump inhibitors to lower gastric pH Octreotide to reduce the volume of GI secretions Antimotility agents such as loperamide hydrochloride to delay small-intestinal transit Small intestine lengthening procedures done to increase absorption and transit time are: Longitudinal intestinal lengthening and tailoring procedure (LILT) Serial transverse enteroplasty procedure (STEP) Intestinal transplantation is indicated only in complicated cases.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is true about the Tillaux sign?
options: Mass is felt in the periumbilical region
Mass is mobile perpendicular to mesentery attachment line
explanation: Tillaux's sign is said to be positive if the mass/swelling is mobile perpendicular to the mesentery attachment line. Tillaux’s sign is seen in a mesenteric cyst. Mesenteric cysts occur either in the small intestine (60%) or the colon (40%) and can be classified as the following: Chylolymphatic (most common type) Enterogenous Urogenital remnant Dermoid Other causes: traumatic hematoma and cyst formation, tuberculous cold abscess of mesentery and hydatid cyst of the mesentery They most commonly occur in adults with a mean age of 45 years. It is more common in females than males (2:1). The most common presentation is a painless abdominal swelling near the umbilicus, which is smooth and not moving with respiration with Tillaux's triad: Soft, smooth swelling in the umbilical region Freely mobile in a direction perpendicular to the mesentery (Tillaux's sign) Zone of resonance around the cyst Other presentations include recurrent attacks of abdominal pain due to temporary impaction of a food bolus in a segment of the bowel narrowed by the cyst and vomiting. Complications of mesenteric cyst include torsion, rupture, infection and hemorrhage into the cyst. U trasonography and CT are used to demonstrate mesenteric cysts. Treatment: Chlyolymphatic cyst is managed by enucleation. Enterogenous cyst is managed by removal of the cyst with resection of the adjacent bowel as it arises as a diverticulum or duplication from the adjacent bowel. In cases where complete excision is not possible due to the close proximity to vital structures, partial excision or marsupialization should be performed.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the investigation of choice in a patient suspected to have a small bowel tumor?
explanation: Enteroclysis is the investigation of choice in patients with small bowel tumours. Enteroclysis is a barium study in which the contrast agent is put directly into the duodenum through a nasogastric tube. Continued infusion of 500 to 1000 mL of thin barium sulfate and methylcellulose suspension is done and then viewed continuously with the use of either fluoroscopy or radiographs taken at frequent intervals. This technique is a double-contrast procedure that allows detailed imaging of the entire small intestine. Enteroclysis has a sensitivity of over 90% in the detection of small bowel tumours and is the investigation of choice, particularly for tumours located in the distal small bowel. Advantages of enteroclysis: The contrast is administered at a controlled rate directly in the small bowel, bypassing the regulatory action of the pylorus. The entire small bowel is demonstrated in a distended state, allowing better diagnosis. As a result of the dilatation, the following can be visualised: Mild strictures Small sinus tracts and fistulas Minimal extrinsic compressions Skip lesions Proximal and distal extent of diffuse diseases. The examination can be completed in 15–30 minutes, thus reducing patient waiting time.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 45-year-old man presents with complaints of breathlessness, dull aching abdominal pain, and diarrhea. On examination, his face and chest appear flushed. CT scan of the abdomen shows a tumor in the terminal ileum with liver metastasis. An increased levels of 5-HIAA is seen in a 24-hour urinary sample. Which of the following is false regarding the management of this patient?
options: Surgery should be done as soon as the diagnosis is made.
MRI is the best method for staging of the disease.
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of carcinoid syndrome caused by a carcinoid tumour. The best method for the staging of a carcinoid tumour is the octreotide scan. They are neuroendocrine tumours of the gastrointestinal tract. They arise from the enterochromaffin cells. They metastasize early to the regional lymph nodes and the liver. Abdominal symptoms include: Pain Abdominal distension Lower GI bleeding Metastasis in these patients can cause increased production of serotonin leading to carcinoid syndrome with features like: Flushing Diarrhoea Bronchospasm Cardiac symptoms because of stenosis and insufficiency of the cardiac valves The diagnosis is made by an assessment of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) in a 24-hour urine sample. It is positive in larger tumours only if metastases are present. U trasonography, CT scan, and MRI may show the primary tumour and metastases. The best method for staging carcinoid tumours is by octreotide scan or somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS). Treatment: Somatostatin and its analogues are used in the symptomatic treatment of carcinoid syndrome. Surgery should be undertaken as soon as the diagnosis is made, even in the presence of liver metastases. Resection of the primary tumour and mesenteric lymph node metastases is done. In the presence of liver metastasis - liver resection, transarterial embolization (TAE), chemoembolization (TACE), chemotherapy, and liver transplantation can be done.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is a false statement about abdominal lymphoma?
options: MALT lymphoma is associated with H.pylori infection.
Primary small-intestinal lymphomas are most commonly located in the jejunum.
Lymphoma is the most common malignant neoplasm of spleen.
Stomach is the most common site for extranodal lymphoma.
explanation: Primary small-intestinal lymphomas are most commonly located in the ileum. Option A: Primary gastric lymphomas are derived from B-cells and classified as diffuse large B-cell lymphomas (DLBCL) and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT). Both DLBCL and MALT are thought to be associated with chronic Helicobacter pylori infection. This linkage is better established for MALT, whereas the association between H. pylori infection and DLBCL is more controversial. Option C: Lymphoma is the most common malignant neoplasm of the spleen. Option D: Gastric lymphoma accounts for the majority of extranodal lymphomas, representing approximately 50–75% of primary gastrointestinal lymphomas.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
Which of the following statements is false regarding lymphoma of the small intestine?
B-cell lymphomas are chemo-resistant
options: It is the most common tumour of the small intestine in children
Resection is indicated in all symptomatic patients
Burkitt’s lymphoma affects the ileocaecal junction
explanation: B-cell lymphomas are chemo-sensitive. T-cell lymphomas are chemo-resistant. Approximately one-third of GI lymphomas occur in the small bowel. In the small intestine, most commonly they are found in the ileum. In children <10 years, lymphomas are the most common intestinal neoplasm. In adults, they constitute up to 25% of small bowel malignant tumours. Patients with celiac disease and immunodeficiency are at increased risk for the development of primary small intestine lymphomas. Clinical features include: Pain Weight loss Nausea Vomiting Bleeding Change in bowel habits Intestinal obstruction Small intestine lymphomas are usually larger than 5 cm. They may extend into the mucosa. Microscopic examination shows diffuse infiltration of the intestinal wall. In the absence of symptoms, they are often chemo-responsive and do not require surgery. In symptomatic patients, resection is indicated. B-cell lymphomas are more chemosensitive and have high remission rates, with or without surgery. T-cell lymphomas are more resistant to therapy and will progress to symptoms of obstruction or perforation if not resected. Small intestine lymphomas cause complications like haemorrhage and perforation. The best prognostic indicator is a response to systemic therapy. The five-year survival rate is 50% to 60% Note: The stomach (50–75%) is the most common site of lymphomas in the gastrointestinal system. Burkitt’s lymphoma can aggressively affect the ileocaecal region. Lymphoma is the most common malignant neoplasm of the spleen. Large Intestine
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the earliest sign in Crohn's disease?
explanation: Aphthous ulcers, surrounded by a rim of erythematous mucosa, are the earliest lesions seen in a patient with Crohn's disease during endoscopy. Crohn's colitis usually spares the rectum and is most severe in the ileocaecal region. In early Crohn's disease, small, punched-out aphthous ulcers are often seen (the result of submucosal lymphoid follicle expansion). In moderate disease, the aphthous ulcers coalesce into larger ulcers, which may take on the appearance of a star (stellate ulcers). As disease severity increases, submucosal edema and injury can result in cobblestoning of the mucosa (option A) and eventually the formation of serpiginous ulcers, which are typical findings in Crohn's disease. Thorn-like extraluminal projections in barium studies are known as rose-thorn appearance, and are a typical sign of Crohn's disease. They represent deep penetrating linear ulcers or fissurings typically seen within stenosed terminal ileum with a thickened wall. (Options C and D)
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about Crohn's disease?
options: For effective treatment of a Crohn's mass, only antibiotics are prescribed.
Symptomatic relapse after surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection.
The proximal ileum is most commonly involved in Crohn's disease.
On endoscopic examination, continuous lesions are visualised, which are diagnostic of Crohn's disease.
explanation: Symptomatic relapse of Crohn's disease after surgery is not related to the presence of the disease during resection. The course of the disease after surgery is unpredictable since surgery does not cure Crohn's disease. Instead, the probability of relapse increases with the time since resection. Other options: Option A: Antibiotics alone cannot treat a Crohn's mass effectively. Abscesses can be treated with metronidazole and ciprofloxacin and should also undergo drainage (and resection if needed). Option C: The terminal ileum is most commonly involved in Crohn's disease. Option D: On endoscopic examination, discontinuous "skip" lesions are visualized. These are irregular areas of inflamed mucosa that are ulcerated with mucopurulent exudate separated by intervening, normal-appearing intestinal mucosa.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with a 9-month history of weight loss, abdominal cramps, and intermittent diarrhea. On examination, a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen is found. Stool cultures are normal. Colonoscopy shows the presence of skip lesions. Biopsy showed the presence of non-caseating granulomas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical scenario and the biopsy showing the presence of non-caseating granulomas are diagnostic of Crohn's disease.
