question_text:
A 28-year-old patient was brought to the casualty ward with high fever and pain abdomen. He had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. His past history was negative for
long-term medications and previous surgeries. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical scenario and the radiograph are suggestive of toxic megacolon. Toxic megacolon may present with fever, abdominal pain, and abdominal distension. Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations. It is usually associated with ulcerative colitis as indicated by history of chronic bloody diarrhoea. It can be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics which interfere with gut motility. Features of secondary bacterial infecton and sepsis may be present. It can be complicated by intestinal perforation. It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, and bowel rest) and medical therapy which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement. Indications for urgent surgery include: Frank intraperitoneal peritonitis, secondary to perforation Life-threatening hemorrhage or increasing transfusion requirements Worsening systemic toxicity Worsening colonic dilatation Other options: Option B: Volvulus occurs when the air-filled segment of the colon twists around the mesentery. The sigmoid colon is the most commonly involved part of the large intestine (90%). The patient can present with abdominal distension, nausea and vomiting. X-ray abdomen shows a bent inner tube or coffee bean appearance. Option C: Ogilvie syndrome, also known as colonic pseudo-obstruction is a functional disorder with colonic dilatation without mechanical obstruction. It occurs commonly in hospitalized patients and is associated with narcotics, bed rest and comorbid disease. X-ray shows dilatation of the colon (predominantly transverse colon) with absent mechanical obstruction. Option D: Pneumatosis intestinalis is the presence of gas within the bowel wall seen in any part of the GI tract but most commonly in the jejunum. It is a pathognomic feature of necrotizing enterocolitis. X-ray of the abdomen will show intramural gas in the bowel.
subject: Surgery

question_text: You are doing an emergency laparotomy for a case of intestinal obstruction. Which organ will you first visualize to know if this is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction?
explanation: The cecum is the first organ to be visualized to differentiate between the small and large bowel in cases of intestinal obstruction. Distension of the cecum will confirm large bowel involvement. The identification of a collapsed distal segment of the large bowel and its sequential proximal assessment will lead to the identification of the cause.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 55-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of intermittent constipation and a sense of heaviness in his lower abdomen. His barium enema film is given below. Which of the following statements is false about the pathology responsible for his condition?
options: Commonly occurs along the mesenteric side of the colon
Sigmoid colon is the most common site
It is characterized by true diverticula
explanation: The given clinical scenario and X-ray film showing saw-toothed appearance of the colon are suggestive of colonic diverticulosis. They are false diverticula. Diverticulosis refers to the herniation of the mucosa and muscularis mucosa through the colonic wall, usually at the point where the nutrient artery enters the colon (mesenteric side). The condition is usually asymptomatic until complications arise. They may be detected incidentally. On a barium X-ray, the colon with diverticular disease will have a saw-toothed appearance. Colonic diverticula are more often acquired than congenital. They are common in developed countries that have a low fiber diet. A low fiber diet results in low stool volume. As the colon generates higher intraluminal pressure to propel smaller volumes of stools, low stool volumes cause an increase in colonic wall tension and segmentation of the colon. Prolonged colonic contractions and high pressures (directed radially along the colonic wall) results in the formation of pulsion diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common site. Note: True diverticulum involves the herniation of all the layers of the intestine whereas false diverticulum involves the herniation of only the mucosa and submucosa.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding left-sided diverticulitis?
options: It is often an incidental finding during surgery
Appendicitis is an important differential diagnosis
Left sided diverticulitis is more common than right
The anatomical location is given by the Hinchey classification
explanation: In the general population, left-sided diverticulitis is more common. The sigmoid colon (left colon) involvement is more common than the right colon involvement. Diverticulitis is the inflammation and infection of the diverticulum. It most commonly presents with eft lower abdominal pain (often termed as left-sided appendicitis) fever a change in bowel habits anorexia, nausea urinary urgency if there is an associated inflammation of the bladder etc. Right-sided diverticulitis occurs more often in younger patients of Asian descent than in other populations and presents with pain in the right lower quadrant. Patients presenting with these symptoms are often thought to have acute appendicitis, and often the diagnosis of right-sided diverticulitis is subsequently made in the operating room. The Hinchey classification is used to describe the severity of the diverticular disease, complicated by perforation. Hinchey classification: Stage 1 Mesenteric or pericolic absce ss Stage 2 Pelvic abscess Stage 3 Purulent peritonitis Stage 4 Fecal peritonitis
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 38-year-old man is brought to the casualty with severe right lower quadrant abdominal pain for the last two days. You suspect right-sided diverticulitis due to the relatively long history and lack of migration of pain. However, your co-resident is convinced it is appendicitis. Which is the best investigation to rule in your diagnosis?
explanation: Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis is now considered by most to be the standard modality for the evaluation of acute diverticulitis. Contrast enema studies are the most accurate way to find out the colonic diverticula. However, because of the risks of extravasation of barium from the perforation and aggravation of inflammation, it is avoided. In contrast to barium enema, a CT scan demonstrates both the intraluminal and extracolonic manifestations of acute right-sided diverticulitis. CT findings include pericolic soft tissue stranding, colonic wall thickening and pericolic fat infiltration (streaky fat). Barium enema in diverticulosis shows a saw-tooth appearance.
subject: Surgery

question_text: While performing surgery on a patient who presented with clinical features suggestive of peritonitis, a diverticular perforation is seen along with fecal peritonitis. What is the Hinchey's stage?
explanation: Fecal peritonitis belongs to grade 4 in the Hinchey classification. Diverticulitis refers to the inflammation and infection associated with the diverticula. Hinchey classification is the most commonly used classification for the severity and complication of acute diverticulitis. It is used additionally to guide the overall management of acute diverticulitis. Hinchey classification: Stage 1 Mesenteric or pericolic absce ss Hinchey classification: Hinchey classification: Stage 2 Pelvic abscess Stage 3 Purulent peritonitis Stage 4 Fecal peritonitis
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 70-year-old man with past history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and chronic constipation presented with right lower abdominal pain associated with fever. CT abdomen findings are suggestive of acute diverticulitis with 6 cm fluid accumulation in the paracolic region. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
options: Oral antibiotics, bowel rest and continued monitoring
iv antibiotics, bowel rest, and continued monitoring
Laparotomy for abscess drainage and surgical resection
CT guided percutaneous drainage with iv antibiotics
explanation: The elderly patient with multiple comorbidities and complicated acute diverticulitis (fluid collection >5 cm) should ideally be managed with CT-guided percutaneous drainage with iv antibiotics. Acute diverticulitis management: Outpatient care Initiated for young patients with no comorbidities It includes: Liquid diet Analgesia Regular follow-up Inpatient care Should be initiated if CT shows complicated diverticulitis characterized by: Perforation Abscess formation Obstruction or Fistulization. Can also be initiated if CT shows uncomplicated diverticulitis but the patient is of high risk such as Sepsis at presentation Elderly patient Immunosuppression Presence of comorbidities Failure of outpatient care Inpatient care includes the following: Bowel rest IV fluids Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics Antibiotic therapy can be continued with careful monitoring if fluid collection is <5 cm CT guided percutaneous drainage if antibiotic therapy fails or fluid collection is > 5 cm Surgical exploration and resection if there is perforation, obstruction, or fistulization Regular follow-up with imaging Note: Oral antibiotics have no proven benefit in the outpatient management of acute uncomplicated diverticulitis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the casualty with a history of fever and abdominal pain. The pain was initially in the left lower quadrant for 2 days but is diffuse and severe for the past 4 hours. The erect X-ray of the chest showed the presence of pneumoperitoneum. Emergency laparotomy was performed. It showed the presence of perforated left-sided diverticulitis with fecal peritonitis. How will you manage the patient?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of fecal peritonitis due to perforation of left-sided diverticulitis. This is managed by Hartmann's procedure. It involves segmental resection, a proximal-end colostomy, and closure of the rectal stump. If the perforation of the diverticulitis leads to a localized pericolic abscess formation, then it is treated with antibiotics alone or along with percutaneous drainage.
subject: Surgery

question_text: An elderly male patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain, increased frequency of micturition, and passing of air bubbles in urine. He was diagnosed with diverticulitis 2 years before and was treated with antibiotics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The history of diverticulitis and pneumaturia point towards a diagnosis of colovesical fistula. The patients present with the symptoms of urinary tract infection caused by colonic flora, pneumaturia (air bubbles in urine), and fecaluria (foul-smelling and brownish material in the urine). Complications of diverticular disease: Bleeding Perforation leading to a pericolic abscess or generalized peritonitis Intestinal obstruction due to fibrosis Fistula formation (colovesical, coloenteric, colovaginal) Emphysematous cystitis can also present with pneumaturia. It is caused by urinary tract infection (UTI) with a gas-forming organism, especially in people with diabetes or patients with urinary tract outflow obstruction.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A CECT confirmed severe acute diverticulitis in a 34-year-old brought to the emergency with lower abdominal pain. A Foley's catheter was promptly placed to prevent a certain complication. Which of the following statements is false regarding the complication?
options: Contrast enema is used to identify the course the pathology
Previous hysterectomy may increase the risk
It more commonly occurs in females
explanation: The colovesical fistula is more common in men than in women because the uterus prevents the sigmoid from adhering to the bladder. Hence, females who have undergone hysterectomy are at increased risk. Clinical features of a colovesical fistula are: Pneumaturia (flatus in urine) Fecaluria (feces in urine) Suprapubic pain Dysuria Urgency Frequency Gross hematuria (rare) Pneumaturia is usually appreciated toward the end of urination because the collection of gas usually sits at the top of the bladder. The finding pneumaturia or fecaluria is virtually pathognomonic for urinary tract fistulas, and patients presenting with this condition should be presumed to have a colovesical fistula and investigated accordingly. Over time, cystitis associated with a colovesical fistula may evolve to pyelonephritis. An abdominopelvic CT with oral or rectal contrast is the investigation of choice. A contrast enema may be used to identify the course of the fistula.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A patient presented with fever, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. She has a history of recent intensive care unit admission for sepsis which required prolonged antibiotic therapy.
Sigmoidoscopy findings are given below. Choose the false statement regarding the given condition.
options: Subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy is done in fulminant disease
IV vancomycin is used for treatment of recurrent disease
Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is an emerging treatment option
Stool sample is used for PCR detection of toxins
explanation: A history of diarrhea associated with prolonged antibiotic treatment and characteristic adherent pseudomembranes in the colon is highly suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis. Oral Fidaxomicin is commonly used in recurrent pseudomembranous colitis. The causative antibiotic agent must be discontinued and infection control measures must be taken for all patients. Initial episode - non severe: WBC 15,000/mm3, Creatinine < 1.5 mg/dL Oral Fidaxomicin(drug of choice) or Vancomycin Oral Metronidazole can be given if Vancomycin/Fidaxomycin is not available Initial episode - severe: >15,000/mm3, Creatinine >1.5 mg/dL Oral Fidaxomicin or Vancomycin Consider fecal microbiota transplantation Initial episode - fulminant Hypotension, ileus or megacolon Oral vancomycin and IV metronidazole Rectal Vancomycin can be used if ileus present Overwhelming sepsis, colonic perforation, or peritonitis Subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy First recurrence Repeat course of antibiotics for another 10-20 days Oral Fidaxomicin(drug of choice) or Vancomycin can be used. Repeated recurrence Consider fecal microbiota transplantation Option A: Subtotal colectomy with end ileostomy is the procedure of choice for patients requiring surgery for severe colitis or toxic megacolon. It allows for disease control, stabilization, and preservation of reconstruction options for the future. Segmental colectomy, ileostomy, or colostomy alone does not address the pancolonic nature of the disease. Option C: Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is emerging as a promising treatment option for recurrent and recalcitrant C. difficile infection. Using FMT, donor stool is administered to the patient through one of a variety of described routes (nasogastric tube, colonoscopic lavage, or upper endoscopy) to restore colonic flora. Option D: Pseudomembranous colitis is caused by Clostridium difficile which is a gram-positive, spore-forming anaerobic microorganism. The pathogenesis is mediated by the enterotoxins - toxin A and toxin B. They can be detected in the stool using PCR
subject: Surgery

question_text: An elderly male patient is brought to the casualty with complaints of vomiting and severe abdominal pain. The abdomen appears grossly distended, is tender to touch, and percussion reveals hyper-resonance. His X-ray abdomen is shown in the image below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
options: Laparotomy followed by sigmoid resection alone
Insertion of a rectal tube through a flexible sigmoidoscope
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the X-ray radiograph showing characteristic coffee bean appearance are highly suggestive of sigmoid volvulus. Non-operative decompression followed by insertion of a rectal tube through a rigid proctoscope or a flexible sigmoidoscope is the next best step in the management of this patient. Sigmoid volvulus is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. Symptoms include constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or vomiting. Onset may be acute or chronic. It occurs more commonly in patients with a history of mental illness and chronic constipation. ray abdomen shows a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include the coffee bean sign and the absence of rectal gas. CT may reveal large gas-filled loop without haustral markings, forming a closed-loop obstruction. Non-operative decompression is successful in treating 90% of the patients. The rectal tube should be left in place for 1-2 days to allow complete decompression and to prevent immediate recurrence of the volvulus. This should be followed by bowel cleansing with cathartics and a complete colonoscopic examination. In patients with signs of colonic necrosis or in whom endoscopic detorsion has failed, sigmoid colectomy with the closure of the rectum and end colostomy (Hartmann procedure) maybe required. Even if detorsion of the sigmoid is successful, elective sigmoid resection is indicated to prevent recurrence.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A lady is brought to the casualty department with a 2-day history of diffuse abdominal pain. She has had several episodes of bloody diarrhea for the past 8 hours and appears dehydrated. On examination, her pulse is feeble and BP is 80/55 mmHg. An abdominal x-ray shows the "thumbprinting sign.” What could be the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The thumbprinting sign is seen in both ischemic colitis and pseudomembranous colitis. Bowel wall "thumbprinting" (the appearance of thumbprint-shaped projections) is a radiological sign of submucosal thickening of the colonic wall. It can result from any process that leads to edema of the bowel wall, including pseudomembranous colitis, ischemic colitis, non-infective inflammatory bowel disease, other infective bowel diseases, as well as submucosal/intramural hemorrhage. The plain abdomen x-ray given below shows submucosal thickening with crescentic margins of the colon described as "thumbprinting" sign.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 44-year-old female patient presents to the casualty with complaints of sudden onset of pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is a palpable tympanic swelling in the left side of the abdomen. X-ray abdomen of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical vignette and the X-ray findings are suggestive of caecal volvulus. It is differentiated from sigmoid volvulus as there is only a single air-fluid level and the apex of the volvulus pointing towards the left upper quadrant. It is commonly seen in females in the 4th and 5th decade who can present with partial or complete intestinal obstruction. The clinical features include: Marked abdominal distention Abdominal pain Obstipation Nausea and vomiting etc. On examination, a palpable tympanic swelling in the midline or the left side may be seen. If there is strangulation or perforation of the obstructed bowel segment, peritoneal signs (rigidity, rebound tenderness etc.) can be present. Radiological findings include caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level, and absence of gas in the distal colon. On X-ray abdomen, the apex of the cecal volvulus points towards the left upper quadrant ( vs apex pointing towards the right upper quadrant in sigmoid volvulus) CECT abdomen is the investigation of choice that shows a whirl sign (also seen in the midgut volvulus). Management of cecal volvulus includes supportive therapy with nasogastric tube, iv fluids, antibiotics etc. and early surgical intervention. Perforated or strangulated cecal volvulus should be treated with right hemicolectomy If there is no sign of perforation or strangulation, either cecopexy or right hemicolectomy can be performed. Option B: Sigmoid volvulus (image shown below) is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. X-ray abdomen shows a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include the coffee bean sign and the absence of rectal gas. On X-ray abdomen, the apex of the sigmoid volvulus points towards the right upper quadrant. Option C: Toxic megacolon (image shown below) is defined as the dilatation of the transverse colon to a diameter of more than 6 cm. It is usually associated with severe ulcerative colitis. It can be triggered by electrolyte imbalance and narcotics as they interfere with gut motility. Option D: Fecal retention is an accumulation of a large amount of stool within any bowel segment, most commonly within the colon usually due to chronic constipation. A colonic distention with fecal material is often called fecal loading on the radiograph. It can be complicated by fecal impaction and subsequent bowel obstruction.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A middle-aged woman underwent an open repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The procedure was uneventful. However, on the 2nd postoperative day, the patient developed symptoms of acute abdomen and bloody diarrhea with significant guarding. The patient was taken up for an exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following areas is most likely to be involved?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of ischemic colitis and it occurs most commonly at the splenic flexure. Ischemic colitis occurs due to interruption or decrease in colonic blood flow. It may occur with many different conditions, including embolism from cardiac disease, low-flow states such as congestive heart failure, sepsis, and vasopressor use. Major vascular surgery (both open and endovascular repair), especially involving the abdominal aorta, is a well-known risk factor for developing ischemic colitis. Although any area of the colon may be affected, the watershed areas of the splenic flexure (Griffith’s point) and the rectosigmoid (Sudeck’s point) are the most prone to ischemia because of the often incomplete anastomoses of the marginal artery in these locations. The next most common area afflicted is the cecum, secondary to low blood flow in the terminal branches of the ileocolic artery. Splenic flexure (also known as Griffith's point) is a watershed area between the superior and inferior mesenteric arteries. Sudeck point is a watershed area between the sigmoid arterial branch from the inferior mesenteric artery and the superior rectal artery (branch of Inferior mesentric artery). The marginal artery of Drummond runs parallel to the colon, connecting the SMA and IMA circulation - the majority of blood flow to the left and sigmoid colon in case of occlusion of the IMA. Arc of Riolan is a variable collateral vessel that connects the SMA (middle colic vessel) to the IMA (left colic).
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient had a painless episode of profuse per rectal bleeding. After initial stabilization, a colonoscopy was performed. The findings are given below. What is the most common site of this condition?
explanation: The clinical scenario and colonoscopy findings are suggestive of angiodysplasia. The cecum is the most common site of angiodysplasia followed by the colon. In the colon the angiodysplasia can occur anywhere, however it is commonly found in the right colon than the transverse and the left colon.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient being evaluated for recurrent lower GI bleeding secondary to colonic angiodysplasia is suspected to have Heyde syndrome. What are the other common features associated with the condition?
options: Aortic stenosis and von Willebrand disease
explanation: Heyde’s syndrome is a multisystem disorder characterized by the clinical triad of: Aortic stenosis Gastrointestinal bleeding from angiodysplasia Acquired type 2 vWD (secondary to valvular stenosis, returns to normal once the valve is replaced) Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins are usually seen on colonoscopy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 4-month-old infant presented with constipation since birth. On a per rectal exam, a sudden release of feces was seen. A contrast enema showed a dilated descending colon leading to a constricted segment. Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of the disease?
explanation: The given clinical scenario, with a positive blast sign (sudden release of feces on PR examination) and characteristic barium enema findings, are suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. Patients with Hirschsprung’s disease have an increased frequency of mutations in certain genes such as glial cell line-derived neurotrophic factor (GCDNF). GDNF promotes the survival, proliferation, and migration of neural crest cells in culture. GDNF is expressed in the gut in advance of migrating neural crest cells and is chemoattractive for neura crest cells in culture. Mutations are also seen its receptor Rearranged during Transfection (RET), or its coreceptor Gfra-1 (GDNF family receptor alpha-1). Gene mutations in chromosomes 10 and 13, family history, and Down’s syndrome are also factors associated with Hirschsprung’s disease.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A neonate was brought to the pediatrician on day 5 of life with bilious vomiting and failure to pass meconium. On examination, the abdomen was distended. and X-Ray showed distended bowel loops. Due to suggestive family history, the resident suspected Hirschsprung's disease. What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
explanation: A rectal biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease. It shows the following: Absent ganglia Hypertrophied nerve trunks Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase Calretinin immunostaining (superior to acetylcholinesterase staining) Anorectal manometry is an important screening tool. It shows the absence of rectoanal inhibitory reflex.
subject: Surgery

question_text: From which of the following sites should a rectal biopsy be taken in order to confirm the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease?
explanation: The ideal site to obtain a rectal biopsy in a patient with Hirschsprung's disease is from a point that is at least 2 cm above the dentate line. The internal sphincter extends up to 2 cm above the dentate line. This region is normally devoid of ganglionic cells. Hence, biopsy in this region may lead to errors in the results. Rectal biopsy is the gold standard investigation in patients with Hirschsprung's disease. It shows the presence of hypertrophied nerve trunks and the absence of ganglion cells.
subject: Surgery

question_text: All of the following are surgeries you may plan in a child with aganglionic megacolon, except?
explanation: Heineke-Mikulicz's operation is a type of pyloroplasty and is not done for aganglionic megacolon (Hirschsprung disease). Surgery is the treatment of choice for Hirschsprung disease. A multi-stage approach may be adopted. A colostomy is done in the newborn period, followed by a definitive pull-through operation after the child is over 10 kgs. Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows: Swenson Duhame Soave
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common problem that arises postoperatively following surgery for Hirschsprung's disease?
explanation: Constipation is the most common postoperative problem after surgery for Hirschsprung disease. Other problems are soiling, incontinence, and postoperative enterocolitis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Up to what length from the anal verge will you be able to visualize through a flexible sigmoidoscope?
explanation: Flexible sigmoidoscope is 60 cm in length and can be used to visualize the rectum and sigmoid colon. Flexible sigmoidoscopy is a procedure involving the following steps: A sigmoidoscope is inserted through the anus and the distal colonic mucosa (up to 60 cm from the anal verge) is visualized. Diagnostic or therapeutic maneuvers are performed, as needed. Scope Length Anoscope 8 cm Proctoscope 15 cm Rectoscope 25 cm Flexible sigmoidosco pe 60 cm Colonoscope 100–16 0 cm
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which structure would you trace to identify enlarged paracolic lymph nodes?
options: Main branches of the superior mesenteric artery
Named branches of inferior mesenteric artery
explanation: Paracolic lymph nodes are located along the marginal artery.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 50-year-old man presents with 2 episodes of bleeding per rectum over the past 2 hours. His vitals are stable. Per rectal examination was normal except for trace evidence of fresh blood. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention for this patient?
explanation: In case of suspected lower GI bleeding or hematochezia, if the hemodynamic status of the patient is stable, colonoscopy with appropriate bowel preparation should be done at the earliest. A patient with hematochezia or fresh blood per rectum should be managed in the following way: Hemodynamically unstable on initial assessment (or suspected massive UGI bleed): At first, resuscitation with iv fluids, blood transfusion, and volume replacement Perform EGD (Esophagogastroduodenoscopy) Consider getting gastro surgery/interventional radiology consult If a source is not found on EGD, Perform angiography ± embolization if still hemodynamically unstable Perform colonoscopy if the patient is hemodynamically stable or, if a source was not identified on initial angiography If colonoscopy did not identify a bleeding source, consider further evaluation with Capsule endoscopy Tagged red blood cell scan Repeat EGD, etc. Hemodynamically stable on initial assessment: Bowel preparation and perform colonoscopy If a source was not found on colonoscopy, EGD should be performed If a source was not found even on EGD, consider further evaluation with Capsule endoscopy Tagged red blood cell scan Repeat colonoscopy, etc.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 56-year-old man with weight loss and pallor comes to the physician. A CBC and Fe studies indicate iron deficiency anemia. The patient denies any history of bleeding disorders or changes in diet. A guaiac test is advised. What parameter does it test?
explanation: Guaiac test is used for testing occult blood in the stool. New-onset iron deficiency anemia in middle-aged men should be thoroughly evaluated for colorectal carcinoma, even in the absence of other symptoms. Principle: Guaiac is a colorless organic compound that turns blue upon oxidation by oxidants, peroxidases, or pseudoperoxidase of hemoglobin. The test is more sensitive for lower GI bleed. Fecal hemoglobin must exceed 10 mg/g of stool (blood loss of 10 ml daily), for the test to be positive in 50% of the cases, although the test can be positive in some cases even if hemoglobin is <1mg/g of stool.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
99mTc-labeled red blood cell scan can be used to detect gastrointestinal bleeding as low as
.
0.1 mL/min
explanation: 99mTc-labeled red blood cell scan can detect gastrointestinal bleeding as low as 0.1 mL/min. Selective angiography, using the superior or inferior mesenteric artery, can detect hemorrhage in the range of 0.5 to 1.0 mL/min. Appendix
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common anatomical position of the appendix?
explanation: Retrocaecal is the most common position of the appendix. Positions of appendix: Retrocaecal: 74% Pelvic: 21% Sub-cecal: 1.5% Pre-ileal: 1% Post-ileal: 0.5%
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is not true regarding the various anatomical positions of the appendix?
options: Tenderness may be elicited on the immediate right of the umbilicus in post-ileal appendicitis
The most common location of the base of the appendix is retro-caecal
An inflamed pelvic appendix may cause an increase in frequency of micturition
Post-ileal appendicitis may have diarrhoea as a presenting complaint
explanation: The base of the appendix is found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum. Its position is constant. Conversely, the tip of the appendix can be found in many positions ( retrocaecal being the most common) The taeniae coli fuse to form the longitudinal muscle coat of the appendix. During surgery, gentle traction at the taenia coli, leads the surgeon to the base of the appendix.
subject: Surgery

question_text: During an appendectomy, the mesoappendix is divided and ligated. Which of the following is false about the major vessel ligated in this step?
options: It is a branch of upper division of the ileocolic artery
Thrombosis is most common at the tip
explanation: During appendectomy, the appendicular artery is the major vessel that is ligated when the mesoappendix is divided. It is a branch of the lower division of the ileocolic artery. The appendicular artery transverses behind the terminal ileum and enters the mesoappendix away from the base of the appendix. It lies along the free border of the mesoappendix. The terminal part or the tip of the artery lies on the wall of the appendix and may become thrombosed in appendicitis, resulting in distal gangrene or necrosis. It supplies only the appendix and is an end-artery. An accessory appendicular artery called the artery of Seshachalam may be present. It anastomoses at the base of the appendix with a branch of the posterior cecal artery.
subject: Surgery

question_text: While assisting a laparoscopic appendectomy, you observe the resident use the Fold of Treves as a guide while coagulating vessels in the mesoappendix. Which of the following best describes the anatomical landmark?
options: Mucous membrane projecting into the ileal lumen
The ilio-cecal fold of the peritoneum
The fold of the mucous membrane around appendiceal orifice
The fold of the peritoneum over ascending colon
explanation: Fold of Treves is an antimesenteric ileocecal fold of peritoneum. A clinical aid useful for detecting the location of the appendix through small abdominal incisions is the identification of the fold of Treves. It marks the junction of the ileum and cecum. As it does not contain any vessel, it is referred to as the bloodless fold of Treves. It is also used as a guide to determine the extent of coagulation during an appendectomy. This prevents thermal injury to adjacent structures. Jackson Membrane: Adhesion from the right abdominal wall to the anterior tenia of the ascending colon. Gerlach valves: A mucosal fold covering the appendiceal orifice.
subject: Surgery

question_text: The CECT findings of a patient who presented with a positive McBurney's sign show a dilated appendix, appendicular wall thickening, and fat stranding. What is the initiating event that leads to his condition?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of appendicitis. The initiating event in the development of appendicitis is luminal obstruction. Deep tenderness at McBurney's point, known as McBurney's sign, is a sign of acute appendicitis. McBurney's point is a point at one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine and umbilicus. It is where the appendix is commonly located. Due to the relatively small diameter of the appendicular lumen, it is easily obstructed. Usually, due to fecoliths. This leads to the buildup of mucus secretions and air due to bacteria. With progressive dilation, venous drainage may get hampered, leading to full-thickness ischemia and perforation. Obstructed lumen of appendix  Retained secretions with distension of lumen  Secretions get infected  Venous occlussion due to increased pressure  Bacterial translocation  Gangrene & perforation  Appendicular abscess
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the earliest symptom in a patient with acute appendicitis?
explanation: Symptoms of acute appendicitis begin as periumbilical pain followed by anorexia and nausea. Acute appendicitis begins with poorly localized colicky abdominal pain, first noticed in the periumbilical region. This is due to midgut visceral discomfort (T8 to T10 dermatomes) in response to appendiceal inflammation and obstruction. Over the next 12-24 hours, it localises to the right lower quadrant due to local peritoneal inflammation.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient presents to the casualty with right lower abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. On examination, there is increased pain in the right lower quadrant when palpating the left lower quadrant. What is this sign is called?
explanation: The given triad of clinical features, namely fever, nausea and right lower abdominal pain is Murphy's triad. It is suggestive of acute appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa can cause pain in the right iliac fossa. This sign is called Rovsing’s sign. This pain is due to the backflow of gases from the colon into the inflamed right intestine when the left lower abdomen is palpated.
subject: Surgery

question_text: You are examining a patient suspected to have appendicitis. During the given manoeuvre, you notice that the patient has sharp right-sided abdominal pain. Which of the following statements is false?
options: This sign elicited is known as Psoas Sign
It is commonly associated with pelvic appendicitis
Flexion of the hip against resistance may be done instead
Pain is due to contact of inflamed appendix with the psoas muscle
explanation: The manoeuvre in the given image shows hyperextension of the hip joint. It can induce abdominal pain when there is irritation of the psoas muscle by the inflamed appendix. This is known as the psoas sign and is commonly seen in retrocecal appendicitis. Flexion of the hip against resistance also elicits the psoas sign. Pain elicited on hip flexion and internal rotation is called the obturator sign. It is commonly seen in pelvic appendicitis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young boy was brought to the casualty with a history of fever and abdominal pain. On examination, he was febrile and his pulse rate was 104 beats/min. The CT scan image is shown below. Which of the following signs is not seen in this disease?
explanation: The patient's history and radiological findings are indicative of acute appendicitis. Ballance sign is not seen in acute appendicitis. Findings on CT that are suggestive of acute appendicitis include: Appendiceal dilatation (>6 mm in diameter) Appendiceal wall thickening (>3 mm) and enhancement Ballance sign is seen due to a ruptured spleen. The ballance sign is positive if there is a fixed dullness to percussion in the left flank and shifting dullness to percussion in the right flank. The fixed dullness is due to the presence of coagulated blood near the lacerated spleen while the shifting dullness is due to the presence of blood in the peritoneal cavity. Option A: Deep tenderness at McBurney's point, known as McBurney's sign, is a sign of acute appendicitis. McBurney's point is a point at one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine and umbilicus. Option B: Rovsing sign is seen in appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa may cause pain in the right iliac fossa. Option C: Psoas sign is seen in appendicitis. Occasionally, an in■amed appendix lies on the psoas muscle, and the patient will lie with the right hip ■exed, for pain relief.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the casualty with a history of abdominal pain and vomiting for the past 4 hours. On examination, the patient is febrile. Rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa is seen. Which among the following is the preferred imaging modality in this patient?
options: Erect X Ray of the abdomen
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute appendicitis. In the pediatric population, ultrasound of the abdomen is the preferred imaging modality to identify the presence of an inflamed appendix. It avoids the risk of radiation exposure. In adults, the best imaging modality is a CT scan.
subject: Surgery

question_text: For which of the following criteria on the Alvarado system, will you assign 2 points to a patient with features of appendicitis?
explanation: The Alvarado score is a clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. In the Alvorado scoring system, leukocytosis  10 × 109 cells/L and tenderness right iliac fossa have two points.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following organisms is most commonly isolated in patients presenting with perforated appendicitis?
explanation: Bacteroides fragilis is the most common anaerobe and Escherichia coli is the most common aerobe isolated from perforated appendicitis. Type of bacteria Patients (%) Anaerobic Bacteria Bacteroides fragilis 80 Bacteroides thetaiotaomicro n 61 Bilophila wadsworthia 55 Peptostreptococcusspp. 46 Aerobic Bacteria E. coli 77 Streptococcus viridians 43 Group D streptococci 27 Pseudomonas aeruginosa 18

question_text: A patient presents with fever and right lower quadrant pain for the past week. On examination, tenderness and guarding in the right iliac fossa are present. An ill-defined abdominal mass is also palpated. CBC reveals leucocytosis. What is the next step in management?
explanation: In appendicular mass, the inflammatory process is already localized and any surgical intervention may be difficult and dangerous. Hence, if the general condition is satisfactory, the conservative Ochsner–Sherren regimen is used.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Identify the incision made on a patient while performing an appendicectomy.
explanation: Lanz incision is a transverse skin crease incision for appendicitis 2 cm below the umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid inguinal line Option A: Gridiron incision is an oblique muscle-splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. It is also called McBurney incision. Option C: Rutherford–Morrison incision is an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary(Shown on the left side in the image for the sake of clarity) Option D: Rockey–Davis incision is a transverse right lower quadrant incision.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts the incision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut?
explanation: The structures cut when the initial incision gridiron incision (McBurney's incision) is converted to the Rutherford Morrison incision are the external oblique, internal oblique, and transverse abdominis muscles. When the preoperative diagnosis is reasonably certain, the widely used incision for appendectomy is known as the gridiron incision. It is made perpendicular to a line connecting the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus, with its center at McBurney's point. When better access is needed, the gridiron incision can be converted to a Rutherford Morison incision by extending the incision obliquely upwards and laterally. Rutherford Morison's incision is suitable for a para- or retrocecal appendix that is fixed. It is an oblique muscle-cutting incision starting from McBurney's point and extending upward and laterally as needed. All layers (skin, subcutaneous tissues, external oblique, internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and the peritoneum) are divided along the incision line. In recent years, the transverse skin crease (Lanz) incision has gained popularity due to improved exposure and ease of extension when necessary. This incision is placed approximately 2 cm below the umbilicus along the midclavicular-midinguinal line, with its length adjusted according to the patient's size and obesity. If required, the incision can be extended medially by retracting or dividing the rectus abdominis muscle (statement 4). When there is uncertainty in the diagnosis, especially in the presence of intestinal obstruction, a lower midline abdominal incision is preferred over a right lower paramedian incision.
subject: Surgery

question_text: As a surgical resident performing an appendectomy, what is the maximum stump size that you can leave behind in order to prevent stump appendicitis?
explanation: The residual appendiceal stump should be no longer than 5 mm, so as to minimize the possibility of stump appendicitis in the future. Stump appendicitis is a complication that occurs after an appendectomy. It is caused by the inflammation of the residual appendiceal tissue after the appendix is removed. The clinical presentation of stump appendicitis is similar to acute appendicitis. Factors predisposing for stump appendicitis: Inadequate identification of the appendicular base due to severe local inflammation Leaving a long stump due to fear of cecal injury or difficult dissection Local ulcerations due to fecoliths.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 19-year-old boy is taken up for open appendicectomy. Which of the combinations of the following instruments is best suited for his procedure?
explanation: Babcock's forceps, 22 size blade, and Langenbeck retractor are used in open appendicectomy. The image below shows Babcock’s forceps, where: Distal part of distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge ut. Tip is non traumatic with transverse serrations on it. It has got a lock in proximal part. Uses: Hold any part of Bowel, Fallopian tube, Appendix, Ureter, Cord, etc. The below image is that of a Langenbeck Retractor: Useful for holding open wounds, as in an open appendicectomy. Often used in pairs (one in each of the assistant’s hands). The width of the lip of the retractors varies. The 11-blade is used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions 15-blade for minor surgical procedures. Deaver’s Retractor is specifically designed for holding the liver up out of the way during a cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver. Lane’s tissue holding forceps It has got stout and thick distal blades with oval fenestra in each blade Apposing tooth in the tip Lock in proximal part Uses: Hold bulky and tough structures, hold lymph nodes. Tracheal dilator is used to keep tracheostomy open.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common post-operative complication that may arise in patients who undergo an appendectomy ?
explanation: Wound infection is the most common postoperative complication of appendectomy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common neoplasm of the appendix ?
explanation: The most common neoplasm primarily identified in the appendix are carcinoid tumors. They account for approximately 66% of all tumors of the appendix. They are detected in 0.3 to 0.9% of appendectomy specimens. Adenocarcinoma of the appendix is very rare, accounting for 0.5% of all gastrointestinal cancers. The adenocarcinoma malignancies are three subtypes: Mucinous Colonic type Adenocarcinoid Mucinous is the most common subtype whereas Adenocarcinoid is the rarest.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about carcinoid tumours of appendix?
options: Size appears to be the best predictor of malignant behavior and metastatic potential
Arise from Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Lieberkühn
Most common location is the base of the appendix
explanation: The most common location of the carcinoid tumour of the appendix is the tip of the appendix i.e., the distal third of the appendix. A carcinoid tumour, also known as argentaffinoma, arises in argentaffin tissue (Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Lieberkühn). It often presents with symptoms of subacute or recurrent appendicitis. On gross examination, it is a moderately hard, yellow tumour between the intact mucosa and the peritoneum. Microscopically, tumour cells are small, arranged in small nests within the muscle, and have a characteristic pattern using immunohistochemical stain for chromogranin B. Carcinoid tumours are the most common appendiceal tumours but they rarely metastasize. Treatment includes appendicectomy. Indications for right hemicolectomy along with appendectomy are : Involvement of the cecal wall Tumour is 2 cm or more in size Lymph nodes are involved.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 35-year-old female patient is admitted to the hospital for complaints of pain and tenderness in the right iliac fossa. She underwent an appendicectomy. A 2.5 cm tumor was encountered at the base of the appendix which was found to be carcinoid on histopathological examination. What is the next step in management?
options: Send the urine for 5- hydroxy indole acetic acid levels
explanation: The carcinoid tumors of the appendix which are more than 2 cm in size are treated with right hemicolectomy. Management of carcinoid tumors: <1 cm – Appendicectomy 1-2 cms - Appendicectomy or right hemicolectomy depending on the individual tumor characteristics. >2 cm – Right hemicolectomy Irrespective of size, it is recommended to perform a right hemicolectomy in: Carcinoids at the appendiceal base (<2 cm from the base) Lymphatic invasion or lymph node involvement Spread to the mesoappendix Tumor-positive resection margins Cellular pleomorphism with a high mitotic index.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Following an appendectomy, the specimen was sent for HPE. A well-circumscribed, yellowish tumor measuring 0.5 cm in diameter at the tip of the appendix was seen. The stained sections revealed a typical carcinoid tumor of the appendix. The specimen had a tumor-free margin on all sides. The base of the appendix, the mesoappendix, and nodes were not involved. What is the next step of management?
explanation: The size of the carcinoid tumour is 0.5 cm (<1 cm), the margins of the resected specimen are tumour free, and there is no involvement of appendix base, mesoappendix, or lymph nodes. The best management approach here is observation. Carcinoid tumour may be detected in ~0.5% of appendectomy specimens. Appendectomy is adequate in the treatment of cases with a diameter of <1 cm and in those with a diameter of 1-2 cm without lymphovascular invasion. If a tumour is found after appendicectomy: If it is an adenocarcinoma, perform right hemicolectomy. If it is a carcinoid tumour, treatment differs according to the tumour size: <1 cm – Observation 1–2 cm – Right hemicolectomy if a lymphovascular invasion is seen >2 cm – Right hemicolectomy Right hemicolectomy treatment is indicated even in tumours < 2 cm in case of: Tumours localized at the base of the appendix Invasion of lymphatic ducts, serosa and mesoappendix Presence of regional lymph node metastasis Positive surgical margins Mucin production (mucinous carcinoid tumours) High mitotic fast cellular pleomorphism
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 6-year-old presented with right lower quadrant pain and fever for 1 day. An appendicitis was suspected and the patient was prepared for surgery. During the surgery, a normal appendix was found but mesenteric lymph nodes were enlarged. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Yersinia enterocolitica causes inflammation of the terminal ileum, appendix, and cecum, alongwith mesenteric lymphadenopathy. It is the most common differential diagnosis of acute appendicitis. Acute mesenteric lymphadenitis manifests as acute right lower quadrant abdominal pain associated with mesenteric lymph node enlargement and a normal appendix. Diagnosis is made after exploration of the abdomen of a patient suspected of having acute appendicitis, which reveals a normal appendix and enlarged mesenteric lymph nodes. It usually occurs in children and young adults.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A postmenopausal lady diagnosed with mucinous cystadenoma appendix is unwilling for surgery. A few weeks later, she complains of vague abdominal pain and progressive abdominal distension. Ultrasound reveals the presence of ascites. CT reveals a thickened peritoneum, multiple loculated fluid collections, and scalloping of the liver and spleen margin. Which of the following statements is false regarding her condition?
The patient is most likely suffering from disseminated peritoneal carcinomatosis
options: The histology of the appendiceal tumor is an important predictor of survival
Cytoreductive surgery with IPHC maybe required for management
This condition can also occur in patients with ovarian neoplasms
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a patient with mucinous cystadenoma appendix and imaging findings are suggestive of pseudomyxoma peritonei. Pseudomyxoma peritonei refers to a condition of mucinous ascites arising due to the rupture of a mucinous tumor of appendix or ovary. It most commonly occurs in patients between 40-50 years of age. They are often asymptomatic or present with non-specific complaints like abdominal pain and distension. Physical examination may reveal ascites with non shifting dullness and rarely, a palpable abdominal mass. CT scan may reveal accumulation of mucinous material and scalloped indentation of the visceral surfaces of the liver and spleen. The peritoneal surfaces may be thickened due to the solid components of the tumor. The histology of the primary appendiceal tumor is an important predictor of survival. Management consists of extensive resection of the tumor (cytoreduction) and intraperitoneal heated chemotherapy (IPHC). Surgical management may include omentectomy, resection of the peritoneum and involved organs, appendectomy or a right hemicolectomy. Polyps and Colorectal Carcinoma
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 50-year-old woman underwent a screening colonoscopy. A single polyp is found, resected, and sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following biopsy findings will have the highest risk of malignancy?
explanation: Villous adenoma has the highest risk of malignancy. Adenomatous polyps can be tubular, tubulovillous, and villous adenomas. Among these, tubular adenoma has the least risk and villous adenoma has the highest risk of malignancy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: During a colonoscopy on a 58-year-old female patient, a smooth nodular polyp is found and excised. The microscopic image is given. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the polyp.
options: Usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life
Malignant transformation takes place within 5 years
explanation: Hyperplastic polyps, as seen in the histological picture, do not have malignant potential. Elongated crypts, i.e., serrated (saw-toothed) or star-shaped appearance, is a characteristic feature of a hyperplastic polyp. They are the most common type of colorectal polyps and are usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life. More than 90% occur in rectosigmoid region.
subject: Surgery

question_text: The biopsy of a polyp reported dysplasia up to the colonic submucosa. Classify this lesion using Haggitt's classification:
explanation: According to Haggitt’s classification, a polyp invading the submucosa comes under level 4.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 35-year-old patient undergoes a screening colonoscopy after his brother was diagnosed with colorectal cancer. Which of the following, if detected, does not indicate a risk of developing colon cancer?
options: Villous adenomas in the ascending colon
More than 100 polyps in the transverse and descending colon
Inflammatory polyps in the sigmoid colon and rectum
Sessile serrated adenomatous polyps in the sigmoid colon
explanation: Inflammatory polyps are not premalignant. Inflammatory polyps (pseudopolyps) are found in cases of: Inflammatory bowel disease (most common) Amebic colitis Ischemic colitis Schistosomal colitis Microscopic examination shows islands of normal, regenerating mucosa (the polyp) surrounded by areas of mucosal loss.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 12-year-old is brought to the emergency with features of intestinal obstruction. An ultrasound reveals a target sign, suggesting intussusception. On closer examination, her palm and oral mucosa are spotted with multiple 1-2 mm blue-gray macules. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The patient most likely has Peutz–Jeghers syndrome. It is characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract (more commonly small intestine) and hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits. In the given clinical scenario, the patient has had an intestinal intussusception. The numerous polyps in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome often serve as a lead point. Option A: Turcot syndrome constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors (including cerebellar medulloblastoma and glioblastomas) Option B: Lynch syndrome is also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). It is due to defective mismatch repair (MMR) of DNA. Option D: Cowden syndrome is characterized by polyps of the stomach or colon, macrocephaly and benign tumors of thyroid, breast, and uterus.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Ophthalmoscopy performed on a 14-year-old boy had the given incidental finding. Family history revealed that his grandfather had colon cancer and an aunt was diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma. Genetic testing confirmed APC gene mutation. Which of the following is false about his condition?
options: Condition can be passed on to his daughter in the future
Mutation of APC gene is on chromosome 15
explanation: The given image showing a pigmented retina, the patient's family history and APC gene mutation is suggestive of familial adenomatous polyposis. Familial adenomatous polyposis is due to the mutation of APC gene located on the long arm of chromosome 5 (5q21), not 15. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is autosomal dominant. It is characterized by the presence of >100 adenomatous polyps in colon and rectum. It usually manifests by the late 2nd or early 3rd decade. Although it accounts for 1% of all colorectal carcinoma, the risk of development of cancer is 100%. CHRPE (Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epthelium) is the earliest extra-colonic manifestation of FAP, present in up to 75% of patients.
subject: Surgery

question_text: All of the following are gastrointestinal manifestations seen in patients with FAP except:
options: Fundal gland hyperplasia in gastric polyp
explanation: Esophageal carcinoma is not associated with FAP Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is associated with gastric and duodenal polyps in approximately 50% of the affected individuals. Most of the gastric polyps represent fundic gland hyperplasia and have limited malignant potential. Duodenal polyps are adenomatous in nature and premalignant. Patients with FAP have an increased risk for duodenal ampullary cancer.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is not a component of Gardner's syndrome?
explanation: Gardner’s syndrome does not include brain tumors. Components of Gardner’s syndrome: Osteomas: most common manifestation, most commonly in the mandible Polyposis colon Dental anomalies (supernumerary tooth, absent tooth, impacted tooth) Epidermal inclusion cysts Desmoid tumors Note: Turcot’s syndrome includes brain tumor and colorectal polyps.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumor?
explanation: Explanation: The most common presentation of an abdominal desmoid tumor is an abdominal mass. Desmoid tumors, also known as fibromatosis, aggressive fibromatosis or desmoid-type fibromatosis are locally aggressive tumors that lack metastatic potential. Desmoid tumors can be sporadic in origin or associated with familial adenomatous polyposis. These tumors arise from fibro-aponeurotic tissue and typically are manifested as a slowly growing mass. They present as firm, non-painful, non-tender masses in the abdominal wall, shoulder, hip and limbs, mesentery, and pelvis. They are also associated with trauma, pregnancy, and oral contraceptive usage. The investigation of choice for a desmoid tumor is MRI. It is superior to CT in defining the pattern and the extent of involvement and can determine recurrence after surgery. Diagnosis is established by a biopsy with immunohistochemistry, which stains positive for beta-catenin, actin and vimentin, and negative for desmin, cytokeratin and S-100. Treatment: An initial observation is preferred for stable, asymptomatic, primary or recurrent desmoids, especially if surgery can cause high mortality. Surgical resection with negative margin clearance is reserved for patients with small abdomina wall tumors associated with pain or an increase in size. Tamoxifen and NSAIDs are used as first-line medical therapy. Other systemic treatment options are low-dose chemotherapy, tyrosinase kinase inhibitors, and full-dose chemotherapy Radiotherapy is preferred for candidates unfit for surgery, patients refusing surgery and when surgical resection is associated with high morbidity.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 29-year-old man was brought to the hospital with a history of headache and vomiting for the past 7 days and an episode of a tonic-clonic seizure. The image of the MRI scan is shown below. Colonoscopy revealed numerous polyps in the colon and the rectum which were found
to be adenomatous on biopsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, the patient has numerous adenomatous polyps and a tumor in the brain. Therefore the most likely diagnosis is Turcot's syndrome. It is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant condition and is caused due to the mutation in the APC gene located on chromosome 5. Clinically, patients develop hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum. Some patients may also develop duodenal adenomas. The lifetime risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in these patients is 100%. The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA). Variants of FAP are: Gardner's syndrome- It is an autosomal dominant variant of FAP. In addition to colonic polyps the patients will have Osteomas of the mandible or sku Epidermal cysts Soft tissue tumors like desmoid tumor Turcot's syndrome- In addition to the colonic polyps the patients will have central nervous system tumors (primary brain tumors). Option D: Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is not related to familial adenomatous polyposis. It is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by Pigmentation of the mouth and lips Multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small and large intestine.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
Colonoscopy and biopsy on a 35-year-old man revealed hundreds of adenomatous polyps in the entire descending and sigmoid colon. Options for prophylactic surgery are discussed.
Which of the following procedures will reduce the occurrence of malignancy the most?
options: Total colectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis
Total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis
explanation: The clinical scenario is diagnostic of familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome. To prevent an occurrence of cancer, total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis is the management of choice. This procedure is usually accompanied by resection of the rectal mucosa. Following surgery, the patient has to be routinely followed up for ileoanal-pouch surveillance. Upper GI endoscopy should also be performed to evaluate for the presence of duodenal adenomas.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 40-year-old man was recently diagnosed and treated for an autosomal dominant disorder. The gross specimen of his resected colon is given in the image. What is the initial step in screening his 9-year-old child?
options: Genetic testing for APC gene mutation
Genetic testing for MSH-6 gene mutation
Routine flexible sigmoidoscopy starting from 10 years of age
Routine colonoscopy starting from 10 years of age
explanation: More than 100 colonic polyps are diagnostic of familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome and the initial step in screening the child syndrome is to perform genetic testing for APC gene mutation. If screening is positive, flexible sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy is done annually starting from 10 years of age. If the APC testing is negative, then the risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in the relative is similar to the general population. The screening can be started from 50 years of age.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which among the following is true about Amsterdam criteria?
options: At least 2 or more first-degree relatives affected
At least one case diagnosed before 50 years of age
explanation: According to the Amsterdam criteria for hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), at least one case should be diagnosed before 50 years of age. Option A: According to the Amsterdam criteria for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC, at least 2 (not 3) successive generations should be affected. Option B: According to the Amsterdam criteria for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC, at least 3 relatives (not 2) with at least one being first-degree relatives should be affected.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common extra-colonic cancer in patients with a mutation in MMR genes?
explanation: Endometrial carcinoma is the most common extracolonic carcinoma in patients with mutated MMR genes. Autosomal dominant mutation in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes, such as hMLH1, hMSH2, hMSH6, PMS1, and PMS2 lead to various cancers. This condition is known as Lynch Syndrome/HNPCC. Gastric and ovarian carcinoma are also commonly found.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which among the following is false about colorectal carcinoma in HNPCC?
options: The onset of cancer occurs early
The progression of the carcinoma is slow
Mucinous adenocarcinoma is the most common type
Tumors predominantly develop in right sided colon
explanation: In hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), there is accelerated tumor progression and normal tumor initiation. Accelerated tumor initiation is seen in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). In Hereditary Non-polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC), the onset of cancer is at a relatively young age (mean, 44 years). Proximal distribution is more common and nearly 70% of cancers are located in the right colon. Mucinous or poorly differentiated (signet cell) adenocarcinoma predominate. There is an increased number of synchronous and metachronous cancers. The outcome after surgery is relatively good.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 25-year-old man presented to the dermatologist's office with multiple small bumps on his forehead. Excisional biopsy findings are suggestive of multiple small sebaceous adenomas. Detailed family history reveals that his grandfather and brother have colon cancer while his aunt was diagnosed with rectal cancer. Which syndrome should be suspected?
explanation: Multiple cutaneous sebaceous adenomas and a family history of various cancers are seen in Muir–Torre syndrome. Muir–Torre variant of hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) may have: Sebaceous adenomas Keratoacanthomas Sebaceous epitheliomas Basal cell epitheliomas
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which criteria is used to select patients for microsatellite instability (MSI) testing?
explanation: Bethesda criteria is used to select patients for microsatellite instability testing. Microsatellites are regions of repeated DNA that change in length (show instability) when mismatch repair is not functioning. Defects in mismatch repair genes (as in Lynch syndrome/HNPCC) leads to microsatellite instability. Amsterdam criteria is used for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC in a family. Because the Amsterdam criteria do not include some patients with known germline MMR gene mutations, another set of guidelines, known as the Bethesda guidelines, was established to help decide whether or not a patient should undergo further molecular testing to rule out HNPCC.
subject: Surgery

question_text: In which part of the colon does colorectal carcinoma most commonly develop?
explanation: In the colon, colorectal carcinoma most commonly develops in the sigmoid colon. Overall, the most common site of colorectal carcinoma is the rectum. The sites of development of colorectal carcinoma in order of frequency are: Rectum Sigmoid colon Caecum Transverse colon Ascending colon Descending colon Splenic flexure Hepatic flexure
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following are risk factors for colon carcinoma?
explanation: Ulcerative colitis, familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), cholecystectomy, ureterosigmoidostomy, and smoking are risk factors for colon cancer.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following dietary recommendation puts patients at risk of developing colon cancer?
explanation: High-calorie, low-fiber, and high-animal-fat diet as well as alcohol consumption increase the risk of colon cancer. Calcium, selenium, vitamins A, C, and E, carotenoids, and plant phenols are protective.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following colonoscopic findings has the highest risk of developing colorectal cancer?
explanation: Sessile/flat polyps are at a higher risk of malignancy compared to pedunculated polyps. Multiple polyps increase the risk of malignancy. The probability of development of malignancy of a polyp depends on the following: Gross appearance of lesion: Sessile polyps are at higher risk for malignancy than pedunculated tumors. Histology: Villous > Tubulovillous > tubular Size: Polyps of size >2 cm are at higher risk.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Mutations in which gene is responsible for malignant changes in late colonic adenomas?
explanation: p53 mutation is responsible for the transformation of late adenoma to carcinoma. The earliest mutations in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence occur in the APC gene and the earliest phenotypic change is known as aberrant crypt formation. The most consistent genetic aberrations within these cells abnormally result in the formation of short proteins known as APC truncations. They occur in the mutational cluster region of the gene, an area responsible for -catenin binding.
subject: Surgery

explanation: Option A states the correctly matched pairs regarding risk category and colon cancer screening recommendation. question_text: A 61-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue and shortness of breath. He has conjunctival pallor and has lost significant weight over 3 months. A CBC reveals low haemoglobin and MCV. A stool occult blood test is positive. What is the next best step in evaluation?
explanation: The clinical scenario of an elderly patient with sudden onset anemia always warrants screening for colorectal cancer, as cancers in the right colon often manifest as melena and fatigue associated with anemia. Thus, the next best investigation is a colonoscopy. Colonoscopy is the investigation of choice & gold standard for establishing the diagnosis of colon cancer. It permits biopsy of the tumor to verify the diagnosis while allowing inspection of the entire colon to exclude metachronous polyps or cancers. Colonoscopy is generally performed even after cancer is detected by barium enema, in order to obtain a biopsy specimen and to detect (and remove) small polyps that may have been missed in the contrast study.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 55-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and constipation. A barium enema reveals an apple core sign. In which part of the colon is such a growth commonly seen?
explanation: Apple core sign on barium enema is suggestive of a constricting type of colon cancer that is more common on the left side. Ulcerative type is more common on the right side. Most patients with left-sided colon cancers often present with increasing constipation while patients with right-sided colon cancer often present with melena and fatigue associated with anemia. The apple core sign describes a short segment irregular circumferential stricture of the large bowel that has abrupt shouldered margins resembling an apple core.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common presenting feature in patients with right sided colon cancer ?
explanation: Anemia is the most common presenting feature in patients with right-sided colon cancer. Cancers in the right colon are more often manifested as melena, fatigue associated with anemia, or abdominal pain (if the tumor is advanced). Cancer of the left colon mainly presents with altered bowel habits, usually constipation and intestinal obstruction.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which among the following statements is false about virtual colonoscopy as compared to conventional colonoscopy?
options: Virtual colonoscopy is less sensitive for small polyps
Provids a better image than conventional colonoscopy
Easier to take tissue biopsy during virtual colonoscopy
Less time consuming than conventional colonoscopy
explanation: Virtual colonoscopy is a non-invasive technique and is not useful in taking biopsy.

question_text: A 50-year-old female presented with low-grade fever, easy fatiguability, and pain in the right hypochondrium. On examination, pallor and moderate hepatomegaly were present. A CT scan revealed non-enhancing masses. The biopsy showed adenocarcinoma, not of hepatic origin. A combination of IHC tests was done and was reported as CK 7 (-), CK20 (+). Which of the following is the most likely primary site of origin?
explanation: Colorectal carcinoma is the most likely primary tumor for the given metastases. Among the given options, cytokeratin 7 is negative only in colon carcinoma. The most common site of distant metastasis from colorectal cancer is the liver. These metastases arise from hematogenous spread via the portal venous system.The lung is the next most common site for metastasis. question_text: What is the most important prognostic factor in patients with colorectal carcinoma?
explanation: The most important determinant of prognosis for colorectal carcinoma is the tumour stage and, in particular, lymph node status. The T-stage (depth of invasion) is the single most significant predictor of lymph node spread.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Choose the parameters used to stage colorectal carcinoma according to Duke's classification ?
explanation: Duke’s classification is based on the depth of tumor and lymph node status.

question_text: The biopsy of a hemicolectomy specimen revealed an adenocarcinoma with colonic subserosa invasion. Deposits were found on the mesentery but lymph nodes were not involved. Further investigation on the patient did not indicate local or distant metastases. What is the stage of the tumor ?
explanation: According to 8th American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) classification of colorectal cancers, tumor deposits in the subserosa or mesentery are staged as N1c and tumor invading the subserosa without involvement of peritonealized organs is T3. question_text: Match the following patients with colon cancer to the procedure that is best suited.
explanation: All of the given procedures may be performed in a patient with colonic cancer presenting with features of left colonic obstruction. The most appropriate answer is 1-B,2-C,3-A. In Hartmann's procedure, the segment of the colon containing the obstructing cancer is resected and closure of the distal sigmoid or rectum is performed. A colostomy is made. Later, intestinal continuity is re-established by the closure of the colostomy and fashioning a colorectal anastomosis. This procedure is preferred in patients when a resection and primary anastomosis cannot be performed immediately due to complications such as inflammation of the bowel, perforation, or peritonitis. Resection and primary anastomosis is done in patients who are hemodynamically stable and have pliable, nonedematous, well-vascularized bowel. In this procedure, the segment of the left colon containing the cancer is resected. The remaining colon is cleaned with saline lavage by inserting a catheter through the appendix or ileum into the cecum and irrigating the contents from the colon. Primary anastomosis between the prepared colon and rectum is fashioned subsequently, without the need for a temporary colostomy Stent placement via colonoscope is a temporary measure to obtain time for bowel preparation for primary anastomosis. A stent that traverses the tumor is placed to relieve the obstruction. It is done in partial obstruction and is preferred in old and frail patients.

question_text: A 60-year-old man was rushed to the ER with abdominal pain, obstipation, and altered mental status for the last 2 days. Physical examination and imaging findings are suggestive of perforated intestinal obstruction with peritonitis. After stabilization, he is immediately taken to the operating room, where a suspicious ascending colon mass is seen. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
explanation: The elderly man with ascending colon mass leading to perforated intestinal obstruction with peritonitis should ideally be treated with right hemicolectomy and ileocolostomy. In case of suspected colorectal cancer presenting with intestinal obstruction the following surgeries are done: Right-sided lesion: A resection (right hemicolectomy) and anastomosis if the patient is stable Perforation with substantial contamination or if the patient is unstable: right hemicolectomy + ileocolostomy Left-sided lesion: Resection and anastomosis if the patient is stable Perforation with substantial contamination or if the patient is unstable: Hartmann procedure is done. Later, intestinal continuity is re-established by the closure of the colostomy and fashioning a colorectal anastomosis. Where endoscopic and radiological facilities are present an obstructing left-sided lesion can be treated with an expanding metal stent provided bowel perforation is absent.

explanation: Immunotherapy is not ineffective in metastatic colorectal cancer. Metastatic or recurrent colorectal cancers are the indications for immunotherapy. question_text: The anorectal angle is formed by which muscle?
explanation: The puborectalis muscle encircles the posterior and lateral aspects of the anorectal junction, creating the anorectal angle. At rest, the anorectal angle is held at 90 - 100°. This becomes more acute (70 - 90°) during squeezing due to the contraction and shortening of the puborectalis muscle. This brings the anorectal junction higher and nearer to the pubic symphysis. During straining and defecation, the anorectal angle becomes more obtuse (110 - 180°) due to relaxation of the puborectalis muscle. The anorectal ring is formed by the fusion of: Puborectalis Deep external anal sphincter Internal anal sphincter Note: Anismus, is caused by a failure of the puborectalis and external anal sphincter to relax during defecation straining. This results in a failure of the anorectal angle to straighten during defecation.

question_text: What is the length of the adult rectum?
explanation: The adult rectum is approximately 12–18 cm in length and is conventionally divided into three equal parts - the upper, middle and lower 1/3rd.
