question_text: Which fascial layer should be dissected to separate the rectum from the coccyx while operating on a patient with rectal adenocarcinoma?
explanation: Waldeyer's fascia separates the rectum from the coccyx. The lower third of the rectum is separated by the following: from the prostate or vagina anteriorly - by Denonvilliers’ fascia from the coccyx and lower two sacral vertebrae- by Waldeyer’s fascia Waldeyer's fascia originates at the S2 to S4 level from the presacral parietal fascia and fuses with the rectal visceral fascia at the posterior aspect of the rectum. It divides the retrorectal space into superior and inferior compartments. Identification and preservation of the presacral fascia play an important role in preventing complications and reducing local recurrences of rectal cancer.

question_text: The instrument shown below will be least useful for examining patients with which of the following conditions?

It is reserved for later when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operating room. An anxious mother rushed her 2-year-old child to the casualty when she noticed a
red-coloured mass protruding from his anus. The mother gave a history of the child straining while passing stools for the past 2 weeks. There was no abdominal tenderness, and on local examination, a 6 cm mass with circumferential folds and slight edema was noted. How will you manage this child?
explanation: The given history and examination finding is suggestive of rectal prolapse. In children, the prolapse is usually mucosal and should be treated conservatively. Rectal prolapse occurs when a mucosal or full-thickness layer of rectal tissue protrudes through the anal orifice. Conservative treatment for rectal prolapse in children is to control: Diarrhea Worm infestation Malnutrition Sclerotherapy can also be used.

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the management of patients with rectal prolapse?
options: Surgery is necessary for full-thickness rectal prolapse
Delorme’s operation is done via the perineal approach
Ripstein's procedure is done via abdominal approach
Abdominal rectopexy is often preferred in high risk individuals
explanation: The perineal approach is often preferred in patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy, i.e. in the elderly. It is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate. Abdominal approaches (laparoscopic, robotic, or open) are preferred for younger patients, particularly those with constipation or associated pelvic floor disorders. Perineal procedures: Delorme's mucosectomy- involves mucosal stripping and muscle plication of the rectal prolapse using interrupted sutures. It is performed externally under regional or general anaesthesia. Thiersch's encirclement- a steel wire, or Silastic or nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal. Largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defaecation Altemeier rectosigmoidectomy- involves removal of the prolapsed rectum and associated sigmoid colon, followed by which a coloanal anastomosis is created. It is often complicated by poor bowel control with faecal soiling secondary to the loss of rectal reservoir. Abdominal procedures: Suture rectopexy Mesh rectopexy Posterior (Well’s and lvalon’s) Anterior (Ripstein’s) Lateral (Orr-Loygue) Ventral Resection Rectopexy (Frykman–Goldberg) The principle of all abdominal operations for rectal prolapse is to fix the rectum in its normal anatomical position.

question_text: Which of the following is not true regarding solitary rectal ulcers?
options: Commonly seen on the posterior wall
Rectal bleeding Is a common presentation
Colonoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice
explanation: A solitary rectal ulcer is usually located on the anterior rectal wall, 6-8 cm from the anal verge. It commonly presents with rectal bleeding in the setting of chronic straining or constipation. Histology reveals a thick layer of fibrosis obliterating the lamina propria and a central fibrinous exudate. Colonoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for diagnostic evaluation, while defecography (proctography) is the radiologic procedure of choice. Stapled trans-anal rectal resection(STARR procedure) is the management of choice.

question_text: What is the radiological procedure of choice in patients suspected to have a solitary rectal ulcer?

question_text: An elderly man with per-rectal bleeding is suspected to have rectal carcinoma. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Majority of the cancers are sporadic
Dose of radiation used for this tumor is 45 Gy
Dissection lateral to the endopelvic fascia investing the mesorectum causes local recurrence
Precise location of the tumor is determined with rigid proctosigmoidoscopy
explanation: Dissection medial (not lateral) to the endopelvic fascia investing the mesorectum causes local recurrence. Dissection lateral to the avascular anatomic space, risks injury to the mixed autonomic nerves, causing impotence in men and bladder dysfunction in men and women. Transmesorectal resection involves complete removal of the lymph node bearing mesorectum along with its intact enveloping fascia. It is a curative resection of rectal tumours of the middle and lower thirds of the rectum, either as part of Low Anterior Resection (LAR) or Abdominoperineal Resection (APR). Option A: The majority of colorectal cancers are sporadic. Approximately 5% of all colorectal cancers are attributed to familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and Lynch syndrome (hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer). Option B: The large bowel can tolerate delivered radiation doses of up to 6000 cGy. However, a lower dose of 45 Gy is recommended for colorectal tumours. High levels of radiation targeted a colon tumours would include the small bowel in the treatment field. This results in complications such as radiation enteritis. Option D: The precise location of the rectal tumour is determined using rigid proctosigmoidoscope or flexible sigmoidoscopy and biopsy. The other investigations used in rectal cancer include: Digital rectal examination - for assessing the depth of penetration Endorectal ultrasound or MRI - provides an accurate assessment of the extent of invasion of the bowel wall MRI with an endorectal coil - is the investigation of choice to assess the 'T' and 'N' stages CECT - for evaluation of metastasis.

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding rectal carcinoma?
options: Hartmann’s operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
Early morning spurious diarrhoea and tenesmus can occur
Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke’s staging
explanation: Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma. Colorectal cancer is: The second most common malignancy globally The second most common cancer in women The third most common cancer in men The fourth most common cause of death due to cancer. Symptoms of rectal carcinoma include: Painless bleeding - earliest and most common Alteration of bowel habits - change in frequency and consistency of the stool Tenesmus - unable to pass a motion even when there is the sensation of needing to evacuate the bowel. It is suggestive of a tumor of the lower half of the rectum Early morning bloody diarrhea (option C) - passage of blood and mucus in addition to feces. Pain and weight loss are usually late symptoms Abdominal examination and digital rectal examination are used for the primary evaluation. Rigid sigmoidoscopy is performed to obtain a biopsy. A synchronous tumor (primary tumor with a different origin than the one currently investigated) is excluded by performing a colonoscopy. Modified Duke’s classification: A Growth limited up to the rect al mucosa (option D) B B1: Tumor invading muscular is propria, no lymph node in vasion.B2: Tumors invading i nto or through serosa, no ly mph node invasion. C C1: The tumour did not excee d the bowel wall, lymph node metastasis.C2: Tumour exce eded the intestinal wall and l ymph node metastasis. D Distant metastasis Surgery is the mainstay of management for rectal carcinoma. Non-operative management is offered to only those patients who have a complete clinical response to neoadjuvant. The type of surgery depends on multiple factors (size, location, age of the patient, etc). However, the general consensus is: Early cancer (T1 and a few T2) is locally excised via the transanal approach. Most rectal cancer is treated by anterior resection and colorectal/coloanal anastomosis. Low extensive tumors are treated by laparoscopic abdominoperineal resection(APR) and permanent colostomy. Hartmann’s operation (option A) is preferred in old and frail patients due to poor anal sphincter and postoperative incontinence.

question_text: In patients with rectal carcinoma, what is the investigation of choice for assessment of perirectal nodes and the depth of penetration?
explanation: Endorectal-coil magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the best modality for predicting lymph node invasion and overall local staging. It can also identify foci at sites not only within the mesorectum but also outside the mesorectal fascia, such as pelvic sidewalls, and can identify the depth of penetration.

question_text: A patient with rectal carcinoma is posted under your unit for surgery. Which of the following correctly describes the margins of clearance that will be required in this surgery?
explanation: The margins of clearance required for the surgery of rectal carcinoma is: Proximal - 5 cm Distal - 2 cm Radial- 5 cm (for the removal of mesorectal nodes) Historically, a 5 cm clearance margin was the common practice. However, the 5 cm rule has been replaced by the 2 cm rule to help preserve the anal sphincters. When a negative distal margin can be achieved by sparing the sphincter, a sphincter sparing surgery such as low anterior resection (LAR) is performed. If it is not possible to achieve a negative distal margin and spare the sphincter (when the tumour is within 5cm of anal verge), abdominal perineal resection (APR) is done. APR/LAR must include total mesorectal excision (TME) to ensure margin clearance and lymph node retrieval.

question_text: A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of intermittent blood in stools for the past 3 months. After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with rectal adenocarcinoma which is located 8 cm from the anal verge. There is no nodal or distant metastasis. Which of the following surgeries would you prefer in managing this patient?
explanation: Low anterior resection (LAR) is the preferred surgery in rectal carcinoma which is located at least 5 - 5.5 cm away from the anal verge. It is not performed: If adequate margin could not be achieved even after preoperative chemoradiotherapy If the sphincters have to be sacrificed to achieve an adequate margin In patients who cannot tolerate low anastomosis. In such cases, where anterior resection cannot be performed in distal rectal cancers, abdominoperineal resection (APR) is done. APR/LAR must include total mesorectal excision (TME) to ensure margin clearance and lymph node retrieval.

question_text: Transanal local excision can be done in rectal carcinoma patients with all of the following tumour features except .
options: Tumor within 8 cm of the anal verge
T2 tumor without lymph node involvemen

Transanal local excision is recommended for selected T1, N0 early-stage cancers which fulfill the following criteria: Small (<3 cm), well- to moderately-differentiated tumors Tumors within 8 cm of the anal verge Tumors limited to <30% of the rectal circumference Tumors with no evidence of nodal involvemen Full-thickness excision must be feasible.

question_text: Which of the following chemotherapy regimens is used for treating patients with rectal carcinoma?
explanation: 5-Fluorouracil-based regimens with leucovorin and oxaliplatin (FOLFOX) reduce recurrence and improve survival in patients with colorectal carcinoma. Irinotecan (FOLFIRI regimen) is also used as a second-line chemotherapy agent. Adjuvant chemotherapy is routinely recommended in patients with lymph node involvement. Hartmann’s operation
explanation: Hartmann’s operation is an excellent procedure in an elderly, frail patient in whom there is concern about anal sphincter function or the viability of an anastomosis. Through an abdominal incision, the rectum is excised, the rectal stump is stapled closed and the proximal colon exteriorized as a permanent end colostomy. Note: Endoluminal stenting is being increasingly used in patients with obstructing carcinomas. It can be either used as a palliative procedure or to relieve the obstruction. question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the anatomy of the anal canal below the pectinate line?
options: Lymphatic drainage is to inguinal nodes
Innervation is by the inferior rectal nerves
Venous drainage is into the systemic circulation
Tumors are more likely to be adenocarcinoma
explanation: Adenocarcinoma is more likely to be seen above the pectinate line. Tumors below the pectinate line are more likely to be squamous cell carcinoma. The pectinate line is at the junction of the upper two-thirds and the lower one-third of the anal canal. Developmentally, it represents the hindgut–proctodeum junction. The part of the anal canal above this line developed from the hindgut and the part below developed from the proctodeum.

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, smooth muscle fibres, and elastic connective tissue. explanation: Prolapse with spontaneous reduction is suggestive of second-degree hemorrhoids.

question_text: A man presented with bleeding per rectum which he noticed after passing stools for the past 2 weeks. explanation: In the given scenario, as the prolapsed haemorrhoids required manual reduction, it is suggestive of third-degree haemorrhoids.

question_text: In patients with which of the following conditions can injection sclerotherapy be ideally used?
explanation: Injection sclerotherapy is ideal for the treatment of first and second-degree hemorrhoids (bleeding or spontaneously reducing hemorrhoids). 1 to 3 mL of a sclerosing solution (phenol in olive oil, sodium morrhuate, or quinine urea) is injected into the submucosa of each hemorrhoid. Complications of sclerotherapy include infection and fibrosis.

question_text: A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with severe anorectal pain during and after defecation. The pain was present for 6 months but has increased in severity over the past 1 day. Examination finding is shown below. A per-rectal examination could not be performed due to pain. How will you manage this patient?
explanation: The clinical features and the image are suggestive of thrombosed external hemorrhoids. Patients who present within 48 hours of thrombosis should undergo thrombus evacuation under local anesthesia. This procedure involves the removal of the clot with an elliptical incision on the skin. After the initial 48-72 hours, pain typically plateaus and hence the patient is treated conservatively with analgesics and a sitz bath. Grade1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, and cryotherapy. Surgery is indicated in: Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids Hemorrhoids with a significant external component Early grade hemorrhoids not responding to simple procedures Surgical procedures used in the removal of hemorrhoids are: Open (Milligan–Morgan) hemorrhoidectomy Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy Stapled hemorrhoidopexy - is circumferential rectal mucosectomy. It is associated with reduced postoperative pain, faster recovery and shorter hospital stay Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation Open hemorrhoidectomy - Artery forceps are applied to the skin-covered external components of the hemorrhoid and traction is given to reveal the internal components. Dissection of the lateral pedicle is performed and finally, the pedicles are transfixed. Mucocutaneous bridges are left intact in this technique. The image below shows the procedure. Closed hemorrhoidectomy - The hemorrhoid is excised with the overlying mucosa. The hemorrhoid is dissected from the underlying sphincter and the mucus defect is then closed. This technique is associated with higher chances of recurrence. This procedure is however quick to perform and less painful. The image below describes the procedure.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common complication following hemorrhoidectomy?
explanation: Urinary retention is the most common complication following hemorrhoidectomy. Conventional hemorrhoidectomy(open or closed technique), is considered to be an extremely painful procedure. Dysfunction of the detrusor muscle or the trigone in response to pain or distention of the anal canal or perineum has been postulated as the cause of urinary retention post hemorrhoidectomy. Other complications include: Fecal incontinence Infection Delayed hemorrhage Stricture
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 35-year-old man came with complaints of chronic constipation, blood-streaked stools, and pain during defecation for 2 months. On examination, a sentinel tag was noted at the anal orifice. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: In the given scenario, the presence of a sentinel tag is suggestive of chronic anal fissure. An anal fissure is a linear or oval-shaped tear in the anal canal starting just below the dentate line extending to the anal verge. It can be acute or chronic. Chronic anal fissures last for more than 6-8 weeks, and are frequently associated with a triad of findings: Sentinel tag Hypertrophied anal papillae at the upper end of the fissure in the anal cana Deep canoe-shaped ulcer Acute fissures are shallow tears in the anoderm. They are associated with: Anal pain Spasm Bleeding with defecation The below image shows features of a chronic anal fissure
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the most common location of anal fissures?
explanation: Over 90% of fissures are located in the posterior midline, with the rest being located in the anterior midline of the anal canal. The main hypothesis is that the posterior midline area may have decreased blood flow due to the configuration of the blood vessels of the anus. Also, the spasm of the internal anal sphincter may cause further reduction of the blood flow to the posterior anal canal.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the procedure of choice in a patient with chronic anal fissure?
explanation: Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the procedure of choice for chronic anal fissures. Surgical therapy has traditionally been recommended for chronic anal fissures that have failed medical therapy. The aim of this procedure is to decrease the spasms of the internal sphincter by dividing a portion of the muscle. Approximately 30% of the muscle sphincter fibers are divided laterally using an open or closed technique. The initial treatment of anal fissures includes: Frequent sitz baths Analgesics Stool softeners High-fiber diet If conservative management with dietary changes and laxatives fail, other options including topical analgesics such as 2% lidocaine jelly, topical nifedipine, topical nitroglycerin, or a combination of topical nifedipine and lidocaine can be attempted. Option A: Miligan-Morgan procedure is an open hemorrhoidectomy Option C: Transanal resection is used to remove early-stage rectal cancers in the lower rectum Option D: Altermeier's procedure is used for rectal prolapse
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which type of anal fistula is seen in this image?
explanation: In the given image, the fistula traverses the internal sphincter and tracks down the space between the internal and external anal sphincters. Hence, it is an inter-sphincteric type of anal fistula. It is the most common anal fistula. A fistula-in-ano is an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. Patients usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain. Anal fistulas can be simplex or complex fistulas. Simple fistulas- include a single tract, subcutaneous tract, and those that involve less than 30% of the external sphincter. They are easier to treat, and have lower chances of recurrence. Complex fistulas- include fistulas involving more than 30% of the external sphincter, with multiple tracts, recurrent fistulas, and those associated with other predisposing factors, such as Crohn disease and radiation treatment. Fistulas can also be classified into high or low-lying fistulas, based on their location with respect to the puborectalis muscle.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a history of discharge from the perianal region for the past 1 week. On examination, an external opening was seen at 2 o'clock position around the anal orifice. On per rectal examination, an opening was palpable at 3 o'clock position at the dentate line. What is the gold standard investigation for assessing this patient?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of an anal fistula. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. Investigations available for fistula-in-ano are: Fistulogram Endoanal ultrasound MRI Computed tomography (CT) scan Endocoil MRI Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient presented with serous discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. On examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. According to Goodsall's rule at what position from the dentate line will the internal opening be palpated in this patient?
explanation: The given case scenario is suggestive of fistula-in-ano with external opening at 8’O clock position which implies that the external opening of the fistula is lying posterior to the midline. According to the Goodsall rule, fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline. Hence, the fistulous tract opens internally at a 6’O clock position. A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin. Goodsall’s rule: Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radia tract. Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline. However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline
subject: Surgery

question_text: A known case of Crohn's disease presented to the clinic with a history of discharge from the anal region for the past 2 weeks. The patient underwent drainage of an ischiorectal abscess 2 months back. Clinical examination and imaging reveal the presence of a supra-sphincteric perianal fistula. How will you manage this patient?
explanation: In the given scenario, a history of Crohn's disease, recurrent anorectal abscess, and the imaging findings point towards a complex anal fistula. It will be managed using Seton's placement, which is done in two stages. A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. Setons can be classified as draining or cutting. Cutting seton A cutting seton has been used as a staged fistulectomy, especially in high trans-sphincteric fistulas. After the seton is passed during the primary surgery, it has to be tightened at regular intervals, till it cuts through completely. Loose/draining seton In this method, the seton is placed to maintain drainage and create scar tissue around the sphincter so that its edges do not retract after cutting. Option B: Fistulotomy involves opening the fistula tract and possibly dividing the sphincter muscle. It is very effective for simple fistulas with minimal sphincter involvement. Option C: Lateral internal sphincterotomy is a technique used for chronic anal fissures. Option D: In fistulectomy, the fistulous tract is cut out completely. Other surgeries for fistula in-ano include: Endorectal advancement flap- involves closure of the internal opening of the tract, debridement of the tract, and mobilization of anorectal mucosa to cover the defect. It is usually done for complex fistulas. LIFT- Ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract involves identification of the internal opening with suture ligation of the intersphincteric portion of the fistula. The tract and infected gland are then excised and the wound is debrided with curettage. It can be done for both simple and complex fistulas.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of anorectal suppuration?
explanation: The most common cause of anorectal suppuration is nonspecific cryptoglandular infection. Anorectal abscess originates from an infection arising in the cryptoglandular epithelium lining the anal canal. The increased incidence of ischio-rectal fossa infection is due to poor blood supply. It may also be caused by other reasons such as: Crohn's disease Trauma Immunodeficiency resulting from human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection or malignancy (both hematologic and anorectal cancer) Tuberculosis Hidradenitis suppurativa
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the most common type of anorectal abscess?
explanation: A perianal abscess is the most common type of anorectal abscess. Anorectal abscess refers to a collection of pus in the anal or rectal region. More commonly seen in men. There are four types of anorectal abscesses: Peri-anal (most common) Ischio-recta Inter-sphincteric Supra-levator Treatment: Drainage of pus + Antibiotics
subject: Surgery

question_text: A jeep driver presented with a swelling in the natal cleft, with pain, difficulty in sitting, and occasional purulent discharge from the area. Examination finding is shown below. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?
options: Hair follicles are seen in the wall of sinus
Hirsute habitus is a risk factor
Commonly seen between the ages of 15 and 40 years
explanation: The given condition is a pilonidal sinus. Hair follicles have almost never been demonstrated in the walls of the sinus. The hair projecting from the sinus is dead hair, with its pointed ends directed towards the blind end of the sinus. Pilonidal sinus disease is a disease of the inter-gluteal region, characterized by the formation of a sinus in the cleft of the buttocks. It is more common in males between 15-40 years of age. Risk factors include: Male sex Family history Being overweight or obese Trauma or irritation to the perianal region Occupations involving sitting for long periods- jeep/lorry drivers Hirsute habitus - thick body hair Poor hygiene Sites involved: Natal cleft (most commonly) Interdigital cleft Face Axilla Buttock friction and shearing forces in these areas allow broken hairs to enter the skin and create a subcutaneous, chronically infected midline track. An infected hair follicle can also form such a track. Secondary tracks can arise as openings, lined with granulation tissue and discharge. Clinical features: Intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine Abscess - due to a foreign-body-type reaction Treatment Conservative treatment: Strict hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area. Abscess: Rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. If refractory to the above treatment- drainage with thorough curettage of granulation tissue and hair. Surgical techniques: Bascom’s, Karydaki's procedures are for chronic pilonidal disease. Recurrence is common even after adequate excision of the tract.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is not used in the treatment of pilonidal sinus diseases?
explanation: Surgical approaches parallel to the natal cleft, and not along the natal cleft are preferred, to reduce chances of recurrence. Pilonidal sinus disease treatment includes non-surgical and surgical approaches. The non-surgical approach includes conservative treatment with proper hygiene and regular shaving of hair in the area. In case of an abscess- adequate rest, baths, local antiseptic dressings, and broad-spectrum antibiotics are advised. Surgical approaches for the management of pilonidal sinus disease include: Incision and drainage- for pilonidal abscess refractory to medical treatment Bascom's procedure- is a cleft lift procedure in which hair follicles parallel to the natal cleft are removed under local anesthesia Karydakis procedure- an ovoid area of pathologic tissue is excised parallel to the natal cleft and a fasciocutaneous flap is mobilized to cover the defect Limberg/ rhomboid flap- excises the pilonidal disease in a rhomboid shape and rotates a fasciocutaneous flap for wound closure Others- VY advancement flaps, and Z-plasty The given image shows a Limberg/rhomboid flap done in pilonidal sinus surgery:
subject: Surgery

question_text: An elderly female presented with severe persisting per rectal itching for the past 1 year, despite standard topical therapy. On examination, irregular eczematous lesions were seen at the anal orifice. Biopsy of the lesion revealed large vacuolated cells containing mucin. Which of the following is it likely to be?
explanation: The given history and presence of large vacuolated cells (Paget cells) on biopsy is suggestive of Paget's disease of the anal canal. It is a rare intraepithelial adenocarcinoma. Paget’s disease is most commonly seen in areas with a high density of apocrine sweat glands, in elderly females. These can develop into an invasive cancer of the underlying apocrine glands. Clinical features include intractable itching, burning, bleeding per rectally. 10% of the patients are asymptomatic. On examination, eczematous, well-demarcated plaque, with occasional ulceration and scaling can be seen. On histology presence of Paget cells (large, vacuolated cells with mucin) confirms the diagnosis. Treatment: Treatment of choice- complete excision Limited, noninvasive disease-wide local excision and closure of the defect with primary sutures or with V-Y advancement flaps Invasive component- radical resection with abdominoperineal resection (APR) Medically unfit for surgery - topical 5-FU, imiquimod, cryotherapy, or argon beam laser therapy Recurrence- re-excision (as long as the disease remains noninvasive) Note: Most common site of extra-mammary Paget’s disease – anogenital region > axilla > eyelid. Perianal Paget’s disease is usually associated with underlying visceral malignancy, most commonly colorectal adenocarcinoma.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal?
options: Proctoscopy is the investigation of choice
Most common presentation is ano-rectal pain
Most common type of anal canal carcinoma
explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common anal canal carcinoma. SCC > Basal cell carcinoma >Melanoma The median age at diagnosis for SCC is 60 years. Patients most commonly present with bleeding per rectum. Commonly metastasizes to the liver and lungs. The most common site of lymph node metastasis is to inguinal lymph nodes. Risk Factors: Human papillomavirus (HPV) (types 16, 18, 31, 33) infection Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or immunosuppression Smoking Anal receptive intercourse Sexual promiscuity Anal intraepithelial neoplasia History of vulvar or cervical cancer Diagnosis: Proctoscopy with biopsy- investigation of choice MRI- for local staging CT scan- to evaluate for distant metastasis Treatment : Nigro regimen- chemoradiation is the treatment of choice If any residual tumor is left behind after chemoradiation, abdominoperineal resection (APR) is performed 8th AJCC: TNM Classificatio n of Carcinoma of the Anal C anal and Anal Margin Primary Tumor: 8th AJCC: TNM Classificatio n of Carcinoma of the Anal C anal and Anal Margin Tis - high-grade squamous in traepithelial lesionT1 - 2 cm or lessT2 - >2 - 5 cmT3 - >5 c mT4 - invades adjacent organ, e.g. vagina, urethra, bladder. (invasion of the rectal wall, p erirectal skin, subcutaneous t issue, or sphincter muscle is not included as T4). Regional Nodes: Regional lymph nodes includ e mesorectal, inguinal (superf icial, deep), superior rectal (h emorrhoidal), external iliac, a nd internal iliac (hypogastric) groups.N0 - no regional lym ph node metastasesN1a - ing uinal, mesorectal, or internal iliac lymph nodesN1b - exter nal iliac nodesN1c - external i liac nodes + N1a Distant Metastases: M0 - noM1 - yes Stage grouping: 0 - TisI - T1 N0IIA - T2 N0II B - T3 N0IIIA - T1-2 N1IIIB - T4 N0IIIC - T3-4 N1IV - M1

question_text: A 60-year-old man with bleeding per rectum is suspected to have squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
options: Surgical excision with CO2 laser treatment
explanation: Treatment of choice for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal is Nigro regimen/ chemoradiation. A combination of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) with mitomycin C/ cisplatin is followed by external beam radiation to the pelvis with a minimum dose of 45 Gy.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
Which of the following is true about melanoma of the anal canal?
Wide local excision is done for tumors with sphincter involvement
options: Staged by depth or thickness of melanoma lesion
explanation: Anorectal melanoma is staged by the depth or thickness of the lesion. Anal canal melanoma is more common in females. The tumor appears as small and polypoidal or large and ulcerating. Clinical features include: Anorectal bleeding, itching, pain, mass Tenesmus, and changes in bowel habits Mesorectal lymph node metastases Inguinal lymphadenopathy Distant spread- to bones, lungs, and liver Diagnosis is frequently made following hemorrhoidectomy or local excision of the perianal mass. Treatment: Tumors without anal sphincter involvement- wide local excision with negative margins Large tumors invading sphincters- palliative APR Regardless of stage, 5-year survival rates for anorectal melanoma are very poor, averaging at about 6%. The median survival time following diagnosis is 12–18 months. Note: Most common sites of melanoma are skin >eye > anorectal region Hernia
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding the inguinal canal?
options: Conjoint tendon forms a part of the posterior wa
Superficial ring is an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis
Deep ring is an opening in the transverse abdominis
Internal oblique forms both the anterior and superior walls
explanation: The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, not in the transversus abdominis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: All of the following are contents of inguinal canal except .
explanation: The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve is not a content of the inguinal canal. The contents of the inguinal canal include: Spermatic cord in males Round ligament in females Ilioinguinal nerve in both the sexes. The contents of the spermatic cord include: Cremaster muscle fibers Testicular artery and accompanying veins Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve Vas deferens Cremasteric vessels Lymphatics Processus vaginalis

question_text: Which of the following structures does not form the boundary of Hesselbach’s triangle?
explanation: Vas deferens does not form the boundary of Hesselbach’s triangle. Hesselbach's triangle (also called the inguinal triangle) is a region of the deep part of the anterior abdominal wall.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A resident while assisting a case of laparoscopic hernia repair observes the surgeon dissect certain anatomical landmarks to expose the triangle of doom. Which of the following does not form a boundary of this triangle?
explanation: Cooper’s ligament does not form the boundary of the triangle of doom.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding inguinal hernia?
explanation: The medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by vas deferens and the medial border of the myopectineal orifice is bounded by the lateral border of rectus abdominis. The triangle of doom is bounded: Medially by the vas deferens Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels) Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection The myopectineal orifice is an osseo-myo-aponeurotic tunnel. It is through this tunnel that all groin hernias occur. It is bounded: Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath. Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle. Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle. Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common type of hernia in females?
explanation: Indirect inguinal hernias are by far the most common type of hernia in women. It is the most common hernia regardless of gender. In men, indirect hernias predominate over direct hernias at a ratio of 2:1. Femoral hernia and umbilical hernias are more common in females compared to males at ratios of 10:1 and 2:1, respectively. Although femoral hernias occur more frequently in women than in men, inguinal hernia remains the most common hernia in women.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of swelling in the right groin for the past 6 months. On examination, an irreducible hernia is present in the right groin. Which of the following structures would be helpful in identifying if the hernia is inguinal or femoral in origin?
explanation: Pubic tubercle is used to differentiate between inguinal and femoral hernias. Inguinal hernia is above and medial to the pubic tubercle. Femoral hernia is below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Another structure that is useful in differentiating between inguinal and femoral hernia is inguinal ligament. An inguinal hernia leaves the abdominal cavity just above the inguinal ligament and a femoral hernia leaves just below the inguinal ligament.
subject: Surgery

question_text: An elderly male patient is diagnosed with direct inguinal hernia. Which of the following statements is true?
options: The sac lies medial to the inferior epigastric artery
Cough impulse is felt on the index finger
Can descend till the bottom of scrotum
The neck is narrow and is prone for strangulation
explanation: The sac and contents of a direct hernia protrude through Hesselbach’s triangle, i.e., medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Bubonocele is a type of .
explanation: Bubonocele is a type of indirect inguinal hernia where the hernia is limited to the inguinal canal. Indirect inguinal hernia is more common on the right side because of the delay in atrophy of the processus vaginalis after the normal slower descent of the right testis to the scrotum during fetal development.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common serious complication expected to occur in patients with hernia?
explanation: Strangulation is the most common serious complication of a hernia. An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the sac of a hernia.An incarcerated hernia can lead to a bowel obstruction or strangulation. Obstruction is characterized by colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, abdominal distension and obstipation. Features of obstruction along with vascular compromise is seen in strangluation. Strangulation occurs in 1% to 3% of groin hernias. It is more common at the extremes of life. Most strangulated hernias are indirect inguinal hernias. However, femoral hernias have the highest rate of strangulation (15% to 20%) of all hernias, and it is, therefore, recommended that all femoral hernias be repaired at the time of discovery. Tenderness is the first sign of strangulation. The first step is the correction of hypovolemia. The treatment of choice is immediate surgery. The fundus is opened first during surgery.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient presents with a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?
options: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a direct hernia, for which Lichtenstein mesh repair is the appropriate surgical method for its management. The contents of a direct hernia protrude outward, forward, and medial to the inferior epigastric artery and the deep inguinal ring. Whereas, the contents of an indirect hernia protrude lateral to the inferior epigastric artery. The sac of an indirect inguinal hernia passes from the deep inguinal ring obliquely towards the superficial inguinal ring and then to the scrotum. A direct hernia protrudes through the Hesselbach triangle, which is a zone of weakness for direct hernias. A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an inguinal hernia. It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic nonabsorbable mesh is used to bridge the defect in this repair. Other surgical methods used for the repair of an inguinal hernia are: Bassini repair - It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches/conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament. Shouldice repair - It is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is associated with a very low recurrence rate. Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) - It is an extension of Lichtenstein’s original mesh repair and has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. In this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like an upside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, large indirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femora hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper's ligament. Stoppa-Rives repair - It is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitonea space. Herniotomy - It is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 50-year-old obese male patient presented with bilateral, large inguinal hernias. He had been operated on for hernia twice in the past and is now posted for Stoppa's repair. Which of
the following statements regarding this procedure is false?
options: This procedure refers to open preperitoneal hernia repair
The mesh is placed in the retromuscular space
The mesh needs to be sutured to the posterior rectus sheath in case of small defects
This procedure is based on the principle of Pascal's law
explanation: With smaller defects, the mesh does not need to be sutured in Stoppa's repair. This is based on Pascal's law. Pascal’s law states that any additional pressure exerted on an enclosed fluid mass is transmitted equally in all directions.The abdomen is an enclosed space and intra-abdominal pressure is distributed equally over the mesh, thereby keeping the mesh in place. Stoppa's repair is an open preperitoneal mesh repair primarily indicated for large, recurrent, bilateral hernias. In Stoppa’s mesh repair, a large piece of mesh is placed in the retro muscular space, over the posterior rectus sheath or peritoneum. This mesh is not sutured in patients with small defects because it is held in place by intra-abdominal pressure (Pascal’s law). This allows the eventual incorporation of the mesh with the surrounding tissues. Alternatively, in larger defects, the mesh can be secured laterally with several sutures.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the clinic with a history of a reducible and painless swelling in the right groin for the past 2 months. After the clinical and radiological investigations, the diagnosis of a right-sided inguinal hernia was made. The patient is posted for hernia repair surgery. Which of the following steps will not be done in this patient during the repair?
explanation: Inguinal hernia in a child is treated by herniotomy. In this procedure, repair of the inguinal ring is not done. This is because the inguinal hernia in the pediatric population is due to the presence of patent processus vaginalis and not due to the weakening of the abdominal muscles or the ligaments. Herniotomy involves either reduction of the hernial sac alone, or opening of the hernial sac, reduction of the contents, transfixation of the neck, and excision of the patent processus vaginalis/ hernial sac.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty?
explanation: The most appropriate mesh used in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores. Lightweight meshes generally contain less material and induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, which results in better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain. Meshes with large pores exhibit less inflammatory infiltrate, connective tissue, and scar bridging, which allows increased soft tissue ingrowth. They have greater elasticity and flexibility and also shrink less resulting in lesser adhesions, better tissue incorporation, and decreased patient discomfort and pain. So the best mesh type among the given options is lightweight mesh with large pores. Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological depending on their composition. Synthetic meshes are made from polypropylene, polyester, or PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene). PTFE meshes are hydrophobic with a lower risk of adhesion. Biological meshes are acellular matrix materials derived from humans or animals and have lesser complications. But due to poor collagen deposition and absorption, they rapidly lose mechanical strength and hence their use is restricted to infected environments. Note: To promote better tissue integration, a composite mesh was developed which combines the attributes of polypropylene and PTFE by layering the two substances on top of one another. POLYPROP YLENE POLYESTE R PTFE monofilam ent multifilame nt solid hydrophobi c hydrophilic hydropho bic rigid elastic rigid
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient operated for direct inguinal hernia developed sensory loss at the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?
explanation: Loss of sensation in the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the ilioinguinal nerve. It is most commonly injured within the inguinal canal in open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury. The iliohypogastric nerve carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve in the right iliac fossa rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nerve supply from other sources too. If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in direct inguinal hernia. Iliohypogastric nerve can also get injured following appendicectomy. Injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females. Injury to the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 50-year-old male patient with chronic constipation is diagnosed with Type 7 Gilbert hernia.
This refers to
explanation: Femoral hernia is classified under type 7 Gilbert hernia. As per Nyhus classification system, femoral hernia is classified under type 3C.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements about femoral hernia is true?
options: All femoral hernias should be repaired
Femoral vein lies medial to the sac
explanation: All femoral hernias should be repaired and incarcerated femoral hernias should have the hernia sac contents examined for viability. Option A: Femoral hernia occurs in both males and females, but it is more common in multiparous females. Femoral hernia is more common on the right side because of the tamponading effect of the sigmoid colon on the left femoral canal. This effect is absent on the right side. Option C: The incidence of strangulation in femoral hernias is high because of the narrowness of the neck of the sac and rigidity of the femoral ring. question_text: While performing an elective hernia repair, the surgeon notices that the posterior wall of the hernia sac is formed by the sigmoid colon. What is this type of hernia known as?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is that of a sliding hernia. Sliding hernia occurs when an internal organ composes a portion of the wall of the hernia sac. The most common viscus involved are as follows: Left side: sigmoid colon and its mesentery Right side: cecum It is more common on the left side. Most sliding hernias are variants of indirect inguinal hernias. The primary danger associated with a sliding hernia is the failure to recognize the visceral component of the hernia sac resulting in injury to the bowel or bladder. Option A: A lumbar hernia is a posterolateral body wall hernia where the bowel, omentum, or pre-peritoneal fat herniates through the lumbar triangles. Option C: A Spigelian hernia occurs through slit-like defects in the anterior abdominal wall adjacent to the semilunar line. question_text: A 25-year-old fit athlete presents to the OPD with complaints of nausea and heartburn. On examination, a soft, pea-sized swelling could be palpated on his abdomen. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: The likely diagnosis in this patient is epigastric hernia, also known as fatty hernia of linea alba. Epigastric hernia is located between the xiphoid process and umbilicus, usually in the midline. It occurs more commonly in males. A soft midline swelling can be felt more easily than seen. question_text: An 83-year-old lady was brought to the OPD with a two-day history of nausea, thigh pain and obstipation. Howship Romberg sign can be elicited
Transinguinal approach is preferred for surgery

Howship-Romberg sign refers to pain in the anteromedial aspect of the thigh due to compression of the obturator nerve that is relieved by thigh flexion. Obturator hernia is also known as skinny old lady hernia and French hernia. It occurs more commonly in thin, elderly, debilitated females. Predisposing factors are: Women with wider pelvis and more triangular obturator cana Malnutrition Chronic constipation Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) Multiparity Ascites Kyphoscoliosis Intestinal obstruction can occur. question_text: An infant who is diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism presents with the following hernia. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this child?

question_text: A baby was born with a congenital defect as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
options: It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce before 7 weeks
Topical application of silver nitrate is done
explanation: The congenital defect showing herniation of the intestinal contents enclosed in a sac from the umbilicus is suggestive of omphalocele. It is due to the failure of the physiological hernia to reduce into the abdominal cavity before 10 weeks resulting in non-closure of the umbilical ring. Physiological herniation of the midgut through the umbilicus occurs during the 5th week so as to accommodate the rapidly growing intestine and persists until the 10th week. Omphalocele is seen in term babies and is usually associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of -fetoprotein. An omphalocele may contain the stomach, liver, and intestines. These contents are enclosed in a sac. The treatment is as follows: Preservation of the intact sac with a sterile, moistened, saline gauze or transparent bowel bag. IV fluids should be started, along with gastric tube decompression and IV antibiotics. Topical application of povidone-iodine ointment, merbromin (mercurochrome), or silver nitrate allows the sac to thicken and epithelialize gradually. Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects.

question_text: A 3-month-old child presented with umbilical discharge. Abdomen examination was normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is?
explanation: The given clinical image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step is the USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous or fistula and it's connections. Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities: Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between the yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which eventually gets obliterated. The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct leads to various abnormalities depending on which part of the duct remains patent. Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel’s diverticula. Persistence of the distal end near the umbilicus leads to the umbilical polyp or sinus. Persistence of the distal end with mucus retention leads to the cyst, which may be associated with the intestine or the umbilicus by a fibrous band. A fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to an enterocutaneous fistula. Patent urachus occurs due to the failure of urachus to obliterate, resulting in a connection between the bladder and the umbilicus. Urachal cyst occurs when the urachus fails to obliterate but there is no connection between the bladder and the umbilicus. The given image below shows a urachal cyst (UC) attached to Meckel’s diverticulum (MD) on one side and urinary bladder (UB) on the other side with a patent tract- urachus (U).

question_text:
Which of the following is the most commonly seen tumor in the retroperitoneal space?
Liposarcoma
explanation: Liposarcoma is the most commonly seen tumor in retroperitoneal space. Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant. Malignant retroperitoneal tumors may be mesodermal (75%), neuroectodermal (24%), or embryonic remnant (1%) in origin. Rarely it can be urologic or metastatic also. The order of frequency of primary retroperitoneal malignancy is as follows: Liposarcoma Leiomyosarcoma Rhabdomyosarcoma Fibrosarcoma Malignant nerve sheath tumors Liposarcoma is composed of three histologic varieties (listed in order of decreasing frequency): Well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma Pleomorphic liposarcoma Myxoid/round cell liposarcoma Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while the well-differentiated is the least malignant. Myxoid liposarcoma has intermediate malignant behavior. Diagnosis is confirmed by contrast-enhanced CT with CT of the chest to look for metastases. Surgery is the main modality of treatment. Wide excision with complete en bloc dissection is done. Post-operative radiotherapy and chemotherapy are used as adjuvant methods. Radiotherapy is given at a dose of 5000 cGY, it can be external beam or intra-operative radiotherapy. Chemotherapeutic agents used are mesna, adriamycin, ifosfamide and dacarbazine (MAID regimen). question_text: What is the most common anomaly of the hepatic artery?
options: Independent origin of the right and left hepatic arteries from the cealic axis
Replaced right hepatic artery arising from the superior mesentric artery
explanation: The most common anomaly of the hepatic artery is replaced right hepatic artery arising from the superior mesenteric artery. Normally, the common hepatic artery gives off the right and left hepatic arteries. A middle hepatic artery branches off from the proximal left hepatic artery. The replaced right hepatic artery directly supplies the right lobe of the liver. Surgical significance: In individuals with replaced right hepatic artery, the diameter of the common hepatic artery is smaller. In liver transplant recipients, this can be a cause for the increased incidence of complications such as thrombosis. Whereas, replaced right hepatic artery is a beneficial variant for donors undergoing donation of the right lobe of the liver. The replaced right hepatic artery provides a longer and larger graft thus reducing chances of thrombosis.

question_text:
The free hepatic venous pressure(FHVP) and wedged hepatic venous pressure(WHVP) of a patient, with suspected portal hypertension, are measured. How will the hepatic venous
pressure gradient (HVPG) be determined from these values?
explanation: Hepatic Venous Pressure Gradient is measured by subtracting Free Hepatic Venous Pressure from Wedged Hepatic Venous Pressure. HVPG = WHVP – FHVP Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) is the pressure gradient between the portal vein and the inferior vena cava (IVC). It is a measure of portal venous pressure. It can quantify the degree of portal hypertension due to sinusoidal resistance to blood flow. The most accurate method of determining portal hypertension is by measuring HVPG. The most commonly used procedure involves placing a balloon catheter in the hepatic vein after a jugular vein puncture. The free hepatic venous pressure (FHVP) is measured with the balloon deflated, and the wedged hepatic venous pressure (WHVP) with the balloon inflated to occlude the hepatic vein.

question_text: Which of the following values indicate a normal portal venous pressure?
explanation: The normal portal venous pressure is 5 to 10 mmHg. Normal portal blood flow is 1 to 1.5 L/minute. Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) is the difference between the wedge and free hepatic venous pressure, which is 1 to 5 mmHg. HVPG interpretation: Normal HVPG is between 1 and 5 mmHg. Portal hypertension is present if the HVPG is  6 mmHg. Portal hypertension typically becomes clinically significant when the HVPG is  10 mmHg, at which point varices may develop. HVPG  12 mmHg, patients are at risk for variceal bleeding and the development of ascites.

question_text: A patient who is a known case of chronic pancreatitis is diagnosed with splenic vein thrombosis. Which of the following is not true about this condition?
options: USG abdomen showed normal liver and an enlarged spleen.
TIPSS is done as part of treatment
explanation: The above clinical scenario points to a case of splenic vein thrombosis which can cause left-sided portal hypertension. It is a pre-hepatic cause of portal hypertension. It is managed by splenectomy. Splenic vein thrombosis can be due to pancreatic inflammation or neoplasms (acute or chronic pancreatitis, pseudocysts, and carcinomas) that extend outside the pancreas and invades the splenic vein. This causes increased pressure in the splenic vein leading to the formation of collaterals and ultimately gastric variceal hemorrhage (not esophageal varices). Normal liver function tests, normal portal venous pressures, and splenomegaly are the distinguishing features from other forms of portal hypertension. The portal vein pressures remain normal as there is no obstruction of the hepatic venous vasculature. Diagnosis is done by gastroscopy, liver function tests, ultrasound examination (with doppler), and contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. Treatment includes splenectomy and management of the primary pancreatic pathology.

question_text: An elderly patient with chronic black tarry stools underwent an upper GI endoscopy. Gastric mucosa appeared as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image shows the snake-skin appearance of the gastric mucosa, which is seen in cases of portal hypertensive gastropathy. Portal hypertensive gastropathy is characterized by the diffuse dilation of the mucosal and submucosal venous plexus of the stomach associated with overlying gastritis. Option A: Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) also known as watermelon stomach is a significant cause of acute or chronic gastrointestinal blood loss in the elderly, characterized endoscopically by watermelon stripes. It is associated with heterogeneous medical conditions, including hepatic, cardiac, and renal diseases. question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Budd-Chiari syndrome?
options: Caudate lobe hypertrophy is seen in approximately 50% of the patients
Doppler ultrasonography is the initial investigation of choice
It becomes clinically significant when one or more major hepatic veins are obstructed
Oral contraceptive use is a risk factor
explanation: Budd–Chiari syndrome (BCS) is an uncommon congestive hepatopathy characterized by the obstruction of hepatic venous outflow and it becomes clinically significant when two or more major hepatic veins are obstructed. Types: Primary Budd–Chiari syndrome: when the obstructive process involves an endoluminal venous thrombosis. Secondary Budd–Chiari syndrome: when the veins are compressed or invaded by a neighboring esion originating outside the vein. Most common presentation: ascites and abdominal discomfort. Risk factors include-Primary myeloproliferative disorders, anticardiolipin antibodies, hyperhomocysteinemia, and oral contraceptive use. Caudate lobe hypertrophy is seen in approximately 50% of the cases and it is because the caudate lobe drains directly into the IVC. Abdominal ultrasonography with color Doppler is the initial investigation of choice and can demonstrate the absence of hepatic vein flow, spider web hepatic veins, and collateral hepatic veins. The definitive radiographic study is hepatic venography to determine the presence and extent of hepatic vein thrombus as well as measure inferior vena cava (IVC) pressures.

question_text: A 43-year-old woman presented to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and distension for the past 3 months. Her past medical records show that she has a JAK2 mutation and investigations revealed serum protein to be 3 g/dL and ascitic fluid protein to be 1.5 g/dL. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Anticoagulation is the mainstay of treatment
Colour flow doppler is the initial investigation of choice
Surgical intervention is done in all cases
Ascites is a bad prognostic factor
explanation: The above clinical scenario describes a case of late budd-chiari syndrome and surgical interventions are not done in all cases of budd chiari syndrome. SAAG = (serum albumin)  (ascitic fluid albumin) = (3) - (1.5) = 1.5g/dL As SAAG is >1.1g/dL( 1.5g/dL) and ascitic fluid protein is < 2.5 g/dL, the most likely cause is late Budd-Chiari syndrome.Surgical interventions are done in those patients of Budd Chiari syndrome who are not responding to medical therapy. Colour flow doppler is the initial investigation of choice. Treatment: Initial treatment consists of medically managing the underlying disease process and preventing the extension of the hepatic vein thrombosis through systemic anticoagulation. The associated portal hypertension and ascites are managed in a manner similar to that in most cirrhotic patients. Radiologic and surgical intervention should be reserved for patients whose condition is nonresponsive to medical therapy. Percutaneous angioplasty and transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS), in combination with thrombolytic therapy, are the preferred strategies to restore the outflow of blood from the liver. Surgical shunting, particularly with the side-to-side portacaval shunt, turns the portal vein into a hepatic outflow tract. Factors contributing to a bad prognosis in Budd-Chiari syndrome: Involvement of all three hepatic veins and/or portal vein Presence of ascites Older age at the time of presentation High Child-Pugh score Chronic disease at presentation Note: JAK2 mutation points to a possibility of polycythemia vera predisposing the patient to hypercoagulable states and the formation of thrombus anywhere in the body. From the serum and ascitic protein values, we can calculate the SAAG (serum protein-ascitic protein).

question_text: A patient comes with active variceal bleeding. Which of the following is not done?
explanation: Platelet transfusion is not done in the case of active variceal bleeding unless coagulopathy is confirmed as the cause. Platelet transfusions are indicated only in patients with a platelet count of <50,000/microL or in patients with evidence of microvascular bleeding. Variceal hemorrhage is a medical emergency. Varices usually present with the acute onset large-volume haematemesis, the lower esophagus being the most common site for variceal bleeding. The sites for portosystemic anastomosis are: Left gastric vein to distal oesophageal veins: oesophageal and gastric variceal bleeding Superior rectal veins to Middle and inferior rectal veins: hemorrhoids and rectal bleeding Left branch of the portal vein to Periumbilical veins: caput-medusae The right branch of the portal vein to retroperitoneal veins draining into azygos, hemiazygos, umbar, intercostal, and phrenic veins Omental and colonic veins near hepatic and splenic ■exures to Retroperitoneal veins near hepatic and splenic ■exures Medical management of variceal bleeding includes blood transfusion (option B) and drug therapy with somatostatin analogs like octreotide (option C). Short-term antibiotics like ceftriaxone are known to decrease bacterial infection and increase survival. Surgical measures are preferred if medical management fails. They include balloon tamponade, endoscopic banding (option D), transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS), portosystemic shunts, splenectomy, and gastric revascularization Note: Sugiura procedure is the non-shunt surgical management of refractory oesophageal varicea bleeding. It is a procedure of de-vascularizing the distal esophagus and stomach.

question_text: A 56-year-old patient with intractable ascites underwent a procedure as shown below. Identify the procedure.
explanation: The image shows the transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt(TIPS) procedure with the viatorr device. The main indication of TIPS is for variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopic treatment, and intractable ascites. The shunts are inserted under local anaesthetic, analgesia and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. Via the internal jugular vein and superior venacava, a guidewire is inserted into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein. The main early complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the main contraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion. question_text: A 40-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with gangrenous appendix underwent an appendicectomy. On the second postoperative day, he developed fever, chills, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain. Blood cultures revealed bacteremia and ultrasound abdomen revealed multiple hepatic abscesses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: In the setting of existing appendicitis, the above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of pylephlebitis (portal pyemia). Pylephlebitis is thrombophlebitis of the portal venous system. It is a rare but very serious complication of intra-abdominal infections, such as gangrenous appendicitis, diverticulitis, etc. It spreads to the portal circulation via the mesenteric vein. Clinical features are high fever, rigors, and jaundice and intrahepatic abscesses (often multiple) due to septicemia in the portal venous system. Treatment is with systemic antibiotics and percutaneous drainage of hepatic abscesses. Option A: Peliosis hepatis is an uncommon vascular condition characterized by hemorrhagic dilatation of the hepatic sinusoids. Option C: Hepatic necrotic nodules are usually small, solitary lesions, mainly located under the liver capsule of the right lobe. It is characterized by a necrotic central core surrounded by a dense hyalinized fibrotic capsule. question_text: A 60-year-old male patient presented to the hospital with right upper quadrant pain and jaundice for the past 5 days. CT abdomen revealed the following finding and cultures of aspirate showed extensive bacterial growth. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Anchovy sauce pus is seen on aspiration of abscess

Pyogenic liver abscess is a polymicrobial infection seen more commonly in the elderly and immunocompromised. Ascending infection from the biliary tree (ascending suppurative cholangitis) is the most common route of spread. The portal vein is the second most common source of infection leading to pylephlebitis (thrombophlebitis of the portal venous system causing portal pyemia) secondary to diverticulitis, appendicitis, pancreatitis, etc. Organism: Most common in western countries: Escherichia coli Most common in Asian countries: Klebsiella pneumoniae Most common in children suffering from the chronic granulomatous disease: Staphylococcus Most common in gas-forming abscess: Klebsiella Order of affected lobe: Right lobe (75%) > left lobe (20%) > caudate lobe (5%). Right lobe predilection might be due to preferential laminar blood flow.

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding investigations in a pyogenic liver abscess is true?

Positive blood culture in 50% cases Ultrasonography (USG) and computed tomography (CT) are investigations of choice . question_text: A healthy 55-year-old man presented with a 1-week history of fevers, chills, right upper quadrant tenderness, and hepatomegaly. CT was suggestive of a pyogenic liver abscess. Which of the following statements regarding management is true?
options: Empiric IV antibiotic therapy is first line
Percutaneous drainage is not routinely done
Open drainage is done with T-tube placement
Resection of the affected lobe is the treatment of choice
explanation: Empiric IV antibiotic therapy is the first-line treatment for pyogenic liver abscess. Percutaneous drainage using a pigtail catheter is done routinely. It helps in the slow decompression of a cyst with viscous contents. It also has a lesser chance of dislodgement. Drainage tube catheter is placed under US/CT guidance into the liver abscess. Surgical drainage using a laparoscopic or open approach is tried only when antibiotic therapy and percutaneous drainage fails. Open drainage is becoming less common at present. Liver resection is only occasionally required in severe hepatic destruction. Pigtail catheter:

question_text: A 35-year-old daily wage laborer presented with fever and abdominal pain for the past 1 week. Laboratory investigations showed anti-amoebic antibodies and CT abdomen showed the following. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

explanation: The patient most likely has an amoebic liver abscess. It is more common in males than females (10:1). Risk factors include: Males, 20-40 years of age Heavy alcohol consumption - liver becomes more susceptible Travel to an endemic area Poverty and cramped living conditions Impaired host immunity Colonic infection The most common sites for amoebic liver abscesses are liver and paracaecal areas. question_text: Which of the following statements regarding amoebic liver abscess is false?
options: Culture of the aspirate is positive.
The diagnosis is based on the detection of antiamebic antibodies.
Management mainly consists of conservative treatment with metronidazole.
explanation: The culture of the amoebic abscess is usually sterile or negative. The most useful laboratory evaluation is the measurement of circulating anti-amoebic antibodies, by enzyme immunoassay. The antibody can be present because of prior infection, and hence, detection of Entamoeba histolytica lectin antigen in the serum and liver abscess pus is more useful for acute infections than chronic infection. Nuclear medicine studies, such as gallium scanning or technetium (99mTc) liver scans, can be helpful in differentiating pyogenic from amebic abscesses because amebic abscesses typically do not contain leukocytes and therefore do not light up on these scans. The mainstay of treatment for amebic abscesses is metronidazole (750 mg orally, three times daily for 10 days), which is curative. Luminal agents such as iodoquinol, paromomycin, and diloxanide furoate can be administered into the cysts.

question_text: Which of the following are not indications for percutaneous aspiration in a patient with a suspected amoebic liver abscess?

explanation: Percutaneous aspiration should be performed in amoebic liver abscess more than 5 cm. Indications for percutaneous aspiration in amoebic liver abscess are: Large abscesses (>5 cm) Lack of response to medical therapy (in 5 days) Suspicion of superinfection Abscesses of the left lobe of the liver at risk for rupture into the pericardium Uncertain diagnosis Laboratory investigations may reveal similar complete blood cell count and liver function test abnormalities in patients with amoebic liver abscesses and pyogenic liver abscesses. An elevated serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level is seen in both and is not specific.

question_text: In the given image, which of the following structures are matched correctly?
explanation: F -Endocyst and H-Hydatid sand are matched correctly. Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of sheep and dogs as hosts. Humans are accidental hosts. A hydatid cyst usually develops three weeks after the infection. The cyst is surrounded by a fibrous capsule called pericyst that is derived from the host tissue. The cyst wall is composed of two layers, ectocyst (outer gelatinous membrane), and endocyst (inner germinal membrane). Ectocyst is a laminated membrane, which is acellular. It helps in the passage of nutrients. The endocyst helps in producing the laminated membrane and scoleces. The brood capsules are cellular masses in the hydatid fluid which consists of scoleces. In a definitive host, these scoleces develop into adult tapeworm while in the intermediate hosts these develop into new hydatid cysts. The brood capsules are attached to the endocyst by a pedicle or stalk. The brood capsules may mature and detach from the mother cyst and become the daughter cysts, which are an exact replica of the mother cysts. The freed brood capsules and scoleces present in the hydatid fluid are called hydatid sand.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient was incidentally found to have a fluid filled cyst in his liver when he underwent a USG abdomen to check for renal calculi. It was later diagnosed as echinococcosis. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Rupture can lead to severe anaphylactic reaction
Echinococcus multilocularis is the most common causative agent
explanation: Echinococcus granulosus is the most common causative agent in hydatid cysts, while Echinococcus multilocularis and Echinococcus ligartus account for a small number of cases. Dogs are the definitive hosts of E. granulosus. Sheep are the usual intermediate hosts, and humans are accidental intermediate hosts. Humans are end-stage hosts of the parasite since there is no human to human transmission. The clinical presentation of a hydatid cyst is largely asymptomatic, until complications occur. The most common presenting symptoms are abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and vomiting. The most frequent sign is hepatomegaly. Approximately 75% of hydatid cysts are located in the right lobe of the liver and are solitary. The life cycle of Echinococcus: Multiple hydatid cysts:

question_text: A young villager presents to the clinic with abdominal pain for the past 1 month. He mentions that he keeps sheep inside the house. On examination, you feel a firm mass in the right hypochondrium and a hepatic hydatid cyst is suspected. Which of the following investigations have the highest sensitivity in confirming the diagnosis?
explanation: Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cyst. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa. CT scan has an accuracy of 98% in the detection of hydatid cysts and higher sensitivity to demonstrate the daughter cysts and extra-hepatic cysts. The indirect hemagglutination test and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) have a sensitivity of 80% overall and are the initial screening tests of choice. The Casoni test is a skin test used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease and involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilised fluid from hydatid cysts/human cysts. A wheal response occurring at the injection site within 20 minutes is considered positive (immediate hypersensitivity). The test is positive in less than 50% of patients with hydatid disease elsewhere in the body and false-positive results are also common so it's not preferred. Note: First/Initial imaging test is USG, best imaging test is CT scan CT scan showing multiple hydatid cysts with detached wavy membranes:

question_text: A patient is suspected to have a hydatid cyst of the liver. If imaging studies are performed, all of the following signs will denote detached or collapsed cyst except

Serpent sign is seen as wavy membranes within the cyst, on CT imaging. Ball of wool sign is seen on ultrasound when the contents settle in the dependent portion of the cyst, as seen below. The water-lily sign is seen in hydatid infections when there is detachment of the endocyst membrane which results in floating membranes within the pericyst that mimic the appearance of a water lily, on USG.
