question_text: Two weeks following an upper respiratory tract infection, a 5-year-old child presents with a skin rash as shown in the image. She also complains of bleeding gums and her platelet count is 18,000/µL. Which among the following is false about her condition?
options: Chronic form of this condition is more common in females
Bone marrow examination shows increased megathrombocytes
Splenectomy is the best alternative treatment for this condition
explanation: The image showing petechiae and the given history of a child presenting with mucocutaneous bleed following an upper respiratory tract infection are highly suggestive of immune thrombocytopenic purpura. In idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), the spleen is palpable in fewer than 10% of the patients, and the presence of gross splenic enlargement should raise the suspicion of an alternative diagnosis. Management of ITP: In patients with platelet counts <30,000/L, treatment may be instituted if there are symptoms of life-threatening bleeding. Prednisone at 1 mg/kg is the initial treatment of choice. Rh(D) immune globulin is used only in Rh-positive patients. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG). Splenectomy is indicated in patients who have relapsed on glucocorticoid therapy. Relapse patients with intermittent or high platelet count can be managed with anti-Rh0(D) immunoglobulin, IVIG, or with a thrombopoietin receptor agonist. Subcutaneous romiplostim and oral eltrombopag are thrombopoietin receptor agonists used in adults who are at risk of bleeding even after splenectomy. Option A: The acute form is more commonly seen in children following a viral infection, while the chronic form is more often seen in adult women of childbearing years. Option C: The bone marrow examination can be normal or show an increased number of megathrombocytes. Option D: 80% of cases undergo spontaneous remission in children. Patients who do not respond to first-line therapy like steroids and IVIG are best treated by splenectomy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young man with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura is posted for splenectomy. His platelet count is 32000 per cubic millimeter. What is the best time to transfuse platelets in this patient?
options: Immediately after the ligation of splenic artery
Immediately after the ligation of splenic vein
explanation: The best time to transfuse platelets in this patient is immediately after ligation of the splenic artery. The platelets are destroyed by the spleen within one hour of transfusion, and the splenic artery is the major vessel that brings blood to the spleen. Therefore, the best time to transfuse the platelets is immediately after the ligation of the splenic artery.
subject: Surgery

question_text: In a patient with hypersplenism, which of the following features can not be seen?
explanation: Bone marrow failure is not seen in a patient with hypersplenism. Hypersplenism is an indefinite clinical syndrome that is characterised by: Splenic enlargement Combination of anemia, leucopenia or thrombocytopenia Compensatory bone marrow hyperplasia Improvement after splenectomy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements is false?
options: Schistosomiasis can lead to tropical splenomegaly
Autosplenectomy is seen in sickle cell anemia
Howell-Jolly bodies are seen in asplenia
explanation: Thrombocytosis occurs following splenectomy. This occurs particularly in patients with myeloproliferative disorders (e.g., chronic myeloid leukemia, polycythemia vera, essential thrombocytosis). It may result in thrombosis of the mesenteric, portal, and renal veins which can be life-threatening as it can lead to haemorrhage and thromboembolism. Option A: Tropical splenomegaly is massive splenic enlargement, which frequently occurs in the tropics due to malaria, kala-azar, and schistosomiasis. Option C: Autosplenectomy is seen in sickle cell anemia. Splenomegaly is seen in thalassemia and hereditary spherocytosis. Option D: Howell-Jolly bodies are the nuclear remnants present in the RBCs. They appear as dense blue colored circular inclusions as shown in the image below. They are usually seen in patients lacking normal spleen function (asplenia).
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young male patient who is on treatment for osteomyelitis was found to have multiple splenic abscesses. This patient is least likely to have which of the following?
explanation: Splenomegaly is not a typical feature of splenic abscess. Splenic abscesses manifest with vague abdominal pain, fever, peritonitis, and pleuritic chest pain. A splenic abscess may arise from an infected splenic embolus, or in association with: Typhoid or paratyphoid fever Osteomyelitis Otitis media Puerperal sepsis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the most common indication for splenectomy?
explanation: Overall, the most common indication for splenectomy is trauma to the spleen, whether external (blunt or penetrating) or iatrogenic (e.g., during operative procedures for other reasons). The most common indication for: Elective splenectomy - Haematological disorders such as ITP, TTP, etc. Emergency splenectomy - Trauma Splenectomy (overall) - Trauma.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common complication that is expected to occur in patients following splenectomy?
options: Avascular necrosis of greater curvature of stomach
explanation: Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common complication after splenectomy. Other complications of splenectomy include: OPSI (Overwhelming post-splenectomy infection)is the most common fatal late complication of splenectomy. Avascular necrosis of the greater curvature of the stomach is a rare complication that can occur after ligation of short gastric vessels. Damage to the tail of the pancreas during surgery can lead to pancreatitis, a localized abscess, or pancreatic fistula. Hemorrhage during the perioperative period etc.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Vaccine for post-splenectomy infection is given against all except .
explanation: Escherichia coli vaccination is not recommended in post-splenectomy patients. Currently, the standard of care for post-splenectomy patients includes immunization with the following if the patient did not receive these before surgery: Polyvalent pneumococcal vaccine (PPV23) Haemophilus influenzae type B conjugate vaccine Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the statements regarding opportunistic post-splenectomy infection are correct?
explanation: The risk of developing opportunistic post-splenectomy infection is greatest when splenectomy is done for haematological conditions than for post-trauma. Opportunistic post-splenectomy infection is a major complication following splenectomy due to septicemia, which may result from an infection of: Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common) Neisseria meningitides Haemophilus influenzae Escherichia coli. The risk of overwhelming sepsis is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy. Hence, if an elective splenectomy is planned, consideration should be given to vaccinating against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) at least 2 weeks before elective surgery. In case of emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 24-year-old professional football player was tackled hard during a match. He complains of severe pain in the left upper abdomen. On examination, his BP is 100/74 mm Hg and there is tenderness and crepitus over the left 10th and 11th ribs. He also complains of pain over the left shoulder when pressure is applied over the left upper abdominal quadrant. This sign is called:
explanation: Kehr sign refers to referred pain in the tip of the left shoulder when firm pressure is applied over the left upper quadrant. It is also elicited by raising the left leg. It is seen in the case of hemoperitoneum, especially due to splenic injury. It occurs due to the collection of blood below the diaphragm and irritation of the phrenic nerve. Option A: Ballance sign is also seen in splenic injury. It is an area of percussive dullness in the left upper quadrant due to the coagulation of blood from the injured spleen. Option B: Cullen sign refers to periumbilical bruising in cases of hemoperitoneum, especially those of pancreatic origin. Option D: Grey Turner sign refers to bluish discolouration around flanks in case of hemoperitoneum especially acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding splenic artery aneurysms is true?
options: It is the most common visceral artery aneurysm
The most common presentation is severe epigastric pain
Rupture is more common during the second trimester of pregnancy
All diagnosed cases require surgical intervention
explanation: Splenic artery aneurysm is the commonest visceral artery aneurysm. Splenic artery aneurysm occurs more commonly in females. It is usually situated in the main arterial trunk. It is usually asymptomatic unless it ruptures. During pregnancy, rupture is more common in the third trimester and in labour. CT angiography is the investigation of choice. Not all diagnosed cases of splenic artery aneurysms need intervention. Treatment should be considered in aneurysms larger than 2 cm in diameter. In an elderly patient with a calcified aneurysm, there is less risk of rupture and observation may be preferred. In a younger patient with an asymptomatic aneurysm, surgery or interventional radiology is indicated. In patients with pancreatic necrosis, the treatment should include drainage of the septic focus. The treatment comprises of: Ligation of the proximal and distal ends of the sac Embolization or endovascular stentin Splenectomy with the removal of the artery
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cyst of the spleen?
explanation: The most common splenic cyst is pseudocyst, secondary to trauma. These are termed pseudocysts due to their lack of cellular lining. Splenic cysts are classified as either parasitic or non-parasitic: Parasitic/hydatid cysts are the most common true/primary splenic cysts Splenic pseudocysts are the most common non-parasitic splenic cysts and occur followin trauma Epidermoid cysts are the most common non-traumatic, non-parasitic splenic cysts. Note: These epithelial cells are often positive for CA 19-9 and carcinoembryonic antigen by immunohistochemistry. Patients with splenic epidermoid cysts may have elevated serum levels of one or both of these tumor markers.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
Which of the following statements regarding tumors of the spleen is true?
The most common primary malignant tumor of the spleen is hemangiosarcoma
options: The most common primary benign tumor of the spleen is hemangioma
The most common cause of isolated splenic metastasis is gastric carcinoma
The most common cause of neoplastic splenic enlargement is metastasis
explanation: The most common primary tumor of the spleen is hemangioma. Option A: Lymphoma (not Hemangiosarcoma) is the most common malignant primary tumour of the spleen. Option C: Ovarian carcinoma is the most common cause of isolated splenic metastasis Option D: Lymphoma is the most common cause of neoplastic splenic enlargement and the most common malignant tumour associated with splenic involvement. Endocrine Pancreas

question_text: What is the most common endocrine tumor of the pancreas?
explanation: The most common functioning endocrine tumor of the pancreas is insulinoma. It is a tumor arising from the beta cells of the pancreas. The most common malignant functional neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is gastrinoma.

question_text: Which of the following statements about insulinoma is false?
options: Majority of insulinomas are benign and solitary
Insulinomas occur more commonly in females
Insulinomas occur more commonly in the tail, than in the head and body of pancreas
Mean age at diagnosis is 45 years
explanation: Insulinomas are distributed equally throughout the pancreas, despite the predominance of beta-cells in the body and tail. The majority (90%) of insulinomas are benign and solitary, and only 10% are malignant and multifocal. Malignant insulinomas are usually found in association with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome. Insulinomas are typically small, with an average size of 1.0 to 1.5 cm. Insulinomas occur more commonly in females, between 40–60 years of age with the mean age of diagnosis at 45 years.

question_text: Which of the following is not a component of Whipple's triad?
options: Symptoms of hypoglycaemia after fasting or exercise
Relief of symptoms on intravenous administration of glucose
explanation: Elevated plasma levels of insulin is not a component of the triad. Whipple's triad is a clinical condition characterised by an insulin-producing tumour of the pancreas called insulinoma. The components of the triad are: Symptoms of hypoglycaemia after fasting or exercise. Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L. Relief of symptoms on intravenous administration of glucose. Patients with insulinoma eat frequently to avoid hypoglycemic symptoms. Hence, weight loss is not a feature of insulinoma.
subject: Surgery

question_text: The gold standard test for the diagnosis of insulinoma is .
explanation: The gold standard for the diagnosis of insulinoma is the 72-hour monitored fasting test. In this test, the levels of blood glucose, insulin, proinsulin, C peptide are measured in 1 to 2-hour intervals. When done so, a patient with insulinoma will have higher values of insulin, proinsulin, and C peptide which are expected to decrease in a normal person in response to the hypoglycemia due to fasting. All patients should be advised to undergo surgical excision of insulinoma following the exclusion of diffuse abdominal metastases by ultrasound or CT scan.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 50-year-old previously healthy man presents to the clinic with complaints of episodic palpitations, sweating, and giddiness which are relieved with food or fruit juices. Laboratory investigations are suggestive of insulinoma. Which of the following will be the best imaging modality to localize the site of the tumor in this patient?
explanation: Intra-operative ultrasound is the best method in localizing the site of the insulinoma. This is a dynamic imaging modality that provides interactive and timely information during surgical procedures. This is essential for the identification of small tumors, especially within the pancreatic head or uncinate process. Preoperatively, the site of the tumor can be assessed by endoscopic ultrasound or CT scan.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 54-year-old woman presents with recurrent attacks of dizziness and abdominal pain for 3 months. Fasting blood glucose level was 40 mg%, and insulin levels were elevated. CT abdomen showed a well-defined 1 cm lesion in the head of the pancreas. The treatment plan should be .
explanation: Recurrent hypoglycemic symptoms (dizziness) and low blood glucose with elevated insulin is suggestive of insulinoma. Tumour enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas. Insulinomas of <2 cm in diameter without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following: Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail Tumors of size >2 cm Tumors within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct Medical management to treat hyperinsulinism includes frequent intake of carbohydrate-rich meals, octreotide or diazoxide.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young man with parathyroid hyperplasia and pituitary adenoma is diagnosed with multiple tumors in Passaro's triangle. Which of the following structures are constituents of the triangle?
options: Superior and descending duodenum, head of the pancreas, lymph nodes
Superior duodenum, head of the pancreas, greater curvature of stomach
Third part of the duodenum, body of the pancreas, greater curvature of stomach
Body of the pancreas, greater curvature of stomach, lesser curvature of stomach
explanation: The patient is most likely suffering from MEN 1 syndrome. Gastrinoma is the most common functional entero-pancreatic tumor in MEN1. Superior and descending duodenum, head of the pancreas, and lymph nodes constitute the anatomical area called gastrinoma triangle, also known as the Passaro's triangle. The triangle is bounded by the lines connecting: The cystic duct The junction between the second and third portions of the duodenum The junction between the neck and body of the pancreas.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome?
explanation: The most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome is the duodenum. Gastrinoma is the most common pancreatic islet tumor in MEN 1 syndrome, arising from the G cells of the pancreas. Gastrinoma, associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent peptic ulcers, is called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. The majority of gastrinomas occur in the gastrinoma (Passaro's) triangle. In MEN 1, they often occur in patients <30 years. Patients present with abdominal pain (the most common symptom), diarrhea and steatorrhea. Management: Medical management for tumors <2 cm with proton-pump inhibitors. Surgery for tumors >2 cm. Proton-pump inhibitors with somatostatin analogues for advanced locoregional disease or metastasis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient who had been suffering from chronic esophageal reflux and diarrhea is diagnosed with multiple gastrinomas. All of the following statements are true regarding his condition except .
options: This occurs more commonly in males
More than 60% of tumors are malignant
Surgical exploration is indicated in all patients without metastasis
explanation: Gastrinoma/Zollinger–Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a non–beta islet cell tumor of the pancreas. Option A: ZES is more common in males than in females. Option B: At the time of diagnosis, >60% of tumors are malignant. Option D: Surgical exploration should be performed in all patients without diffuse metastases, t remove known malignant and benign tumors.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 25-year-old man with chronic abdominal pain was brought to the casualty in a dehydrated state due to multiple diarrheal episodes. He was started on IV fluids and analgesics. On further investigation, multiple ulcers were seen in the second and third part of the duodenum and his serum gastrin concentration was 2000 pg/ml. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with this condition?
options: Improvement of diarrhoea following nasogastric aspiration
Reduced basal to maximal acid output rati
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome/gastrinoma. Here, the basal acid output (BAO) is increased. Hence, the BAO:MAO ratio is increased. In these patients, there is gastrin hypersecretion that stimulates gastric acid secretion. This leads to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple. Abdominal pain is the most common complaint in these patients. However, diarrhea can occur due to: Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH Precipitation of bile salts. The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions. Gastric pH <2.5 and a serum gastrin concentration >1000 pg/mL confirm the diagnosis of Zollinger Ellison syndrome. If the diagnosis remains in doubt, a secretin stimulation test is done. In this test, the fasting gastrin level is measured before secretin (2 IU/kg) is administered intravenously, and subsequent samples are obtained 2, 5, 10, and 20 minutes. Gastrin levels >200 pg/mL after administration of secretin are suggestive of gastrinoma.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient who is recently diagnosed with Zollinger-Elison syndrome is started on proton pump inhibitors. There is no previous history of acid-reduction procedure done. The target basal acid output should be less than .
explanation: The proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) dosage should be titrated to keep basal acid output <10 mEq/hr in this patient. The target BAO is <5 mEq/hr if the patient has had a prior acid-reducing procedure. Ideally, the dose of proton pump inhibitors is titrated using acid output in order to improve the healing rate of peptic ulcer disease, and to avert its complications.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following would be the preoperative imaging study of choice in patients with gastrinoma?
explanation: Currently, the preoperative imaging study of choice for gastrinoma is somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (octreotide scan). The majority of the gastrinomas are found within the Passaro’s triangle and can be detected by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS). However, it still misses many of the smaller lesions, and may confuse normal lymph nodes for gastrinomas. If there is no tumor visible on EUS, a somatostatin receptor study is useful in identifying the location. When the pretest probability of gastrinoma is high, the sensitivity and specificity of this modality are almost 100%.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which among the following statements is false about non-functioning pancreatic endocrine tumors?
options: Most of the tumors are malignant
They account for 60-90% of all pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors
They have a much better prognosis than functioning tumors
explanation: Non-functioning pancreatic endocrine tumors (NF-PETs) have a worse prognosis compared to functioning tumors. They account for 60-90% of all neuroendocrine tumors. They are usually larger (>5cm), solitary, mostly in the head of the pancreas, malignant and metastatic. These do not cause any clinical symptoms. They stain positive for immunohistochemical markers such as synaptophysin, chromogranin A (CgA), and neuron-specific enolase. Chromogranin A is used as a serum marker to monitor response to treatment and to detect recurrence. Treatment is mainly surgical. It includes partial pancreaticoduodenectomy as well as the synchronous or metachronous resection of liver metastases.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the OPD with a skin lesion as shown in the image below. The lesions were initially small but have now spread to the entire limb and the abdomen. She has a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent episodes of deep vein thrombosis despite anticoagulation therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The image depicts necrolytic migratory erythema. This skin lesion along with a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent deep vein thrombosis is suggestive of glucagonoma.

question_text: A 49-year-old female patient presents with complaints of abdominal pain and foul-smelling, greasy stools for one year. She is known to be diabetic and underwent cholecystectomy one year back. CT scan shows the presence of a tumor in the pancreas. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The most probable diagnosis is somatostatinoma. Somatostatin inhibits pancreatic and biliary secretions. Patients with somatostatinoma usually present with vague abdominal pain along with the triad of: Gallstones - due to bile stasis Diabetes - due to inhibition of insulin secretion Steatorrhea - due to inhibition of pancreatic exocrine secretion and bile secretion.

A patient with MEN 1 syndrome is diagnosed with VIPoma. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
Watery diarrhea
explanation: VIPoma is associated with achlorhydria. Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumor (VIPoma) is also known as Verner–Morrison syndrome/WDHA syndrome. WDHA stands for: WD - Watery Diarrhea H – Hypokalemia A – Achlorhydria Metabolic acidosis from fluid and bicarbonate loss is common in VIPoma. Congenital Anomalies and Acute Pancreatitis

question_text: What is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas?
explanation: Pancreas divisum is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas. During embryogenesis, the developing pancreatic ducts usually fuse in such a way that most of the dorsal duct drains into the proximal part of the ventral duct. The proximal portion of the dorsal duct usually persists as an accessory duct. In about 10% of the population, there is a failure of fusion of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds leading to a condition called pancreatic divisum (pancreas divisum). Pancreatic drainage is accomplished mainly through the accessory papilla. Since most of the pancreatic exocrine secretions exit through the dorsal duct, the pancreas divisum can lead to a partial obstruction due to the small minor papilla, leading to the development of relapsing acute or chronic pancreatitis
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of pancreatic divisum?
options: Pancreatojejunostomy is also known as Puestow's procedure
ERCP is more advantageous than MRCP for the diagnosis
explanation: MRCP is more advantageous than ERCP in diagnosing pancreatic divisum. This is because, MRCP can delineate the entire dorsal pancreatic duct, whereas ERCP can assess only the ventral duct on cannulation of the major duodenal papilla. The diagnosis of pancreatic divisum can also be made by EUS, or ERCP, augmented by injection of secretin if necessary. Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stenting of the minor papilla relieve the symptoms. Surgical intervention may involve sphincteroplasty, pancreatojejunostomy (Puestow procedure), or even resection of the pancreatic head. The image given below shows an MRCP done for a case of pancreatic divisum.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 9-year-old girl was referred to the OPD with a chronic history of early satiety and recurrent non-bilious vomiting after heavy meals. Barium meal revealed a diffusely narrowed second portion of the duodenum, suggesting extrinsic compression. Which of the following statements is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?
options: It is associated with failure of complete rotation of the ventral bud
Can be associated with classic double bubble sign on radiograph
Duodenoduodenostomy is the treatment of choice
MRCP is the gold standard investigation
explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of annular pancreas, which is a type of developmental anomaly leading to duodenal compression. Laparotomy with a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas is the gold standard test for an annular pancreas, not an MRCP. The annular pancreas is due to result of the failure of the complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud. During development, a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum. It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal atresia and is, therefore, more prevalent in children with Down’s syndrome. Duodenal obstruction typically causes non-projectile, non-bilious vomiting in neonates. Plain abdominal radiographs may demonstrate the classic double bubble sign. But it is non-specific for the annular pancreas. Despite many advances in diagnostic techniques such as CT scan, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), MRCP, and ERCP, the gold standard test for diagnosing AP remains to be laparotomy. It involves a thorough gross examination of the duodenum and the head of the pancreas. The treatment for an annular pancreas is a duodenal bypass procedure (duodenoduodenostomy).
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with sudden onset abdominal pain in the epigastric region radiating to the back. The pain relieves on leaning forwards. X-ray abdomen shows no
gas under the diaphragm. Elevated amylase levels and total WBC count are seen. Which of the following signs are likely to be present in this condition?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Rovsing sign and Aaron sign are seen in acute appendicitis. Rovsing sign: Pain in the right lower quadrant during palpation of the left lower quadrant. Aaron sign: Pain or pressure in the epigastrium or anterior chest with firm pressure applied to McBurney’s point. In severe acute pancreatitis, the injured pancreas releases pancreatic enzymes that cause fat necrosis and inflammation, occasionally resulting in peri-pancreatic bleeding. The resulting fluid collection can travel via an anatomical defect of the transversalis fascia. This accumulates at various sites and shows discoloration of the skin. Cullen's sign: If the blood diffuses from the retroperitoneum along with the gastrohepatic and falciform ligaments to the umbilicus, it results in bluish discoloration around the umbilicus Grey Turner sign: If the blood diffuses from the posterior pararenal space to the lateral edge of the quadratus lumborum muscle, it results in bluish discoloration of the flanks F x sign: Pooling of retroperitoneal hemorrhage at the inguinal ligament shows discoloration below the inguinal ligament Bryant sign: Pooling of blood at the scrotum
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common cause of acute pancreatitis?
explanation: The most common cause of acute pancreatitis is the presence of gallstones (50-70%). The second most common cause is alcohol abuse (25%). Causes of acute pancreatitis: (Mnemonic: I GET SMASHED) I – Idiopathic G – Gallstones E – Ethanol T – Trauma S – Steroids M – Mumps, malignancy (pancreatic cancer) A – Autoimmune S – Scorpion sting H – Hypercalcemia, hypertriglyceridemia (Usually more than 1000 mg/dL) E – Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) D – Drugs
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient presenting with acute abdomen was found to have elevated serum amylase levels. Which of the following should be part of your differential diagnosis?
explanation: All the above conditions should be part of the differential diagnosis in patients with acute abdominal pain and elevated serum amylase levels. Conditions associated with elevated serum amylase levels: Burns Pregnancy Pancreatitis Cholecystitis Diabetic ketoacidosis Ruptured ectopic pregnancy Aortic aneurysm Renal failure Renal transplantation Chronic liver disease Intestinal obstruction Drugs like morphine Salivary gland involvement: mumps, calculus, maxillofacial surgery Tumors of the lungs, esophagus, breast, or ovary (LEBO)
subject: Surgery

question_text: All of the following derangements can be expected in a patient with acute pancreatitis except:
explanation: Acute pancreatitis causes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. The pancreatic enzymes cause autodigestion of the mesenteric fat leading to the release of free fatty acids. These free fatty acids combine with calcium to form calcium salts, causing low levels of circulating calcium. Hypercalcemia may cause acute pancreatitis. Hypocalcemia is a complication of acute pancreatitis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is not used to assess the severity of acute pancreatitis?
explanation: Alvarado scoring is used in acute appendicitis, not acute pancreatitis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: All of the following parameters will be included in the assessment of acute pancreatitis using Ranson's criteria, except:
explanation: Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) > 350 IU/L is included in Ranson’s criteria, not 250 IU/L.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Revised atlanta classification is used for assessing severity of:
explanation: Revised atlanta classification is used for assessing the severity of acute pancreatitis. Revised atlanta classification: Mild Acute Pancreatitis No organ failure No local or systemic complications M derately Severe Acute Pancreatitis Transient organ failure (<48 hours) and/or Local or systemic complications without persistent organ failure Severe Acute Pancreatitis Persistent organ failure (>48 hours) – Single organ or multiorgan
subject: Surgery

question_text: A gasless abdomen is seen in:
explanation: A gasless abdomen is an X-ray feature that can be seen in acute pancreatitis. Patients with acute pancreatitis can have significant vomiting and diarrhea that may produce a gasless abdomen. Common causes of gasless abdomen include: High obstruction: gastric outlet obstruction, congenital atresia Small bowel obstruction Bowel ischemia Ascites Acute pancreatitis Gastroenteritis Large abdominal mass - due to displacement Post-surgery following total colectomy, esophagogastrectomy, gastrectomy, and low anterior resection A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults Note: In intussusception, an X-ray shows small bowel obstruction, a mass, and a paucity of gas in the right iliac fossa.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the sign that is seen in the radiograph?
explanation: The image shows the colon cut-off sign, which is seen in acute pancreatitis. The colon cut-off sign refers to the abrupt termination of the gas filling of the colon on the left side. The inflammation of acute pancreatitis may extend to the phrenicocolic ligament via the transverse mesocolon. This causes functional spasm of the splenic flexure resulting in the colon cut-off sign. All the other options mentioned above are also seen in acute pancreatitis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding usage of the contrast-enhanced CT scan in cases of acute pancreatitis?
options: It is the investigation of choice
It should be done within 72 hours from the onset of symptoms
Balthazar criteria is used to stage the severity of pancreatitis detected on CT scan
Signs of sepsis is an indication for CT scan
explanation: The optimal time for performance of contrast-enhanced CT imaging in cases of acute pancreatitis is more than 72 hours from the onset of symptoms. In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimate the extent of necrosis. A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice in acute pancreatitis. However, it is not performed in all cases of pancreatitis. Indications of CT scan in pancreatitis: Diagnostic uncertainty In patients with severe acute pancreatitis, to distinguish interstitial from necrotizing pancreatitis In patients with organ failure, signs of sepsis or progressive clinical deterioration When a localized complication is suspected, such as fluid collection, pseudocyst, or a pseudoaneurysm The image below is a CT scan from a patient with acute exudative pancreatitis. The severity of pancreatitis detected on CT scan is staged according to the Balthazar criteria.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient with acute pancreatitis underwent a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. CT scan shows diffuse enlargement of the pancreas without necrosis. What will be the CT severity index of the patient?
explanation: The CT severity index (CTSI) of this patient will be 1. The CT severity index for grading of acute pancreatitis is determined as the sum of two scores: Balthazar score: grading of pancreatitis Necrosis score: grading of the extent of pancreatic necrosis The Balthazar score for diffuse enlargement of the pancreas is 1. Since there is no necrosis, the necrosis score of the patient is zero. Hence the CTSI of this patient is 1.
subject: Surgery

question_text: When will you use the SOFA score in a patient with acute pancreatitis?
options: To assess the need for surgery
In cases of pancreatic abscess formation
To assess the length of hospital stay
explanation: The Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score is used to assess organ failure in acute pancreatitis. The three organ systems most frequently involved are the cardiovascular, respiratory, and renal systems. Multiple organ failures are said to exist when 2 or more organs register 2 or more points on these scoring systems. qSOFA score (quickSOFA) is a bedside prompt that may identify patients with suspected infection who are at greater risk for a poor outcome outside the intensive care unit (ICU). It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for Low blood pressure (SBP100 mmHg) High respiratory rate ( 22 breaths per min) Altered mentation (Glasgow coma scale, <15) The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points is a simple prompt to identify infected patients outside the ICU who are likely to develop sepsis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 35-year-old man presented with a 1-day history of sudden onset of severe abdominal pain with radiation to the back. He gives a history of binge drinking on the night prior to his symptom onset. He is hemodynamically stable and there is no sign of organ impairment. His serum amylase level is 500 U/L ( normal: 23–85 U/L) and lipase level is 1100 U/L (normal: 10-140 U/L). Which of the following is false regarding the most likely diagnosis?
options: CECT abdomen is almost always necessary to establish the diagnosis
CT should be performed 72 hours after the onset of symptoms to assess complications
Modified marshall scoring system can be used to assess the severity of organ failure
Early initiation of enteral nutrition is beneficial for overall improvement of prognosis
explanation: The given clinical scenario with characteristic lab findings is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. CECT abdomen is not always necessary to diagnose acute pancreatitis. According to the revised Atlanta classification, acute pancreatitis is clinically defined by at least the first two of three features: abdominal pain suggestive of pancreatitis (epigastric pain often radiating to the back), serum amylase and lipase levels  3 times normal (imaging is to be used if the elevated values are less than 3 times normal); and characteristic imaging findings on CT, magnetic resonance (MR) imaging, or transabdominal ultrasonographic (US) studies. If acute pancreatitis is diagnosed on the basis of the first two criteria with no systemic sign of severe systemic inflammatory response syndrome or persistent organ failure, contrast material–enhanced CT may not be necessary for determining patient care. Option B: The optimal time for performance of contrast-enhanced CT imaging in cases of acute pancreatitis is more than 72 hours from the onset of symptoms. In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimate the extent of necrosis. Indications of CT scan in pancreatitis are Diagnostic uncertainty In patients with severe acute pancreatitis, to distinguish interstitial from necrotizing pancreatitis In patients with organ failure, signs of sepsis or progressive clinical deterioration When a localized complication is suspected, such as fluid collection, pseudocyst, or a pseudoaneurysm Option C: For severe acute pancreatitis with systemic inflammatory response syndrome and possible organ impairment, the modified marshall scoring can be used to assess the severity of organ failure. It includes respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal systems scores. A score of more than 2 for any organs indicates organ failure. Revised Atlanta classification recommends the modified Marshall scoring system as the main tool in determining organ failure. Option D: Current evidence confirms that the administration of enteral nutrition is beneficial for the treatment of severe acute pancreatitis. Enteral feeding reduces mortality, infectious complications, and multiorgan failure. In terms of the timing of enteral nutritional support, relatively early administration within 48 or 72 h of hospital admission is suggested.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient with pancreatitis is likely to develop all of the following vascular complications, except:
explanation: Mesenteric artery thrombosis is unlikely in patients with acute pancreatitis. The most common vascular complication following acute pancreatitis is arterial pseudoaneurysm.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A chronic alcoholic presented with complaints of progressive abdominal distension. His past history is significant for acute pancreatitis which was managed by supportive care. USG abdomen showed peri-pancreatic ascitic fluid collection. A large volume paracentesis (LVP) was performed. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
options: The ascitic fluid will be low in protein.
Amylase levels in the fluid are raised.
Somatostatin will help in decreasing secretion.
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of pancreatic ascites. The pancreatic ascitic fluid is rich in enzymes, and not low in protein. Pancreatic ascites occurs due to the disruption of the pancreatic duct. It presents with significant abdominal distention, with free intra-abdominal fluid. Diagnostic paracentesis typically demonstrates turbid fluid with elevated amylase and lipase levels. Treatment involves suppression of pancreatic secretion by parenteral or nasojejunal feeding and administration of octreotide/somatostatin. Abdominal drainage combined with the endoscopic placement of a pancreatic stent across the disruption is done. If the above steps fail, surgical treatment consisting of distal pancreatic resection and closure of the proximal stump is done.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young lady presents with acute epigastric pain and vomiting. She also gives a history of pain and swelling over the right parotid gland for 3 days. USG abdomen reveals peripancreatic ascitic fluid collection. Which of the following is not true about the fluid collection?
options: It is not associated with fibrous wall
The most common vessel involved is the splenic artery
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pancreatitis caused due to mumps. Hemosuccus pancreaticus in acute pancreatitis is not associated with ascites. Hemosuccus pancreaticus is due to the erosion of the wall of the pancreatic pseudocyst into the splenic artery forming a direct communication. It presents with abdominal pain and upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, without ascites. In contrast to pseudocysts and cystic neoplasias of the pancreas, fluid collections are not surrounded or encased by epithelium or fibrotic capsules. Diagnostic paracentesis typically demonstrates turbid fluid with elevated amylase and lipase levels. M st fluid collections will be spontaneously reabsorbed by the peritoneum. Treatment involves suppression of pancreatic secretion by parenteral or nasojejunal feeding and administration of octreotide/somatostatin. Abdominal drainage combined with the endoscopic placement of a pancreatic stent across the disruption is done. If the above steps fail, surgical treatment consisting of distal pancreatic resection and closure of the proximal stump is done.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A patient with acute pancreatitis was admitted following binge drinking. 7-days
post-admission, he complains of fever with chills and rigor. Blood investigation shows a WBC count of 21,450. CT scan reveals the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic tissue.
How will you manage this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with a history of pancreatitis, elevated WBC, and CT scan findings are suggestive of pancreatic abscess. It is treated by percutaneous drainage. A pancreatic abscess is a circumscribed intra-abdominal collection of pus, usually in proximity to the pancreas. It may be an acute fluid collection or walled-off necrosis that has become infected. Clinical features include: Fever with chills Elevated white blood cell count Abdominal pain Contrast-enhanced CT scan and MRI are both options for the assessment of pancreatic necrosis and abscesses. On imaging, the presence of extraluminal gas in the pancreatic and/or peripancreatic tissues is consistent with an underlying infection. Treatment is by percutaneous drainage with the widest possible drains placed under imaging guidance, along with appropriate antibiotics and supportive care.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following will not be part of the management plan of patients with infected pancreatic necrosis?
explanation: Infected pancreatic necrosis should not be managed conservatively with antibiotics alone because of the high risk of multiorgan failure and death. CT scan has to be performed in patients with severe acute pancreatitis, organ failure, sepsis, and in patients with clinical deterioration despite the treatment: If the CT scan shows the presence of sterile pancreatic necrosis medical management is recommended. If the CT scan shows the presence of necrosis with evidence of infection, then ultrasound or CT-guided aspiration of the fluid has to be done and the fluid is sent for staining and culture. Infected pancreatic necrosis is treated by the administration of intravenous antibiotics (preferably carbapenems) and percutaneous drainage of the infected fluid. Pancreatic necrosectomy is be considered in the patients if the clinical condition worsens despite percutaneous drainage.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Regarding the revised Atlanta classification for morphologic stages of acute pancreatitis, which of the following is not true?
options: Acute necrotic collection is non-encapsulated necrosis within 4 weeks of onset
Acute peripancreatic fluid collection can be seen in interstitial edematous pancreatitis
Pancreatic pseudocyst can be seen in necrotizing pancreatitis
Collection that contains non-liquefied material is more likely to become infected
explanation: Pancreatic pseudocyst is seen as a sequela of interstitial edematous pancreatitis, which is a non-necrotic collection. Necrotizing pancreatitis usually leads to acute necrotic collection (ANC) and walled-off necrosis (on encapsulation of ANC). Based on the revised Atlanta classification, peripancreatic fluid and their collections can be classified into 4 different types based on their morphology and time of presentation. IEP - Interstitial Edematous Pancreatitis APFC - Acute Peripancreatic Fluid Collection: Non-necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks Pancreatic pseudocyst: Non-necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks) Necrotising Pancreatitis ANC - Acute Necrotic Collection: Necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks WON - Walled-Off Necrosis: Necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks) ANC, APFC, WON, and pancreatic pseudocysts can be infected or non-infected. Collections that contain non-liquefied material or show the presence of gas, are more likely to be infected. Duration since onset IEP Necrotizing pancreatitis <4 weeks after onset(not enc apsulated) APFC ANC Undergoes encapsulation  4 weeks after onset(encapsu lated) Pancreatic pseudocy st WON
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 12-year-old girl was rushed to the casualty after she was injured by a bicycle’s handlebar in the abdomen. She complains of severe epigastric pain. On examination, bruises are seen in the epigastrium. Her CT scan is given below. Which of the following statements is false about her condition?

Damage control surgery is done.
options: Distal pancreatectomy will be the definitive management.
Surgery is indicated if the main pancreatic duct is disrupted.
explanation: The given clinical scenario with a handlebar injury and the CT scan showing transection of the body of the pancreas are suggestive pancreatic injury. Plasma amylase levels are not sensitive in pancreatic injuries. The most common mechanism of pancreatic injury in children is blunt trauma (because of the decreased amount of fat and incomplete protection of the rib cage). In adults, penetrating injuries are the most common cause. Involvement of other organs is also likely to be seen. Direct compression of the epigastrium against the vertebral column and a blunt object (handlebar) is typically seen after bicycle injuries. The most common segment of the pancreas affected is the body. Patients usually present with epigastric pain. In some cases, a delayed presentation may be due to leakage of pancreatic fluids. The modality of choice is the CT scan of the abdomen. If there is doubt about duct disruption, an urgent ERCP or MRCP should be done. Surgery is indicated if the main pancreatic duct is disrupted. A damage control procedure with packing and drainage should be performed initially and the patient referred for definitive surgery after stabilization. Definitive management includes: Distal pancreatectomy - If the body or tail is involved External drainage - If the head of the pancreas is involved Pancreatoduodenectomy - If the pancreatic head and duodenum is involved Chronic Pancreatitis
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with complaints of recurrent epigastric pain, progressive weight loss, and foul-smelling diarrhoea for the past 6 months. CT scan reveals pancreatic calcification and dilatation of the main pancreatic duct. Which of the following statements is false about his condition?
options: It is more common in males
Abdominal pain is the most common symptom
Pain increases as destruction of the pancreas progresses
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic pancreatitis. Pain decreases or disappears as the destruction of the pancreas progress. This is called a burned-out pancreas. This correlates with the progression of disease from a mild or moderate stage to severe destruction of the pancreas. Chronic pancreatitis is a progressive inflammatory disease in which there is an irreversible destruction of pancreatic tissue. It is more common in males, with a male: female ratio of 4:1.
subject: Surgery

question_text: What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis?
explanation: Alcohol consumption is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis, accounting for 60–70% of the cases. Smoking increases the risk of alcohol-induced chronic pancreatitis. Cystic fibrosis is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis in the pediatric age group. Other causes of chronic pancreatitis include: Pancreatic divisum Annular pancreas Hyperlipidemia Hypercalcemia Hyperparathyroidism Chronic duct obstruction Autoimmune pancreatitis Cystic fibrosis Tropical pancreatitis Hereditary pancreatitis
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is not a part of the TIGAR-O classification?
explanation: The T in the TIGAR-O classification stands for toxic-metabolic, not trauma. The TIGAR-O classification system is an etiological approach to classify chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young patient with recurrent abdominal pain and pancreatic calcification was found to have a mutation in SPINK1. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
options: Associated with high incidence of diabetes mellitus.
It can be distinguished from chronic alcoholic pancreatitis histologically.
Cassava ingestion is an etiological factor.
explanation: The given clinical scenario of chronic pancreatitis with SPINK1 mutation is suggestive of tropical pancreatitis (nutritional pancreatitis). Tropical pancreatitis is histologically indistinguishable from chronic alcoholic pancreatitis. Normally, if trypsinogen does become prematurely activated within the pancreas, it is inhibited by SPINK1 and then gets destroyed. A loss-of-function mutation in SPINK1 affects this process and predisposes to tropical pancreatitis. Tropical pancreatitis is a form of idiopathic pancreatitis that begins at a young age and is usually seen in Indonesia, southern India (Kerala), and tropical Africa. It is associated with a high incidence of diabetes mellitus (a brittle form of pancreatogenic diabetes) and stone formation. Causes of chronic tropical pancreatitis include: Malnutrition Ingestion of cyanogenic glycosides in cassava Exposure to hydrocarbons released from kerosene or paraffin lamps Tropical pancreatitis is histologically indistinguishable from chronic alcoholic pancreatitis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Hereditary chronic pancreatitis is caused by the mutation of:
explanation: Hereditary chronic pancreatitis is caused by the mutation of PRSS1 (protease serine 1). Hereditary pancreatitis is an autosomal dominant disorder, associated with a gain-of-function mutation in the cationic trypsinogen gene (PRSS1) on chromosome 7q. This leads to intrapancreatic activation of trypsinogen and the production of the degradation-resistant form of trypsin. PRSS1 mutation accounts for about two-thirds of cases of hereditary pancreatitis. There is an increased risk of developing pancreatic cancer, particularly if the patient smokes tobacco. Option B: Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 7, and it regulates bicarbonate and chloride concentrations in respiratory and pancreatic secretions. Homozygous CFTR mutations result in cystic fibrosis Heterozygous mild CFTR mutations predispose to pancreatic exocrine insufficiency and chronic pancreatitis Options C and D: Serine peptidase inhibitor Kazal type 1 (SPINK1) or pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor (PSTI) is associated with tropical calcific pancreatitis as well idiopathic chronic pancreatitis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 35-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of recurrent abdominal pain and weight loss. Investigations showed features suggestive of obstructive jaundice and MRI revealed the following abnormality. All of the statements are true regarding the given condition except:
options: It is likely to resolve spontaneously
Serum IgG4 is elevated in type 2
Corticosteroids are the treatment of choice
explanation: The clinical features and characteristic sausage-shaped appearance of the pancreas on the T2 weighted image are diagnostic of autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP). Serum IgG4 is normal in type 2 AIP. It is elevated in type 1 AIP. Autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the pancreas. Patients present with features of obstructive jaundice, weight loss, and mild abdominal pain. CT scan or MRI showing a diffuse enlarged, sausage-shaped pancreas is characteristic of autoimmune pancreatitis. Serum IgG4 level is considered the best serological marker for AIP. Most of the cases resolve spontaneously. However, corticosteroid therapy is the treatment of choice as it causes increased remission of AIP. Also, AIP is associated with gastric ulcer formation as there are abundant IgG4 levels. Hence NSAIDs are not part of the management. They are of two types: Features Type 1 AIP Type 2 AIP Age Elderly Young Gender Males Equal Features Type 1 AIP Type 2 AIP Features Type 1 AIP Type 2 AIP Features Type 1 AIP Type 2 AIP Serum IgG4 Elevated Normal Histopathology Lymphoplasmacytic sclerosin g pancreatitis Idiopathic duct centric pancr eatitis Infiltrating cells IgG4 + plasma cells Granulocytes Relapse rate High Low Other organ involved Biliary stricturesPseudotumo rsKidneyLungOthersRetroper itoneal fibrosisSialoadenitis No Extra pancreatic lesion IgG4 related disease Inflammatory bowel disease( 15-30%)
subject: Surgery

question_text: The Rosemont criteria for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis is based on:
explanation: Rosemont’s criteria for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis is based on endoscopic ultrasonographic (EUS) findings.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following diagnostic tests have the highest sensitivity and specificity to diagnose chronic pancreatitis?
explanation: The diagnostic test with the best sensitivity and specificity for chronic pancreatitis is the secretin test. Secretin is a hormone secreted by the small intestines. It normally stimulates the pancreas to secrete a fluid with a high concentration of bicarbonate. Secretin stimulation test is a test that measures the ability of the pancreas to respond to secretin. In order to perform the test, a tube is passed into the duodenum. Secretin is administered intravenously and the contents of the duodenal secretions are aspirated and analyzed over a period of about 2 hours. The test becomes abnormal when  60% of the pancreatic exocrine function has been lost. This usually correlates well with the onset of chronic abdominal pain. Other investigations to diagnose chronic pancreatitis: Pancreatic calcifications can be seen on abdominal X-rays. Endoscopic ultrasound showing the presence of four or more of these following features is highly suggestive of chronic pancreatitis: Presence of stones Visible side branches Cysts Lobularity An irregular main pancreatic duct Hyperechoic foci and strands Dilatation of the main pancreatic duct Hyperechoic margins of the main pancreatic duct An abdominal CT scan is the initial modality of choice for diagnosing chronic pancreatitis. CT or MRI scan will show the outline of the gland, the main area of damage, and the possibilities for surgical correction. The investigation of choice for chronic pancreatitis is MRCP with secretin stimulation. ERCP is the gold-standard investigation. They help in identifying the presence of biliary obstruction and the state of the pancreatic duct.
subject: Surgery

question_text: All of the following are tests used to diagnose exocrine deficiency of the pancreas except:
explanation: sFLT-1 (soluble FMS like tyrosine kinase-1) is not used to test pancreatic exocrine deficiency. sFLT-1 is a marker used for pre-eclampsia. Tests for pancreatic exocrine deficiency Direct tests: Lundh test The pancreatic secretion is di rectly measured following a t est meal Secretin or CCK stimulation t est Following intravenous injecti on of secretin or CCK, the pa ncreatic secretion is measure Indirect tests: Nitroblue tetrazolium–para-a minobenzoic acid (NBT–PAB A) test The NBT-PABA is administer ed orally and degraded in the gut by a pancreatic enzyme. The breakdown product (PAB A) is absorbed by the intestin e and excreted in the urine. I ts urinary value is measured. Pancreolauryl test Works on the similar principl e of NBT-PABA Measurement of thefecal elas tase A value below 100 g/g establ ishes the diagnosis of severe pancreatic exocrine insufficie ncy Fecal fat and weight estimati on test
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 65-year-old man who had multiple episodes of pancreatitis presented with a history of mild epigastric pain and the presence of foul-smelling greasy stools for the past 5 months. MRCP showed the presence of a chain of lake appearance in the pancreas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The chain of lakes appearance on pancreatography (ERCP or MRCP) is diagnostic of chronic pancreatitis. In chronic pancreatitis, there are multiple strictures and stones in the pancreatic duct. This leads to the alternate stenosis and dilatation of the pancreatic duct leading to the chain of lakes appearance.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient with chronic pancreatitis can develop all of the following complications, except:
explanation: Renal artery stenosis and insulinoma are not complications of chronic pancreatitis. Complications of chronic pancreatitis: Intrapancreatic complications: Pseudocysts Duodenal or gastric obstruction Thrombosis of splenic vein Abscess Perforation Erosion into the visceral artery Inflammatory mass in the head of the pancreas Bile duct stenosis Portal vein thrombosis Duodenal obstruction Duct strictures and/or stones Ductal hypertension and dilatation Pancreatic carcinoma Extrapancreatic complications: Pancreatic duct leak with ascites or fistula Pseudocyst extension beyond lesser sac into mediastinum, retroperitoneum, lateral pericolic spaces, pelvis, or adjacent viscera
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about the complications of chronic pancreatitis?
options: All the complications of acute pancreatitis can occur in patients with chronic pancreatitis.
Calcium oxalate is the most common type of stone in chronic pancreatitis.
At least 90% of acinar cells should be lost before malabsorption symptoms manifest.
explanation: Calcium carbonate stone is the most common type of stone formed in chronic pancreatitis. Calcium and bicarbonate ions are normally present in pancreatic juice in high concentrations. Lithostathine is a potent inhibitor of calcium carbonate crystal formation. In alcoholics and in patients with alcoholic chronic pancreatitis, lithostathine expression and secretion are dramatically inhibited leading to calcification. Other complications of chronic pancreatitis: Exocrine insufficiency - At least 90% of the gland needs to be dysfunctional before malabsorption symptoms manifest like: Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency Bleeding Osteopenia Osteoporosis Endocrine insufficiency - Diabetes mellitus. Exocrine insufficiency usually precedes endocrine insufficiency. All the complications of acute pancreatitis can occur in patients with chronic pancreatitis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young male patient presents with steatorrhea associated with chronic pancreatitis. A stool examination of the patient shows increased fecal fat and decreased fecal elastase. What is the mode of administration of the pancreatic enzymes in this patient?
explanation: The mode of administration of pancreatic enzymes in exocrine pancreatic insufficiency is through an oral route. Effects of pancreatic enzyme replacement in chronic pancreatitis: Reverses exocrine insufficiency Prevents secondary complications such as metabolic bone disease due to inadequate absorption of the fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K Reduces pain due to chronic pancreatitis Pancreatic enzyme supplementation is done with meals. Non-enteric-coated tablets are degraded by gastric juice and the released enzymes inhibit cholecystokinin (CCK) secretion. This, in turn, decreases the pancreatic secretion and thereby reduces the pain caused due to the increased accumulation of the secretions within the pancreatic duct. Enteric-coated tablets are not degraded in the proximal small intestine and, hence, might not be effective in reducing CCK secretion and relieving pain.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Pain relief in chronic pancreatitis can be obtained by the destruction of:
explanation: Celiac plexus block is used for pain relief in chronic pancreatitis as well as pancreatic carcinoma. It can be done using alcohol or other analgesics. It is a safe procedure, but the effect is short-lived.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient with chronic pancreatitis complains of intractable abdominal pain despite the administration of analgesics. CT scan shows pancreatic head enlargement. A EUS guided fine-needle biopsy ruled out pancreatic malignancy. What will be the preferred management in this patient?
explanation: Beger's procedure is the procedure of choice for patients with chronic pancreatitis, having an associated mass in the head of the pancreas. Beger's procedure is a duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection. It preserves the function of the foregut. Once the pancreatic head is removed, a Roux-en-Y is created and anastomosed to the rim of the pancreas or duodenum, pancreatic duct, and body and also the bile duct, if involved.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 34-year-old patient presents with intractable pain associated with chronic pancreatitis. MRCP shows the chain of lakes appearance. What will be the preferred management in this patient?
options: Resection of pancreatic tail and pancreatojejunostomy
explanation: The pancreatic duct dilation observed on pancreatography for chronic pancreatitis is classically described as a chain of lakes, which reflects the presence of multiple dilations and stenoses. When it is accompanied by intractable pain, this condition is best treated with side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy, also known as the modified Puestow procedure or lateral pancreaticojejunostomy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 36-year-old man presents with dull aching epigastric pain. He gives a history of acute abdominal pain following a binge of alcohol 5 weeks back which was managed conservatively. On examination, he appears icteric and a firm mass was palpable in the epigastrium. His CT scan is given below. Which of the following statements is false about his condition?
options: Cyst wall is lined by squamous epithelium.
Splenic artery is the most common artery involved.
explanation: The given clinical scenario with a history of acute pancreatitis, epigastric mass, and the CT image showing a cyst is suggestive of pancreatic pseudocyst. The capsule of the cyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. Hence, it is called a pseudocyst. Pseudocysts are post-inflammatory cysts that arise following an attack of mild acute pancreatitis. Formation of a pseudocyst requires 4 weeks or more from the onset of acute pancreatitis. They are also the most common complication of chronic pancreatitis. Pseudocysts are usually solitary and most commonly seen in the lesser omental sac. The most common artery involved is the splenic artery. Complications of pancreatic pseudocyst include: Abscess Systemic sepsis GI bleeding Fistula formation Peritonitis Obstructive jaundice Bowel obstruction Hemorrhage into the cyst Hemoperitoneum Pancreatic pseudocysts can be distinguished from cystic neoplasms by having high amylase levels and absence of mucin and low serum carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A young man is incidentally found to have a pseudocyst of the pancreas on abdominal ultrasound during a master health check-up. The size of the pseudocyst is 5 cm and is located in the tail of the pancreas. Past history is notable for two episodes of acute pancreatitis. How will you manage this patient?
explanation: Observation is the preferred treatment in this case since the size of the pseudocyst is <6 cm and is arising from the tail of the pancreas. Indications for conservative management in pancreatic pseudocyst: Asymptomatic patients Pseudocysts smaller than 6 cm (according to Bailey) Located on the tail No evidence of pancreatic duct obstruction or communication with the main pancreatic duct
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A 45-year-old patient presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain and severe
non-bilious vomiting. He was treated for upper abdominal pain 5 weeks ago. CT scan reveals a pancreatic pseudocyst of size 8 cm in close proximity to the stomach with secondary pressure effects. What is the best treatment option for this patient?
explanation: The best treatment option for this patient would be to perform a cystogastrostomy since the size of the tumor is greater than 6 cm and in close proximity to the stomach. Interventions in pseudocyst are required when: Complicated by infection Presence of a mass effect Diameter increasing in size or greater than 6 cm Recurrence following the previous resection Endoscopic drainage is usually curative. Surgical drainage is done if endoscopy is contraindicated or has failed. In this cystogastrostomy, an anterior gastrostomy is performed. Once the pseudocyst is located, it is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach using a linear stapler. The defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers. The image shows the procedure involved in cystogastrostomy. Feature Treatment approach Close contact (<1 cm) with th e stomach Transgastric drainage Close contact (<1 cm) with th e duodenum Transduodenal drainage Communicating with the mai n pancreatic duct Transpapillary drainage Pancreatic duct stricture asso ciated with a pancreatic pseu docyst Endoscopic dilation and sten t placement Cystoduodenostomy is done when pseudocyst is adjacent to the duodenum, or concern about disrupting pancreatic ductal entry into the duodenum. Roux-en-Y Cystojejunostomy is generally done for cysts that are neither in close proximity to the stomach and nor to the duodenum. This is generally preferred as the last resort as it is associated with a lot of complications. Percutaneous drainage to the exterior under radiological guidance is associated with a high recurrence rate and high incidence of pancreatic-cutaneous fistula. Hence, it is not usually done.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with recurrent abdominal pain radiating to the back and passage of dark-colored stools. He has pallor and mild epigastric tenderness on palpation. Blood investigations show severe anemia and high serum lipase. CT scan reveals a pancreatic pseudoaneurysm and subsequent endoscopy shows blood near the ampulla of Vater. Identify the false statement about his condition:
options: ERCP is the gold standard investigation.
Coil embolization is done only in stable patients.
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemosuccus pancreaticus. CT angiography is the gold standard in diagnosing hemosuccus pancreaticus. Haemosuccus pancreaticus, also known as pseudohaemobilia, is a rare cause of GI bleeding, due to blood originating from the pancreatic duct into the duodenum via the ampulla of Vater. It is usually caused by the erosion of a pancreatic pseudocyst into the splenic artery. In hemosuccus pancreatitis, abdominal pain radiating to the back accompanied by melena is the most typical presentation. The pain usually has an up and down pattern, which means it changes in intensity over time. This is due to the transient closure of pancreatic ducts. Other features include: Hematochezia Hematemesis Anemia Jaundice A palpable pulsatile mass with a thrill murmur Retroperitoneal bleeding Laboratory values show elevated lipase and low hemoglobin levels. The diagnosis is mainly through imaging modalities like upper GI endoscopy, ERCP, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), and contrast-enhanced CT scan. CT angiography is the gold standard diagnostic tool. It helps to localize the site of bleed and plan the management accordingly. Once the bleeding source is identified, hemodynamically stable patients are managed by coil embolization, balloon tamponade, or stent placement. Hemodynamically unstable patients are managed by distal pancreatectomy.

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about this procedure done for pancreatic pseudocyst?
options: Failure to respond to an endoscopic treatment is an indication.
Defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers.
The pseudocyst is drained through the anterior wall of the stomach.
Hemorrhage is the major complication expected.
explanation: The image shows cystogastrostomy, which is done for the pancreatic pseudocyst. The pseudocyst is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach. Surgery in pseudocyst is indicated for patients who fail to respond to endoscopic treatment. Pancreatic pseudocysts closely attached to the stomach should be treated with a cystogastrostomy. In this procedure, an anterior gastrostomy is performed. Once the pseudocyst is located, it is drained through the posterior wall of the stomach using a linear stapler. The defect in the anterior wall of the stomach is closed in two layers. Hemorrhage is the major complication expected post-surgery.

question_text: Milwaukee classification is used for the assessment of:
explanation: Milwaukee classification is used for the assessment of sphincter of Oddi dysfunction. Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction or dyskinesia (SOD) is a clinical syndrome in which pain, biochemical abnormalities, and dilatation of the bile duct and/or pancreatic duct are attributed to abnormal functions of the sphincter of Oddi. SOD may result from stenosis of the sphincter or from dysmotility. Scarring or stenosis of the sphincter can result from the passage of stones, pancreatitis, or prior endoscopic sphincterotomies. Whether such patients should undergo dual sphincterotomies (biliary and pancreatic) is debatable. Identify the marked structure:

Bile duct
explanation: The structure marked is the main pancreatic duct. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is performed using a side-viewing fibreoptic duodenoscope. The ampulla of Vater is intubated, and contrast injected into the biliary and pancreatic ducts to display the anatomy radiologically. ERCP is helpful for: Direct opacification of bile ducts and pancreatic ducts Dynamic information during the introduction and drainage of the contrast medium Visual assessment of the duodenum and ampulla of Vater, thereby facilitating biopsy Interventional procedures such as sphincterotomy, stone extraction, biliary stenting, and biliary stricture dilatation ERCP shows filling of the main pancreatic duct (MPD), common bile duct (B), and gallbladder (G). question_text: Which of the following statements is false about mucinous cystadenoma of the pancreas?
options: It is lined by columnar epithelium
Identified histologically by the presence of ovarian-like stroma
explanation: Mucinous cystadenoma of the pancreas is a premalignant condition. Mucinous cystadenoma or mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN) is a benign tumor of the pancreas with high risk of malignancy. They are commonly seen in perimenopausal women, and about two-thirds are located in the body or tail of the pancreas. MCNs are mostly incidental findings. When symptoms are present, they are usually nonspecific and include upper abdominal discomfort, early satiety, or weight loss. The cysts are lined by tall columnar epithelium. MCN's contain mucin-producing epithelium and are identified histologically by the presence of mucin-rich cells and ovarian-like stroma. Staining for estrogen and progesterone is positive in most cases. Malignant transformation of MCN is common with large tumors and old patients. This is due to a stepwise accumulation of mutations (K-ras, p53). question_text: A 58-year-old man is being evaluated for recurrent attacks of pancreatitis. An ERCP is done and it shows the presence of a fish-mouth sign at the ampulla of Vater. Which of the following statements is true about his condition?
options: It is more common in males
It only involves the main pancreatic duct
Head of pancreas is most common site of the neoplasm
explanation: A fish mouth sign at the ampulla of Vater during ERCP is indicative of intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN). It is most commonly seen in the head of the pancreas. The intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm can be diagnosed with the following findings (Ohashi triad) during endoscopy: Bulging ampulla of Vater (fish-mouth sign) Dilated pancreatic duct Mucin secretion from the opening Equal distribution is seen between males and females in IPMN. Patients are usually in their seventh or eighth decade of life and present with abdominal pain or recurrent pancreatitis. This is caused by the obstruction of the pancreatic duct by thick mucin. Some patients have symptoms secondary to pancreatic insufficiencies like steatorrhea, diabetes, and weight loss. IMPNs are of three types: Branch-duct IPMN (BD-IPMN) - affects only the small side branches. It is less frequently associated with malignancy. Main duct IPMN (MD-IPMN) - Affects the main pancreatic duct. Malignant transformation is commonly seen. Mixed-type IPMN - side-branch IPMNs that extend into the main duct

question_text: A 60-year-old man was incidentally found to have a pancreatic lesion on a USG. On further evaluation, a CT scan revealed the presence of a multicystic, lobulated mass in the pancreatic head, suggestive of serous cystadenoma. He is currently asymptomatic. What will be the next step in the management of this patient?
explanation: Endoscopic ultrasound-guided FNA (EUS-FNA) will be the next step in the management of this patient. Serous cystadenomas are essentially benign tumors without malignant potential. Serous cystadenocarcinoma has been reported very rarely (<1%). Therefore, malignant potential should not be a consideration for surgical resection. Surgical resection is done only for symptomatic patients. In asymptomatic patients, conservative management is adopted. However, it is important to confirm the diagnosis using EUS-FNA. question_text: What is the initiating event in the oncogenesis of pancreatic cancers?
explanation: The activation of the K-ras 2 oncogene is the initiating event in the oncogenesis of pancreatic cancers. It is activated in more than 95% of pancreatic cancers. Pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) develops into pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) in a sequential pathway. A number of tumor suppressor genes and oncogenes play a significant role in the pathogenesis of PDAC. They include: K-ras 2 PDX1 CDKN2A/p16 p53 DPC4 (SMAD4)

question_text: Which of the following are not risk factors for the development of pancreatic cancer?
explanation: An history of acute pancreatitis and female gender are not risk factors for the development of pancreatic cancer. Risk factors for pancreatic cancer: Demographic factors: Age (peak incidence, 65–75 years) Male gender Black ethnicity Cigarette smoking Genetic factors and medical conditions Family history: Two first-degree relatives with pancreas cancer Germline BRCA2 mutations in some rare high-risk families Hereditary pancreatitis Chronic pancreatitis Lynch syndrome Ataxia telangiectasia Peutz–Jeghers syndrome Familial breast-ovarian cancer syndrome Familial adenomatous polyposis Diabetes mellitus Obesity

question_text: What is the most common type of pancreatic malignancy?
explanation: Ductal adenocarcinoma is the most common type of pancreatic cancer. Types of exocrine pancreatic cancer: Ductal adenocarcinoma (85%) Adenosquamous carcinoma Acinar cell carcinoma Endocrine cancer of the pancreas is rare. They account for only 5% of clinically detected pancreatic tumours.

question_text: What is the most common site for pancreatic carcinoma?
explanation: Pancreatic carcinomas arise most commonly from the head of the gland.
