question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the presentation of patients with pancreatic carcinoma?
options: Release of platelet aggregating factors cause migratory thrombophlebitis
Abdominal pain is the most common presentation
Courvoisier's law implicates possible cancer of the head of the pancreas
Tumors of the body present at an advanced unresectable stage
explanation: Jaundice is the most common presentation of carcinoma of the head of the pancreas. It is secondary to obstruction of the distal bile duct. Clinical features of pancreatic cancers: Jaundice (most common) Nausea Epigastric discomfort Pruritus, dark urine, pale stools Steatorrhea Anorexia Weight loss Back pain - indicates retroperitoneal infiltration On examination, the patient can have: Palpable abdominal mass Ascites Supraclavicular lymphnodes Migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (Trousseau’s sign of malignancy) - due to release of platelet aggregating factors from the tumor Secondaries in the rectovesical pouch (Blumer’s shelf) A palpable, non-tender gall bladder Courvoisier's law states that in the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild jaundice, the cause is unlikely to be gallstones. This sign implicates possible cancer of the head of the pancreas. Tumors of the body and tail of the gland often grow silently and present at an advanced unresectable stage. Image showing migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (Trousseau’s sign of malignancy): Note: Trousseau's sign is also seen in hypocalcemia. It indicates carpopedal spasm (finger and wrist spasm) after inflation of a blood pressure cuff for several minutes when the brachial artery is occluded.

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true about pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma?
options: It is associated with desmoplastic changes, with scattering of neoplastic glands
Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas causes obstruction of both the pancreatic and biliary ducts
explanation: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas situated in the body of the pancreas are usually larger. Pancreatic adenocarcinomas are solid, slow-growing tumors, characterized by neoplastic tubular glands within a markedly desmoplastic fibrous stroma. They infiltrate locally, typically along nerve sheaths, along lymphatics, and into blood vessels. Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas causes obstruction of both the pancreatic and biliary ducts.

question_text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic pancreatitis presents with jaundice, severe itching, and weight loss. A smooth, globular mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. You suspect pancreatic cancer. What will be the imaging modality of choice for the evaluation of the tumor?
explanation: Multidetector computed tomography (CT) is the imaging modality of choice for the evaluation of pancreatic tumors. It allows an accurate determination of the level of biliary obstruction, the relationship of the tumor to the blood vessels, and the presence of regional or metastatic disease. For a detailed assessment of the luminal pancreato-biliary anatomy, MRCP should be considered. ERCP is reserved for cases requiring therapeutic or palliative intervention. It helps to perform a biopsy and to relieve obstruction by biliary stenting. The invasiveness of ERCP increases the rate of wound infection. Hence, it is not suitable for patients who will be undergoing surgery. F-fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) has the ability to differentiate between benign and malignant pancreas tumors. However, false-positive results are seen in FDG-PET. The benefits of FDG-PET over CT scans are yet to be determined. A CT-scan of pancreatic cancer:

options: Narrowing of C-loop of the duodenum
explanation: Widening of the C-loop of the duodenum is a barium meal finding seen in the adenocarcinoma of the pancreas. question_text: The best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma is:
options: Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound
explanation: Transgastric or transduodenal FNAC or trucut biopsy performed under endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) guidance is the best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma. This is because it avoids the spillage of tumor cells into the peritoneal cavity. Endoscopic ultrasonography with a fine needle aspiration (EUS-FNA) is done if CT has failed to demonstrate a tumor. When a tissue diagnosis is required prior to surgery to distinguish between inflammation and neoplasia, EUS-FNA is helpful. Diagnostic laparoscopy prior to resection can spare an unnecessary laparotomy by identifying small peritoneal and liver metastases. Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsy of potentially resectable pancreatic tumors is avoided.

question_text: Which is the most reliable tumor marker for the pre-treatment evaluation of a patient with pancreatic adenocarcinoma?
explanation: Carbohydrate antigen (CA) 19-9 is the most reliable tumor marker for pretreatment evaluation and post-treatment surveillance of pancreatic adenocarcinoma. Other tumor markers for pancreatic carcinoma are carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and -fetoprotein.

Short segment occlusion of superior mesenteric vein
explanation: Encasement of the celiac artery ( i.e >180° or >50% of the vessel circumference involvement) indicates surgical inoperability and is therefore considered to be non-resectable. question_text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of jaundice, clay-colored stools, and pruritis. After detailed radiological and pathological investigations, a 2 cm adenocarcinoma is found at the head of the pancreas. There is no spread to the adjacent structures. What is the preferred surgical management in this patient?
explanation: Since there is no involvement of adjacent structures, the preferred surgical management in this patient is pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy (PPPD), also known as Longmire–Traverso procedure. Pylorus-preserving pancreatoduodenectomy (PPPD) involves the removal of: Duodenum Pancreatic head The distal part of the bile duct The original pancreatoduodenectomy, as proposed by Whipple, included resection of the gastric antrum. Preserving the antrum and the pylorus results in a better physiological outcome, with no difference in survival or recurrence rates. Hence PPPD is preferred. For tumors of the body and tail, distal pancreatectomy is the preferred surgical management. Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (Beger's procedure) and Puestow's procedure (resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy) are management options for chronic pancreatitis.

question_text: You assist in performing a Whipple procedure in a patient with carcinoma of the pancreas. All of the following structures will be resected in this surgery, except:
explanation: Whipple procedure does not involve the removal of the spleen and tail of the pancreas. The Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done for carcinomas involving the head of the pancreas. It is done only in cases when: The entire duodenum has to be removed e.g. in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) Tumor encroaches in the first part of the duodenum, or stomach A clear resection margin is not achieved by pylorus preserving pancreatoduodectomy The following structures are removed during Whipple’s procedure: Distal stomach Duodenum Proximal jejunum Head of the pancreas Gallbladder Common bile duct (CBD) Regional lymphatics

question_text: During the reconstruction of the Whipple procedure, all of the following anastomoses will be done by a surgeon except:
explanation: Ileojejunostomy will not be done during the reconstruction of the Whipple procedure. The reconstruction following Whipple’s procedure or pylorus-preserving pancreaticoduodenectomy involves anastomosis in the following order: Pancreaticojejunostomy  Choledochojejunostomy  Gastrojejunostomy This is controversial since there is a difference in the reconstruction procedures mentioned in standard textbooks: Bailey and Love, 27th edition (Pg no: 1236) - Pancreaticojejunostomy + choledechojejunostomy + duodenojejunostomy Schwatrz, 11th edition (Pg no: 1493) - Pancreaticojejunostomy + choledechojejunostomy + gastrojejunostomy/duodenojejunostomy Sabiston, 20th edition (Pg no: 1546) - Pancreaticojejunostomy + hepaticojejunostomy + duodenojejunostomy

question_text: During the Whipple procedure, a surgeon performs the Kocher maneuver to access the retroperitoneum. This maneuver involves:
options: Mobilization of second part of duodenum
explanation: The Kocher maneuver involves the mobilization of the second part of the duodenum. It allows exposure of the retroperitoneal fat and the inferior vena cava (IVC). Another maneuver that is used to access the retroperitoneum is the Cattel Braasch maneuver. It involves the mobilization of the ascending colon. Other Kocher's in medicine: Kocher's technique is used for the reduction of anterior shoulder dislocation. It involves four steps: Traction  External Rotation  Adduction  Medial Rotation (TEAM) During thyroid palpation, Kocher's method is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding complications of the Whipple procedure?
options: Delayed gastric emptying is characterized by the need for prolonged nasogastric decompression
Any drainage output on or after postoperative day 3, with amylase >3 times normal value indicates pancreatic fistula
Biliary leakage is the most common complication
explanation: Delayed gastric emptying is the most common complication following the Whipple procedure, not biliary leakage. Delayed gastric emptying is characterized by the need for prolonged nasogastric decompression or the inability to tolerate oral intake. Most pancreatic fistulas are controlled by drainage catheters placed at the time of surgery. A pancreatic leak or pancreatic fistula is defined as the output via an intraoperatively placed drain (or percutaneous drain) of any measurable volume on or after postoperative day 3, with amylase >3 times the normal value. Other complications of the Whipple procedure include: Wound infection Intra-abdominal abscess Cardiac events Bile leak Overall reoperation Exocrine insufficiency Endocrine insufficiency

question_text: What is the most common cause of death in patients following pancreaticoduodenectomy?
explanation: The most common cause of death following pancreaticoduodenectomy is sepsis due to anastomotic leakage. Anastomotic leakage is responsible for 33–88 % of postoperative deaths after pancreaticoduodenectomy. Only about 5–16 % of patients develop post-surgical bleeding complications.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A patient was found to have a 3 cm adenocarcinoma of the body of the pancreas invading into the superior mesenteric artery. All of the following chemotherapeutic agents can be utilized for the management of this patient except:
FOLFIRINOX regimen
explanation: MVAC regimen (methotrexate, vinblastine, adriamycin, and cisplatin) is not used in the management of this patient. MVAC regimen is used in advanced bladder carcinoma. Chemotherapy in pancreatic cancer is indicated in patients with unresectable tumours and lymph node metastasis. Agents used in chemotherapy are: Gemcitabine Gemcitabine with capecitabine Albumin bound paclitaxel (nab-paclitaxel) FOLFIRINOX - a combination of fluorouracil, irinotecan, oxaliplatin, and leucovorin However, there is only a 2–5 months increase in median survival with these regimens. No long-term cure is seen with chemotherapy or radiotherapy for pancreatic carcinomas. Congenital Diseases of Kidney and Urinary Calculi

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the surgical anatomy of the kidney?
options: The right renal artery is longer than the left renal artery
The line of Brodel is an important access route for renal surgeries
The renal arteries are end arteries without collateral circulation
The kidney has a very poor lymphatic network
explanation: The kidney has an extensive lymphatic network. It begins in three plexuses which drain into the lateral aortic nodes. These are located around the renal tubules, under the renal capsule, and in the perirenal fat. The renal arteries are end arteries without collateral circulation. The right renal artery is longer than the left renal artery. This is due to the position of the abdominal aorta which is slightly to the left of the midline. The left renal vein is much longer than the right renal vein. This is due to the position of the IVC which is slightly to the right of the midline. The line of Brodel is the avascular plane of the kidney. It lies between anterior and posterior segmental branches. It is an important access route for both open and endoscopic surgical procedures, as it minimizes the risk of damage to major arterial branches.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements is true concerning a live-donor kidney transplant?
options: The iliac fossa on the posterior abdominal wall is the usual site
The renal artery is anastomosed end-to-end to the external iliac artery
The renal vein is anastomosed end-to-side to the internal iliac vein
Right kidney is preferred over the left for transplantation
explanation: The iliac fossa on the posterior abdominal wall is the usual site chosen for transplantation of the kidney. The left kidney is preferred for transplantation because the left renal vein is longer. In the case of a deceased donor, the arterial graft is traced until the aorta which makes it longer, and hence end-to-side anastomosis is possible. Whereas, in the case of a live donor, the arterial graft cannot be extended until the aorta. question_text: An intravenous pyelogram done for evaluation of recurrent UTI in a child is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Associated with an increased incidence of renal cell carcinoma
Lies just below the origin of inferior mesenteric artery
Division at the level of the isthmus improves function
explanation: The given scenario with intravenous pyelogram showing flower vase sign points to a diagnosis of horseshoe kidney. Division of the relatively avascular isthmus between the kidneys is usually not indicated. This is because it can lead to an increased risk of urinary fistula. Horseshoe kidneys are the most common fusion defects of the kidney, characterized by abnormalities in the position, rotation, and vascular supply of the kidney. The fused portion lies adjacent to the L3 or L4 vertebra just below the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery. Ascent of the fused kidneys is prevented by the inferior mesenteric artery. Adrenal glands remain in the normal position. There is a 2:1 male predominance. It is also commonly associated with renal cell carcinoma, Wilms tumor, multicystic dysplastic kidney, and Turner’s syndrome. Patients may be asymptomatic or may present with: Dull renal pain Abdominal lump Urinary tract infections Increased angulation of ureters resulting in - Nephrolithiasis Hydronephrosis Radiological diagnosis is by intravenous pyelogram which shows flower vase sign or handshake sign. Symptomatic management is preferred. Heminephrectomy is usually not indicated for horseshoe kidneys with unilateral RCC/ Wilms tumor. This is because it can result in devascularisation due to the unpredictable blood supply of the horseshoe kidney from nearby major vessels. Note: Division of the relatively avascular isthmus between the kidneys is only indicated in the course of surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm. The below CECT shows a fusion defect of the kidneys.

question_text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent UTI. Ultrasound revealed a dilated renal pelvis. Intravenous urogram done is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario and intravenous urogram showing a "drooping lily" sign point to a diagnosis of a duplex kidney. It refers to the presence of duplicated ureters or collecting systems. This is due to the incomplete fusion of the upper and lower pole of the kidney. Duplex kidneys have two separate pelvicalyceal systems draining single renal parenchyma. The lower pole ureter is normally inserted into the bladder. However, the upper pole ureter has an ectopic insertion. It crosses the lower pole ureter to open inferior and medial to the normal site of insertion (Weigert–Meyer rule). This results in reflux and incontinence. Option B: In retrocaval ureter, the IVC presses on the right ureter as it lies behind the IVC. Intravenous urogram shows reversed ‘J’/ fish hook ureter.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A known hypertensive presented with intermittent left-sided flank pain. His brother passed away two years ago due to a ruptured berry aneurysm. CT abdomen done is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?
options: Decompression of cyst improves renal function
explanation: The given scenario with CT showing multiple cysts in the kidneys and liver points to a diagnosis of adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). In such patients, decompression or deroofing of the cysts (Rovsing’s procedure) cannot restore normal renal function. ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). The disease does not usually manifest before 30 years of age, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed. The progression of the disease is faster in males. Hypertension is the most common presentation. Renal manifestations of ADPKD include: Flank/loin pain - either due to hemorrhage inside cysts or due to renal stones (most commonly uric acid stones) Irregular upper quadrant renal mass Hematuria Uremia Renal failure (seen in 10-15% of the patients who receive hemodialysis) Intravenous pyelography shows characteristic spider leg sign, as a result of stretched calyces due to multiple cysts. Nephrogram shows a swiss cheese appearance. On prenatal USG, the presence of either > 3 cysts in unilateral kidneys or > 2 cysts in each kidney is suggestive of PKD. Treatment includes: Long-term dialysis Renal transplantation Vasopressin V2 receptor antagonists Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) occurs secondary to a mutation of the PKHD1 gene. The severe form manifests in-utero or during infancy; milder cases can manifest later in childhood. 50% of affected newborns die in the first few days of life.
subject: Surgery

question_text: The following image shows the retrograde ureteropyelogram of a patient with loin pain. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
explanation: The given image showing dilated clubbed calyces with stricture of the left ureteropelvic junction points to a diagnosis of hydronephrosis. Hydronephrosis refers to the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system caused by a partial or complete blockage of urinary flow. Investigations: Ultrasound is the least invasive technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis. Retrograde pyelography is rarely indicated but will confirm the site of obstruction before corrective surgery. Intravenous urogram (IVU) is helpful only if the obstructed kidney is functional. In IVU, the extrarenal pelvis is dilated and the minor calyces lose their normal cupping. In early stages, there is blunting of calyces followed by its clubbing in the late stages. A renal isotope scan (DTPA or MAG-3) is the best modality to confirm the obstructive dilatation of the collecting system.
subject: Surgery

question_text: An ultrasound scan done at 32 weeks for a woman with oligohydramnios revealed fetal hydronephrosis. What is the most likely cause for this condition?
explanation: Ureteropelvic junction obstruction is the most common cause of hydronephrosis found on prenatal ultrasound. The causes of UPJ obstruction can be: Intrinsic - due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter Extrinsic - due to accessory renal arteries Treatment includes Anderson Hynes dismembered pyeloplasty. Option B: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is the second most common cause of hydronephrosis. In VUR, the valve that prevents the backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureter is defective. Option C: Ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter, thought to result from the persistence of the membrane between the ureteral bud and urogenital sinus. IVU shows cobra head/ adder head appearance. Option D: Posterior urethral valve is an obstructing membrane in the posterior male urethra as a result of abnormal in-utero development. It is the most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male newborns. Note: Renal stones are the most common cause of acquired unilateral hydronephrosis.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A mother brings her 3-month-old infant to the OPD with complaints of him crying while urinating. On palpation, a left-sided flank mass is felt. A USG KUB revealed dilation of the pelvicalyceal system with a normal-looking distal urinary tract. What is the investigation of choice to confirm his diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of a ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction. The investigation of choice for UPJ obstruction is 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan. Delayed clearance of contrast or the radiotracer implies obstruction. Renal isotope scans have replaced intravenous pyelogram as the diagnostic modality of choice in UPJ obstruction. 99mTc-MAG3 is the most commonly used isotope in dynamic renography. Its uptake reflects the tubular function. 99mTc-DTPA may also be used. Its uptake reflects the glomerular function. Hence, it is commonly used to assess GFR. In obstructive uropathy, 99mTc-DTPA is the preferred isotope as glomerular function declines earlier and more rapidly than tubular function. Micturating cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice in vesicoureteric reflux. Tc-99m dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is used for assessing renal scarring. Note: In children, crying before and after micturition is usually considered normal. While crying during micturition is usually suggestive of pathology.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A child was brought to you with recurrent episodes of colicky abdominal pain. USG revealed left-sided hydronephrosis. On the third follow-up day, a decrease in abdominal pain was noted after he passed a large amount of urine. Repeat USG showed a significant decrease in the size of the left kidney. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario of hydronephrosis with renal pain relieved after the passage of a large amount of urine is suggestive of Dietl's crisis. It is defined as intermittent ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction causing episodic abdominal pain and nausea, most often due to an aberrant accessory renal artery or vein. In an acute phase of ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, loin swelling occurs along with renal pain due to the retention of urine in the kidney. When the obstruction is relieved, the patient passes a large amount of urine, the swelling is reduced and the pain disappears. This is termed Dietl's crisis. In the majority of cases, pyeloplasty results in the complete resolution of symptoms.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following are risk factors for calcium stone formation?
explanation: Hypercalciuria, hyperoxaluria, and hyperuricosuria are risk factors for calcium stone formation. Risk factors for calcium stone formation include: High urine concentration of calcium, oxalate, or uric acid Low urine concentration of renal stone inhibiting factors such as citrate and magnesium Abnormal urine pH Renal stone formation is governed by factors promoting and inhibiting stone formation. Stone formation occurs when the concentration product is more than the formation product i.e., CP > FP, where: Concentration product (CP) - the amount of solute in solution Formation product (FP) - maximum concentration of solute in solution after taking into account stone inhibiting factors.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which among the following is the investigation of choice in a patient suspected to have ureteric stones?
explanation: Non-contrast CT abdomen (NCCT) is the investigation of choice for the clinical evaluation of ureteric stones. NCCT is the preferred investigation for evaluation of: Renal stones except for indinavir stones Ureteric stones Head injury Salivary gland stones
subject: Surgery

question_text: A man presents to the casualty with fever and hematuria for 3 days. He also gives a history of recurrent left-sided loin pain radiating to the groin. X-ray KUB done is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding stones seen in his condition?
options: Composed of calcium, ammonium, and magnesium phosphate
It is formed in acidic urine
Increased risk with infections by urease producing organisms
Rectangular or coffin lid appearance on microscopy
explanation: The given scenario and X-Ray KUB showing staghorn appearance points to a diagnosis of struvite stones. Struvite stone is produced in alkaline urine. It is commonly associated with infections with urea-splitting organisms like Proteus and Klebsiella species. Increased metabolism of urea results in alkalinity of the urine. Struvite is a triple-phosphate calculus (calcium, ammonium, and magnesium phosphate). The calculus may enlarge to fill most of the collecting system, forming a staghorn calculus. These stones are dirty-white in color, and grossly smooth in texture. Rectangular or coffin lid appearance is seen on microscopic examination.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Acetohydroxamic acid will be prescribed for patients with which of the following types of renal stones?
explanation: Acetohydroxamic acid is used for the treatment of struvite stone. It is a urease inhibitor. The urease enzyme generates ammonia from urea, elevating the pH of the urine. This favors the production of struvite stones. Thus, the use of AHA(Acetohydroxamic acid) causes complete, noncompetitive inhibition of urease production, thereby slowing struvite stone growth. Owing to its side-effects, the use of this drug has been restricted in cases of recurrent UTIs, and those intolerant or who refuse surgical management. It can also be used for oral chemolysis and can potentiate the action of antibiotics.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient is referred for the evaluation of severe right-sided abdominal pain. Abdominal X-ray appears normal, and a USG revealed the presence of a 6mm renal stone. Which of the following stones is most likely to be seen in this patient?
explanation: In the given scenario since the stone is radiolucent, it is most likely to be uric acid stone. Uric acid stones are preferentially formed in acidic urine. It is commonly associated with disorders of purine metabolism such as gout, and tumor lysis syndrome. On microscopic examination, the crystals appear as glass shards. Patients with recurrent uric acid stones are treated with Allopurinol. Note: 90% of the renal stones are radio-opaque, while 80% of gall bladder stones are radiolucent.
subject: Surgery

question_text: The urine microscopy of a young man admitted for the evaluation of renal stones shows the following finding. What type of stone is this?
explanation: The urine microscopy shows the presence of hexagonal-shaped stones which are likely to be cystine stones. These stones are commonly found in acidic urine. Recurrent stones are treated using D-penicillamine.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding renal stones?
options: A low calcium diet can prevent the recurrence of calcium stone
Potassium citrate reduces the risk of uric acid stone
d-Penicillamine can be used to prevent cystine stone formation
Pyridoxine can reduce the risk of oxalate stone formation
explanation: A low calcium diet has not shown any significant benefit in the prevention of calcium stone formation, compared to a normocalcemic diet. However, a diet rich in calcium rather binds with dietary oxalate and reduces dietary absorption of oxalate. This effect leads to a lower risk of calcium oxalate stone formation in the kidneys. Option B: Uric acid crystallization and stone formation take place in acidic pH. Therefore, urinary alkalinization by potassium citrate reduces the risk of urate stone formation. Option C: Cystine stones are usually formed in presence of cystinuria. Initial treatment options to prevent recurrent cystine stone formation includes increased fluid intake and urinary alkalinization (e.g citrate). If this therapy fails, d-penicillamine can be used. Option D: Pyridoxine acts as a cofactor in the oxalic acid metabolism process and helps in the reduction of endogenous oxalate levels. Several studies have mentioned the role of pyridoxine in the reduction of oxalate stone formation.
subject: Surgery

question_text: An HIV-positive man on HAART presents to the casualty with intermittent right-sided flank pain. He is suspected to have renal stones. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be responsible for this condition?
explanation: Indinavir (a protease-inhibitor) is most likely to be responsible for renal stones in a patient on HAART. It has the highest incidence of nephrolithiasis among anti-retroviral drugs. Indinavir is released in high concentration in the urine due to poor solubility in the physiologic pH. Consequently, patients develop stones that are principally composed of indinavir or of a mixture of indinavir and other substances, such as calcium oxalate. Other urolithogenic drugs are: Antihypertensives - furosemide, bumetanide (loop diuretics), triamterene (potassium-sparing diuretic) Decongestant - ephedrine Expectorant - guaifenesin Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - acetazolamide, topiramate, and zonisamide Newer antiretroviral agents - lopinavir-ritonavir, ritonavir-boosted atazanavir, nelfinavir, and amprenavir
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following types of renal stones are produced by laxative abuse?
explanation: Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse. Loss of potassium and sodium in laxative abuse causes intracellular acidosis, which increases the production of ammonia in urine. Dehydration and sodium loss further exacerbate hypokalemia and reduces the urinary volume, resulting in hyperuricemia. Highly concentrated uric acid and ammonia promote the formation of ammonium urate stones. These are also associated with inflammatory bowel disease, chronic diarrhea, ileostomy, recurrent urinary tract infection and recurrent uric acid stone formation. The below image shows an ammonium urate stone.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A woman with severe right-sided colicky loin pain is suspected to have renal calculi. What is the maximum size of the calculi up to which this patient can be managed expectantly?
explanation: Patients with renal calculi  0.5 cm in size can be treated expectantly, as they are likely to pass spontaneously. Medical management of renal stones involves: Pain control with NSAIDs or opioid analgesics Medical expulsive therapy with tamsulosin ( blocker) and Nifedipine (calcium channel blockers) Monitoring for the symptoms of urinary tract infection and decreased renal function
subject: Surgery

question_text: In patients with which of the following renal stones, will extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy not be considered?
explanation: Cystine stones are very hard stones, hence it is difficult to disintegrate it with extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL). ESWL is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Stones that are difficult to disintegrate by ESWL: Cystine Brushite Calcium oxalate monohydrate Stones that are relatively easy to disintegrate by ESWL: Calcium oxalate dihydrate Phosphate
subject: Surgery

question_text: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy is contraindicated in all of the following patients except?
options: A young woman with untreated bleeding diathesis
A man with a ureteric stricture
A middle aged man with a saccular aneurysm
explanation: Saccular aneurysm or berry aneurysm is not a contraindication for extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL). Contraindications to ESWL: Pregnancy Uncorrected coagulopathy or bleeding diathesis Untreated urinary tract infection Arterial aneurysm near stones (renal or abdominal aortic aneurysms) Obstruction of urinary tract distal to the stones Skeletal malformations resulting in an inability to target stones Complications of ESWL include: Pain Hematuria Steinstrasse - means a street of stones. It occurs due to the collection of stone fragments in the ureter Urinary tract infections
subject: Surgery

question_text: An elderly woman was brought to the hospital with a history of severe loin pain for the past 7 hours. Ultrasound of the kidney reveals a 2.5 cm renal stone. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
explanation: The treatment of choice for renal calculi of size >2cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL). In PCNL, endoscopic instruments are passed into the kidney using a percutaneous technique, and stones are removed. PCNL is also indicated in: Staghorn calculi Multiple stones Proximal ureteral stones >1 cm Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include hemorrhage, perforation of the collecting system, and of the colon or pleural cavity. Another approach for the management of renal stones is ureteroscopic removal(URS) or retrograde intra-renal surgery (RIRS). In URS, stones are removed via a retrograde approach using a dormia basket, or a Holmium YAG laser is used to break the stones. If PCNL or URS fails, open or laparoscopic pyelolithotomy or nephrolithotomy is done. The image below summarizes how the Dormia basket works with ureteroscopy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A man came to the casualty with right-sided colicky loin pain radiating to the inner thigh. NCCT abdomen revealed a non-impacted 1cm calculi in the right ureter. How will you manage this patient?
explanation: Ureteroscopic removal is the preferred treatment in non-impacted ureteric stones >5-6mm in size.
subject: Surgery

question_text:
A man was brought to the casualty with severe left-sided colicky flank pain. On examination, he was febrile, with a BP of 90/60 mmHg and a feeble rapid pulse. Investigations revealed WBC= 16,800 with a 2.5 cm calculi in the left ureter. What is the preferred management in this patient?
Nephrostomy
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of a patient in sepsis secondary to an obstructed renal calculi. Nephrostomy is the preferred management in these patients. Treatment in patients with sepsis secondary to an obstructing urinary tract calculi includes: Insertion of a percutaneous nephrostomy Insertion of a ureteric stent via cystoscopy Nephrostomy is preferred in extremely unwell patients as it is less manipulative and has a lower risk of septicemia. Infections and Tumors of Kidney
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding acute pyelonephritis?
options: CECT abdomen is the investigation of choice
Commonly associated with uric acid stones
Renal scarring is common in untreated cases
The mainstay of treatment is broad-spectrum antibiotics
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute pyelonephritis. Patients with acute pyelonephritis are more likely to have struvite stones, not uric acid stones. This is because of infection with urea-splitting organisms such as proteus that release ammonia. This makes the urine alkaline and promotes the formation of struvite stones. Acute pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection causing inflammation of the kidneys. Ascending infection in the urinary tract is the most common route. It is more common in young, sexually active women. Up to 50% of children with urinary infections have an underlying anatomical abnormality (e.g., reflux or obstruction). Clinical features include: Prodromal symptoms such as headache, lassitude, vomiting Flank pain, fever, rigor Pyuria and occasionally hematuria CECT abdomen is the investigation of choice to rule out pyonephrosis. The mainstay of treatment is broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent renal scarring. Surgery is indicated only if antibiotic therapy fails.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A diabetic patient presents with pyrexia and left flank pain. On examination, Murphy's punch sign is positive. CECT abdomen done is shown below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
explanation: The given history with Murphy's punch sign positive, and streaks of gas on CECT abdomen point to a diagnosis of emphysematous pyelonephritis. Escherichia coli is the most common causative organism. Emphysematous pyelonephritis is associated with an acute necrotizing infection of the kidney by gas-producing organisms that occurs predominantly in diabetic patients. E. coli produces carbon dioxide by the fermentation of sugar. Patients frequently present with sepsis and ketoacidosis. It can be associated with tenderness at the costovertebral angle known as Murphy's punch sign. CECT abdomen shows an enlarged destructed renal parenchyma with small linear streaks of gas. Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics with drainage. In patients who fail to respond to treatment, nephrectomy is considered. Note: Clostridium species are the most common causative organisms in emphysematous cholecystitis. Murphy's punch sign is also seen in infection, inflammation, or obstruction of the kidney. The below image shows the costovertebral angle formed between the lower border of the 12th rib and the vertebral column.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A woman is referred to you for evaluation of recurrent episodes of right flank pain and high-grade fever. She also had a history of recurrent urinary calculi in the past. CECT abdomen done is shown below. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?
explanation: The given scenario with CECT abdomen showing bear paw sign is suggestive of xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (XGP). Subcapsular nephrectomy is the preferred treatment in patients with XGP. It is a form of chronic pyelonephritis seen most frequently in middle-aged diabetic women and, rarely, in children. XGP is most commonly caused by proteus followed by E. coli. The disease is usually unilateral and is associated with prolonged obstructing nephrolithiasis. CECT abdomen shows dilated and enlarged renal pelvis and calyxes showing a multiloculated appearance. This is referred to as the bear paw sign. Histology shows foamy, lipid-laden macrophages.
subject: Surgery

question_text: CT done for a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario of sterile pyuria with CT showing right-sided putty kidney points to renal tuberculosis. Putty kidney refers to the amorphous dystrophic calcification seen over the entire kidney during the end stage of genitourinary TB. Genitourinary tuberculosis is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream. It occurs either due to reinfection or reactivation of old TB. CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB. ATT is given to all patients with genitourinary TB. Nephrectomy is the preferred treatment in patients with putty/ cement kidneys. Option D: Nephrocalcinosis refers to the deposition of calcium salts in the kidney parenchyma and tubules.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A man presented to the OPD with hematuria and intermittent right flank pain. He received ATT for pulmonary TB two years ago. Urine analysis revealed pus cells, and no growth was seen on culture. Which of the following lesions are associated with this condition?
explanation: The given history of pulmonary TB and presence of sterile pyuria on urine culture is suggestive of a diagnosis of renal tuberculosis. All of the above lesions can be seen in renal TB. Lesions in the kidney include: Papillary ulcer - earliest lesion Pyonephrosis/ Putty kidney - caused by multiple scattered papillary ulcers undergoing caseous necrosis, which later become filled with pus Cement kidney - caused by calcifications in putty kidney Perinephric abscess - by extension of pyonephrosis or tuberculous renal abscess Pseudocalculi - occurs when calcium gets deposited in a papillary ulcer healed with fibrosis Ghost calyces - caused by the destruction of the calyces Thimble bladder - caused by fibrosis. The earliest sign is the paleness of bladder mucosa. managed by ileocystoplasty Golf hole ureteric orifice - Dilated ureteric orifice. Managed by ureter reimplantation.
subject: Surgery

question_text: The Bosniak classification system is used in assessing patients with which of the following conditions?
explanation: The Bosniak classification system is used for assessing patients with renal cysts. It divides renal cystic masses into five classes based on imaging characteristics seen on CECT. It is helpful in predicting the risks of malignancy and identifying the appropriate choice of clinical follow-up or treatment. Renal cyst clas s Risk of malignan cy Workup 1 0% Nil 2 0% Nil 2F 5% USG/ CT follow up 3 50% Partial nephrectomyRadiofre quency ablation - in elderly o r poor surgical candidates 4 100% Partial or total nephrectomy
subject: Surgery

question_text: An ultrasound abdomen done for evaluation of flank pain in a man revealed a large mass arising from the right kidney. CECT abdomen done showed the presence of a central stellate scar. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: In the given scenario, the presence of a central stellate scar on CECT is suggestive of a diagnosis of oncocytoma. Oncocytoma is the most common benign renal tumor. It arises from cells rich in mitochondria. Familial type is associated with Birt Hogg Dube syndrome. Most patients remain asymptomatic even with large oncocytomas. In some cases, it may present as an abdominal lump. The cystic variant of the tumor is classified as Bosniak class III on CECT. On histological examination, large eosinophilic cells owing to an abundance of mitochondria are seen arranged in distinct nests. Partial nephrectomy is the preferred treatment. Note: Central stellate scar on CECT is also seen in chromophobe RCC and focal nodular hyperplasia of the liver. The given CECT shows an enhancing right renal mass with a central stellate scar The given slide shows large eosinophilic cells arranged in nests
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient presented to the casualty with severe back pain and vomiting. He was diagnosed to have tuberous sclerosis during childhood. CT scan revealed the presence of renal tumors with high-fat content as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario and CT findings are suggestive of a diagnosis of angiomyolipoma. Angiomyolipoma (AML) is a benign neoplasm of the kidney. It contains blood vessels, smooth muscles, and fat, and arises from perivascular epithelioid cells. It can occur in isolated forms or may be associated with tuberous sclerosis. Patients can either be asymptomatic or may present with abdominal pain or a lump. Some patients may also present with massive hemorrhage referred to as Wunderlich’s syndrome. Lenk’s triad seen in patients with Wunderlich’s syndrome includes: Abdominal mass Abdominal pain Shock Due to the presence of abundant fat tissue, they can be easily identified on CT scans. Immunohistochemistry is positive for HMB 45. Treatment includes: Asymptomatic tumors and tumors less than 4 cm in size - Observation with serial CECT Symptomatic tumors and tumors more than 4 cm in size - Partial nephrectomy/ nephron-sparing surgery Bleeding tumors - Angioembolization followed by partial nephrectomy Everolimus is FDA approved for the treatment of AMLs. Note: HMB45 is positive on IHC for malignant melanoma and angiomyolipomas.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding Grawitz tumor?
options: Derived from the proximal tubular epithelium
Clear cell is the most common histological type
explanation: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) also known as Grawitz tumor or hypernephroma, is a radio-resistant tumor. RCC accounts for 85% of renal neoplasms in adults. It is more common in males between the sixth to seventh decades. Clear-cell RCC is the most common type of renal cell cancer. The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) of the nephron is usually the site of origin of RCC. Risk factors for RCC: Smoking Obesity Family history of RCC Drugs like phenacetin and diuretics Thorotrast exposure Increased protein intake
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is not true regarding the presentation of renal cell carcinoma?
options: Flank pain is the most common presentation
It is more commonly associated with left sided varicoceles
It may be associated with pulsatile bony metastasis
Palpable abdominal mass is part of the classic triad seen in RCC
explanation: The most common presentation in patients with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is gross hematuria. The classic triad (seen in <10% of cases) includes : Gross hematuria Flank pain Palpable abdominal mass Rapidly developing varicoceles can be seen in patients with RCC. Varicocele is usually seen on the left side, as the left gonadal vein drains into the left renal vein at a sharp angle. On the right side, the gonadal vein opens into the much larger IVC. Patients may also present with paraneoplastic syndromes. RCC can give rise to pulsatile bony metastases.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A man presents with intermittent hematuria and flank pain for 2 months. He is a known smoker and is found to be anemic. Further investigations reveal an enhancing lesion arising from the right kidney. Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes is not likely to be seen in his condition?
explanation: Hematuria and flank pain in a known smoker with the given investigation findings is suggestive of renal cell carcinoma. Cerebellar degeneration is not a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with RCC. Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with RCC include: Endocrine paraneoplastic syndromes - Stauffer syndrome - non-metastatic liver dysfunction, characterized by elevated serum bilirubin, ALP, and prolonged prothrombin time Hypercalcemia - due to increased vitamin D, PTH-related protein Hypertension Polycythemia Galactorrhea Cushing’s syndrome Alterations in glucose metabolism Non-endocrine paraneoplastic syndromes include Lambert Eaton syndrome (neuromyopathy), amyloidosis, anemia, vasculopathy, nephropathy, coagulopathy, elevated ESR, prostaglandin elevation. Elevated ESR is the most common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with RCC. Note: Cerebellar degeneration is a paraneoplastic syndrome in Hodgkin's lymphoma.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Lab values from a routine workup done for a hypertensive man are given below. Further investigations revealed hepatosplenomegaly with a 5.5 cm tumor arising from the right kidney. No signs of metastasis were noted. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
explanation: The given scenario points to a diagnosis of Stauffer syndrome in a patient with renal cell carcinoma. Stauffer syndrome is a rare paraneoplastic syndrome seen in RCC. It is a non-metastatic liver dysfunction mediated via interleukin 6. It is characterized by the presence of hepatosplenomegaly with no features of metastasis and the following lab findings: Hyperbilirubinemia Raised ALP Hypoalbuminemia Hypergammaglobulinemia Prolonged prothrombin time Option A: Hepatorenal syndrome refers to the development of renal failure in patients with advanced chronic liver disease. Option C: Budd Chiari syndrome is characterized by hepatic venous outflow tract obstruction (HVOTO).
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following types of renal cell carcinoma is characterized by multiple losses of entire chromosomes?
explanation: Chromophobe type renal cell carcinomas (RCC) are uniquely associated with multiple losses of entire chromosomes, including chromosomes 1, 2, 6, 10, 13, 17, and 21. Thus, they show extreme hypodiploidy.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A man was referred for the evaluation of an unsteady gait with weakness of his legs for the past 1 month. He gave a history of similar problems in his brother. Imaging revealed cerebellar hemangioblastomas and bilateral renal masses suggestive of RCC. Which histological type of this renal malignancy is he most likely to have?
explanation: The clinical features mentioned are consistent with renal cell carcinoma and cerebellar hemangioblastoma which along with the family history points to a diagnosis of von Hippel Lindau’s disease (VHL). Clear cell RCC is the most common type associated with VHL disease. VHL disease is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and is caused by a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. A second hit can increase the predisposition to a variety of neoplasms, particularly hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum and retina, and clear cell renal carcinoma(in 40-60%). The given slide shows clear cell RCC.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is the most common method of diagnostic investigation in patients suspected to have hypernephroma?
explanation: The most common method of diagnostic investigation in hypernephroma or renal cell carcinoma is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. Characteristic features of RCC on CT scan include: Enhancement of the lesion after injection of IV contrast Thickened irregular walls Thickened or enhanced septa within the mass or multilocular mass CT scan has replaced IVP and ultrasound as the radiological modality of choice to evaluate renal masses. MRI can be performed for diagnosing poorly characterized renal masses on CT or if a CT scan is contraindicated (in case of allergy to IV contrast). It also helps in defining tumor extension into the renal vein or IVC. The below image shows a cystic tumor involving the left kidney suggestive of renal cell carcinoma.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A CECT abdomen done to evaluate an elderly man with intermittent flank pain is shown below. Which of the following will be the most common site for secondary metastasis in patients with this tumor?
explanation: The history and CECT mentioned in the above scenario are consistent with a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. The most common site for secondary metastasis in RCC is the lungs, where they form secondaries commonly known as cannonball secondaries. The tumor is prone to extend into the renal vein and reach the lungs via circulation. RCC also metastasizes to the bone, lymph nodes, liver, adrenal glands, and brain. Para-aortic nodes are the first draining lymph nodes. The image below shows multiple round opacities in bilateral lungs suggestive of cannonball metastasis in the lungs.
subject: Surgery

question_text: In patients with which of the following findings on CECT abdomen, would you stage the tumor as T3 stage of RCC?
options: 8.5 cm tumor limited to the kidney
5 cm tumor limited to the kidney
12 cm tumor involving the supra-diaphragmatic IVC
11.5 cm tumor extending into the ipsilateral adrenal gland
explanation: In the T3c stage of hypernephroma or renal cell carcinoma, the tumor spreads to the supra-diaphragmatic IVC or invades the wall of the IVC. TNM staging for renal cell carcinoma Note: Robson staging is a less commonly used staging system for RCC. Fuhrmann grading is used for grading RCC. question_text: Which of the following should be the treatment of choice for renal cell carcinoma with tumor less than 4 cm in size?
explanation: Partial nephrectomy (also known as nephron-sparing surgery) is the treatment of choice for tumors <4 cm. Indications for partial nephrectomy: Tumors < 4cm Well-selected tumors between 4-7 cm Bilateral tumors Tumor in solitary kidneys Patients with pre-existing renal dysfunction. Recently, partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed for stage T1b tumors. Treatment of renal cell carcinoma: RCC is a radio and chemoresistant tumor. Radical nephrectomy consists of the removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes. The adrenal gland is no longer removed except in cases of obvious tumor involvement. Lymphadenectomy is indicated only in high-risk patients with large primary tumors and enlarged lymph nodes. Cryoablation is indicated in the T1a stage of RCC if surgery cannot be performed. It is also indicated in advanced/metastatic tumors. Note: Sunitinib and sorafenib are also used in GIST and hepatocellular carcinoma. Radical nephrectomy Stag e 4 Tumor invades beyond Gerot a fascia (including contiguou s extension into the ipsilatera adrenal gland) Debulking surgerymTOR inhi bitors such as everolimus, sir olimusTyrosine kinase inhibi tors: sunitinib, sorafenib

question_text: You are assisting in a radical nephrectomy in a patient with renal cell carcinoma. Which of the following statements is false regarding this procedure?
options: Early ligation of vessels is performed to reduce tumor spread
It includes removal of the kidney with Gerota's fascia
Excision of ipsilateral adrenal gland is done in all the cases
Regional lymphadenectomy is done for tumors more than 10 cm in size
explanation: Excision of the ipsilateral adrenal gland in radical nephrectomy is done only if the tumor is adherent to it. Classical radical nephrectomy includes: Early ligation of the renal artery and vein to prevent tumor spread Removal of the kidney with primary dissection external to the Gerota's fascia A complete regional lymphadenectomy from the crus of the diaphragm to the aortic bifurcation Regional lymphadenectomy is not required in every radical nephrectomy. It is indicated in the following conditions: Enlarged lymph nodes on imaging Cytoreductive surgery for metastatic disease Tumor size > 10 cm Nuclear grade  3 Sarcomatoid histology in renal tumor Presence of tumor necrosis on imaging Extrarenal tumor extension Tumor thrombus Direct tumoral invasion of adjacent organs
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which is the most common abdominal tumor seen in children?
explanation: Neuroblastoma is the most common abdominal tumor of childhood. Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. The renal origin of the mass is usually apparent on CT, but it can be mistaken for neuroblastoma. Wilm's tumor shows peripheral calcification in contrast-enhanced CT, unlike intratumoral calcifications and vascular encasement, which are observed in neuroblastoma. question_text: A boy was brought by his parents, with complaints of blood in his urine. A left-sided reniform mass was palpated. Further investigations were suggestive of Wilms tumor. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Most cases occur in children between 2-5 years of age
It is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood
Early metastasis occurs to the liver
Nephrogenic rest cells are precursor lesions
explanation: Metastasis to the lungs occurs early in Wilms tumor. Liver, bone, and brain metastasis is rare. Wilms tumor or nephroblastoma is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood. It is commonly seen in children between 2-5 years of age. More than one-third of the cases contain precursor lesions known as nephrogenic rests. Asymptomatic abdominal mass discovered incidentally is the most common presentation. Patients may also present with: Abdominal pain Gross painless hematuria Fever Hypertension Most unilateral tumors are treated by chemotherapy (cyclophosphamide, vincristine, and dactinomycin) followed by nephrectomy. Radical nephrectomy is the standard surgical procedure done. Partial nephrectomy is considered if all the following conditions are met: The tumor involves only one pole of the kidney No evidence of collecting system or vascular involvement The involved kidney has an appreciable function There are clear margins between tumor and surrounding structures It is done for children with bilateral disease or with a solitary kidney. Preoperative chemotherapy can be used in these cases to induce tumor shrinkage.

question_text: A mother notices a swelling in the abdomen of her 3-year-old child while bathing him. He had a history of hematuria two weeks back which resolved spontaneously. On examination, a right-sided reniform ballotable mass was found. What all investigations will you do?
explanation: The clinical features of a ballotable renal mass with hematuria in a 3-year-old child are suggestive of Wilms tumor and FNAC is not done in this condition. Investigations in suspected cases of Wilms tumor: Laboratory study - shows hematuria, polycythemia, thrombocytosis, and elevated APTT USG with doppler study of renal veins - for evaluation of the collecting system and to look for tumor thrombi in renal veins and inferior vena cava CECT abdomen - to identify the extent of the disease, to access the contralateral kidney, and for metastasis MRI - not used routinely as it requires sedation Positron emission tomography(PET) scan - to identify regional spread and metastatic lesions Diagnosis should be made by imaging studies and it is confirmed after nephrectomy. A biopsy is discouraged in this condition as it results in disease upstaging. Only in cases with atypical presentation such as older age, signs of infection, etc, or with unusual imaging findings a core needle biopsy via the posterior approach can be performed. Note: Neuroblastoma also presents similar to Wilms tumor. It is commonly seen in children of preschool age. Affected children commonly present with a palpable abdominal mass and the most common site of the tumor is the retroperitoneum. Therefore, this disease becomes an important differential diagnosis. So we should also test for the presence of vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA) in this patient to exclude this tumor.

question_text: Which of the following is the most important factor in determining the prognosis of a child with Wilms tumor?
options: Age less than 1 year at presentation
explanation: The most important prognostic factor in Wilms tumor is the histology of the tumor. Wilms tumor (WT) is characterized by abnormal proliferation of the metanephric blastema, with no differentiation into tubules or glomeruli. It usually arises from three tissue elements (triphasic tumor): Blastema (poor prognosis if the blastemal component is more) Epithelium Stroma Wilms tumors lacking anaplasia (presence of atypical, polyploid mitotic figures, large nuclear size, and hyperchromasia) are designated as having “favorable histology".

question_text: Which of the following staging systems is used for staging of Wilms tumor in a child posted for partial nephrectomy post neoadjuvant chemotherapy?

It was previously known as national Wilms tumor staging (NWTSG). Option C: TNM staging (AJCC) is used for staging internal malignancies such as gastric, renal, breast, etc. Option D: Shimada staging is used for neuroblastoma.

question_text: A newborn child was noted to have a congenital anomaly as shown in the image below. All of the following statements are true about this condition except:
options: Closure of abdominal wall should be done within the first year
Bilateral inguinal hernia is seen in males
explanation: The congenital anomaly seen in the above image is exstrophy of the bladder (ectopia vesicae). It is associated with epispadias, not hypospadias. Bladder exstrophy refers to herniation of the urinary bladder through an anterior abdominal wall defect. The bladder is open and exposed on the outside of the abdomen. The male to female ratio is 4:1. Chronic exposure of the bladder to the external environment can lead to adenocarcinoma of the bladder. The clinical features of bladder exstrophy include: Separation of the pubic bones with non-united symphysis pubis Epispadias In males: Broad and short penis and bilateral inguinal herni In females: Bifid clitoris Management involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia. Closure of the abdominal and bladder wall is done in the first year of life. This often requires an iliac osteotomy to relax the tension on the bladder and repair the abdominal wall during wound-healing. Later, reconstruction of the bladder neck, sphincters, epispadias, and other genital defects is done.

question_text: A young girl presents with continuous dribbling of urine but she voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with continuous dribbling of urine, in spite of regular voiding, is suggestive of an ectopic ureter. Ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly that occurs as a result of abnormal caudal migration of the ureteral bud during its insertion into the urinary bladder. They are usually associated with duplex ureters and drain from the upper pole of the kidney. It is more common in females. The ectopic ureter usually opens into the urethra, vagina, and perineum. Hence, female patients present with constant urinary dripping all day, even though the child voids regularly (Paradoxical incontinence). It can cause hydroureteronephrosis and recurrent UTI. In males, the ectopic ureter opens always above the external urethral sphincter. Hence they are usually continent. However, it can cause other complications such as orchitis and epididymitis. Management involves re-implantation of the ureter into the bladder to treat incontinence and preserve renal functions. If the kidney is severely affected, partial nephrectomy is helpful.

question_text: During a cricket match, a batsman controls his urge to urinate as he is unable to take a break in-between. question_text: A patient was rushed to the casualty after sustaining a suprapubic injury. On examination, no blood is seen at the meatus. On inserting Foley’s catheter, gross hematuria is noted. question_text: An elderly man was rushed to the casualty at midnight with complaints of severe suprapubic pain and inability to pass urine for the past 24 hours. The abdominal examination finding of the patient is given below. A smooth and enlarged prostate was felt in the per-rectal examination. While attempting to insert a 16-F Foley catheter in this patient, you feel resistance and fail to catheterize. What will be the next step in the management?
options: Insert a smaller sized Foley catheter
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute retention of urine, possibly because of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). The next step would be to insert an 18-Fr Coudé catheter. In men, the BPH especially the middle lobe enlargement obstructs the insertion of Foley's catherter. Hence, a Coude catheter is advised over suprapubic catetherization as the immediate next step as larger Fr Coude catheter is helpful in negotiating past the angulation in the prostatic urethra. (Note: In acute urine retention, urethral strictures should be suspected when there is resistance at the urethral meatus as the strictures are more common in distal urethra than proximal urethra) Bladder outlet obstruction is usually the most common cause of acute retention of urine. Its clinical features include: Inability to pass urine Severe suprapubic pain A distended, palpable, and tender bladder Acute urinary retention is managed by placing a urethral catheter as early as possible. Usually in BPH, smaller catheters will not pass through the angulation of the prostatic urethra as they are flexible and kink. Hence in BPH, the Coudé-tip catheter, which has a rigid and angulated tip, can be used to overcome the urethral obstruction. If urethral catheter placement is not successful, suprapubic catheterization should be done. If there is a urethral stricture, a council tip catheter is used to dilate it using a cystoscope, guide wires, and urethral dilators.

question_text: You are asked to remove a Foley’s catheter after a procedure but you are unable to deflate the balloon. The surgeon himself tries to remove it after cutting the sidearm but is unsuccessful as well. What should be the next step of management?
options: CT-guided rupture of bulb of Foley's
Inject ether to dissolve the balloon and pull it out
Inject water to over distend the balloon until it bursts and remove the catheter
Inflate with 20ml of water and under USG guidance, locate and prick the balloon
explanation: USG-guided rupture of the balloon percutaneously after inflating it with 20ml water should be the next step of management. The failure of the balloon to deflate may be caused by: Faulty valve mechanism Blockage of the inflation channel by debris Crystallization of the fluid within the balloon (when saline is used) The next best step in the management of a retained Foley's catheter is to further inflate the balloon with 20mL of water, following which the inflated balloon is ruptured percutaneously with needle under USG guidance. A suprapubic approach is used in males, while in females, either a transurethral or transvaginal route can be used. A cystoscopy should be done to ensure that all fragments are removed. Other methods of approach include cutting the sidearm of the catheter, thereby disabling the valve mechanism, or advancing a ureteric stylet or fine-gauge wire through the inflation port to dislodge debris or puncture the balloon. But these are often unsuccessful. Option A: CT is not routinely used in most settings with retained Foley's. Option B: Injection of ether through the balloon port causes the rupture of the balloon within seconds. But this technique causes significant bladder irritation. Option C: Balloons should not be overinflated until they rupture. This may cause severe pain and could cause bladder rupture.

question_text: In the given picture of a Foley’s catheter, what is the function of the tube marked ‘A’?

question_text: What is the earliest sign seen on cystoscopy in a patient suspected to have bladder tuberculosis?
explanation: The earliest sign of tuberculosis of the bladder observed by cystoscopy is the pallor of the mucosa around the ureteric orifice due to submucous edema. Subsequently, tubercles may be seen. In long-standing cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced (thimble bladder). question_text: A 50-year-old man comes with complaints of hematuria and difficulty in urination for the past few weeks. Microscopic examination of urine samples shows parasitic eggs as shown in the image. Which type of bladder carcinoma is the patient most likely to develop?

Primary bladder tumors usually originate from the transitional epithelium of the bladder (90%). Sometimes, they arise from connective tissue. question_text: Which of the following drugs causes carcinoma bladder?
explanation: Cyclophosphamide (an alkylating agent) causes bladder cancer The risk of bladder cancer with cyclophosphamide is directly proportional to the duration and intensity of cyclophosphamide treatment. Phosphoramide mustard is the primary mutagenic metabolite that causes bladder cancer in patients exposed to cyclophosphamide. Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom that is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise. Depending upon the depth of invasion, bladder carcinoma can be divided into Flat, non-invasive carcinoma in situ (CIS) Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (70% of cases) - does not invade detrusor muscle but can invade lamina propria. Muscle-invasive bladder cancer - invades the detrusor muscle. Diagnosis is by cystourethroscopy (directly visualizing the growth) and biopsy. Management is as follows: Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer: Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) followed by intravesical chemotherapy with mitomycin C or epirubicin Immunotherapy with regular intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette Guerin (BCG) in high-risk tumors. Muscle invasive bladder cancer: Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy Other options: Option B: Cisplatin is an anticancer drug used to treat testicular cancer. It is associated with an increased risk for acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Option C: Taxane is an anticancer drug and is the main component in the treatment regimens of metastatic cancers. Taxane's adverse effects are neutropenia and fluid retention (pulmonary edema). Option D: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) and is used in the treatment of estrogen-dependent breast cancer. Due to its partial agonistic activity, it is known to increase endometrial cancer in post-menopausal women.

Inactivation of the Rb gene is implicated in the cancer formation

Activation of oncogenes such as ras, c-erbB, E2F3, and inactivation of tumor-suppressor genes such as p53, p21, p16, and Rb gene is implicated in the cancer formation of the bladder. question_text: Urinary diversion is indicated in all the following clinical conditions, except:
explanation: Urinary diversion is not done in cases of bladder hematoma. Urinary diversion procedures are performed to divert urine from the bladder to a new exit site. Cutaneous ureterostomy - ureters are directed through the abdominal wall and attached to an opening in the skin. Continent urinary diversion (Internal urinary diversion): A portion of the intestine is used to create a new reservoir for urine. The internal pouch is placed inside the abdomen. The ureters are attached to the internal pouch, and the internal pouch is attached to the urethra or to a stoma in the abdomen with a valve. question_text: A 35-year-old lady experiences increased frequency of urination and lower abdominal pain which is relieved by micturition. Urinalysis is normal. Cystoscopy reveals fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with normal urinalysis and cystoscopy findings are suggestive of interstitial cystitis. Interstitial cystitis is a persistent, painful form of chronic cystitis, occurring most frequently in women. It is also known as chronic pelvic pain syndrome or bladder pain syndrome. Its clinical features include: Severe suprapubic pain Urinary frequency Urgency Hematuri Dysuria without evidence of bacterial infection Cystoscopic findings seen in bladder mucosa are: Fissures Punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations) Ulcerations in the fundus of the bladder (Hunner's ulcer) The image shows Hunner's ulcer seen in interstitial cystitis: Treatment options include : Conservative - Patient education about the chronicity of the condition, behavioral modification (timed voiding, bladder training), stress reduction, dietary alteration (avoidance of caffeine and spicy and acidic foods) and physical therapy should be the initial management for all patients. Pharmacological - Neuropathic analgesics (e.g. amitriptyline, pregabalin) are used for those with significant pain component, whereas antimuscarinics and 3-agonists are used for frequency, nocturia and urgency symptoms. Surgical - For those with Hunner lesions, fulguration or laser to these lesions can be beneficial. Cystodistension as a treatment has variable evidence for success. If these options fail to improve symptoms major surgical reconstruction can be considered in selected cases. Option b: Malakoplakia is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It appears as soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques. Option d: Cystitis cystica occurs due to chronic irritation of the bladder mucosa. Cystoscopy reveals cystic lesions in the bladder.

question_text: Which of the following will be seen in a patient with Marion’s disease?

Congenital obstruction of the prostatic urethr
explanation: Hypertrophy of the internal sphincter of the bladder is seen in Marion’s disease. This leads to bladder outlet obstruction. Therefore it is also called prostatism sans prostate: Increased urinary frequency Urgency Dribbling of urine Hesitancy Intermittent stream Nocturi It is commonly seen in young patients. question_text: Which of the following is true regarding the condition shown below?

explanation: The given intravenous urography (IVU) image depicts cobra head/adder head deformity which is classic sign of ureterocele. It is associated with dysplastic renal tissue. Ureterocele: A ureterocele is the cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter. It is thought to be caused due to ureteric orifice atresia. It is observed more in females than males in a 4:1 preponderance and is bilateral in about 10% of the cases. They are similar to ectopic ureters wherein the upper pole of the kidney is drained. This condition is typically associated with dysplastic and non-functional renal tissue. Clinical presentation: Children with ureterocele usually present with infection. Adults present with renal stones. Diagnosis: IVU shows a classical cobra head sign but is relatively infrequently performed these days. question_text: A 60-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and dysuria. On per-rectal examination, his prostate was tender and boggy. His PSA level was 7.4 ng/dl. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bacterial prostatitis and should be managed by antibiotics. A rigorous and prolonged treatment for 2-6 weeks with an antibiotic that penetrates the prostate wall is indicated (trimethoprim, ciprofloxacin or aminoglycoside). Incomplete infection eradication lead to recurrent attacks and chronic prostatitis. Acute bacterial prostatitis is usually caused by an ascending urinary tract infection (UTI) or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts. The most common organism is Escherichia coli. An associated increase in levels of PSA(>4ng/ml) may be present due to prostate inflammation. Catheterization and prostatic massage are contraindicated in patients with suspected acute prostatitis, as they increase the chance for bacteremia and sepsis. Instead, suprapubic tap should be performed to alleviate retention. Chronic bacterial prostatitis is the sequela of inadequately treated acute prostatitis. Diagnosis includes: Three-glass urine test - If the first glass with the initial urine sample is clear, but the second and third samples contain prostatic threads and leukocytes, it indicates the presence of prostatitis. Digital rectal examination - Prostate may be normal, boggy, or tender. Prostatic fluid examination - post-prostatic massage fluid shows pus cells and bacteria.

question_text: Which is the most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis?
explanation: The most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP) is Escherichia coli. It is commonly caused by an ascending urethral infection or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts. Sexually transmissible infections and other urinary pathogens, such as Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus faecalis may also be responsible. The patient presents with fever, perineal pain, chills and rigor, and dysuria. Per rectal examination will reveal a tender, boggy prostate. Care should be taken to avoid aggressive palpation or prostatic massage as it can lead to bacterial dissemination and sepsis. Urine examination and culture should be done. Urine examination reveals threads in urine. Management: Patients with systemic signs of infection should be admitted for IV antibiotics, hydration, and monitoring of laboratory parameters. Patients who have no signs of systemic infection, who can tolerate oral intake, and who have no urinary retention can be treated with oral antibiotics. A 6–- year-old patient presents with difficulty in initiating micturition. A DRE reveals an enlarged nodular prostate with adherent rectal mucosa. PSA was found to be 25 ng/ml and a biopsy result was suggestive of adenocarcinoma. Which of the following statements is false
regarding his condition ?

Gleason score correlates with the pathological stage
It is associated with decreased % free PSA
It arises from the transitional zone of the gland.
explanation: Prostatic carcinoma, as indicated in the clinical scenario, arises from the peripheral zone of the gland. Anatomically, the prostate is divided into three zones. The peripheral zone lies posteriorly and has an abundance of prostatic glands. The central zone lies posterior to the urethral lumen and above the seminal vesicles as they course through the prostate. The transitional zone is periurethral. Benign prostatic hyperplasia arises from the transitional zone. Gleason grading may be used after biopsy to evaluate the stage of histopathological specimen. Gleason scores range from 6 to 10 where 6 is low risk for prostate cancer while 10 is high risk. PSA (prostatic specific antigen) is a glycoprotein peptidase that facilitates the liquefaction of semen. It is useful for screening and for monitoring response to therapy but is neither specific nor sensitive to the condition as it can be elevated due to old age and benign conditions such as prostatitis and BPH. Slightly elevated total PSA (between 4.0 and 10.0 ng/m˜) and low free PSA (<25%) is suspicious for prostate cancer.

How many biopsy cores should be obtained?
explanation: Ideally, 12 systematic biopsy cores are obtained in patients with suspected prostatic cancer. question_text: Where does urethral stricture most commonly occur?
explanation: The most common site of urethral stricture is the bulbar urethra. A urethral stricture is a narrowing of the urethra caused by scarring, which functionally causes obstructive voiding dysfunction of the lower urinary tract. The most common cause of urethral stricture is trauma. It can also be iatrogenic due urethral catheterization and infections. These patients present with features of the hesitancy of micturition, straining to void, and poor urinary stream. The most common complication of urethral stricture is urinary tract infection.

question_text: A 40-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of difficulty to start urination and that he has to strain to maintain a proper flow. He gives a history of pelvic injury one year back. Investigations reveal a stricture of length 1.5 cm at the bulbar urethra. What will be the best management for this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with a short bulbar urethral stricture (<2cm) due to trauma, will be best managed by excision with end-to-end urethroplasty. It is the gold standard for the repair of anterior urethral stricture. The management of a urethral stricture depends on the site, the length, and the cause of the stricture. They include: Endoscopic urethrotomy - The stricture is released using a knife passed through a rigid urethroscope. Urethroplasty - Excision of the stenosed length of the urethra and re-anastomosis is done. A buccal mucosa graft can be used to bridge the gap. It is considered when a stricture is due to rauma or recurred following endoscopic treatment. Urethral dilation - The urethra is stretched using urethral dilators. This is a blind procedure and it can cause injury. Hence, it is not done frequently. Intermittent self-dilatation - In patients with recurrent strictures who are unable to undergo urethroplasty, then intermittent self-dilatation with soft hydrophilic catheters is done on a daily basis.
