question_text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Buerger's disease?
explanation: Statements 1 and 3 are false. In thromboangitis obliterans, there is normal brachial and popliteal pulses but reduced or absent radial, ulnar, and/or tibial pulses. Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger’s disease) is an inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving small and medium-sized arteries and veins in the distal upper and lower extremities. question_text: A 34-year-old male construction worker presents with exertional pain and darkening of the skin in both forearms and hands as shown in the image. Angiography of his upper extremity shows smooth tapering segmental lesions in the distal arterial vessels. Which of the following treatments has the greatest chance of success?
explanation: The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of thromboangiitis obliterans. There is no specific treatment except abstinence from tobacco. Key findings in this patient is age < 40 years, smoker, and involvement of upper extremity. Although the cause of thromboangiitis obliterans is not known, there is a definite relationship to cigarette smoking in patients with this disorder. There is no specific treatment except abstention from tobacco. MRA, CTA, and conventional arteriography show smooth, tapering segmental lesions in the distal vessels with collateral vessels at sites of vascular occlusion. The prognosis is poor in individuals who continue to smoke. Surgical revascularization is not possible due to extensive vascular inflammation and damage. Anticoagulants and glucocorticoids are not helpful. If the condition worsens, amputation may be required.

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding abdominal aortic aneurysm is false?

question_text: A 41-year-old female patient presented with a tortuous swelling over the left side of the scalp and face as shown in the image given below. On local examination, the swelling was pulsatile. On auscultation, a bruit was heard. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The presence of a tortuous, pulsatile swelling over the scalp and face is suggestive of a cirsoid aneurysm. Cirsoid aneurysm is a slow-growing, tortuous swelling that develops due to abnormal arteriovenous connections among the subcutaneous blood vessels. They are usually congenital. However, in some cases, they may be traumatic. The superficial temporal artery is most commonly involved. Patients present with a tortuous, pulsatile swelling over the scalp or face. They are usually asymptomatic and present to the clinic due to cosmetic deformity. However, some patients may have headache, tinnitus, and/or bleeding. A loud bruit is heard on auscultation. Angiography is the investigation of choice. Treatment includes surgical resection, endovascular occlusion or injection of percutaneous sclerosing agents.

question_text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient?
options: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >77mm
explanation: Surgery is indicated in an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) only if its diameter is more than 55 mm in a male patient. If the diameter is less than 55 mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size < 55 mm. Indications for surgery in abdominal aortic aneurysm: Size >5.5 cm in males Size >5 cm in females Expansion of >1 cm in one year Painful tender aneurysm Thrombosed aneurysm; aneurysm with distal emboli Management of aortic aneurysm: AAA is surgically managed by dacron graft repair. It can be either open or EVAR (endovascular aneurysm repair) Open surgical repair is done by exposing the aorta through a mid-sternal incision and graft replacement. To expose the aorta the descending colon should be mobilized medially and this is known as left visceral rotation or Mattox procedure. EVAR is a minimally invasive procedure in which an aortic stent graft is placed on the nonaneurysmal aortoiliac segment. Complications following an AAA repair are: Cardiovascular (ischemia and infarction) Respiratory (atelectasis or consolidation). Colonic ischemia. Renal failure. question_text: Which is the most common site for peripheral aneurysms?

question_text: A 30-year-old man presented to the emergency department with complaints of fever and severe back pain. He is an IV drug abuser. CT scan of the abdomen revealed a saccular, lobulated dilatation of the aorta as shown in the image. What organism is his blood culture most likely to grow?
explanation: The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of mycotic aneurysm and it is secondary to microbial aortitis. The most common organism causing mycotic aneurysm is staphylococcus and is mostly due to IV drug abuse. Symptoms may include hypotension, abdominal pain, pulsatile abdominal mass with concomitant fever. Laboratory findings reveal elevated inflammatory parameters such as CRP, ESR, and increased white cell count. A contrast-enhanced CT scan is the initial imaging modality of choice. Patients require prolonged antibiotic therapy tailored to the culture and sensitivity findings. Surgical management includes debridement, revascularization, or bypass techniques. The term 'mycotic aneurysm' is a misnomer as the aneurysm commonly occurs secondary to bacterial infection, and is rarely caused by a fungal infection. Any major artery may be infected, however, the aorta is most commonly affected. The organisms infect the aorta and destroy the wall of the aorta, which may lead to an aneurysm.

question_text: An elderly man presented with a new-onset pulsatile swelling over his wrist as shown in the image. He was recently discharged after a one-month-long ICU admission for urosepsis. On examination, systolic bruit was audible and a doppler revealed bidirectional flow of blood. Which of the following is false regarding the given condition?
options: Due to focal dilation in a vessel in which only the intimal layer is disrupted
Treatment includes endovascular stent insertion and thrombin therapy
Yin-yang sign is seen on doppler ultrasound of the swelling
explanation: The patient most likely has a pseudoaneurysm of the radial artery due to repeated arterial blood gas sampling done in the ICU. Dilatation of vessel due to tear involving only the intima is a dissection, not a pseudoaneurysm. In pseudoaneurysm, the intimal and medial layers are disrupted and the dilated segment of the aorta is lined by adventitia only and at times by perivascular clot. Pseudoaneurysm is most commonly seen due to repeated arterial puncture for blood sampling or catheterization procedures where there is an increased chance of arterial wall injury. It is usually pulsatile and systolic bruit can be heard on auscultation. Doppler ultrasound reveals bidirectional, 'to-and-fro' flow of blood which is known as the yin-yang sign. Treatment options include endovascular stent insertion, ultrasound-guided thrombin injection, and surgical repair. Note: A true aneurysm involves all three layers of the vessel wall.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 70-year-old man presents with acute pain in the chest which radiates to the interscapular region of the back. He is a known hypertensive for the past 7 years. His CT is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the condition is false?
options: Men are affected more than women
In Stanford type B ascending aorta is affected
Pleural effusion associated with aortic dissection is usually left sided
Sensitivity of transthoracic echocardiography in diagnosing proximal ascending aortic dissections is higher
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the CT image showing the double-lumen of the aorta are suggestive of aortic dissection. Stanford type A is when ascending aorta and arch are affected while Stanford Type B involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery. Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta. Predisposing factors include increasing age, hypertension, Marfan syndrome. The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain. Aortic dissection affects men more than women by a ratio of 2:1. Pleural effusion associated with aortic dissection is usually left-sided. Transthoracic echocardiography has an overall sensitivity of 60–85% for aortic dissection. For diagnosing proximal ascending aortic dissections, its sensitivity exceeds 80%. It is less useful for detecting dissection of the arch and descending thoracic aorta.

question_text: A 57-year-old male patient presented with a sudden tearing type of chest pain. He has had hypertension for the past 15 years and has not been on regular treatment. The patient was hemodynamically stable. A CECT chest was done and is given below. What is the preferred treatment option for this patient?
options: Medical management with blood pressure control
Further diagnostic workup with transesophageal echocardiography
explanation: The patient seems to be having an aortic dissection and CT chest indicates a Stanford Type A aortic dissection from the aortic root. He requires urgent surgical management. The Stanford classification is used to separate aortic dissections into those that need surgical repair, and those that usually require only medical management. The Stanford classification divides dissections by the most proximal involvement. Type A is when ascending aorta and arch are affected. It requires urgent surgical management and may result in: Coronary artery occlusion Aortic incompetence Rupture into the pericardial sac with resulting cardiac tamponade Type B begins beyond brachiocephalic vessels and dissection commences distal to the left subclavian artery affecting only the descending aorta. Medical management with blood pressure control is the preferred choice of treatment. The DeBakey classification divides dissections into: Type I: involves ascending and descending aorta (= Stanford A) Type II: involves ascending aorta only (= Stanford A) Type III: involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery (= Stanford B) Further diagnostic workup with TEE(transesophageal echocardiography) or MRA (magnetic resonance angiography) is not required as CT is showing ascending aorta dissection clearly.

question_text: In which of the following conditions is a double-barrelled aorta seen?
explanation: A double-barrelled aorta is seen in an aortic dissection. An aortic dissection usually initiates with an intimal tear. In some instances, the dissecting hematoma reenters the lumen of the aorta through a second distal intimal tear, creating a new vascular channel and forming a double-barreled aorta with a false channel. Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on location of proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system that uses location of proximal tear alone. DeBakey system: Type I: involves the ascending aorta and extends through the aortic arch and into the descending aorta/abdominal aorta Type II: confined to the ascending aorta Type IIIa: limited to the descending aorta Type IIIb: descending aorta and abdominal aorta

question_text: An AV fistula in the forearm is created in a patient with end-stage renal disease so that he can undergo dialysis. Which of the following responses will you not see when you apply pressure proximal to the AV fistula?
explanation: Pulse pressure returns to normal when pressure is applied to an artery proximal to an AV fistula. In an AV fistula, peripheral resistance is decreased because of which diastolic pressure is less leading to higher pulse pressure. Compression of the artery proximal to the AV fistula increases peripheral resistance leading to increased diastolic pressure and the pulse pressure returns to normal. Compression of the artery proximal to an arteriovenous fistula results in: Reflex bradycardia Pulse pressure returns to normal Decrease in size of swelling Bruit will decrease or disappear The reflex bradycardia and increase in blood pressure that immediately follows the sudden occlusion of an arteriovenous (A-V) fistula is known as the Nicoladoni-Branham sign.

question_text: What is the investigation of choice for evaluation of peripheral AV malformation?
explanation: MRI has become the imaging study of choice for the evaluation and follow-up of peripheral arteriovenous malformations. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) offers numerous advantages over both CT and radiographs and has become the most important modality to diagnose AVM's. MRI techniques including time-of-flight and phase contrast can be used to isolate inflow blood supply to better predict the risk of ischemia following embolization. MRI also provides well-defined images defining boundaries between the AVM, surrounding fat, and neurovascular bundles, which is necessary for the planning of surgical or embolic interventions.

question_text: A 50-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) presents with complaints of recurrent postprandial abdominal pain associated with vomiting and diarrhea. Abdominal examination shows no tenderness or rigidity. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: Postprandial abdominal pain in the background of CAD is suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia(CMI). The most common cause of chronic mesenteric ischemia is atherosclerotic disease. The three classic symptoms pathognomonic of CMI are: Postprandial pain (crampy periumbilical abdominal pain within 30 minutes of meals) Food fear (foods that precipitate symptoms are avoided by the patient and unintentional weight loss can result) Significant weight loss CT angiogram demonstrates both the arterial lesion and the patterns of collateral blood flow. Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) and stenting have gained acceptance as the first line of therapy for mesenteric ischemia. Nutcracker syndrome refers to compression of the left renal vein, most commonly between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, with impaired blood outflow often accompanied by distention of the distal portion of the vein. explanation: Option B is the false statement. In superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome, the aortomesenteric angle is reduced to less than 25°. question_text: Which of the following patients are not at an increased risk for developing deep vein thrombosis?
options: Woman on high dose oestrogen therapy for menopausal symptoms
Middle aged man with polycythemia vera
Teenager who has sustained major trauma in an accident
explanation: Nephritic syndrome is not associated with an increased risk of DVT. Nephrotic syndrome is associated with an increased risk of developing deep vein thrombosis. question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
options: Most common clinical presentation is pain and tenderness in calf
Some cases may directly present as pulmonary thromboembolism
explanation: Most cases of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) are unilateral. It is bilateral in only 30% of the individuals. DVT refers to thrombosis of the deep venous system. Caused by: Postoperative thrombosis (most common cause) Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) After childbirth Immobility Sites: Pelvic veins—common Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (common on the left side). Fever is the earliest symptom, which is also most commonly accompanied by pain and tenderness in the calf and thigh (option C). The following signs could be elicited: Positive Homan's sign: Resistance of calf muscles on passive foreceful dorsiflexion of the foot. Mose's sign: Gentle squeezing of the lower part of the calf from side to side is painful. Neuhof's sign: Thickening and deep tenderness seen on deep palpation of the calf muscles. Sometimes, the thrombus may get dislodged and present as pulmonary thromboembolism (option D) with features of dyspnoea, tachypnoea, and chest pain. Clinical features are unreliable for making a definitive diagnosis (option A), and a venous Doppler is the best modality for confirming DVT. It reveals a non-compressible dilated vein. The likelihood of pulmonary embolism can be predicted using modified Wells criteria. Patients with DVT should be immediately started with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). If contraindicated due to renal insufficiency or thrombocytopenia-related conditions, they should be started on fondaparinux (indirect factor Xa inhibitor) or bivalirudin (direct thrombin inhibitor). Anticoagulants should be administered for a minimum period of 3 months. Vena cava filters are used in patients with bleeding risks (like hemophilia).

question_text: When performing the test on a patient as shown in the image, you noticed that there was tenderness and resistance on flexion. What is this finding known as?

question_text: A 30-year-old woman who is in the third trimester of pregnancy started to experience pain in her left leg. She also noticed that her left leg was turning pale and edematous as given in the image below. What is the cause of this condition?
options: Femoral vein thrombosis and lymphatic obstruction
Due to pressure exerted by uterus on the iliac veins
explanation: The patient is having phlegmasia alba dolens also known milk leg or white leg. It is due to ileofemoral deep vein thrombosis. It is usually seen in pregnant women and in individuals at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis. They typically present with painful, oedematous, and pale lower limb that blanches to touch. The lack of cyanosis differentiates this entity from phlegmasia cerulea dolens. In phlegmasia alba dolens, the thrombosis involves only major deep venous channels of the extremity, thus sparing collateral veins. The venous drainage is decreased but still present. In phlegmasia cerulea dolens, the thrombosis extends to collateral veins, resulting in severe venous congestion with massive fluid sequestration and more significant edema. Both phlegmasia cerulea dolens and phlegmasia alba dolens results from acute massive deep vein thrombosis and can be complicated by venous gangrene. Edema of pregnancy does not present with pain in the lower limbs but edema due to pressure exerted by the gravid uterus on the iliac veins.

question_text: You are tasked with giving post-operative care to a patient who just underwent open abdominal surgery. Which of the following is the most effective treatment to prevent the patient from developing deep vein thrombosis?
explanation: Heparin, especially low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is more effective for prophylaxis of DVT in patients who have undergone major surgeries where early ambulation is not possible. The choice of prophylaxis depends on the type of surgery, trauma, and duration of postoperative immobilisation. Major trauma, abdominal and orthopaedic surgeries warrant a longer duration of postoperative immobilisation. So, the pharmacological method is preferred in these situations. Mechanical methods are advised in patients who are expected to be up and walking within 24 to 48 hours such as after minor trauma. The simplest method is for the patient to ambulate. The activation of the calf pump mechanism is an effective means of prophylaxis. Additionally, compression stockings are advised. It can reduce the risk of DVT by exerting graduated pressure on the leg, with the pressure being greatest at the ankle. Advantages of LMWH over unfractionated heparin: LMWH has a longer plasma half-life and significantly higher bioavailability. The consistent bioavailability and clearance of LMWH do not require monitoring of aPTT or anti-factor Xa activity. Dosing is merely based on the patient’s weight. There is a more predictable anticoagulant response than with unfractionated heparin. LMWH inhibits factor Xa and not IIa activity, with the ratio of anti-factor Xa to anti-factor IIa activity ranging from 1:1 to 4:1.
subject: Surgery

question_text: All of the following are risk factors for developing varicose veins, except?
explanation: Superficial venous thrombosis is not a risk factor for developing varicose veins because the deep venous system is not affected and there is no increased stasis of blood. Varicose veins are defined as dilated, usually tortuous, subcutaneous veins >3 mm in diameter measured in the upright position with demonstrable reflux. Important risk factors for varicose veins are: Sex – Females > Males Age – increases with age Pregnancy (especially multiparity) Family history Body mass and height: Increasing BMI (obesity) and height are associated with a high prevalence of varicose veins. There is inconclusive evidence regarding the increased prevalence of varicose veins in smokers, patients who suffer constipation, and occupations that involve prolonged standing. Primary varicose veins are due to genetic or developmental defects in the vein wall that causes diminished elasticity and valvular incompetence. Secondary varicose veins arise from destruction or dysfunction of valves caused by trauma, DVT, AV fistula, non-traumatic proximal venous obstruction (pregnancy, pelvic tumor).
subject: Surgery

question_text: A truck driver presents with dilated, tortuous veins of 4 mm in the foot. What is the stage of clinical classification according to CEAP(Clinical-etiology-anatomy-pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders)?
explanation: Dilated tortuous veins of 4 mm indicate varicose veins, so the stage is C2.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 42-year-old daily wage laborer comes to you with discoloration of her legs. She was diagnosed with varicose veins 5 years ago which was left untreated. Identify the feature given in the picture.
explanation: Atrophia blanche is localised white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankles. This is a sign of chronic venous disease. Lipodermatosclerosis is changes in the skin of the lower legs due to chronic venous insufficiency. It is a form of panniculitis (inflammation of the layer of fat under the skin). There is swelling and a tapering of the legs above the ankles, leading to 'inverted champagne bottle' appearance. Corona phlebectatica are fan-shaped patterns of small intradermal veins on the medial or lateral aspects of the ankle or foot. It is also called ankle flare or malleolar flare. It is an early sign of advanced venous disease.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A bus conductor was diagnosed with varicose veins. On examination, skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis were noted. According to the CEAP classification system, He would be classified as
explanation: According to CEAP classification, varicose veins with skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis come under the clinical class of C4. The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as, C4a- pigmentation or eczema C4b- lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche C4c- corona phlebectatica Recent 2020 update on the CEAP system: C2r for recurrent varicose veins C4c for Corona phlebectatica C6r for recurrent active venous ulcer.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome?
options: Surgery is indicated in all cases
Increased risk of deep vein thrombosis
explanation: All patients with Klippel–Trenaunay syndrome should be treated conservatively with elastic compression. A surgical intervention is only indicated for affected large superficial veins provided the underlying deep system is normal and demonstrates only mild-to-moderate reflux. Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome is a sporadic nonhereditary mesodermal abnormality that usually affects a single lower limb with deep veins which have hypoplastic or aplastic segments. It is characterized by a triad of: Haemangioma presenting as nevus flammeus (port-wine stain) Varicose veins Soft tissue and bone hypertrophy Venous stripping, ligation, excision, or sclerotherapy are done in suitable cases. Low molecular weight heparin should be given to all patients undergoing surgical procedures as this syndrome is associated with an increased risk of venous thromboembolism.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient presents to you with dilated, tortuous veins of the legs. Which is the best investigation to perform that will confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: Duplex ultrasound is the best investigation to confirm varicose veins. Duplex ultrasound gives information about the presence of blood flow in the studied vessels such as its speed, direction and turbulence alongwith image of surrounding tissues. The aim of the duplex scan in patients with varicose veins is to establish: If saphenous junctions are incompetent and the extent of reflux in the saphenous veins and their diameters. Number, location, and diameter of incompetent perforating veins Source of all superficial varices Competence and evidence of previous venous thrombosis in the deep venous system. Doppler study only gives information about the presence of blood flow in the studied vessels such as its speed, direction, and turbulence, not the surrounding tissue. Very rarely if pelvic and iliac veins are involved then CT or MR venography might be opted for, when duplex ultrasound fails to visualise properly.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which vessel is not involved in the formation of mickey mouse sign that is seen while performing a duplex ultrasound?
explanation: Mickey mouse sign is seen in transverse B mode image of duplex ultrasound formed by: Common Femoral Vein (CFV) Common Femoral Artery (CFA) Greater Saphenous Vein (GSV) at the Saphenofemoral junction (SFJ). It represents the normal anatomy of the femoral vessels as seen in a duplex ultrasound.

question_text: A duplex ultrasound was done on a patient with varicose veins. It revealed incompetence of the perforator connecting the great saphenous vein to the superficial femoral vein. What is this perforator known as?
explanation: Dodd’s perforator connects the great saphenous vein to the superficial femoral veins. It is also known as ‘above knee’ perforator and is seen at the inferior ■ of the thigh. Perforating veins connect the superficial venous system to the deep venous system by penetrating the fascial layers of the lower extremity. Although the total number of perforator veins is variable, up to 100 have been documented. Named perforators: Adductor Canal (thigh) – Hunter's perforator Above Knee – Dodd's perforator Below Knee – Boyd's perforator Medial Calf – Cockett I, II, and III perforator Ankle - May or Kustner perforator

question_text: Presence of which of the following would make a patient with varicose veins unsuitable for sclerotherapy?
options: Recurrence of varicose veins after ligation and stripping surgery
explanation: Deep vein thrombosis is a contraindication for sclerotherapy in varicose veins. This is because, in patients with DVT, the superficial veins are the only valved venous pathway carrying blood back to the heart, and excising them in the presence of deep venous thrombosis will only aggravate the condition.

question_text: Which sclerosant is most commonly used when performing sclerotherapy for varicose veins?
explanation: The most commonly used sclerosant is sodium tetradecyl sulfate. In injection sclerotherapy a detergent is injected directly into the superficial veins. The detergent destroys the lipid membranes of endothelial cells causing them to shed, leading to thrombosis, fibrosis and obliteration (sclerosis). Injection sclerotherapy alone can be successful in varicose veins <3 mm in diameter and in telangiectatic vessels. Complications of sclerotherapy: Allergic reaction, Local hyperpigmentation Thrombophlebitis DVT Skin necrosis Patients with symptomatic GSV or SSV reflux may be treated with endovenous ablation techniques or surgical removal of the affected vein. Saphenous vein ligation and stripping is preferred therapy for patients with GSVs of very large diameter (>2 cm). Types of sclerosants: Detergents Sodium tetradecyl sulfate Polidocano Sodium morrhuate Ethanolamine oleate Osmotic agents Hypertonic saline Chemical irritants Chromated glycerin Polyiodinated iodine Alcoholic solution of zein Bleomycin Tessari method Widely used method to prepare foam for sclerotherapy Sclerosant : Air ratio taken is 1:3 or 1:4.

question_text: Which of the following is done in Trendelenburg operation?
options: Stripping of the superficial varicose vein
Ligation of small tributaries at the distal end of superficial varicose vein
explanation: Saphenofemoral flush ligation is done in Trendelenburg’s procedure. The great saphenous vein is stripped and tied close to the common femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction so that there aren’t any branches left that lead to recurrences. Procedure: An oblique groin incision is made at the level of and lateral to the pubic tubercle. The great saphenous vein is identified and dissected to the saphenofemoral junction. Six great saphenous vein tributaries are normally encountered close to the saphenofemoral junction: The superficial inferior epigastric vein and superficial circumflex iliac vein laterally The deep and superficial external pudendal veins medially More distally the anterolateral and posteromedial thigh veins A flush saphenofemoral junction ligation is then performed and the great saphenous vein retrogradely stripped to the knee. Flush ligation is when the great saphenous vein is stripped and tied close to the common femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction so that there aren’t any tributaries that lead to recurrences.

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding complications of varicose vein surgery is false?
options: Injury to the lymphatic system can cause secondary lymphoedema
Saphenous nerve injury causes loss of sensation in the medial aspect of the leg
The sural nerve is in danger during stripping of the great saphenous vein
explanation: The sural nerve accompanies the short saphenous vein laterally along its course and supplies cutaneous sensation to the lateral malleolar region. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of the short saphenous vein, not the great saphenous vein. The saphenous nerve accompanies the great saphenous vein medially from the ankle to the level of the knee and supplies cutaneous sensation to the medial leg and ankle. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of the great saphenous vein. Surgery for the varicose veins extraction may trigger injury of the lymph vessels and may lead to secondary lymphedema. Injury and inflammation to the venous system during varicose vein surgery can cause slowing and stasis of blood flow in the lower limb, making them prone to develop deep vein thrombosis postoperatively.

question_text: In patients with chronic venous insufficiency, where are venous ulcers most likely to develop?
explanation: Venous ulcers due to chronic venous insufficiency are most commonly seen in the lower ■ of the leg and foot. They usually lie just proximal to the medial or lateral malleolus. Venous ulcers are accompanied by lipodermatosclerosis and hemosiderosis. question_text: A 61-year-old man presented with a recurrent, tender, erythematous rash on the medial aspect of the right forearm and lower limb as shown in the image. He was diagnosed with pancreatic adenocarcinoma 1 year ago. Blood investigations showed normal eosinophil counts and no signs of infections. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: Secondary to repeated cannulation of vein
explanation: The most likely diagnosis is migratory thrombophlebitis. It is a paraneoplastic syndrome that is also known as Trousseau’s syndrome or Trousseau's sign of malignancy. It is characterised by recurrent episodes of localised thrombosis of the superficial veins of limbs. It can lead to tender and erythematous rashes. Migratory thrombophlebitis is seen in: Pancreatic cancer (most common) Lung cancer Gastrointestinal cancer Ovarian cancer Prostate cancer Lymphoma Note: Trousseau’s sign is seen in hypocalcemia where there is an involuntary contraction of the muscles of the hand and wrist when a blood pressure cuff is placed on the arm and inflated to 20mm of Hg above systolic blood pressure.

question_text: A 60-year-old male patient with sudden onset pain, cyanosis, and edema of the left upper limb. Doppler ultrasound revealed thrombosis of the left subclavian vein. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Can be caused by indwelling venous catheters
Primary axillary vein thrombosis is seen in hypercoagulable states
May occur following excessive arm exercise
explanation: The patient has axillary-subclavian vein thrombosis. Hypercoagulable states lead to secondary axillary vein thrombosis. Axillary-subclavian vein thrombosis (ASVT) is of 2 types. Primary ASVT occurs as a result of compression of the subclavian vein in the costoclavicular space by repeated contraction of muscles that surround the thoracic outlet. There is repeated compression and traumatization to the vein. This leads to the formation of clots. It is also known as: Paget-Schrotter Syndrome Venous thoracic outlet syndrome Effort thrombosis Secondary ASVT occurs due to venous injury by indwelling central venous catheters, external trauma or pacemaker wires. It is also seen in hypercoagulable states. Symptoms and signs include pain, edema, and cyanosis of the upper extremity. Significant superficial venous distension can be seen in arm, forearm, shoulder and anterior chest wall. Doppler study is the investigation of choice. Anticoagulation is initiated once ASVT is diagnosed to prevent pulmonary embolism.In severe cases, thrombolytic therapy is done using tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) or streptokinase. Adjuvant procedures following thrombolytic therapy may include balloon angioplasty for residual venous narrowing and cervical or first rib resection for thoracic outlet abnormalities.

question_text: Identify the device given below.
explanation: The given image shows a chemoport. Chemoports are implantable venous access devices used to facilitate chemotherapy administration. Internal jugular veins and subclavian veins are the commonly used access veins for port placement. These devices are usually retained for a period of 1 to 2 years or more after which the device is explanted.

question_text: Which of the following vessel is affected in May-Thurner syndrome?
explanation: May-Thurner syndrome refers to iliofemoral venous thrombosis. At the site where the right iliac artery crosses over the left iliac vein, the left iliac vein may become chronically narrowed predisposing to iliofemoral venous thrombosis.

question_text:
A 65-year-old woman with a history of varicose vein, presented with a painless lesion on her left leg for the past 1 month. On examination, an ulcer of size 5 ¥ 5 cm with an irregular margin and sloping edge was found on the medial malleolus of the left leg. All the following can be used to manage this patient except?
[Image unavailable]
options: Surgical excision and pinch mesh grafting
explanation: The likely diagnosis, in this case, is a venous ulcer secondary to the varicose vein. Revascularization is not a part of the management of venous ulcers. Venous ulcers are due to chronic venous insufficiency and are particularly seen in the area between the muscles of the calf and ankle. It has a sloping edge and the floor contains granulation tissue covered by slough and exudate. Marjolin’s ulcer is a type of squamous cell carcinoma seen in chronic long-standing venous ulcers. Regular dressing. Medical management by oral pentoxifylline is considered which helps in reducing the viscosity and improving circulation. Surgery - Ulcer excision with pinch mesh grafting has a good outcome and helps in preventing recurrence.

question_text: A 40-year-old hairdresser presented with complaints of swelling, throbbing pain, and heaviness in her left leg for the past 1 year. A duplex scan done showed great saphenous vein incompetence. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of varicose veins and the treatment of choice in this patient is endothermal ablation. Management of varicose veins Great saphenous vein (GSV) and saphenofemoral incompetence (SFJ) Endothermal ablation - It is the gold standard method. question_text:
A 55-year-old locomotive operator presents with complaints of worm-like swelling over his right leg. During clinical examination, a Brodie Trendelenburg test is performed. Which of the following statements is false regarding the test?
A tourniquet can be used for occluding the saphenofemoral junction
options: Rapid filling from above indicates saphenofemoral incompetence
Gradual filling from below upwards indicates saphenopopliteal incompetence
Positive Brodie Trendelenburg test indicates a need for surgery
explanation: The gradual filling of veins from below upwards indicates the perforator incompetence. Brodie Trendelenberg test is performed to test for the incompetence of the saphenofemoral valve and the communicating system. Trendelenburg’s test - Lay the patient down and elevate the leg. Empty the vessels and tie a tourniquet below the SFJ. Ask the patient to stand up: Trendelenburg’s test part ll - Here the tourniquet is not released. A gradual filling from below to upwards indicates perforator incompetence. Trendelenburg’s test part l - Here the tourniquet is released. A rapid filling from above shows the saphenofemoral incompetence. Morrisey’s cough impulse: the patient is asked to cough. A cough impulse at the saphenofemoral junction indicates SFJ incompetence. Schwartz test: If a thrill is felt at SFJ on tapping over the incompetent vein, indicates SFJ incompetence. Modified Perthes test: A tourniquet is tied below SFJ and the patient is asked to walk. An increase in pain and prominence of dilated veins indicate DVT. Fegan’s method - Mark the places of excessive bulges within the varicosities. Ask the patient to lie down and empty the varicose vessels. Palpate along the marked area to look for gaps and pits in the deep fascia, which indicates perforator incompetence. Lymphatic Diseases

question_text: A patient comes with long-standing non-pitting edema in the legs. What is the most probable cause?
explanation: Lymphedema is the most probable cause of long-standing non-pitting edema in the limbs. Lymphedema is the abnormal accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the interstitial spaces of the tissues. Lymphedema can be primary or secondary. Primary lymphedema includes: Lymphedema congenita (0-2 years): more common in males, involves multiple limbs, face, and genitalia. It can be familial or sporadic. The familial type is called Nonne Milroy syndrome. Lymphedema praecox (2-35 years): more common in females, the most common type of primary lymphedema with a peak incidence in puberty. It can be familial or sporadic. The familial type is called Meig's disease. Lymphedema tarda (>35 years): Rare and uncommon. Secondary lymphedema is more common than primary and is the most common cause of lymphedema overall. Causes include lymph node dissection (axillary or inguinal), post-mastectomy, postoperative radiotherapy, obesity, varicose vein surgery, and trauma. Complications of lymphedema include infections, skin changes, recurent cellulitis, non-healing ulcers, and lymphangiosarcoma. Treatment mostly includes patient education and nonsurgical interventions, which include limb elevation, and external compressive garments. When the above methods fail, surgery can be considered.

question_text: A patient comes to you with complaints of long-standing swelling of the left leg, as shown in the image. The swelling disappears in the morning and on examination, pitting is seen. What grade of lymphedema is this?
explanation: In the given clinical scenario, pitting edema which disappears completely on elevation and bed rest indicates grade I lymphedema, according to Brunner's classification. Skin changes seen in lymphedema include peau d'orange, erythema, hyperkeratosis, ulceration, stemmer sign, and buffalo hump. Stemmer sign is the inability to pinch a fold of skin on the dorsum of the toes due to lymphedema. explanation: In lymphedema, skin on the base of the toes cannot be pinched due to subcutaneous fibrosis. This sign is called Stemmer’s sign. question_text: An 8-month-old girl child was brought to the hospital with complaints of swelling of both feet as shown in the image. On examination pitting is seen. Her ECG, RFT, and urine analysis were normal. What is the true statement regarding this condition?
explanation: The patient most likely has Milroy disease which is the familial version of congenital lymphedema. It is inherited as a dominant trait. Primary lymphedema is classified on the basis of age of onset and the presence of familial clustering. Congenital lymphoedema - onset before 2 years of age Lymphedema precox - most common type. onset between 2 to 35 years of age Lymphedema tarda - rare. onset after 35 years of age Treatment includes conservative management such as massage, compression stockings, or bandaging. question_text: Which of the following will you perform when asked to do a lymphangiography of the leg?
options: Inject sodium diatrizoate subcutaneously on the dorsum of the foot
Inject sodium diatrizoate retrogradely under pressure into a small vein on the dorsum of foot
Dissect the lymphatics through an incision on the dorsum of foot and injecting contrast
Insertion of guidewire into the lymphatic system of the leg and inject contrast
explanation: Direct contrast lymphangiography is done by dissecting the lymphatic vasculature through an incision on the dorsum of the foot and injecting contrast. Direct contrast lymphangiography is an invasive study done to visualise the lymphatic system. It involves exposure and cannulation of lymphatics and slow injection of contrast medium such as ethiodized oil. Complications: Damage to the visualized lymphatics Allergic reactions Pulmonary embolism if the oil-based contrast agent enters the venous system through lymphovenous anastomosis. Contrast magnetic resonance lymphangiography is a newer testing method. It is performed after intracutaneous injection of gadobenate dimeglumine into the interdigital webs of the dorsal foot. It is capable of visualizing the anatomy and functional status of lymph flow transport of lymphatic vessels and lymph nodes of lymphedematous limbs. Image A shows a lymphangiography with normal uptake. Image B shows a lymphangiography scan with no uptake in Milroy's disease. Image C depicts a lymphangiography scan in a patient with lymphoedema and reflux.

question_text: Which of the following complications are least likely to develop, in patients with chronic lymphoedema?
explanation: Marjolin's ulcers are unlikely to develop in patients with chronic lymphedema. Marjolin’s ulcers are malignant ulcers that develop over chronic scars, most commonly from burns. Marjolin's ulcer may also develop in chronic long standing venous ulcers but are not seen in chronic lymphedema. Initially, the lymphedema is soft and pits on the pressure but with time the skin becomes thickened and non-pitting due to fibrosis, dermal thickening, and hyperkeratosis. Frequent episodes of lymphangitis and cellulitis may occur. This is due to loss of local immune defense mechanisms. Chronic eczema, the fungal infection of skin and nails, fissuring, verrucae, and papillae (warts) are frequently seen in advanced disease. Rarely malignancy (lymphangiosarcoma or angiosarcoma) may occur in chronic lymphedema. This neoplastic transformation of blood vessels and lymphatics is called Stewart-Treves syndrome.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following statements regarding mediastinal lymphoma is false?
options: Middle mediastinum is the most common site of mediastinal lymphoma
Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice
Video assisted thoracoscopy is used to diagnose the condition
explanation: Anterior compartment is the most common site of lymphoma in the mediastinum. Other sites include the middle compartment and hilar nodes. Primary mediastinal lymphoma is an uncommon type of lymphoma. Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL), primary mediastinal B-cell lymphoma (PMBCL), and T-lymphoblastic lymphoma are the most common primary mediastinal lymphomas. In about 50% of patients who have both Hodgkin’s and Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma, the mediastinum may be the primary site. Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome refers to symptoms produced by the obstruction of blood flow through the SVC by the enlarging mediastinal mass, resulting in symptoms of dyspnea, facial and upper-extremity edema, cough, chest pain, and dysphagia. Video-assisted thoracoscopy (VATS) is used to obtain a biopsy of the mediastinal mass for confirmation and diagnosis. Chemotherapy with six cycles of R-CHOP regimen is preferred. Rituximab is a chimeric monoclonal anti-CD20 antibody and has become a standard component of treating all B-cell lymphoma histologies that express CD20. Note: Thymoma is the most common mediastinal tumor in adults (overall).
subject: Surgery

question_text: A 5-month-old boy is brought to the hospital with complaints of swelling in the neck as given in the image. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
options: It is a congenital sequestration of lymphatic channel
Sclerotherapy is not used in treatment
explanation: The given image depicts a lymphangioma, also known as cystic hygroma. They are brilliantly transilluminant. Lymphangiomas are congenital benign tumors of the lymphatic system. They are the isolated cystic mass of lymphatic tissue that has the ability to produce lymph. Over time the tumor enlarges due to the accumulation of lymph within the cyst. Types of lymphangiomas: Simple or capillary lymphangioma: They occur subcutaneously in the head, neck, and axilla. They may also occur within the internal organs and connective tissues in the thoracic and abdominal cavities. Cavernous lymphangioma or cystic hygroma: They also occur in the neck or axilla. Rarely they may occur in retroperitoneum. Treatment includes surgical excision of the tumor and image-guided sclerotherapy. If there is any residual lymphatic malformation after the treatment, then a conservative excision or unroofing of the cyst is done. It may be combined with sclerosing therapy or repeated partial excisions. Note: The terms lymphangioma and cystic hygromas are older terms. They are now called lymphatic malformations.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Where is lymphangiosarcoma most commonly seen?
explanation: Lymphangiosarcoma is most commonly seen in post-mastectomy edema of the arm. Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare tumor that develops as a complication of long-standing lymph- edema. Clinically, the patients present with acute worsening of the edema and appearance of subcutaneous nodules that have a propensity toward hemorrhage and ulceration. The tumor can be treated, like other sarcomas, with preoperative chemotherapy and radiation followed by surgical excision, which usually may take the form of radical amputation. Overall, the prognosis is very poor.
subject: Surgery

question_text: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical vignette and the image are suggestive of post-mastectomy lymphedema involving the upper limb. Lymphoedema occurs when interstitial fluid accumulates due to defective lymphatic drainage. It is a common complication of breast cancer treatment involving axillary lymph node dissection and radiotherapy. Sentinel lymph node dissection (SLND) reduces the risk of lymphedema significantly. Clinical signs and symptoms are observed in the ipsilateral arm. A significant increase in the limb size due to swelling is seen. Other symptoms are heaviness, tightness, numbness, tingling, limb fatigue, and reduced limb mobility. Diagnosis is predominantly based on the clinical swelling of the arm. The girth of the affected arm >2 centimeters than the normal limb, a 200-mL or more increase in limb volume, or a 5% or greater limb volume change are other diagnostic criteria. Management: Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices can help reduce swelling. Dry skin can be seen due to fluid accumulation, which can lead to cellulitis/skin infections. Using a low pH water-based moisturizer is helpful. Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) by the patient daily aids interstitial fluid evacuation. Benzpyrones and flavonoids are some naturally occurring substances that may be of use to treat lymphedema. Surgical options are lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking. Other options: Option B: Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma seen in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy (more than 10 years). They present as single/multiple bluish-red skin and subcutaneous nodules. They can ulcerate and hemorrhage. Option C: Axillary venous thrombosis or Paget-Schrotter disease is seen in patients doing rigorous exercise and in weightlifters. The subclavian vein is compressed at the thoracic outlet. Painful swelling of the arm is observed. Option D: Cellulitis usually presents with an ulcer and the skin is erythematous, swollen, and painful. Fever, chills, and rigor follow.
subject: Surgery

question_text: Which of the following is not a part of decongestive lymphoedema therapy (DLT)?
explanation: Diuretics and Homan’s procedure are not a part of DLT, and are a part of drug therapy and surgical management. Decongestive lymphoedema therapy (DLT) is the currently used method for controlling swelling in lymphoedema. It consists of 2 phases: intensive and maintenance. Intensive phase includes: Skin care: Prevent drying of skin and exposure to the sun, avoid venipuncture from the affected limb. Limb elevation Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) - Proximal massage along lymphatic channels. Compression therapy: Multilayer lymphoedema bandaging (MLLB), Pneumatic lymphoedema stockings, Graded compression stockings (100% in the ankle/foot, 70% in the knee, 50% in mid-thigh, and 40% in the groin). Exercise: Slow rhythmic isotonic movements are beneficial, while vigorous, anaerobic isometric exercises are to be avoided. Standard MLLB is only done if ABPI is  0.8. question_text: A 75-year old man came with complaints of a painless nodule on the left palm for the past 4 weeks. He gave a history of sustaining a thorn prick injury to the palm 5 weeks ago. On examination, the lesion appears as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: A 65-year-old man has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is
explanation: The given history with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders points to a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma. Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is an epithelial tumor arising from basal cells. It is the most common type of skin cancer most commonly seen over the face, above the line joining corner of the mouth, and lobule of the ear. Risk factors for BCC include ultraviolet radiation (strongest risk factor), age 40-80 years with excessive sun exposure, light-skinned people, and exposure to arsenic compounds, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and infrared light. It is more common in males than females. It is also associated with syndromes such as xeroderma pigmentosum and Gorlin's syndrome. Features of BCC include: Pearly nodule with rolled border Tortuous telangiectatic vessels Surface which can get ulcerated with raised and beaded edge, often with a central depression or umbilicatio Bleeding on minor trauma BCC has various subtypes such as nodular (most common type), pigmented, nodulocystic, morphoeic, infiltrative, and fibroepithelioma of Pinkus. It is locally aggressive and can erode the bone or facial sinuses. It rarely metastasizes via lymph nodes. The occasional presence of melanin in the nodular variant of BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma. Depending upon the type of the lesion, a shave, punch or excisional biopsy may be employed for diagnosis. X-ray or CT may be needed if there is a local invasion. Histology shows peripheral palisading of cells. Treatment: Surgical: Wide excision (4-6 mm clearance) with a skin graft or flap or primary suturing Mohs' surgery for BCC close to the eyes, nose, or ear to preserve more tissue. Non-surgical: Radiotherapy, vismodegib and sonedegib. Other options: Option A: Dermatofibrosarcoma, also known as dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) is a rare, slow-growing, well-differentiated primary fibrosarcoma of the skin, associated with increased production of platelet-derived growth factor-beta. It presents as a protuberant nodule within a firm, indurated plaque that can ulcerate. They are locally aggressive tumors with high recurrence rates. Treatment is wide excision and Mohs microscopic surgery. Imatinib is used for unresectable, metastatic, and recurrent tumors. The given image below shows a DFSP near the umbilicus. Option B: Marjolin's ulcer is a painless, slow-growing, locally malignant, well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in a chronic scar (burns scar, scar of venous ulcer). It presents as an indurated, non-tender ulcer with raised and everted edges with scarring in the surrounding area with marked fibrosis. The ulcer can spread to the lymph nodes when it reaches the normal skin. A wedge biopsy and MRI of the region involved confirm the diagnosis. Management is by wide excision, for larger ulcers, amputation is done. The given image below shows a marjolin's ulcer of the leg. Option D: Naevus is a common benign neoplasm caused due to mutations in the components of the RAS signaling pathway. It has various types, such as congenital naevus, blue naevus, Spitz naevus, halo naevus, and dysplastic naevus. The given image below shows a patient with multiple dysplastic nevi.

question_text: ABCDE rule applies for:
explanation: ABCDE algorithm is used to diagnose melanoma. It comprises of: Asymmetry Border irregularity Color variegatio Diameter of more than 6 mm Evolution or change Melanoma is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction. Though it represents only 4% of skin cancers, it accounts for 80% of deaths (high mortality rate). It presents as a pigmented lesion that has enlarged, ulcerated, or bled. Histopathological confirmation is the gold standard in the diagnosis of melanoma. It is divided into four main types: nodular melanoma (NM), superficial spreading melanoma (SSM), lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM), and acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM). The treatment consists of wide local excision of the tumor and follow-up to detect any local recurrence around the scar and excluding nodal spread.

Most common melanoma i dark-skinned individuals. Lentigo maligna melanoma - also known as Hutchinson's melanotic freckle. More commonly seen on sun-exposed areas like the face, neck, or hands of the elderly. It is the least common and has the best prognosis.

question_text: What does the finding depicted in the image signify?
explanation: The image shows Hutchinsons's nail sign in subungual melanoma. It arises from the nail matrix, most commonly in the great toe or thumb. Hutchinson's nail sign is an important clinical clue to subungual melanoma. It is characterized by the extension of brown or black pigment from the nail bed, matrix, and nail plate to the adjacent cuticle and proximal or lateral nail folds. It is also associated with nail dystrophy. Note: Pseudo-Hutchison’s sign is a reflection of the pigmentation of the nail bed and nail matrix through the transparent nail folds. Option A: Subungal hematoma is a close differential of subungual melanoma. It is seen secondary to trauma which causes bleeding and resultant hematoma formation and pigmentation. It is important to note that the features of Hutchinson's nail sign are not seen with subungual hematoma. Option B: Nodular melanoma is a condition where malignant melanoma cells proliferate downwards through the skin – this is known as vertical growth. The lesion presents as a nodule that has been rapidly enlarging. Option D: Lentigo maligna is an early form of melanoma, in which the malignant cells are confined to the tissue of origin, the epidermis, hence it is often reported as in-situ melanoma. Note: Subungual melanoma can be either superficial spreading melanoma or acral lentiginous melanoma. A difference of opinion has been noted in Bailey and Love, 27th ed. where it has been mentioned that melanoma under the fingernail is usually superficial spreading melanoma. However, most dermatology textbooks including the Rooks 9th ed. and Fitzpatrick's 9th ed and several research articles mentioned subungual melanoma as a variant of acral lentiginous melanoma.

question_text: Which of the following can be used for staging patients with melanoma?
explanation: Both Breslow and Clark’s system is used for melanoma staging. Breslow thickness is the depth of invasion measured from the granular layer of the epidermis to the base of the lesion. As the thickness of the melanoma increases, the prognosis worsens. Clark's is based on the layer of skin to which melanoma has invaded. Breslow thickness has largely supplanted Clark's as it is a more accurate method of predicting prognosis. Van-nyus prognostic index is used for DCIS. Atlanta's is used for acute pancreatitis. Onodera's prognostic index is used for hepatocellular carcinoma after initial hepatectomy

question_text: Which of the following will be the most important prognostic indicator in patients with stage 1 melanoma?
explanation: The best prognostic factor in primary stage 1 melanoma (T1N0) is the tumor thickness or depth of the melanoma. The presence of lymph node metastases is the single most important prognostic index for melanoma in general. But in Stage 1 melanoma, as there is no lymph node involvement, the depth of the melanoma is the best prognostic factor. Other major prognostic factors, in order of impact on survival, include: Presence of lymph node metastases Ulceratio Age Anatomic location of the primary tumor Gender

question_text: Arrange the types of melanoma from best to worst according to their prognosis?
explanation: The order of prognosis for types of melanoma from better to worse is: Lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) and acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) > superficial spreading melanoma (SSM) > nodular melanoma (NM) The LMM and ALM both have long horizontal phases. As a result of this, there will be more time to detect them before they enter the vertical phase of growth. Thus LMM and ALM have a better prognosis than other subtypes. The SSM has an intermediate prognosis, as the horizontal phase is rapidly followed by the vertical phase. The NM has the worst prognosis, as there is no horizontal phase and it starts with a vertical growth phase. This leads to a greater average tumor thickness.

question_text: A patient presented from the dermatology out-patient with a biopsy-proven melanoma on her right arm with a Breslow depth of 2.1 mm. Nodes were clinically negative. What is the surgical management for this patient?
explanation: Wide local excision with a resection margin of 2 cm along with sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) will be recommended for melanomas invading to a depth > 2mm. Recommended margins of wide local excision: Wide local excision with SLNB is preferred for early-stage tumours. SLNB should be performed for lesions >1mm in depth. If SLNB is positive or if nodes are clinically positive, lymph node dissection should be performed. SLN biopsy is more challenging in the head and neck than in other regions because of the rich lymphatic drainage network, and the false-negative rate for SLN biopsy is generally higher for melanomas in these locations. Cross-sectional imaging, such as with a single-photon emission CT, helps to identify the exact anatomic location of the SLNs more accurately. question_text: A lady comes with a reddish firm nodule on her chest which hasn't grown in size. Its histolopathological image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a woman with reddish firm nodule on her chest and histology showing multiple dilated vascular structures with a single layer of epithelial cells is suggestive of a hemangioma. Hemangioma is a benign tumor caused by the abnormal growth of blood vessels. Types of hemangioma are capillary hemangioma (most common), juvenile/ strawberry hemangioma, cavernous hemangioma and pyogenic hemangioma. I dications for immediate treatment are complications such as ulceration or those pertaining to the location of the mass (e.g. visual issues due to a large hemangioma over the eyelid). Treatment options include: Beta-blockers - oral propranolol Steroids - intralesional triamcinolone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine - for steroid-resistant lesions Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser The given image shows a flat to elevated, irregular, pinkish-red mass over the skin of the abdomen suggestive of a strawberry hemangioma. question_text: Extra mammary Paget's disease is commonly seen in the:
explanation: Extramammary Paget's disease arises most frequently on the vulva. Other sites include the perineum, scrotum, perianal skin, and penis. Extramammary Paget's disease (EMPD) can be primary or secondary. Primary EMPD is more common and occurs in the absence of an underlying malignancy, thought to arise from intraepidermal parts of apocrine glands or from pluripotent cells from the epidermis. Secondary EMPD arises from an underlying adnexal carcinoma or internal malignancy due to the epidermotropic spread of malignant cells from the underlying tumor. Visceral malignancies associated with EMPD are carcinomas of the colon, rectum, bladder, urethra, cervix, and prostate. The patient presents with well-defined, moist, erythematous scaly plaques and severe pruritis. Lichenification and excoriations may also be seen. Diagnosis is confirmed by punch, wedge, or excisional skin biopsy. A systemic workup should also be done to identify any underlying malignancy and they include colonoscopy, cystoscopy, colposcopy, and pelvic examination with pap smear in females. Treatment: Mohs microscopic surgery with 5 cm margin clearance Radiotherapy Topical 5-fluorouracil and imiquimod Chemotherapy Photodynamic therapy The given image below shows extramammary Paget's disease of the vulva.

question_text: A postmenopausal lady presented with an itchy plaque over the vulva for the past 2 years, which persisted despite multiple topical treatments. Biopsy of the lesion revealed large vacuolated cells with mucin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given scenario and presence of large vacuolated cells with mucin (Paget's cells) points to a diagnosis of extramammary Paget's disease. It is a form of intraepidermal adenocarcinoma. Extramammary Paget's disease usually presents in the sixth to eighth decades of life. It may occur in the genital or perianal regions, or in cutaneous sites rich in apocrine glands such as the axilla. Approximately 25% of the cases are associated with an underlying in situ or invasive neoplasm. It most commonly presents with pruritus. The clinical appearance is similar to mammary Paget's Disease. Scattered areas of erosion and white scale can give rise to a “strawberries and cream” appearance. The invasion of the lymphatic system by the tumor gives rise to underpants-pattern erythema. Surgical excision forms the basis of treatment. The given image shows large vacuolated cells with mucin (Paget's cells)
